description: Bad shaken sazeracs?, bad cocktails, ugly fish pond looking, bland chicken noodle soup with no egg, yet menu said jidori egg. Bland deviled eggs, bland tomato salad, actually everything was bland.  Really surprised this is a city restaurant.
author: Chris S.

description: The food was delicious, and the setting was beautiful. I went with my parents for brunch and we sat outside on the sunny deck. We enjoyed tasty cocktails beforehand. The service was a bit slow, but otherwise I recommend the place enthusiastically.
author: Alison W.

description:
In a throwback kind of way, Presidio Social Club (PSC) has a nostalgic charm that matches its former military base turned national park location.  

Had brunch here one Saturday in a fairly large group. It's a great space fin the day - bright and airy. Absolutely love the vintage bar area. Our server was truly attentive and on top of her game. The food, a little hit and miss unfortunately. 

Starting with cocktails, I had the Ruger Mule consisting of vodka, cranberry liqueur, lime, and ginger beer. Perhaps a little stingy on the pour, I found it teetering on the side of being too sweet. Switched to beer shortly after. 

In terms of food, we started with a couple of items from the bakery. Didn't care much for the brioche beignets with the hot chocolate sauce but did like the fresh baked scones which struck a nice balance with between the sweet preserve and buttery pastry. I had the PSC hamburger with gruyere cheese and it was a decent but forgettable burger. I did dig the pickled onion for contrast but overall, I've had better burgers for less. 

Overall though, PSC is worth considering for lunch/brunch after a morning hike around the park if you're not too picky about the food. You probably get better for your money elsewhere but it's a charming little spot with pretty good service so rounding it up a little.
author: Jon L.

description:
Meh

Brunch on Saturday 

Scrambled eggs were tasteless
Quiche was boring 
Rigatoni with meat was bland
Cheddar bacon biscuit was just ok

All in all, I wouldn't come back
author: Kitty M.

description:
I came for Sunday brunch after hearing a lot about this place. Did an open table reservation that morning for 12:15pm for a party of 2. It's a lovely laid out place with indoor and outdoor seating. We got a lovely table by the window.
The menu is a good selection of brunch style food. Of course I ordered a Bellini (very good), a latte (also very good however I'm a little confused by Americans serving lattes in cappuccino cups rather than taller glasses) and then had the poached eggs and ham dish. 
Everything was nice but did not jump out at me. Would I come back? Yes, probably. 
Pricing for plates are between $14-$18ish. Bellini was $11. Nice servers too. 
All very reasonable but nothing 'wow-ed' me to be honest.
author: Van-Anh N.

description:
Go if you want  a unique experience the Presidio- for lunch or breakfast but skip dinner as there are so so so many better restaurants in San Francisco for the price. I live here.  It is hard to mess up eggs. 

The pros:
You will not be rushed out when done as the waiter will never come.
The food is good traditional- meatloaf was great .
The roasted vegetables main dish is a 1970's vegetarian dish.  The sauce - who knows?
They probably have a good steak

The service is poor

1. We waited a long time to order drinks- 20 minutes at least 

2. The appetizers arrived at the same time as the main dish, after a really long wait.

3. The bill had an extra bottle of wine- when I alerted the waiter he indicated "that he was aware and he meant to remove the extra bottle  but forgot".

4. We were never offered dessert or coffee- not a word.

People make mistakes and I can understand that.  
So it must be that there the waiters are stretched too him.

I would change the menu here to bar food- hamburger, etc because that is the type of service you receive.  And based on the other reviews this does not seem to be an isolated incident.    

Don't take your special date here!
author: Ginger S.

description:
Sorry guys, I just don't get it.

I work across the street from Presidio Social Club, so I'll admit I'm a little jaded by the view (gorgeous Presidio trees, Palace of Fine Arts, Golden Gate Bridge, yadda yadda).Once you get inside the restaurant, it's decorated in a quaint, classy manner. The service staff is very attentive and quick. Unfortunately, my grievance is the food.

It's not bad... it's just not... good. For my entree I had the Bucatini Pasta with Ham (paired with crispy artichokes, Calabrian chili, and sheep's milk ricotta). It sounds delicious, but only tasted A-OK. Nothing special, maybe I could make it at home if I was feeling fancy. Just boring. 

I also tried the Truffle Fries. Good, just not great. That's how I seemed to feel about all the food here. Overall, lovely aesthetic but sub-par food.
author: Nicole W.

description:
The only thing I dread more than writing 3-star Yelp reviews is writing a 2 1/2 star review. Unfortunately, that's the best rating I can give my recent experience at Presidio Social Club. I used to really like this place. Not sure what happened.

I came here with a friend/biz colleague for a 5pm happy hour. Since my friend lives in SF and I was coming from Marin, the Presidio was the perfect midway point for us to meet. Plus, they have plenty of free parking. But something about the whole experience left me cold. When I walked in, there was no host/hostess to greet me. The lighting in the place was very dark (so it felt like it was later than 5pm). My friend and I saddled up at the bar. It took over 10 minutes for a bartender to even acknowledge us. And keep in mind, there were only two other people at the bar. It was bizarre. I felt like we were wearing invisibility cloaks. When we finally caught a bartender's attention, we ordered a few cocktails. I opted for the Aged Negroni. $13 was a bit steep, especially during happy hour. But I will give them this, it really was a mighty fine beverage. I could've easily ordered another, but alas, I had to drive home.

We were a little hungry, so we decided to order a few bar snacks. We opted for the Truffle Fries, Deviled Eggs, and the Gruyere Cheese Toast with Tomato Fondue. These seemed like the easiest, quickest dishes to order on the menu. And yet our food must have taken 25-30 minutes to come out. 

So how was the food? Well, it was just fine. The deviled eggs were tasty. But 4 tiny eggs for $8 seemed a tad pricy. They gave us a generous helping of truffle fries with an aioli and ketchup for dipping. I'll admit, I've never met a fry I didn't like. But these were a bit soggy and lacking any real crispiness. I'd say the biggest disappointment was the Gruyere Cheese Toast with Tomato Fondue dip (which really is a fancy way of saying grilled cheese sandwich with a side of tomato soup). For a grilled cheese toast, I was surprised by the lack of cheese. And the tomato soup for dipping was luke warm at best. 

At no point did anyone come by to ask how our food was. We had to ask the bartender for water multiple times before he brought us anything. When the bill arrived, we owed $50 (not including tax or gratuity).

So there you have it. I want to like this place. And maybe it's better for dinner or brunch. But the over all vibe here was cold and unwelcoming. And I got the impression that these guys could care less if we ever came back or not. So it might be a while before I come back to give it another shot.
author: Kevin B.

description: This is a go to sunny day brunch spot. Great food, patio, parking, and usually you can even walk in on the weekends! It is a bit isolated in the Presidio. So if you are looking for to see and be seen, probably not your jam. Bahn mi with pork belly, burger, oysters, chicken salad are all stand out dishes.
author: Shari J.

description:
I had chosen the Presidio Social Club for the location of my birthday dinner based upon a few very positive dining experiences there and my love for its classy yet simple atmosphere. The food and atmosphere were great as always, however we were served by the most inattentive waitress I have ever experienced. We were rarely if ever checked on or asked if needed anything, when we more often than not almost always needed a small task such as more water for the table. 

We were constantly having to flag her down, including a time when she walked through our dining room and didn't even look at our table. We were also consistently re-pouring ourselves water and champagne because she was never around or attentive. We were a very mellow and simple group of 7, however she seemed to just dread coming to our table, which was not the best feeling especially on a special occasion. Dan who cleared our table at the end of the night was great, though!
author: Darcy D.

description: What a unpleasant experience. This place is just not what I expected. Food is bleh, coffee and tea were cold. Would not recommend! We came to celebrate a birthday and they brought a scoop of ice cream with no candle when we were still eating our meal. Don't come here unless you plan on having just drinks.
author: Yas G.

description:
A beautiful space to enjoy breakfast.

My friend made the reservation here. She had visited in the past and wanted to come back. It was my first time. They make stellar coffee and their brunch cocktails are a must.

Flatbread special was amazing. I should have opted for that. It was tough to make a decision and somehow I landed on a standard order of Eggs Benedict. Not that it was a bad choice, I just wish I went with something unique or more adventurous. Especially because I can get eggs benny anywhere. To it's credit, the dish was wonderful and I ate every last bite. The eggs were poached perfectly and the hollandaise was a perfect companion to moisten the rest of the dish atop homemade English Muffins. Bellinis, yes please, I'll take another.

Then there's the building itself. It feels like an old school '40s country club. Open, airy, crisp, with dark accents. The floor were amazing -- is that weird to say? I loved the (seemingly handmade) clay tiles. 

I would love to come back and sit at the bar.
author: Breanna B.

description:
Go for the brioche beignets w/ brown sugar & Mexican chocolate fondue!  Their entrees are kinda blah...had the poached eggs & ham (squash & mushroom ragu, toasted levain, salsa verde), but the few thin slices of tasteless stale ham reminded of a bad deli run (total bummer).  It's really too bad 1 key ingredient like this will ruin your whole dining experience.  

This time I took my friends there to give it another shot, beignets are still delish but my Mission-style chilaquiles (w/ chicken) had a big chunk of 1/2 cooked chicken in it...immediately had to spit it out cuz last thing I need was to get sick at the table.  Fortunately, I had a Painkiller (w/ rum, pineapple, coconut & orange) to wash it down.  My friends had better experience w/ their quiche (came in this huge wedge of quiche & mixed greens) and the PSC burger w/ truffle parm fries (a must!).

I really hope their inconsistency will improve as I suggested my friend to have her baby show at PSC after we brunched there.  We agree the convenient parking and idyllic Presidio location really is worth the revisit.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Looks nice. Like, if you have friends in town, maybe your parents or some in-laws, it's a nice place to bring them. 

We came for brunch and things sounded better than they tasted. Nothing tasted bad but I blame my slightly bougie taste buds for expecting a little more. For example, if you've never had beignets, you might be all, "Hot damn, these are great!" But if you're used to getting them at a place like Brenda's, you might be all, "These are nice. They're a bit more donutty." I ordered a quiche that was on special and felt a bit let down. Nothing sadder than an unimpressive quiche. 

Maybe the non-brunch options are better?

Luckily, the mimosas are fine. 

Staff is friendly.

Tons of parking.
author: Loli L.

description:
Nothing is very special here for you to:
- drive ALL THE WAY from downtown to presido just for a meal in this restaurant
- pay $50 per person for a main course and 2 glasses of wine
- try their services. The servers were too attentive... Kept checking in and disrupting the exciting conversation between me and my friends 

....unless you love dining in the middle of nowhere to drink good wine and eat a $40 steak. Then this is a place for you.
author: Shaz L.

description:
Presidio Social Club, nice to have a wonderful restaurant and bar in the Presidio.

My wife and I spent the weekend in San Francisco enjoying Fleet Week festivities, dinner at the PSC was one of the highlights - right after the Blue Angels!

Great location, easy to park (we walked from the Inn at the Presidio) and the decor is comfortable and relaxing. It had been a few years since we'd been there for dinner, it certainly has changed, all for the Good!

The menu has expanded since the last visit, but still includes their wonderful meatloaf and the half-chicken. I had the chicken, which was so moist and bursting with flavor and mashed potatoes as a side, yummy. My wife had the lamb shank, she loved it. 

Our waiter, Daniel, was the best. Friendly and knowledgeable about the bar (my wife loves a good martini, she got one) and the menu. Wonderful service.

We're already booked for 2017 Fleet Week, will certainly be having drinks and dinner at the Presidio Social Club again.
author: Roger W.

description: Fun and exciting restaurant!  Good ol' fashioned American cuisine served with a new Californian twist.  The venue is pleasant in a quiet area of the Presidio.
author: R L.

description:
I love oysters. I love oysters and prosecco. 

If you stop listening to your wallet and let yourself indulge in their oyster and sparkling wine selection you will be thrilled!

Had a lovely date here another day and couldn't be happier that this place exists.
author: Anelya S.

description: This place is kind of awful, starting with the waiter greeting us by declaring ... at his food service job ... that he was under the weather.  Tables were crammed too close, and the eggs Florentine were barely edible. The venue is historic, but in desperate need of some basic makeover touch-ups. Any passable attempts at decor were like lipstick on a pig (or smart lipo on a cuckolded wife). The only saving grace was the dessert of brown sugar beignets with hot chocolate.
author: Kim S.

description:
What do you call a restaurant that fails to serve you brunch in about 80 minutes?

a) incompetent
b) crap
c) The Presidio Social Club
d) all of the above

Being unable to serve a simple brunch when all the tables around are being served and leaving is a sign of a non-functioning restaurant - when the waiter isn't competent enough to be on top of the order, when the manager fails to notice what's happening on the floor, and when the kitchen is capable of not making food on an electronic system you have a serious problem.

I would love to say whether the food was good or bad, but I can't as it never even arrived.  They failed even the most basic function of a restaurant - putting food on the table.

With so many good restaurants in the City - why come here? Why indeed. I certainly won't again.
author: Mike B.

description: Off the beaten path... first time here. Kinda old school feel , not modern. I liked the bar and space. Lots of windows. Excellent drinks, great service. Yummy food.
author: Cecilia D.

description: If you're a meatloaf lover, this place has one of the best. Truffle fries are delish as well. "Gruyere toast" is basically a grilled cheese Sammy on white bread cut into triangles - skip it.
author: SF M.

description:
Classy but you can wear a jeans and t-shirt.  Stumbled across this place when we came to sf to walk across the Golden Gate Bridge.

We came in for dinner, ordered the liver and onions and roasted half chicken. Unfortunately (reason for four stars) ten minutes after we ordered we were told no more liver... so instead we subbed in a veggie pasta dish, can't recall the name. 

Both were delicious and after a long walk across the bridge we ate every bite.

Desert we ordered ice cream. It was good!
author: Andrew M.

description:
Several weeks ago we received an email from PSC advertising their Sunday pig roast dinner. I called and booked for four of us. We showed up today right on time for our reservation and discovered that there was no pig roast and they hadn't contacted us to let us know. This was super disappointing, and had happened to us once before in exactly the same manner with the crab roast. In that case our parents were in town for crab season and it was too late to go anywhere else, and they specifically wanted crab. 

In this most recent case, I was embarrassed as I had invited friends to join us for what we thought was the special pig roast event. The waiter did comp us our initial round of drinks, and the dinner we did eat there was good. The cocktails and drinks were excellent. 

I really wish the front of house would track what people reserve for, and contact people if a special event changes. Either don't advertise special events, or if you have them, stick to them, inclusive of contacting the people who base their plans around your plans.
author: Walter K.

description: Great building, history and food! We sat on the patio and enjoyed a perfect California day, could not have asked for anything better. We stumbled upon this driving around the Presidio and so glad we decided to give it a try. The couple next to us were planning out their wedding reception and it is simply a fantastic place to celebrate.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Rude Manager and wait staff.  We had a reservation and ate a meal in less than an hour.  Then, before we even got the check, the manager came over and said we need to leave becasue they had another reservation.   

It was so rude. 

Will not go back.  Food was OK.  Better the first time I went
author: Beth K.

description:
Unfortunately, for the second time, we made reservations for a special advertised event (this time the pig roast), only to show up and have it not be happening with them giving us no notice about the change. Really embarrassing thing to happen when you invite people to a special event. 

Last time, my parents had come from Idaho specifically for crab season and we took them to a crab roast with no crab and no one who worked there cared at all about the predicament we'd been put in. Then the food we ordered instead, since it was too late to go elsewhere, was pretty terrible - just humiliating. My face burned. This time was more casual with friends also from here in the city, so not as big of a deal, but still a disappointing head scratcher. I hadn't been back since the last time because it left such an awful taste in my mouth, and we had been regulars for a couple years previous, so super lol that it happened again when I finally returned almost five years later. Shows me! 

Front of house should handle these situations differently, hands down. But very good cocktails in a lovely space, other food a mixed bag mostly coming out positive.
author: Veronica L.

description:
Picked Presidio Social Club because of the cute outdoor patio, but didn't have a good experience at all.   We were there for lunch/ brunch on a Saturday and I was pleasantly surprised that it wasn't over-crowded.  No wait at all. 

The iced tea was watery and totally flavorless; I don't know that I've ever had an iced tea I didn't like, to be honest. The menu sounds great, but I learned from the waiter that they don't have any gluten free options for dishes with biscuits or toast.  Sort of unusual in SF, but no big deal.  I ordered the chilaquiles, as he suggested them as a good GF option. 

I was served an enormous bowl of chips in a tasty sauce.  There was half an avocado on top.  If there were two tablespoons of egg in the dish I would have been surprised. It was $15. basically nachos? Not a satisfying brunch at all. very expensive for a bowl of chips. 

I picked at it and ate all the egg I could find.  When he cleared the plates it seemed pretty obvious I hadn't eaten much.  He never even asked if we had enjoyed the meal. 

So, very overpriced dish considering it was smothered chips with egg garnish.  Not attentive service.  Maybe just go for a cocktail on the patio?
author: leah w.

description: Crowded on sunny weekends, but the atmosphere and location is wonderful. The usual $20 brunch items, with some inventive twists which is nice. They also serve oysters, which I had and really enjoyed (not huge ones, but still good). I would like to spend a little less on brunch for what you get here, but this is definitely the place you go to because of the location to Presidio and Palace of Fine Arts. Wonderful for a stroll before or after and taking in San Francisco sights. Would recommend that you have a mimosa or glass of champagne. It just sort of makes your weekend morning. I can also see this being a good place for celebrations (birthdays, graduation brunches, etc).
author: Ana Maria F.

description: This place is fun for their Wednesday night beer and bbq on the back patio. If you get cold they even have blankets! They have a really great beer list and fun cocktails too. Their ribs were good, huge portions. Make sure to sit outside though. You can't get the whole bbq menu when you sit inside.
author: Makenzi B.

description: Great food, service OK. Maybe a little outdated. Would be nice to have more Napa Valley wines.
author: Ahmed R.

description: Nice ambiance and food above average.  Went for a Sunday brunch and the espresso machine was out of commission and they were also out of a couple of food items.  Feels like they should be better prepared for a Sunday brunch.
author: Scott H.

description: This place was a nice little area for a venue outside the presidio. I had the chicken dish which was on point. The service was really good and they had a nice wine selection. A bit difficult to find parking though and you have to park residential
author: Han S.

description:
This beautiful restaurant is set in the Presidio District of San Francisco. Right after you enter the Presidio Gates, the restaurant is located on the left. There is an indoor area, designed like an old French Bistro, and a back outdoor patio which is nice for warm summer days and nights.

While I have hoped to like this restaurant & bar, I have yet to be impressed by my few visits. 

During my last visit, we sat at the bar with the intention of getting some special craft cocktails. I suggested to the bartender that he come up with something innovative based on my preferences. He couldn't even answer a simple question as to what makes up a gin vs. vodka. He also didn't know that Gins are typically made with juniper but can also be infused with practically anything. To be honest, he also didn't appear to speak fluent English. 

For such a classy joint, the bartenders should be on point. He was not. As a result, I just ordered something from the menu. Boring. We left after our first drink because we had no desire to stay.
author: Sara B.

description: The location, atmosphere and service were great.  Unfortunately, the bar was not up to par.  It could have been an off day but my friend ordered a lemon martini and they brought out straight vodka, sent it back and then they brought out a lemon martini but the glass was rimmed with salt instead of sugar and on the third try they got it right.  My other friend ordered a non alcoholic sangria and it tasted like seltzer water so she sent it back not opting for another.  My dirty martini was awful.  I will say they did fix the errors without a problem.  The food was just okay.  Our appetizers were actually great.  We got the ahi poke which was good, oysters on half shell, good and French fries.  My order of carbonara with pork belly was bland.   Dessert was good.  I probably wont go back unfortunately..
author: Leah R.

description: Amazing place! Staff is friendly, attentive, and professional. Of course don't forget about the delicious menu they provide. You really can't go wrong. Good for romantic nights and for a fun meal with friends. What they say is true: feels like a nice social club, but without the dues. We will be back for sure! Might even rent out the side room for my 40th birthday party :-)
author: Chris H.

description:
We recently enjoyed brunch here on a Sunday Afternoon.  It is very popular,  so I recommend a reservation!  We enjoyed the service, atmosphere and the food was really great.   I highly recommend   
this place.  The only neg was they insisted that our whole party be present before seating us.  I think this is a normal standard for SF nowadays.  I particularly appreciated the quiet atmosphere, great for a real conversation.
author: Stephanie M.

description: This place is a pleasant surprise. Tucked inside the Presidio, it is old time San Francisco. The food is great and the prices are not bad at all.
author: Karen C.

description: Very unfriendly staff minus our one server who had the purple eye liner, he saved the day and made everything amazing. Our initial server spilled a mimosa all over my shoes and my friends dress and could've handled better... instead he ran away and stopped being our server after this. The Bloody Mary was just ok: the chilaquiles were nice but myself and 3 friends all ordered them and each portion wasn't even. The best thing about this place is the ambiance..
author: Natalia G.

description:
3.5! 

The day was friday and I was part of an ass kicking double date. 
As someone who frequents the city knows, It's always tricky to find a reservation on a Friday night -at a reasonable hour-in SF.  Glad my pal from TX was hip to the scene and decided we should try something new. 

PSC is one of those places that enjoy finding.  It's in the presidio down a long curvy road paved with tall trees.  The environment is chill and the ambience is reminiscent of something back in the 1940's, well at least in my mind.  

The farm doors, well lit bar, patio chairs, and drum set are perfect companions to an evening of food. 

The party of 4 ordered a variety of things:

oysters on the half shelf-always a treat
fire roasted butternut squash with burrata-Odd pairing, but good. 

For dinner we opted for the pork and fish specials.  Both were flavorful, well prepared, and fantastic.  

I really enjoyed my dining experience and the service. I wouldn't say this was life changing or mind blowing, but it was a legit place to eat american comfort food. I look forward to posting at the bar and enjoying another great date night.
author: Flor D.

description: My Husband and I were celebrating our anniversary weekend in San Francisco. We perused some of our favorite local haunts,however, we found them to be slightly overcrowded, and we were looking to dine in comfortable and slightly quieter surroundings. We decided to have a late lunch at Presidio Social Club. It was approximately 2:30 in the afternoon on a Saturday, we didn't have reservations as we were playing it by ear.The hostess was very sweet giving us a nice windowside table.Our server was professional, courteous, and exhibited impeccable timing,allowing us to relax in between appetizer and main courses. We started with two glasses of French Rose and Raw Oysters with a nice acidity adorned with a shallot,vinegar,mignonette which paired wonderfully with the wine.My Husband and I went with the Housemade Meatloaf, mashed potatoes, and glazed carrots for our ENTREE . ABSOLUTE PERFECTION. The quality of this entree was evident from the first bite,the carrots were perfectly cooked slightly al dente.We were very pleased with our experience, to end the meal we shared the Housemade Cannoli, being of Italian Descent we of course were drawn to this dessert,although what thoroughly impressed us, is the fact that all desserts are made in house,this Cannoli featured a touch of fresh ginger,along with the traditional candied fruit,pistachio, and dark chocolate chips, the shell was perfectly crisp,which is indicative of filling the cannoli to order! Excellent experience, thank you for being a happy memory to our special weekend.
author: Jennifer G.

description:
This review is for their repeating pig roast menu.

It sucks... 

$48 for butter lettuce drenched in vinegar, overly cooked roast pork with an ok tasting vinegar based slaw, and a pineapple upside down cake for desert. Expectations were low to start with and we only showed up because a friend was organizing a group dinner and did not want to shoot him down, but the restaurant under performed even our low expectations. The suckling pig we ordered from a Chinese place way out on Irving, or Judah, or Noriega, or whatever... absolutely spanks PSC's version.

Aside from the food the restaurant has an interesting location, nice decor, open and airy seating, and an average staff. Some tables looked to have attentive service. Ours was rather slow, but friendly.

Definitely would not recommend.
author: Easwud C.

description: Waiter was the RUDEST and most despicable person ever!! I love the PSC and am the Yelp Duchess. The way Jon treated us was awful!! I had a reservation today for 1 PM and was seated promptly. When Jon came over to our table, my friend was not there yet. He brought over two small water glasses and a bottle of water and spilled it on the table and my napkin. When I asked him for a new napkin he picked it up and stared at it and wondered why. I told him because he poured water all over it. I then asked if he had the lunch menu, not the brunch menu. He kept saying this is the brunch menu. I said no kidding but do you have the lunch menu. His response? This is the brunch menu. OMG! Now it was on! He  acted like a complete ass the rest of the time I was there. I asked him for the chicken and arugula salad with a different dressing on it then avocado dressing. I had to explain to him how I was allergic to avocado in order for him to understand I did not want the avocado dressing. When my friend ordered her sandwich I asked her what it was. He started explaining the sandwich to me when I wasn't even talking to him. Jon should be seen and not heard! Then again Jon should not be seen at all in a customer service role. He should be down in the basement like Milton in Office Space and not come in contact with anyone. He never asked me or my friend if we want to drink refills, he never came by to see if our meals were OK, and he simply wanted us the hell out of there. It was very obvious from the minute we sat down. Not only will I not go to the Presidio Social Club again, but my friend who was new to the place, won't go back either. What a disappointment but the management should understand that the waiter is 90% of the experience. This waiter was the worst! He ensured I will not return and will let others know to go elsewhere. He ruined my lunch with my friend and my day. What a loser.
author: Sandra P.

description:
Ugh!!! So gross!!!!! Nothing like dining here for your company Holiday dinner and upon finishing your meal your coworkers spy a RAT!!! Yes a RAT inside the restaurant! The rat was looking for a Holiday drink as he scurried across the bar! For the prices that Presidio Social Club charges a rat does not make a good dinner companion ! Are you kidding me?!  Hire a exterminator!  

We made dinner reservations for four guests on the evening of Sunday December the 13th. My coworker and I arrived prior to our dinner reservation and had a cocktail at the bar while we waited for our coworkers to arrive. The place was busy with Holiday diners and the bar was busy as well. The cocktails were very good and we pursued the menu. 

Shortly there after my coworkers arrived and we were seated promptly. We ordered some cocktails while we all looked over the menu. French 75, Moscow Mule, Old Cuban, and some wine were in order given it was a Holiday dinner. The cocktails were all very well prepared and were delicious!  


 We decided on several appetizers we had the oysters on the half shell, deviled eggs, and the PSC gruyere cheese toast with tomato fondue dip. All three appetizers were delicious and arrived in good time while we were still deciding what to order for the main course.

When it came down to ordering the main courses they were out of the special fried chicken. But they had the roasted chicken?! We has a awkward exchange with the waitperson while he tried to explain why they had the roasted chicken but not the fried chicken that was on special. 

We all ordered our main dishes my coworker and I decided to split the order of oven roasted ribeye steak for two, while my other two dinner companions chose the herb roasted half chicken. We also decided on a side of Macaroni and cheese as well as the roasted brussels sprouts. The main dishes were very good and had great portions as well as presented beautifully. 

Who doesn't have room for dessert? We chose PSC Cookie Plate as well as the Brioche Beignets that came with a brown sugar hot chocolate for dipping the warm Beignets a very nice touch! 

The service as attentive but not flawless as the awkward exchange about the chicken. And our party felt that we were being rushed out which is not a good feeling given that it was a Holiday gathering and they were in no urgent need for our table as it was later in the evening and no one was waiting for the said table. 

But while everything was as good as it was and the service while a little lacking but still ok the topper of the night was the unwelcome dinner companion! The RAT! Maybe that is why the staff wanted us out because the restaurant was growing quiet and they did not want us to see what comes out! Either way that is why I gave it a one star review. 

In hindsight I wish we would have mentioned something to the staff but we were being rushed out and after seeing the rat running across the bar we were more than ready to make our exits! Please staff at Presidio Social Club if you do read this please take care of the issue IMMEDIATELY!

 I understand that you host many events including weddings I being a bridal consultant have had brides getting married at your location and I do not know what to say when asked what my thoughts are on your dining establishment. Please take care of your unwanted friend this is not Ratatouille you know!
author: Veronica Y.

description: My family has loved this place for years.  We especially enjoy the patio seating when possible.  The food is always top notch and the servers make you feel that they are happy to be there as well.  Looking forward to our next brunch.
author: Barbra H.

description:
Missed Presidio Social club's brunch menu by thirty minutes since it ends at 2:30; however the kitchen has an abbreviated menu of small plates to nosh on.

We were seated in the patio which was nice, but didn't really have a view of anything great.  We had the burrata with roasted butternut squash puree and the kale salad with pork belly.  

Loved that the mimosas were made with freshly squeezed orange juice.

My only complaint was the bathrooms which were dark and a little smelly which was a disappointment for such a nice place.
author: Hieu H.

description:
This place is cool. I spent the evening having a wonderful dinner with friends. 
Our Devils eggs appetizer was delicious, but the grilled cheese we ordered (after reading an article on yahoo about returning to our childhood food) was mediocre at best and not at all made us fondly remember childhood tastes. Or any taste.
My main course of soul fish was deliciously prepared and presented on top of vegetables, but my friend's crawfish was not a good choice. Desserts were excellent. We had the yummy dirty dozen (hot mini donut halls filled with cream), we also liked the cookies with hot chocolate, and kind of Smores - a lot!!
The Service was spotty, we had to wait way to long for our drinks, and their beer offering is very limited. Add the inconsistent quality of the different entries and It sums to only three stars.
The atmosphere was good, even if a bit loud.
I might be back here if I'm around the near area, I would not make an effort to come here especially.
author: Stephanie A.

description: This place is soooo great. My husband and I wandered in for lunch on vacation. Service was excellent, and the good was so damn awesome. I had the meatloaf (good grief, BEST meatloaf I've EVER had), and we liked it so much we came back for dinner on our vacation and it was just as great the second time. Definitely love and recommend this place. Five stars all the way. P.S. Try the beignets. Seriously.
author: Leora W.

description:
Located right near the Lombard Street entrance, the Presidio Social Club is a great place to have a meal in the Presidio. My husband and I stopped in after a fun day of hiking through the Presidio. They have a great patio in the back for basking in the sunshine.

I really enjoyed the Gruyere cheese toast served with a tomato soup dip and the ahi poke. The ahi poke was really refreshing with grilled avocado. My husband had the Cubano sandwich. Presidio Social Club also makes some delicious seasonal lemonades.

Cool decor, good food, and seriously great location!
author: Kari G.

description: We love this place and have been going for years. It's definitely unique and it has a fun old world charm to it. The menu is unusual and the food is always consistently good. Only reason I don't give it 5 stars is because the service has always been subpar. There seems to be a lot of staff turnover. The waiters are very slow and not always on the ball. It has been this way for years - not sure why. But nonetheless you might occasionally get one of the really good waiters and the food and the atmosphere makes it all worth it!   This is a consistent and yummy place!
author: JT B.

description:
Wait, am in Dirty Dancing? 
The decor was awesome, and super funky compared to the typical SF restaurant. The host was on top of her game, but can't say that about our server. Service was severely delayed while he chatted up other restaurant staff and tables. We waited over 10 minutes for a spoon...and they weren't that busy on a Thursday night after 9pm.
The food however...excellent! We shared the deviled eggs. I had the meatloaf, my friend, the chicken soup. Delicious!!
author: Amy O.

description: This is an update -- and it just gets better!  Today I called as we have a reservation tonight for a special occasion -- and Julia, the manager who I spoke with was a delight in every way!  I was thinking of ordering a dessert (boring) to mark this special night, and she suggested a bottle of bubbly, set on the table for when we arrive -- and is also writing a card to put on the table -- with flutes, etc.  So perfect!  I was able to pay w my credit card, so I didn't have to worry about that later. She was accommodating and very customer focused!  I'll tell you tomorrow about the actual dinner.  LOL
author: Katherine E.

description:
Was in San Francisco to see The Girl With The Pearl Earring at the DeYoung. Many of the Dutch paintings featured people drinking beer and eating oysters and it made our mouth's water. My friend suggested Presidio Social Club as a place to get oysters -- over Hog Island which would have been closed by the time we got there. 

Now, I love the Presidio and it's pretty hard to beat as a location so if this place was anywhere else, I would probably give it 3.5 stars. It's a great historic building with a fantastic view of the bustling Presidio and ILM buildings. The decor is spectacular and really does feel like an old social club. Our waiter was not only gorgeous but fabulously friendly and attentive, albeit young and not terribly informed about where our $3 oysters were from. Turns out the "Northwest" oysters are from Orcas Island. The oysters were very good and nicely presented.

We decided to get a variety of nibbles from the appetizer menu and share everything. We got a butter lettuce salad, kale salad, french fries, a dozen oysters and a prosciutto/cheese plate. The kale salad was probably the best thing, followed by the french fries. The butter lettuce was yummy but it's so unsubstantial, it's like eating air. The prosciutto/cheese plate was a disappointment. Just thin slices laying on a plate with nothing to eat it with, no fruit, no bread, no condiments. And really only a few ounces of food. 

The beer selection was pretty sparse, after all my mouth watering this was a disappointment. It seems like this is more of a cocktail joint. The wine list was alright and my friend found a good one. We polished the plates and then ordered fritters and one of us got coffee. The beignets were okay, nice texture but not particularly delicious, but the chocolate sauce was to die for. I drank the rest of it which was like a thick mexican hot chocolate. Yum!

All in all, we spent about $50 per person and walked away not exactly hungry but not exactly satisfied either. We were already talking about what we were going to have for dinner when we got home.
author: Angelique L.

description: Love the Presidio Social Club! It's great for brunch or a drink with friends, there's always seats available at the bar. It's nice that they accept brunch reservations, not many restaurants in SF do! Definitely split one of their baked goods. Huge fan of the cinnamon roll and beignets. The huevos rotos and the chilaquilles are my favorites. If it's nice out try to grab a seat on their patio!
author: Rachel C.

description:
We had our wedding reception here and it was excellent. Gio was absolutely superb in terms of service, attentiveness and flexibility. We were supposed to go in with 35 guests, it balooned to over 45 and yet Gio was able to handle everything from the extra seats, working with our cake vendor and allowed us to go in early to set up and prepare. Emails and calls were answered quickly and we could not say enough good things.

Food was also great. Steak Salad, Chicken Sandwich, Cheese Toast and so much more and all our guests were incredibly happy and impressed with it all. I can't speak to dinner, but for lunch it was incredible in every way!
author: Matthew L.

description:
One of my favorite go to spots. Great for date night or dinner with the parents, always quality food and service. They have a little something for everyone. 

I really like their fresh fish. I generally order whatever the fish of the day is. Apps are delicious also, go for the grilled cheese and tomato soup, deviled eggs or the side of
Mac and cheese (glutinous and delish).

Have a cocktail from the bar before sitting, good variety and well made.
author: Meredith M.

description: Nice waitstaff and dining environment. Simple and well-executed menu. Great prix fixe menus on the weekends.
author: Emily J.

description:
Had wanted to try this for a while, but never had the chance until last weekend.  Loved the unique setting of the venue and almost felt like I was transported to a country club dining room somewhere in the woods.  Service was friendly, if a bit slow at times.  Drinks were very good and food was as well -- I had the signature meatloaf, which was a fun treat.    Solid time, with no complaints.

Also, the fact that they have plentiful parking is a bonus for sure!
author: Jeff A.

description: After walking the dogs at Crissy field, we decided on a late lunch.  I saw that this place was dog friendly, and it was close.  The parking lot is a bit small but that is ok, you are in a park, and a bit of a walk is nice.  If you decide to come here, make a reservation, it will make your life a whole lot easier.  Because we were on the fly, I did not do this, and the lady at the hostess station, was very gracious and was able to fit us in with in 15 min.  Because we had our pets, we sat on the covered patio with heaters, and had a remarkable lunch.  The lunch menu is limited, but that speeds up the ordering process, as well as the cooking process.  Our waiter was super busy, so I suggest ordering a cocktail or something from the extensive wine list, enjoy the historical surroundings, and the company you are with.  I had the meatloaf, and it was wonderful, I definitely recommend this, my girlfriend ordered the cheeseburger, and said it was just alright.  They were busy with several private parties, so most of the people were dressed very nicely, so, be aware of this.  This is not a "sweatpants,TGIFriday's" type of place.  I would love to come here again, and try something else on the menu.
author: Paul G.

description:
Welcoming vibe while entering. Lighting and simple decor. Started with the deviled eggs. Nothing too fancy but consistent tasting with the right amount of texture & firmness.
I got the veal, my only complaint while I enjoyed the entree was that veal wasn't sautéed more (fried) 
The butter lettuce salad good size with a nice lemon vinaigrette. 
Polished it off with lemon meringue CAKE
author: Mark C.

description: We went to a private event here and were pleasantly surprised with the family-style served options. From the cocktails, get the gimlet - super fresh and lime-y. The butter lettuce salad was really nothing to write home about (in fact, pretty uninspired) and the gruyere cheese toast is just silly (you can make something better at home), but the mains and sides were very good. We really like the short ribs, minted peas, macaroni and cheese (not too salty!), and broccoli. Desserts were also a win: though the beignets were a little heavy (didn't love the raspberry sauce, which was too thick), the mini-vanilla cupcakes were perfect and the chocolate cookies delicious. Overall would recommend.
author: MichLee A.

description: Presidio Social Club is great!  I have been for both brunch and dinner and both are great.  The atmosphere is a ton of fun, its feels like you take a step back in time and are dining in an old school country club.  The bartender is great, he let me try and few different wines before deciding on my glass and he seemed genuinely interested in making sure I choose the right one.  We ordered the chicken and the meatloaf, both were great.  The meatloaf was a very large portion, would recommend sharing.  It's on the pricer side but perfect for a girls dinner or a great place to take your parents when they are visiting.
author: Chelsea W.

description: I've heard about this place, I've seen it on check please so my expectations were high. Talk about a disappointment! The service left much to be desired. Our cocktails were just ok. We ordered the eggplant for an appetizer, which was the best part of our meal. We ordered the steak (medium) and a burger as our entrees. The steak was charred to a crisp, worst $35 steak I've ever had. The burger was ok. Our waiter never checked on us to ask how our meal was. It wasn't until we got our check that he pretended to care. SF has so many great dinning options, recommend you save your money and go elsewhere else.  Unless you like to pay for subpar food and bad service.
author: Mike S.

description:
Average food. There wasn't enough of what we originally ordered so a substitution was provided when the main courses were delivered. Surprise! The waiter was great and mentioned all the specials and then returned with bad news, so my party made an alternate choice. 
One burger came with cheese when it was requested that no cheese be on it. Scraped it off. The waiter apologized. Nothing else was done. We also found square pieces of paper under our entrees. Just shrugs from the manager. 
I will say that the coffee was excellent! The best part of the evening. 
My party said that they were happy to try the place but would not return. It's true that I was expecting a little more, money not well spent.
author: Phil B.

description:
The PSC is a very charming venue. I attended a wedding reception here and it was a a nice experience.  Cocktail hour was held in a room on the side that lead out to the back patio. They have a huge bar that stretches the length of the restaurant. The staff was professional and accommodating. Lighting was romantic and perfect for the occasion.

I'm trying not to be too critical about the dishes served bc I know it was mass produced for the wedding. Although, the hors d'oeuvres for cocktail hour were yummy. We were served a 3 course meal consisting of salad, entree and dessert. It was nice that there were 3 entree options: meat, fish or veggie.  The waiters came and took our orders right before service. I had the swordfish and my date had the braised short ribs. It actually turned out to be a lot of food and we were pretty stuffed. The salad was good...nothing too special. The swordfish was a little dry maybe bc it was precooked. Braised short ribs were tender but also a little dry. Good thing there was gravy. 

Here go the cons - Food preparation was inconsistent. At our table, one of the salads had no sesame seeds....while everyone elses' salad had them. One of my friends' short ribs had no gravy at all. I guess those were oversights since it was a wedding. However, I don't think that should be an excuse. The dessert consisted of salted caramel ice cream with a small brownie. I wish there was more brownie...that was the best part. However, the consensus was that the ice cream was too salty. Some of us didn't finish it bc there was too much coarse sea salt in it. What a shame to waste ice cream!
author: Liv A.

description:
Enjoyed a delightful lunch with girlfriends to kick off 2015.  Most of us ordered the chilaquiles, which are available with an additional side of protein (additional because the chilaquiles come with scrambled eggs).  I opted for a side of pork belly, and one of my girlfriends chose the duck confit.  My pork belly was a well-cooked, fork tender hunk of delicious meat.  I only wish that more of the chips in my chilaquiles were still crunchy by the time they made it to our table.

This is not to say that service was anything but top notch.  Our waiter was attentive without being too obtrusive.  And, so far as I could tell, he was responsive to my pregnant girlfriend's dietary restrictions about pasteurized cheeses.

Although the menu was limited, the prices are actually quite reasonable for brunch in SF.  $30 (excluding tip) per person (3 of us had a bellini or mimosa).
author: Christina L.

description:
Don't go here. 

If you do, only drink the cocktails. Whatever you do don't order the fried chicken. Took 45 minutes and didn't have any skin. 

Brussels tasted like they were boiled only.
author: Peter M.

description:
Dear Chef Ray Tang,

Please go back to culinary school. 

P.S. - Thanks for giving my friend food poisoning.

Regards,
Ladies of BTEC
*******************

Usually I spend a good 2-2.5 hours writing and perfecting a review. Presidio Social Club doesn't deserve my time as I already wasted 2.5 hours last night (painstakingly slow and inattentive service) and $80 per person for the WORST foie gras I've ever had in my life.

Being the only restaurant in San Francisco and quite possibly in California that still serves foie gras after the statewide ban (7.1.12), I'll give Presidio Social Club props for finding a loophole to continue serving foie gras (on Federal land and not subject to ban). Not only has Presidio Social Club gained national attention, it has sent a flurry of foie gras lovers  to their doors so they can continue getting their fix.

What I do NOT give them props is for milking it for all its worth and then some. For an additional $18, you have the option to add foie gras to your entree. There's only two entrees on the menu which the foie gras would work with, the steak bavette ($26) or ribeye for two ($68). We opted for the ribeye which to our dismay arrived topped with foie gras torchon (not seared foie gras as you would expect). Picture: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/U1nNL9ur-0RO7gROm9PpOw?select=taTNKc8U8YzqbWoJnEs-wg#LH9ouGM_dVh15o4bwuAq8w  

Foie gras torchon is meant to be served as an appetizer with bread and a fruity acidic component and NOT served atop a steak. For $18 a piece, we got a disk of foie gras torchon that was disgustingly salty. To add salt to the wound (literally), it was topped with MORE salt. Like slimy snots, sinew within the torchon made it even viler that none of us could stomach finishing it (and you know how much I love my foie gras).

The other dishes we ordered weren't any better as they were poorly executed (my friend got food poisoning from the mussels) and presentation for some of our dishes were reminiscent to food served to senior citizens at a convalescent home (I wish I took pictures of the smashed peas and mashed potatoes).

I know Chef Tang is not classically trained in French cuisine but it's an insult to this French delicacy to not take the time to learn how to properly prepare it and even worse, serve it and charge an absurd amount for complete crap. 

GREEDY MUCH?
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Congratulations to Ray Tang, you have officially made my worst meal of 2012.

For once, I side with protestors. Please, stop serving foie. 
I read the glowing reviews here and noticed they're all 3+ years old. This place must have been good at one point but has seriously gone DOWNHILL and in a last ditch attempt, they are revitalizing themselves by capitalizing the fact that they're on federal land and serving foie.

Here's the thing:

IF YOU DON'T KNOW HOW TO PREP IT, DON'T SERVE IT. Go read foie for dummies or something! 

When the meal first started I was thinking, "yea , this place is so so. I would probably give it 3 stars" but as the meal progressed, the lower my rating sunk.

Our waiter didn't bother to give us the special menu, we had to inquire about that.. I also had to inquire about the fish of the day. BTW, this foie slider that they are serving is poached foie w/ pineapple. 

Started off with the chicken liver pate and pan roasted mussels in cioppino broth. 
The chicken liver pate was good. Loved the cornichons as well but that was it. My friends had arrived before me and they had plates. I was missing plates for a good while.  This was when I was thinking PSC is so so. 
 Don't order the mussels. For the love of seafood, do not claim it's a cioppino broth. Just because you toss in half a tomato the last couple of minutes does not make it a cioppino broth.Cioppino broth is aromatic and flavorful whilst the one at PSC is not. It was bland bland bland bland BLAND. They also didn't bring us a bowl for our shells until we were nearly halfway done with the dish. Not to ention the onions were not even thoroughly cooked?? 


Got the rib eye and added 3 orders of foie. For our sides, we had the mashed potatoes, peas with mint oil and an order of the mac & cheese. When our entree arrived, we were sorely disappointed. It's just a torchon of foie but the torchon slathered with tons of salt. The rib eye itself was flavorless (how sad) and the foie was overly salty. It tasted better when you had a bite of both but I started feeling sick. This is when it went downhill for me. I got dizzy and lightheaded. At first I was thinking it was too much salt for me. I excused myself and headed to the restroom where I proceeded to upchuck 4x.

I can't say much for the peas, mashed potatoes and mac & cheese although my friend did say the peas looked like convalescent home food.

The rest of the night, I felt terrible. I was praying on the porcelain throne well until 1am. It was probably the mussels.

I was so dissatisfied with the foie torchon on my rib eye that I cannot even fathom that poached foie slider *shudders*
I took the leftover rib eye home thinking my brother would eat it. I texted him to tell him I had some food for him and he thanked me. I woke up this morning and it was still sitting on the kitchen table barely 1/4 eaten. He said it was flavorless.

I'd rather be hungover in a 3rd world country.
author: Susy C.

description:
Our waitress seemed to be less than thrilled, kind of ruined it, but I'll tell you what. If you don't care about the personality and can ignore that you seem to be a burden to the server, the food is outstanding!!!

Holy crud, the meatloaf, order the meatloaf it's to die for, no seriously,  order the meatloaf.. The wife had the mac and cheese and that was stellar and my son, who is the pickiest eater of them all (oh not, I'll put my boy up against anyones child, no, really!)) had the burger, they do a mix of buffalo and hamburger, and he didn't flinch, good stuff, their fries were quality as well :)

I would not hesitate going back if we do another show in the area. And ya I'll have the meatloaf again!
author: Tory B.

description:
I went to Presidio Social Club for the first time to celebrate a friend's engagement this past Saturday at around 4pm.  We walked in, excited for our newly engaged friends, and asked for a table for 7. We were met by an extremely rude response from the extremely rude hostess. We didn't think anything could kill the mood that day, but for a brief moment, she did. 

Despite empty table upon empty table, she told us it would be ~incredibly~ hard to seat us. When we asked if it would be easier if we just had drinks she gave us a sarcastic answer, "well, yes, that ~would~ be easier" and pointed to the bar. We finally talked to another employee who was able to seat us at a proper table, without the attitude. 

The only reason I am rating this experience two stars instead of one was the wonderful waiter who managed to salvage the occasion.
author: Anne V.

description: Skip the food!!  Go for a drink at the bar to enjoy the experience!  The specialty drinks and wine list is very good. The service was horrible on a Saturday and the food was Ok at best. We went in between 2 museum visits at around 2 pm.  It was packed and extremely noisy.  The Cubano sandwich was dry.  The quiche and salad just Ok. The poke with chips just Ok.  Go for a drink and skip the food!!
author: Diana L.

description: Had lunch there recently and love the ambiance. Food was morsel size and pretty expensive but was quite prompt. They did a nice job refilling my ice tea.
author: Craig J.

description:
Ate here with 7 other girls earlier this month and had an overall good experience. The start was not promising, I ordered what I think was called a firecracker cocktail, hoping for a warm spicy cocktail. This wasn't interesting spicy, it was like fireball candy (or whiskey) in the back of your throat spicy. Not even that it was too hot, but whatever the red cinnamon stuff they used in that drink overwhelmed my mouth completely. Later, wine suggestion did not go well with either my mouth or the food or both. Waiter wasn't really engaging us in our questions either.

However, the food was the highlight of the meal. We started out with some oysters (nice and clean) and grilled cheese toasts (good but pretty small portion). I took the waiter's recommendation and ordered the swordfish special over brussels sprouts, and split it and the meatloaf dish with a friend. They were both fantastic, swordfish was a little bit better because those sprouts were some of the best I've had. And that's saying something since seeing brussels sprouts in a dish usually puts me on auto-order.

I thought this place was going to be more about the experience than the food, but it ended up being food first! Will try to come back if in the area.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Wanting the 10 star system as always... actually a 7 but I suppose the good weather has gotten the best of me and so I'll go with 4.

Went for Brunch.

Outdoor patio seating = Yes.

You can make a reservation, so, hello! Do it - this is San Francisco - nobody likes to sit in lines.  

The indoor space was actually really cool too.  Very clean. Nice big windows. Modern with a still old/diner feel.  Good vibe.

Mimosa: Too much orange juice... especially for $11

Eggs Benedict (the only really important thing): Good hollandaise, but there wasn't enough of it. Eggs: perfectly poached.  Toast, decent. Ham, on the better side.  Addition of greens: surprisingly good, but a little overpowering, but still i'm for it. 

Service: hilarious. Our waiter was a strange guy, but there was nothing wrong with the service, he was just a character.  A kind character.  

Parking: yes.  

I'd come back on another beautiful sunday....
author: Sarah C.

description: I was here a couple weeks back for a holiday dinner with friends. It was very warm and festive and the food phenomenal. For apps, we got the grilled cheese triangles to dip In tomato soup as well as the deviled Eggs. They wee good. My sea bass entree was amongst the best pieces of fish  I've ever had. The mashed peas side was incredible- the Brussels sprouts just average. BUT, the desserts were melt in your mouth - we got coconut cream pie and salted caramel ice cream sandwich. Bonus star- their retro inspired, herb infused cocktails are flavorful and will surely  take you back to a simpler time....
author: Kirsten M.

description: Rather pricey for the meager portions. Ordered the chicken salad to find a few strands of chicken. Our waiter, Michael, had attitude. Provided poor service: served cold coffee, didn't bother asking us if we wanted more. He thought was clever but he really came off as pompous. Go for the decor and atmosphere and not for the food or service.
author: Peterpeter P.

description: I've been wanting to try this spot in the Presidio for some time.  Parking easy.  The space is pleasant and the service was great and attentive.  Tried the recommended crab sandwich which was good but the bread used was not up to SF standards.  The accompanying salad was ok but the lettuce was bruised.   My partner at lunch complained that the crab was "off tasting".   I'll give it another try and make some alternate selections.
author: steve o.

description:
I always want to like this place more than I actually do. The look and feel of the place, and the location are all very nice. But the food is just okay and a little over-priced for what it is. My $32 pork chop was certainly big and impressive. And the sautéed corn it was sitting on was very good, but the chop itself was dry and tasteless. The others at our table had the same kinds of reactions to their food. Okay, but nothing special.

The real problem though is the service, and especially the officious hostess and reservation staff. I made my reservation via Open Table. Then I got a call from the restaurant asking to confirm. Fine. I confirmed. Then a couple days later I got another message asking for another confirmation. I ignored this one figuring that Open Table and one confirmation should be enough. Then, I got another message saying if I didn't confirm they couldn't guarantee my reservation. So, I called again.

Then, when five of us arrived on time for our table for six we were told that we would all have to wait to be seated until our sixth person who was stuck in Bay Bridge arrived. So, for 30 minutes we sat at the bar looking at our table, but unable to sit at it. Why? We were told, "That's just the way it is." 

Well, here's another way it is, I really don't think I need to go back.
author: Rick H.

description: I had an AMAZING experience. The waitress(Emily) gave great recommendations for food and drinks, and made my anniversary perfect. The drinks rock, food came super fast, and the service was very professional. Looking forward to our next visit!!!
author: Becca S.

description:
We came in for lunch on Saturday and were given a brunch menu which luckily included breakfast AND lunch items. I had the chopped salad which was good, though it was a bit heavy handed with the (bitter) arugala. The pork belly was warm and crispy and the dressing light and good. My friend had the chicken soup which had a very down-home taste to it (I dislike canned or gloppy soups), it was simple, but good. Our waiter (Eric?) was the kind of guy who was either smirking at the customers as he took orders, or had a smirky face. He was nice enough, though I didn't get a genuine friendly vibe from him. 

The flourless chocolate cake with coffee ice cream was very good. The cake was so light and moist that I wondered if it was really flourless. The beignets were long and good, not great. They are sprinkled with sugar not powdered sugar which is okay, but not ideal. The little pot of chocolate dipping sauce was irresistible. 

I had a good experience, but it's not "as good as it gets," instead I'm merely a fan and would come back though I'm not in a super hurry to do so. Worth checking out.
author: Thalia F.

description: We celebrated my mother's 70th birthday with 17 individuals... they accomodated us even though 5 of us have life threatening allergies. We all thoroughly enjoyed ourselves, loved the atmosphere and the good food.
author: Monica D.

description:
Meh, I wouldn't come here again. It's situated in a nice and scenic location, tucked away in a quiet part of the city so it's not so hectic, and the parking situation is a bit easier. That's where the good stuff ends. 

The food is pretty mediocre for the price. Not a cheap place, but the food is pretty much like any other brunch place in SF. Well, the bacon was especially crappy - very thin and crummy slices, even though you pay good money for a side order of it. The omelet and the latte were pretty decent.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Nice place. Kind of an unusual brunch menu. The area in which we were seated was a bit on the cold side, but the food was good and the service fast and courteous.
author: Mikkel R.

description: We had tried Sessions for mother's day so we figured we would give this place a try for father's day brunch. I am not sure where I could find any positive about my experience there. Waiter was semi rude, food took a long time to arrive and when it did, what was described on the menu as a mushroom sugo with polenta and poached egg was a sad watery tasteless mixture with a vague plain polenta drowned in it and an egg that was beyond hard boiled (not even close to a memory of a poached egg). I was hoping the levain bread would help make me forget this but they ran out and gave me white bread instead. Oh and to make sure you really don't enjoy they have NO AC so everyone was sweating bullets. Could not wait to get out of there. If you want a nice brunch place go across the street to Sessions. I am never going back.
author: Jean-Francois R.

description:
Loved this place -- here r the highlights:

-- super cozy
-- has kind of an equestrian feel to it... Kind of reminded me of Munich 
-- really friendly staff
-- the meatloaf was on point
-- reasonably priced

Only con was the drinks were wack and they don't have any proper barware, so get beer or wine (although it's likely both will come n coffee mug).
author: Nolan M.

description:
we had lunch there recently and nothing was really great on the food part, truffle oil fries at $8.50 were a giant mess and overpriced..Cuban sandwich sounded really good but again nothing special except that it was warm, I've had better sandwiches at Deli's!
Kale salad with citrus segments was ok but again I've had better, was really plain and dressing did not do it.
Iced tea at $4 was hardly a bargain...
the only good about this place are the settings, the Presidio is really a special place and love coming here on a regular basis.
Next time I'll bring a picnic which will most likely be half of what "lunch" costed us at PSC.
author: Scott L.

description:
Came here for date night with the honey. First, this place gets top ratings just due the fact that it has a parking lot!! Yes, you heard it right, free and easy PARKING!! And not just a 3-4 car dinky little lot, but it has at least 20-25 spots!! I thought I died and went to suburban heaven. And on a completely unrelated note, even for the Marina/Presidio, this place is extremely white (not that there's anything wrong with that). I have never seen so many blondes (fake or otherwise) in my life.

After perusing the menu, we agonized between sharing the pork chops and burger or get the steak for two. In the end, we decided to hedge and error on the side of variety. We also ordered the chicken liver pâté to start, a Moscow mule for me and Makers on the rocks for the boy. We held hands and dreamily locked peepers over the flickering candle night -- another romantic date night was about to commence. Not sure if it was the booze or the dim light, but hot damn, the boyfriend looked good!

First up, the pâté. It had a nice layer of fat on top, which my boyfriend (not so) surreptitiously scrapped off and dug in for the pink stuff. I didn't mind the fat; more flavor for me. The pâté was smooth and didn't taste organ-y at all; paired with the fig (?) jam, me likey! The toast points that came with the dish could use a bit more refinement, they were essentially whole wheat bread cut into sticks. I think a fancier, more toasted bread would be preferable. Nevertheless, it was a great start to the meal.

After we sufficiently mopped up every last morsel of the pâté, our entrees promptly arrived. I got the burger first and Orin the pork chops. The patty of the burger was chubby and thick, almost like a meatball. We requested it medium rare and the kitchen delivered. The center was nicely pink. Although not the most juicy or flavorful burger that I've tried, the fact that the patty was so compact made the mouth feel seem more succulent than it was. I say that because there were no run-off from the burger at all. Maybe it was because they rested the patty? Although, do people really rest hamburger meat? The thin cut fries were crispy and paired with the garlic aioli, pretty much spud heaven. I would give the burger a B+.

The pork chop, on the other hand, was a lackluster. I told our waitress that I prefer the pork less done, if possible. The meat was pretty tough and dry, especially the parts that were further away from the bone. It was seasoned well, though. The greens provided some needed moisture to the dish, but it was on the salty side. The apple sauce balanced it out a bit, but the chop itself was simply too overcooked to salvage the dish. In my book, that's a C-.

I read in other yelp reviews that the banana cream pie was the star of the dessert menu, however, I was informed that the restaurant has a new pastry chef and they no longer make the pie. It's nice to know that the place makes desserts in-house, but I had my mind set on the banana cream pie so didn't end up ordering anything. Next time, I'll be sure to save room for sweets.
author: Alice W.

description:
Had a great brunch this morning after a very soggy run in Crissy Field. 

The food was excellent - the brioche beignets were amazing as was everything else. 

The server was a bit slow - our beignets came out before our coffee (and the coffee was cold). 

But the hostess more than made up for everything by bringing us blankets from the outdoor seating area when she saw how cold and soaked we were from the rain.
author: Amanda S.

description: Father's Day brunch was a bust to say the least. It was too hot inside and the lack of screens on the windows to keep the pesky flies away resulted in them staying shut. The food took FOREVER to come out and the one dish that barely required any preparation, the Vietnamese sandwich came out last. Their "beignets" are NOT beignets and are best sugar donuts shaped into logs! Save yourself the money! My husbands poached egg came hard boiled too!  At least they gave crayons to my 12 month old who thought trying to eat it would be more entertaining.
author: Rosalind S.

description: I took a date here for dinner a few weeks ago.  I had heard mixed reviews so I wasn't sure what to expect.  The restaurant was well set up, from the nice ambiance to the efficiency of the service.  We were greeted and sat right away.  We both enjoyed our dinners, but we both agreed later that we enjoyed our server, Austin even more.  He gave us plenty of attention (but not in an annoying way), answered the few questions we had and gave us some helpful suggestions.  This was a first date and it was a little awkward at first, and whether he could tell that or not, he really helped us both feel more comfortable, even breaking the ice once, when my date and I were stuck in an awkward silence.  I will come back for sure.
author: Nicholas P.

description:
This is a PSA regarding the quinoa/curry special (2.5 stars) at lunch. If you have a big ol' appetite like lil ol' me, you will probably be disappointed. What sounded like a decently hearty dish (price: $10) came out in a bowl with a diameter smaller than my (lady) hand and was only filled a third of the way up from the bottom. 

The quinoa and the curry sauce were mixed together in the bowl....like a curry porridge. The "summer vegetables" consisted of just chunks of carrot (not even slightly joking). Overall, the flavors were fine but the portion size is sad.

Thank the gluttonous heavens I added on pork belly (price $6), which created a decently filling (but not happily stuffed) lunch together with some apps and sides. Also thank the wallet gods my boss paid for this meal.

If you want something more filling for lunch, the chicken sandwich or burger are better bets. The mac and cheese is delicious. Outside patio has limited shade.
author: Carolyn F.

description: What the hell kind of a restaurant takes off one of their most popular items on the menu, the cubano, because they "can't keep up with demand"? Here's a tip - don't do that. Seriously, how dumb can you be? Give the people what they want. I won't be back. One star because I have to. One for the memory of what once was, a pretty good cubano. FDR is rolling over in his grave.
author: Mike D.

description:
The minute we entered the restaurant they were friendly and fun.
Great unpretentious ambience.
The fries were wonderfully delicious, a good indicator of the fine food to follow.
Mussels tasted like the ocean. Yum.
A little hard to find in the Presidio.
author: Kristin J.

description:
I wanted to like this place much more than I did, but the food was only meh, especially for the price.  Great scenic location, nice building.

Fried chicken should have some contact with a fryer.  This was the biggest disappointment.  We just ate at Gus's Fried Chicken in Austin TX, which was as different from this chicken as night is from day.

The Manhattans we ordered didn't taste much like Manhattans, more like someone's attempt at a Manhattan who had never had one before.  Brussel sprouts needed to be cooked better.  The liver and onions was good, but not great.  For the prices they charge, the food should be amazing.

Desserts were by far the best part of the meal.
author: Brad B.

description:
Came here for a late sunday dinner. Food was pretty good; service was pretty crappy

Server really tried to push the "foie gras for the table" on us. I get that PSC is "special" because it's on federal land and foie gras is as enticing to a foodie as crack to the SF homeless, but some of us just don't like the seared preparation of foie gras, ok? After we told the waiter "no" on the foie gras, he walked off like we just insulted his mother.

Waiter would hound us and be overly nice at times, and them seem super distracted and distant other times, barely looking/listening to us.  Is there such a thing as Bipolar Waitering? 

They were also out of oysters. le tear.

We had the ahi tuna poke (delish), lamb meatballs (good if you like lamb. i don't), and kale salad to start.  All were great; good sized portions. 

The three of us ended up all getting the scallops special - i think with a chickpea and lentil puree. Well seasoned; we ate it all up.  

Also indulged in the beignets and ice cream sandwiches dessert.  Beignets were pretty unspecial. Tasted just like sugar donuts.  But the salted caramel ice cream sandwich dessert with burnt marshmallows is a A+. 

 I also got the mac & cheese to-go (but had a small bite when they brought it out) - good but not worth the hype or the $15. Super salty too, and I like salty foods.

French 75 was well made; wine list is fantastic.

I'd come back here for brunch. Fingers crossed I don't get the bipolar waiter again.
author: Alice Z.

description:
This meal was just fine. Nothing special, nothing horrible. I went because my cousins live in the Presidio and, honestly, they wanted to go to Liverpool Lil's but it was still closed due to the fire. So we ended up here and it's not a very large menu. I went the soup and salad route. The cauliflower soup was actually quite good. The PSC chopped salad with pork belly vinaigrette was tasty, too. However, there was nothing about either dish that stood out or will make me rush back here. 

The one thing I'll say is that the beans that came with my cousin's roasted chicken were amazing. 

If you're nearby and hungry, this place will fit the bill. But I don't believe it's worth trekking out to the Presidio for, if you're looking for a great meal.
author: David B.

description: Came to the Wednesday BBQ on the patio twice with 2 sets of friends. Pork ribs one week were fine, 7 ribs with small side of coleslaw and cornbread were fine although $25 a bit steep. Returned following Wednesday for the beef ribs. Option of small at $12 and large at $38 were overpriced for food, although tasty. Everyone still hungry so tried the sloppy Joe's and the sausage plate that were average and also overpriced at $12 each. Some local beers for $5 fine. Something different but shouldn't have arrived hungry.
author: Reynold C.

description:
Wonderful building, setting, and interior design. The place has an air of classy old school but stays casual. First impression: positive. Second impression: neutral but with hope. Why? My friend and I shared the rib eye for two as it's called but let me jump back to the appetizers.

We ordered the spinach dip. It was small and not nearly enough for a table of three. The toast it came with was done in a minute and we had to order regular bread which simply didn't work with the dip. The server didn't seem to get that. Tip to restaurant: the server should let a table of three know that it's small and maybe order two or simply bring us more of the toast it came with... or make it larger.

Now, back to the rib eye. It was perfectly cooked. It was a nice piece of meat. I have two complaints: 1) Cooked with WAY too much salt. 2) It must have been two pounds of fries just dumped on top covering the meat, adding more salt taste and grease to the meat. Not to be picky but I didn't like fishing around a pile of french fries to get the meat. It's too casual and burger joint like.

These are just my comments - you may like your food prepared differently and find the Presidio Social Club to your liking as it has a lot to offer. My comments are details but details are where a restaurant makes or breaks with an individual.
author: Matt T.

description:
I'm really disappointed by this place. They missed the mark on so many fronts, it really put us all of. If i lived in san fran, i would never intentionally come back here. 


Food (2.0/5):
Very small menu and it's a little confused. If a restaurant has a small menu, then you expect they do their dishes really well. Instead we ended up with mediocore food at best. Heavily salted, poorly flavoured, badly cooked, excellently cooked - it was all over the map.

Service (2.0/5):
Servers are all very nice. However, service is slow.
