Not sure what all the hype is about. Service wasn't great - they forgot some orders and also rarely came around to check on whether we needed anything. 
I got the hamburger, which was beyond underwhelming. Lemon meringue pie was just okay. I will say the poke and fries were very tasty. No reason to come back though.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Presidio Social Club is a classy establishment appropriate for a dinner when your family is in town or even a business lunch. Tucked into the Presidio as it is and populated by kindly silver-haired clientele, It has a warm, even nostalgic, feel to it. I come here about once per week for business lunches because I find it to be a welcoming, non-stuffy atmosphere.  I have had the mac & cheese and tomato soup and it is as yummy as can be. The soups and salads are also quite good.  And I love the burger.  In fact, the whole menu is above average.

I deduct a star because the staff is occasionally inattentive.  Not usually, just occasionally.  For example, the hostesses don't seem to recognize me even though I am probably one of their more regular customers. 

Overall, a reliable, nice restaurant that transports you out of the city and back in time a few decades.
author: Evan B.

description:
I've dined here on two occasions now. The best part of this restaurant is the location. It's hidden away in the Presidio, and it transports you away from the hecticness of the city.

Portions are a little small for the price. The pork chop was good. Arugula salad was solid. If you're looking for a more relaxed but sophisticated, country-like dining experience, consider this.

I will definitely return and hopefully try the brunch.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Didn't have high hopes for this place, but was hoping for at least 3 stars. Unfortunately, 2 stars it is.

The restaurant looks like a small old aged elementary school or something from the outside, but the inside is big, modern, elegant, and filled with classily dressed San Franciscans.

The seating situation made no sense. Came for brunch with a group of 6 and there was a group of 14 before us, a group of 6 after us, and another group of 4 after them. There were tables connected for the group of 14, however it was currently occupied. There were 3 available tables of 6 behind the occupied table. So since the tables for 6 were empty you would think they would seat us. However, the hostesses were waiting for the big party to leave so they could seat the 14, but wanted to keep the 3 tables open just in case the big party didn't leave anytime soon. Which they didn't. Yet the hostesses still didn't combine the 3 tables to seat the 14 and still wouldn't seat us because the 14 hasn't been seated. So basically there were 18 available seats and 30 people waiting to be sat and 0 people actually sitting. This continued for 50 minutes as the big party never left so the 14 people could not be seated and so on. Luckily the bar is huge and could accompany 30 people quite comfortably. So finally after 50 mins and the hostesses decide to seat us and the other two groups behind us, while the group of 14 are still waiting. Therefore, it made no sense to make the other groups wait??!

Anyways, our waiter was new and annoying and spilt water all over. Thought it was just him, but the other waiters didn't seem to be very knowledgable about anything either and also spilt the cream for my friend's coffee all over the floor (at least it wasn't the coffee he spilt but still). 

Food was meh. The toast on my eggs benedict was pretty much burnt. The menu also lacks selection.

As its name implies, this is definitely a place for socializing more than anything.
author: Jeanie F.

description: Michael advised us to order the beef ribs, and pork chop with the Tomjom Pinot. Outstanding service and food.
author: Joseph R.

description: Best pork belly. Have it straight up. Probably anything here with pork will be good. I saw the Cuban sandwich. Would order that too. Skip the poke. Abc stores in Oahu equivalent.
author: Wilca G.

description:
Location, Location, Foods pretty good! 
Kale salad, Salmon over salad couple of glasses wine and you are 
far from downtown San Francisco!
author: Leonard H.

description:
I've been here twice, once mostly for a drink and last night for dinner. What a lovely space. It's in an old Army building at the Presidio, across from the Letterman digital campus. 

We've only sat at the bar, but the bartenders are knowledgeable and good at their job. Had a couple of martinis and then dinner. 

Starters were a creamy blue-y mac and cheese, highly recommended and pureed cauliflower soup. The soup was heavenly with just a touch of cream and then a drizzle of smoked paprika oil. 

What a delicious and wonderful idea. I'm stealing it the next time I make leek and potato soup.

Had a burger and fries and the burger was thick, juicy and cooked just right, fries were thin, crispy and delicious. 

My friend had a steak which he also loved. The food is simple, well prepared and very good.

Highly recommended.
author: Mike F.

description:
Sometimes you get it right the first time and subsequent visits can't live up to the initial thrill. I absolutely adore the atmosphere (modern military chic) and the location in the Presidio, but during my last visit, the service was so poor that I would be hesitant to return. 

My first visit was a casual lunch last year. I sat at the bar after a long day walking all over the city and both the dungeness crabcake sliders and the house Manhattan, 100 Reason Rye, were very good. Recently I needed to find a restaurant for a large group at the last minute after a visit to the nearby Exploratorium and was thrilled they could seat us immediately with almost no notice for dinner. 

Seating is one thing, serving is another. My number one restaurant pet peeve is when there is a long delay taking your order. Everything falls apart from there. Once our drink order was taken, our server essentially disappeared for about half an hour. I'm not shy, so I have no problem flagging someone down, but that wasn't even an option. 

Once our order was taken, the rest of the service was fine with a few other odd moments here and there. We ordered a wide variety of food and it was hit-or-miss. I ordered the meatloaf from their Classics menu and it was a disappointment. The mashed potatoes in particular were not very good. From the antipasti menu, the pesto carrots were probably the most interesting item and the daily special, a crab bake, looked very good.

Since I'm so fond of The Presidio and want to explore it further on future visits, I would probably return for that casual drink at the bar so I can pretend I'm Kelly McGillis about to be serenaded by Maverick and Goose. But for a real meal, I think I'll head elsewhere.
author: Jen K.

description:
Me and my date went here for a nice dinner. We made a reservation for 6 p.m., but got held up because we got in a pretty rough argument.

I started with the oysters, while my date got the arugula salad with blackened sesame dressing. 

That night her tongue still tasted of it and I knew I didn't love her.

For dinner, she got the Wild Mushroom with Seared Faro, which she thought was okay, but the faro was a little warm. I got the Oven-Roasted Bone-In Ribeye Steak For Two.

She asked me what my skin felt like and if I recalled what it had felt like the first time I ate an Oven-Roasted Bone-In Ribeye Steak For Two and what it would feel like after I had stopped wanting.

She hadn't wanted since she was five. She still needed things, of course: food, touch, approval. But desire had nothing to do with it. She said that wanting made her tired. I told her that it makes me tired, too. It makes us all tired, which is why our eyes get saggy and our DNA slowly unravels. But most of us go ahead wanting anyway. 

I got an espresso, which packed a real kick.

The minus one star is because the wait staff sort of hovered. 

Hovering is impressive but it seemed pretentious, since they should just be content walking on the ground like the rest of us.
author: Benjami N.

description: Seemed like they had a function on the patio and while we were sitting there and ordering good, we were a bother to the wait staff.  Overall nice Presidio setting.
author: Lawland L.

description: The decor of this restaurant reminded me of a nice restaurant out in the Hamptons.  It was probably one of the least San Francisco-ey crowds that I've seen.  Lots of white bread and some people even bothered dressing up! Our waiter was superduper duper nice and very attentive.  The presentation of the food was quite cute but overall it was nothing much to write home about.  The lamb meatballs were surprisingly tasty.  Oh and the beignets.  Those were yum.
author: Marissa F.

description:
The menu did not seem to be complete. There were many pick-of-the-day or day-of-the week offers. We had to ask our waiter a couple of times what the daily this or that was, as he answered the one question but not all of them. For example, he explained the fish of the day when asked, but did not offer to tell us the chop of the day which had to ask about the next time we saw him. We were not told the prices for these dailies, which were on the menu as Market Price. There were also some day-of-week "dinners" which identified the entree but had no price or explanation of what comes with it or if it is a prix fixe or what made it special.

The barn-like room was very noisy and the tall waiter had to lean into our table so we could hear him. Two of us split a 2x6 Vancouver oysters which were excellent. My wife had the gruyere toast which she had heard about, and it was tasty but skimpy on the cheese. I point out that our oysters arrived a full five minutes before my wif'e's appetizer so we waited for her.

My friend and I shared a large rib steak for two - it was tasty, but slightly chewy, definitely not aged beef. My wife asked for the Petrale sole, which she saw mentioned in a Yelp review, but it wasn't on the menu and was not the fish of the day. They did offer it when asked and the fish was a whole filet, done to perfection and well-seasoned. The rib steak came done to order and was well-seasoned also. The sides were a mix of roasted vegetables and mashed potatoes. The two wines-by-the-glass (a sauvignon blanc with oysters and fish, and a Pinot Noir with the beef) were both excellent. No bread was served or offered and it wasn't really missed.

Dessert was good, but nothing special. The lemon meringue cake was very sweet and a bit mealy. The oatmeal fruit tart with apple and cinnamon was good, but also somewhat too sweet.

We might go back for lunch or brunch, but it is too noisy for a relaxed dinner.
author: Eric S.

description:
We've been for brunch more than a few times by ourselves and with friends.               Always solid, dependable and enjoyable.
Wife decided it would be a nice place for a date night for dinner, since we hadn't the pleasure.  Service was solid and attentive.  We started with sharing the burrata and tuna poke and a couple of cocktails.  Cocktails were tasty and refreshing.  The burrata was served in a pool of marinara with thin crostini.  The marinara while very flavorful, overwhelmed the mild burrata.  Tuna poke was over flavored with sesame and fish was a bit on the chunky side with a few pieces chewy and stringy.  Wife had the black cod special and while described as baked, seemed almost poached and over cooked to the point of mush.  Served on a bed of mashed leeks the only part of the dish that had much of any texture were the green peas on top.
I had the liver and onions and to be fair, I hadn't ordered that at a restaurant in quite a few years, I asked for it to be medium and what I got was more than half the cut a mushy rare (blah).  Since it was sliced and sunk into mashed potatoes it didn't seem worth the effort to send it back. 
140$ not including tip doesn't add up to 2 cocktails, 2 glasses wine, 2 mediocre apps and 2 mushy entrees.
2 stars food
4 stars service 
We'll be back for brunch, but not dinner I'm afraid.
author: Walt L.

description:
I'm having a hard time writing this review because I'm not really sure how I feel about Presidio Social Club. Yelp's definition of 3 stars is "A-OK", so I'm sticking to that.

I love the atmosphere, layout and service here, however the Chilaquiles failed to impress. It just fell flat - nothing special, bland and not exciting. 

The burger was DELISH. As were the bellinis (but that isn't that tough).

if I come back it'll be for the burger, but now I'm scared to try other menu items.
author: Francesca F.

description:
The four of us went to PSC for dinner tonight.  Overall, it was a delightful, experience (though at around $60/person after all was said and done, I'm not entirely certain I couldn't have had better, if you'll forgive the double-negative).

The foie gras -- which does not appear to be on the menu but is available if you ask for it (PSC is technically not in California due to federal land rules, so they can serve FG) was, of course, amazing -- seared, with some jam that contrasted beautifully with the rich texture of the foie gras.  As the only place, I think, to regularly serve it in the area, it's a must-visit if only for that.

The deviled eggs with caviar were pretty damn good, and super-delicious, though a little more caviar on them probably would have made more of an impression on a dish that mostly tasted like ... well, deviled egg with a hint of caviar.  I wanted to be slapped in the face by the caviar, and that didn't happen.

My wife had the parts of whole pig special, which seemed pretty reasonable.  I had the whole petrale sole which was ... well, for one thing, not whole.  You tell me whole fish, I expect head.  This just had the body.  Oh well, I'm probably being pedantic.  It tasted lovely, but the plate seemed a little bare with just it (and a lemon) on it.  It came with some artichoke dip and salsa on a different plate, but ... it didn't really make much sense.  Tasty, though.  

Dessert was pineapple cake for my wife (it came as part of the pig special) and beignets for the table.  Beignets appeared perfectly competent, though I didn't bother having any.  

Lovely view out the windows, delightful service -- friendly, humorous, and professional all at once.  I'd probably come here again.
author: Roy R.

description: I do like this place, the service is good, the waiters and waitresses very friendly and helpful.   The location is great especially on a sunny day. The  outside space and inside of the restaurant is  nice . The food is decent , I had the macaroni and cheese and the shrimp with a Creole sauce but one thing about the sauce was that it tasted like cheap barbecue sauce. The poke tasted fresh but the chips that came with it were soggy.
author: Pat C.

description: We did brunch. Beautiful location, but medium level service and food. For the price, I really expected my croque madame sandwich to be incredible, but it wasn't. It was just OK. And that was pretty much the entire experience at Presidio Social Club. You're paying for the atmosphere. The drinks were decent, and I'd go again with the right group, but it's not making the list of San Francisco favorites.
author: Jon R.

description: Very mediocre food for a pricey meal. It was in a cute place and the waitresses were super nice, but the brunch food was just meh. I had the hash special but I wouldn't say it's worth the $$. Everyone felt the same about their meals. Maybe the dinner food is better though!
author: Elizabeth K.

description:
We were last at Presidio Social Club about a year ago, when it seemed kinda loud and kinda expensive but still a pleasant place in the neighborhood to spend time with company. Plus, they serve liver, which I adore and don't get to order too often. However, our visit last week  was oddly unpleasant, mostly because of the service, although the food and its prices didn't help.  We were seated promptly, with menus, but then sort of forgotten--had to ask for water, for a chance to order drinks, later for dessert menus.  The two male waiters serving us were clearly over-extended, and both brusque to the point of rudeness.  It was rather embarrassing, given that we'd invited guests to what we'd described as a nice, friendly neighborhood spot.

The Presidio Social Club menu is small, mainstream, comfort-food-oriented, with most entrees in the $18-$24 dollar range; however, it features several items that are not listed with prices, such as catch of the day, roast of the day,  and the oven-roasted rib-eye for two,  which is "market-price."  Be sure to get the prices--our uncommunicative waiter didn't mention them, and we wouldn't have guessed that the rib-eye for two would be $96, or that a smallish piece of halibut on chickpeas would be ap. $34.  The under-flavored chick-peas could have come from a can.  My liver, on a modest bed of good mashed potatoes, was under-cooked, even for medium-rare, but rather than fight for non-existent waiter attention, I just ate around the squishy spots. One flavor that was present, in over-abundance, in the meal was salt--in the sauce accompanying the rib-eye and its (excellent) asparagus, in the truffle-oil fries, even in some of the ever-smaller cookies that were part of the cookie platter we've usually been happy to finish up our meal at the Social Club with before. 

I don't know--convenience, lovely location, happy buzz,  and the handsome interior have made this a place we've fallen back on in the past, but I'm not sure we'll be returning.  A venue this close to the competition provided by the restaurant mecca of the Chestnut/Fillmore area maybe needs to think about upping its game, particularly in the service department.
author: Chris C.

description:
3.5 really...

Came here on a Thursday night for the forbidden fruit, foie gras!  

What happened to the foie burger?

It's torchon, not seared?  Although I love foie gras no matter what the form, I didn't care for PSC's presentation of it that night.  

Anyway, meatloaf was delicious. Veal was okay. Salad was okay.  Burger looked tasty, but I didn't try it.  

Nothing really stood out for me, except that it's a decent restaurant.  There really wasn't any wow factor.  Probably won't come back unless I MUST have foie gras.
author: Carrie-C N.

description: We had a large group on a busy night, but seriously? 2 hrs before the salad came, 2.5 hrs for the main course. We ordered beer and it took 1/2 hr and was the wrong ones.  It's 9:10 pm and we have not seen our dessert.  The waitress was super nice, but we rarely saw her.
author: GranMama P.

description: I had a group event at PSC and had a really fantastic experience there. We had about 15 people and reserved the private room. Gio was thorough and fantastic to work with. Great ambience and a wonderful park-like setting that feels like it's in its own world, yet right in the City. The food was very good and service was outstanding! Every single staff member we worked with went above and beyond the call of duty -- the attitude was consistently positive and helpful. I have to send a HUGE shout-out to Julia in events, who FedExed a bracelet to Hawaii when one of our guests had lost it at the event. She was efficient, communicative, and made it seem it was no hassle at all (though I'm sure it was!). This was just a great experience and we will definitely be back. Thanks PSC!!
author: Holly S.

description: Amazing location. Nice servers but the food is truly bad. We live in the neighborhood and try and come month after month to support the neighborhood but always disappoints. If it's not undercooked food, it's bad flavor or lack of flavor. If it's not that, the bartenders are missing in action. Great place to drink. Brunch isn't terrible. But dinner is not worth it. Keep your money and go to Union St or Chestnut st. Hopefully they will find a new owner soon. Amazing location and restaurant. Terrible food.
author: Steph D.

description:
Awful business practices! Presidio Social Club ruined my new purse and my iPhone, inconvenienced me for a month, and did not reimburse me for the damage to my belongings! Sorry for the length, but customers need to know the risk of going to this restaurant. 

Went to the restaurant for Brunch on a Saturday morning and our waitress spilled several Bloody Marys and Mimosas onto me and into/all over my 1-week-old purse that was hung appropriately on my chair. The waitress proceeded to take my purse to "clean" it while I went to the restroom to wash sticky mess off my sweater, pants, and even the inside of my shoes. When the waitress returned with my purse, she had failed to "clean" off much of anything, AND failed to notice at least an inch of alcoholic puddle in the bottom of my purse, that my iPhone was completely submerged in. While I sopped up the large amount of liquid inside my purse with napkins myself, my husband attempted to dry off my iPhone, hoping to save it from damage. 

The manager, Simon, gave me his card and offered to reimburse me for the cleaning of my bag. Our meal was NOT even partially paid for by the restaurant. Very quickly after leaving the restaurant we realized that my iPhone's touch screen was permanently damaged and the purse had been soaked through to the outside bottom of the bag.  We called the restaurant to immediately alert them that my phone was also damaged in this incident.

We are very reasonable people, and we tried to be as polite and as positive about this situation as possible, understanding that accidents happen. We even tried to reassure the waitress that it was okay, so she didn't continue to feel terrible for soaking me. 
At this point, even despite not offering to comp our meal, this situation could have been handled with integrity and there would have been no problem. 

Instead, the manager had us return to the restaurant and took both my phone and my purse to take care of the cleaning and fixing himself (under the guise of trying to save us the hassle). At my own expense, I got a temporary phone from my cellular provider. Long story short, it took him almost 2 weeks to get my phone replaced and another several days to get my purse "cleaned". However, when I went to pick up my purse, the manager gave it to me to inspect in the poor lighting of the restaurant. Before I was able to even examine it visually, I noticed that it still smelled like rotting tomato juice and a bar. I told him that the smell was still lingering and the manager argued with me, saying he didn't think it smelled at all and that he took it to a "reputable" cleaner.
Considering how substantially the purse was soaked through, I was not surprised that it would be difficult to clean, so I requested that the manager either replace the bag or get it cleaned again. The manager then started to be very rude to me and told me that he would look into it and get back to me.

After over another week went by, I received a voicemail from the manager that my bag was ready to be picked up, no other information. My husband and I went in to pick up my bag and found that the manager had NOT tried to get it cleaned again, had sprayed the inside of my bag with Febreeze without consulting me and was "unable to consider replacement". Since we were VERY tired of this situation, I could now only smell Febreeze on my bag, and the bag seemed to look OK in the dark of the restaurant, we took the bag and went to leave the restaurant. Upon getting outside the into the light, I could see that the inside of my bag was still caked with Bloody Mary film and still had stains on both the outside and inside of the bag (clearly barely cleaned if at all?) My husband went back in to demand replacement or reimbursement of my bag from manager, to which he replied "There was nothing else he could do" and would only give my husband the name and contact information of the owner after my husband threatened legal action. We have no intention of suing (lucky for them I don't have expensive purse taste), but I am frankly shocked at this horrible customer treatment over less than the cost of our group's brunch.
I hate to think what might happen if someone is injured there, considering how unprofessionally and rudely they handled damaging my property.

Give them your business at your own risk!
author: Kelley B.

description: Love the patio when weather is perfect like today. Friendly, easy atmosphere. Full house which is a good sign. Love the Latin specials on Tuesday and the all American basics.  Fun and good!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
Hello Chef/Owner Ray Tang.  How can you serve me a "whole fish" without the head and tail?  Really?  And you're Chinese?  I am Chinese, but even for the American diner I think they would expect a full whole fish if it is called a whole fish.  This is San Francisco, if you're afraid of a head on a fish, you better move out to the Midwest where you probably see more filets and fish steaks.  So pissed...

It started off bad when I booked on their website for opentable and couldn't add a note.  I called in to request for our table to be closer to the tv for the world series.  I was on hold for a while and finally explained to the gentleman on the phone for 5 minutes and then he asks me to wait for the hostess to add the note on my reservation???  I thought he was the host?  Now I had to explain again my story to the hostess.  And she said it is not guaranteed blah blah...Anyway we got a table near the tv but often many people were standing in front of it because it was sort of a waiting area.  That sucked.  We continued to watch on the small tv at the bar.  We didn't know why 7x7 magazine would put PSC on the map as a good place to watch the world series and have dinner.  Watching and eating were both bad to do here.

The food was super mediocre.  I remember coming here for just drinks and apps once and that was ok.  Price was quite high for items that didn't have one stand out.  Really upset about that.  Chicken pot pie had a filo dough cut out on top, very lazy for $19.  Can't you just make a nice pot pie dough?  I don't think its too much trouble and it can be kept in the freezer and then fridge to prep a day before.  Filo is like store bought, I don't think you can make filo yourself, super difficult and too delicate.  Meatloaf was too tight and flavors were weird to me.  Pork belly was very tender but boring flavors, nice parsnip puree.  Deviled eggs with a very small dollop of caviar was bland and not worth 20 bucks.  Smoked trout ok.  Smoked oysters just ok and had two little ass pieces of bread.  Farro for the wife, I didn't try it but she said she liked it and I've made it before and not something I would eat often.  Did the mac and cheese have some blue cheese?  It was a bit bitter and I had better.  And of course, last and only the best for last (pun intended), the "whole fish" which was a sole without head and tail.  It looked pathetic, garnish of box tomatoes were everywhere, the grilled half lemon looked dirty and the plate was so wet.  Should of let the fish rest more before plating.  

Service was whack too and hella slow.  

You have some what looks to be delicious food, like on Sundays you have whole roast pig.  That sounds good and I would love it but are you sure you can execute?  Don't tell me the pig doesn't have a head or tail.  If Chef Chris Cosentino said he had whole roasted pig on his special, I would trust him 100% to be freaking awesome, but Chef Ray Tang...I don't know man...

As my good friends know, I only treat dinners when they're super fantastic and I'm WOWed!    Thanks Derrick for dinner and being a great sport.  Sorry I chosed PSC for the 4th game of the World Series and we ended up going home to finish the game because 7x7 was totally wrong about a good place to watch the game.  But GO GIANTS!
author: Kevin L.

description:
My mom and I came here on Mother's day and had a great experience. I had a really hard time finding somewhere to go in SF on Mother's day because most places make you do an overly expensive, prefixe brunch. I loved that they had their regular menu along with several specials.

Really weird reservation experience though...Open table said they were full, but I called them up and they told me to call back Saturday to see if there were any openings after they confirmed reservations. I got really lucky and was able to make a reservation for 2 the day before, but it was so bizarre! When we came in at 12:30, half the restaurant was empty and there was no host at the stand. They were probably saving the tables for later seatings at 1/1:30, but you can turn a table in an hour. They need new hostesses.

We started with the gruyere cheese toasts and YUM! I was very happy that we did, especially considering we needed food ASAP after starting on our delicious cocktails and not eating all morning. We loved the cheese toasts and ate them all in roughly a minute. I had the El Presidio scramble with the PSC bellini cocktail. My scramble was huge and had a lot of peas and ricotta cheese in it, which I really enjoyed. My mom had some special purple cocktail and the hamburger. Her meal was very large and she loved every bite. 

Our waitress was very attentive and the food came out pretty fast. The ambiance in the restaurant is light, airy, and modern and great for small parties or large groups. Next time I want to have dinner here and sit at the counter.
author: Alisha K.

description:
Let me start out with the positive-the food was good. I had the meatloaf. 

We were a party of six on a Wednesday. We were sat right away with a nice table by a friendly host. After that, the service went down hill dramatically.  It took 35 minutes to get drinks on the table and that's after sitting there for 10 minutes before she took our drink order. There was never a "Hello. My name is xxxx. Tonight our specials are..."  The first guy at the table ordered a beer and she started walking away to get it. I quickly called her back because the other 5 people at the table also wanted to order drinks. In terms of the food, my wife ordered the trout filet and it came as a whole fish with the head and tail. The waitress took it back only to return in two minutes with the head and tail cut off and now called it a "filet".  There was never a chance to order a 2nd round of drinks because she would never return to the table.  The whole dinner took three hours only because it took our server 5x longer that it should to do anything.   She was friendly, but absolutely clueless 
When the six of us got outside, my friend turned to the group and said: "Was it me or was that the worst service ever?"  Since we were 3 separate couples, no one wanted to make an issue of it at dinner not knowing what the other couples were thinking.  It was unanimous that we felt the waitress needs to get re-trained or let go immediately. 
We won't be back anytime soon.
author: Michael R.

description: This place deserves more than 3.5 stars, if only for the fact that they serve foie gras in the middle of this lovely nanny-state of California. But the rest of the food, and the atmosphere, was great too.
author: Tom R.

description: Really liked this place, classic cocktails, really good food, beautiful setting. Different and fun!
author: Peter H.

description: Great food but service is limited! Poor waiter had like 8 tables!!! And it isn't inexpensive...
author: Suki M.

description: I made a last minute reservation here the other evening for myself and a dear friend. We were welcomed warmly and sat at a perfect two-top towards the back. I swear, with a little blur of your eyes, you could picture yourself in an old black and white in Singapore. The long bar was filled with beautiful people drinking sexy cocktails. The big fans overhead kept us perfectly comfortable and even the bathrooms with their intricately tiled floors had old school music that made you want to wash your hands a little longer. We ordered a fresh salad and a pork pasta to share. We tried a couple of cocktails and they had a delicious house white. We went with the chocolate cake dessert and were completely satisfied. We had to ask for water a couple of times, but that seems to be pretty standard in SF these days. I recommend this place for any special evening, from a date, to dinner with the folks.
author: Jasmine W.

description:
Love the ambiance - we sat outdoors in the patio - it was a nice day.. The brunch here is delish! 

Mac & cheese - soo good!
I had the mission chillaquiles with pork belly - I really enjoyed it! 

While I don't spend a ton of time on this side of SF - I'll make the drive for brunch here.
author: Monica S.

description:
I never heard about this restaurant. The only reason I went was because my friend and a coupon from restaurant.com

We came for Sunday Brunch. We felt a little out of place because everyone else eating here were all older, golfers, part of the club. Regardless, we were seated right away.

Our waiter was exceptional. He looked genuinely happy and willing to serve us. He checked up on us twice during our meal and make sure we had everything we needed. 

I ordered the eggs benedict. The eggs and the sauce was cooked perfectly. 
 
Overall, the food was delicious and I enjoyed my experience. 

I'd love to come back again and try their dinner menu!
author: Jessica Y.

description:
Despite working across the street, I always forget that this place is here, and that's a shame.  Came here for lunch today and had a phenomenal burger topped with a great bacon-onion sauté.  My dining companions had the meatloaf sandwich lunch special, and they both raved about it (and by the looks of it I can't blame them).  They're a bit overpriced, but then that goes with the territory in this part of town.  The only real competition within a few blocks is Liverpool Lil's, who serves inferior food at the same price point.  

I'll say that despite being provided a free lunch by my company each day at the LDAC dining commons, the burger I had today at the PSC was good enough to justify walking across the street and spending my own money.  When your food is worth passing up a free lunch for, you're doing something right.
author: Joshua W.

description: Sunday brunch at this old barracks in the presidio was awesome. The lamb sausage was excellent and a patio for the dog was a surprise plus. Would definitely make this a habit if I lived in San Fran.
author: Don W.

description:
This is quite possibly my favorite spot in San Francisco. Really. It's mostly about the atmosphere - big, airy, spacious and gracious. They have an outdoor area, too. 
The sleek and classy marble bar extends the full length of the restaurant and is open seating for anyone to drink and/or dine. 
Pretty much all of the food is delicious, but I love going for oysters and rose (they have a great Provence option, light salmony-pink). The bartenders are friendly and efficient and know how to make real classic cocktails. 
Menu highlights: artichoke, burger, fish special, Mac and cheese (I know I'm missing something. Really it's all yummy).
Overall it's great for dinner, brunch, date, friends, family, or even alone. A+
author: Natasha T.

description: Surprisingly good food and service for such a weird spot - nondescript building in the middle of a park. Uber driver had trouble finding it even with gps. Got last minute reservations on a Saturday with no problem and walked to the palace of the fine arts and marina district after. I'd go back, but only if I was  going to stay in the area.
author: Matt C.

description: We love to go here on the weekends. Place has great food, good servers, clean bathroom, and super cute inside.
author: Elisa L.

description:
Went on a Saturday for brunch and brought along out of town guests so a lot of faith was placed in the PSC being our first time there as well.  I usually bring guests somewhere I have been and vetted out at least once.  When we arrived our table was ready (inside by the window) but they first let us choose inside or outside which to me is bonus points bc any place with outdoor seating usually protects it for reservations only.  

Our waiter was good and attentive, tripped over the specials slightly but overall did well.  We asked for his opinion on a few of the pastries and he highly recommended the cinnamon roll, which was incredible!  He also let us know it was large enough to share, which was great bc none of us could eat one alone and still eat a main after that. I had read online their pastry chef is great so I had to get one pastry to try... It did not disappoint.  Thick, moist, just the right mix of spice and frosting... Delicious.  I have read the scones are also great, so I'll try those next time. 

I can't recall what everyone had for mains, but I had the chilequeles which were good not great... The green sauce was perfect but the eggs were a little spongy.  One of our guests had the French toast which I tried some of and they were great.  It's obvious that the pastries and sweet mains are their best offering.  The other friends each got something with eggs and I don't remember them being overly impressed, but they seemed to be satisfied.  

The PSC is close by our apartment so I am glad it was good, we look forward to going back soon.  We had also not eaten in any of the old military barracks, so we also enjoyed that aspect.
author: Brad W.

description: Neat setting and location, nice wine selection. Interiors partly chic, partly dated. Service was good. Food disappointing.
author: Natasha W.

description:
Went here with a group of friends recently - VERY IMPRESSED!  

I started out with a drink - a Ruger Mule but quickly switched it up for the rest of dinner with their EXCELLENT Pain Killer!  Food wise we were all very happy - two of my friends had the Classic Meatloaf special and loved it!  Two of us ordered the Mac & Cheese (with bacon added of course) and I ate one bowl all by myself as an appetizer!  AWESOME!  A friend ordered the Herb Roasted Half Chicken and said that it was to die for!  Another friend ordered the Chef's Grilled Club Steak and was both impressed by how good it was and by how much food was on the plate!  I personally ordered the PSC Hamburger with added bacon and blue cheese - it could not have been cooked any more perfect - very good!  For dessert we chose a variety of items off the menu (Salted Caramel Ice Cream Sandwich, Mocha Crunch Torte & PSC Cookie Plate) - all of which we shared and they were very good!  

NOTE - get a reservation - it gets busy here!

We all left full and satisfied - great service and great atmosphere!  Will be back again!
author: Cris R.

description:
Got together with some old co workers on a nice wonderful Sunday. The weather is nice a cool outside.

The hostess was friendly and we were seated in a very fast fashion. 
I ordered a Veggie Sandwich, and it was one of the best ever. The only down side is the bread was so crispy that it made you want to be careful biting into it as it may just poke a hole in your mouth if you are not careful. I love the sandwich, and the salad that came with it was delicious and fresh looking. 

Waiter was very friendly and courteous, and the place is very clean.
author: Yo L.

description:
I really, really want to love this place. It is one of the best settings in the city at the Marina gate in the Presidio. The inside looks terrific and even if you come just for a cocktail, I can't recommend it enough. 

The food, well, needs work. I have bene here several times. A while ago, it was terrific. Recently, I have had guests sent food back on two separate occasions. Since I rave about this place, this was highly embarrassing. 

I remain hopeful that they will get this together in the kitchen. Until then, I won't take important guests there.
author: Bob R.

description: A pretty good spot for brunch. Major pros are the parking and the fact that the patio is dog friendly. The menu skews a bit more towards lunch, but they do have a few breakfast options which are very good. Helpful staff, but overall wasn't blown away. Definitely want to try to go back for dinner though.
author: David D.

description:
Came to the Presidio Social Club for brunch this weekend.  Great little spot.  Parking is a major plus!   No kids changing table in bathrooms, but overall, a kid friendly place.

I had the seasonal veggie scramble.  Wish it had a bit more veggies, and a bit less egg, but it was delicious and the ricotta and squash blossom topping was divine.  

Service was great! 

I would definitely recommend!
author: Katie C.

description:
Good spot, but the menu has been shrinking continuously since they first opened.  Although the food is good, the menu is simply lacking in breadth or dept.  It is neither populated with basics such that everyone can find a meal, nor is it filled with items which are particularly interesting such that you'd be willing to regularly chance it with something unique.  The selection of main courses is often small enough that I'll go for dinner and simply find nothing that interests me, and end up ordering appetizers.  Previously, it was much more robust and interesting selection.  (Perhaps they were getting bogged down and decided to streamline the kitchen so as to be able to churn the tables.) 

Their bar, however, is excellent, and so are the desserts, making this a good choice for someplace after dinner.  The lemon meringue cake is especially good if you are in the mood for something sweet, and goes well with a sidecar. 

WORD OF WARNING: CALL BEFORE YOU GO OUT THERE.  It is kind of out of the way, and we've trekked out there for drinks only to find it closed for a private event on a Saturday night.  Luckily, there is another bar/restaurant right outside the Presidio gate, but if you are making a special trip and don't have a reservation, be sure to call first or just go elsewhere.
author: Robert F.

description: Lovely atmosphere and the food is really good, there's something on the menu for everyone. The only thing I didn't like much is how dark the restrooms are... I needed my flashlight on my phone just to reapply my lipstick after eating in the middle of the day! That's the one thing I'd suggest they fix, it was kinda silly. Overall we had a really nice time, it's a great spot for celebrations.
author: Emilie M.

description:
I'm here to tell you about a little resurrection.

PSC started out strong, but over the years became kind of tired.  Which was a shame because with its great location, it should have already been a modern classic.  It's not every day you get to sit at a long bar, looking around at what used to be a military barracks, surrounded by the lush greenery of the Presidio. A couple years in business is not enough time to create laurels, let alone rest on them.

But everyone is entitled to a new beginning, and PSC is making some changes to revive what was had become a bland, overpriced experience.

Last night my friend Michael L. and I enjoyed a late-night meal at the bar - simple fare, a burger and the fried chicken salad.  Oh yes, and the lobster bisque.  The burger was excellent - simple, well cooked, not too much bun, and with the caramelized onion/bacon topping - it was pretty near perfect.  With that, we had some truly excellent cocktails (me, Pink Lemonade; him, Manhattan) followed by some beer.  An enjoyable time all around.  

We had one critique of the food, which was that the cabbage pieces were too big to comfortably fit on our forks - we wanted more chop in the chopped salad.  We voiced this and were acknowledged and heard - hurrah.  We also got to learn of the upcoming improvements that will be made by the new management - basically, to make your experience better and more satisfying.

This is a reminder for all of you out there in Yelp Land - if you are not happy with something, say so.  Don't just smile at your server and say everything was fine, and then go home and slam the place in your review.  By speaking up, you give them the chance to correct it on the spot, or offer you something more to your liking.   If they are a decent place, they will want to ensure that you walk away happy.

I'll be back soon enough to see how things are going.  Let it be noted that they are making these changes even though the restaurant was pretty much full on a Wednesday night - so while they don't appear to be hurting for business, someone there knows that it could be much better.  Smart thinking.
author: Liz S.

description:
We had our wedding reception at the Presidio Social Club in August.  I have to say that the day of  food, service, etc was outstanding...the chef did an amazing job with the menu execution and all of the servers were so accommodating to the guests and whatever we needed.  The venue was perfect for pulling off the modern vintage style we wanted and it had a laid - back party vibe - people had so much fun!  

We did some bring things like candles, photo booth props, banners, etc that the staff put up and they followed our instructions/made everything look great.  PSC was open to working with us to determine the pros/cons of different options based on our budget.    

I won't lie it wasn't always the easiest to get answers to my questions, but i've heard this is challenging with many vendors during the wedding experience.  Overall, I would highly recommend PSC.
author: Christina W.

description:
I have not eaten here,. but attempted twice!

Saw on the news that they are still currently serving foie gras.  Last week I came with a foodie from SJ and wanted to try the foie gras sliders that I have been reading about. Came here around 2-3pm and they didn't serve it until 4:30pm. So we "GOT UP AND LEFT", they were practically out of everything from the brunch menu since it was so late,.. but I did make a reservation for tonight,. 7 people, 6pm and confirmed that my party and I were coming just for the foie gras. 

PSC called to confirm my reservation today at 3pm. I DOUBLE TRIPLED CHECKED with them and told them that I am only coming here for foie gras. They said yes and is aware. We sat down and asked about the "secret menu" and if they had FOIE GRAS. The waiter says,.. 

"SORRY WE ARE actually OUT OF FOIE GRAS" 

Disappointing much! When a party specifically makes reservations, states the main purpose for dining at PSC, PSC should be prepared to have the item.  A simple courtesy call to let me know that it is out of stock; would have been nice. My party of 7, "GOT UP AND LEFT AGAIN", what a waste of time and gas. 

Failed twice,. I guess I won't be having any foie gras anytime soon and def will not make a trip out to PSC any more.
author: Chanel L.

description: Wine selection is limited. Waited for an eternity for a well done burger that came pink with cold fries. The only positive is that there is parking & seating at the bar.
author: Candy S.

description:
I've been to PSC twice and have enjoyed myself.  I love the setting and beautiful bar area.  It's one part each old school, class, and sophistication. Topped off with great service, quality dishes, and fun cocktails, all the makings for a fun night out! 

The menu, although arguably limited, has a decent variety, the meatloaf, mac and cheese, and chicken are all great.  Would happily dine at PSC again (and again!)
author: Brianna M.

description:
Went with a group of four, and all were very happy with the food and service. More focused than Pres a Vi (now closed ... which was in the Presidio as well) , and with a sustainable ( in the business sense) mix of food/drink/environment/service. Yes, as some reviews reflect, it is not a place for the 22 year old hipster dude looking for a babe.... nope. Also the food pricing for those folk is not in their realm, unless they work for Google. 

Food is solid,  well prepared, creative but not crazy.

Service is stellar.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
Very middle of the road type place. I wouldn't steer anyone away from coming here if they were considering it but I would not recommend it as a place that they should go. On the positive side, the restaurant itself and the location is nice. The cocktail menu had some winners on it too.

The food was pretty good but there was nothing that I tried that was really memorable. The menu has a descent selection of land and sea and is not crazy expensive, but also not cheap (think $60-80 for dinner for two with a drink each and a shared app).

I won't be rushing to come here again but if I was in a group that wanted to go here I wouldn't put up a fight.
author: Frank J.

description:
Great place to enjoy lunch, dinner or weekend brunch.  They take reservations which unlike most of SF is a godsend knowing you don't have to hurry up and wait for sunday brunch.  I have eaten more brunches here than lunch or dinner but I am always greeted with excellent customer service, good tasting food and EXCELLENT coffee.  I don't know what kind of coffee they serve here, but it is by far my favorite coffee in SF.  They have many options for different foods and everything has always arrived hot and well prepared.

Then only knock I have is one time when I was eating a late lunch, I saw one of the workers refilling a grey goose bottle with a funnel.  I am not with ABC but refilling alcohol bottles seems like something that is probably not allowed, especially when you can easily purchase cheaper vodka and mix it in and the customer probably wouldn't ever know.  Not something I would expect from an expensive restaurant.
author: Eli Z.

description:
I agree with the review below

"Dear Chef Ray Tang,
Please go back to culinary school. 
P.S. - Thanks for giving my friend food poisoning."

The food was mediocre and the service was average.  One of the members of our party got sick later in the evening.

This place use to be a above average place to eat, the atomoshpere is fun, but in recent years the service has been far from good and the menu items preparation and presentation has fallen far below average. There are so many other better options in San Francisco.
author: Mark D.

description:
4 starts might be a stretch here but I will be kind since we live close by and I like the ambiance here. It seemed like a bit of an older crowd even though we were eating later on a Saturday night but it was relaxing and I enjoyed having a cocktail at tthe long marble bar before our reservation. The older building and the ambiance takes you back a few decades but I thought it was fun and something different.

The food was good but nothing to rave about. Simple, hearty dishes seemed to be the winners of the meal. The meatloaf, burger, and ny strip were all good, and very reasonable in price which should be taken into account.  Side dishes of veggies and the macaroni were also surprisingly tasty. We had the toasted cheese with tomato soup for an app and that was really good as well, although we were hoping for a bit more because the serving is fairly small. Except for the appetizer the portions were all fairly generous and we left full. We passed on dessert as nothing tempted us.

Not sure why all the remarks about poor service, our service was perfectly fine. Overall a fun relaxing experience, I really liked the ambiance of this place around the holidays. We'll be back because of the convenience and reasonable food, stick to the comfort food if you come here.
author: Kate N.

description: We just celebrated a birthday there.  The lunch was delicious and our server could not have been nicer.  It was our first time and the waiter made great suggestions about what to order.  The Vietnamese sandwich was incredible as was the lemon meringue cake.  We'll definitely go back.
author: Melody B.

description: We have been fans PSC fora long time.  Tonight was the best.  They have a fantastic bar and while I would recommend reservations we always try to ditch our resi for two seats at the bar.  Tonight we had the oysters which were amazing.  Deviled eggs with caviar which were so interesting.  I highly re come do them and go ahead and splurge for the caviar on them.  You won't regret it.  We also had the poke and share the veal picatta to finish it off.  Love the bartenders and hats off to the chef!
author: Britt R.

description: This is a great place to go for a special occasion. I highly recommend the beef liver & onions & the meatloaf. Recently I had two of the "speciality" cocktails. Both were Gin based and really good!
author: Celeste D.

description:
Classy . Comforting . Cool . San Francisco Old School . 

Hidden in the Presidio National Park is a long, rectangular wood-framed building erected in 1903 as enlisted men's barracks. This space has  been tastefully renovated to house the Presidio Social Club, a restaurant specializing in classic American comfort cuisine. 

Step inside and you'll be transported to an entirely different space and time. The open room is cleanly decorated with simple colors and retro decor. Large wooden tables look out onto the green Presidio park scene from wide wall sized windows.  A long white marble bar with leather stools and adjacent palm trees provides the ultimate old California flair. 

The menu carries on the mid-century theme in its design and features simple brunch and dinner fare of classic American comfort food. We started our experience off by sampling some of the specialty house cocktails carefully created by the bar. The Presidio Pink Lemonade ($11 Meyer Lemon Vodka, Limoncello, tinted with campari), the 100 Reasons Rye ($ 8 Manhattan Variation w/ Triple Sec ), and the Sidecar ($8 Classic brandy drink from the 1920's) were delicious and a welcome beginning to our meal.

The menu offers only a few options of comforting American Classics (about 13 main courses ranging from $15 to $22). Side dishes, salads, and appetizers are also available. We began our meal with the Island Style Tuna Poke ($11 with Housemade Kennebec Chips ), the Grilled Artichoke ( $7 with Blue Cheese and butter), and the white bean specialty soup of the day ($3). Perfectly proportioned, savory, and satisfying.

Our choice main dishes included the Fried Chicken with  Smashed Red Potatoes ($19), an orange glazed Pork Shoulder with Cannelli beans ($19), the PFC Meatloaf  with Sour Cream & Chive Potatoes ($18), and the chef's specialty pasta with pork sauce ($15). Portions were generous and service was fabulous. 

Presidio Social Club is the perfect pick for a family dinner, a lively brunch, or an old school cocktail date. It's unique atmosphere, attentive service, and comforting classics make it well worth a visit. Go, let the jazz music play, sip a cocktail, savor a meal, and enjoy the feeling of being in a mid-century private club.
author: Caroline J.

description:
This place is all over the map. Nice location, awesome historic building, inconsistent service, overpriced food. 

This is a good location for a party of two sitting outside on the deck with an umbrella and all the time in the world.

This is not a good choice for a large party that includes children. Similar to Thanksgiving dinner in grandma's double-wide, chairs are jammed together and require those unfortunate enough to be sitting in the middle to hurdle the seats. 

Service was painfully slow. The drinks were ordered after a substantial wait. The drinks were received after an even longer wait. More than once a member of our party (someone lucky enough to be sitting on the ends and have mobility) would have to go in search of our servers. Diners shouldn't have to do that, especially at these prices.

Overall, the quality of the food was good. Just don't come here if you're starving. The portions are small, almost dainty. Room temperature water is served in old bottles and poured into juice glasses. Wow, water shots.

For a restaurant described as 'classy', order some more damn umbrellas! Don't tell me you can't afford them. Patrons were left to fend for themselves to acquire some shade in the blazing sun. The umbrellas were moving  faster than the wait staff. 

Just another pretentious, hipster hotspot in the city with the attitude to back it up. Got some extra income? Buy this place an umbrella. Eat someplace else.
author: Bada B.

description:
had to go here for a work dinner. assumed it would be a bread & lettuce situation, but they actually have a few vegan items on the menu. had the kale salad- YUM. farro & mushroom stew was OK, although salt seemed to be the main spice.  no dessert for me, but that's no biggie. decent wine by the glass options.  

great service. lovely ambiance.

parking can be tricky.  also, kind of chilly inside.

a bit on the $$$ side, like most things in the Presidio. they know they have a captive audience.
author: Virginia D.

description: Atmosphere is this spots best selling point but the food is definitely worth mentioning as well.  Always get the PSC hamburger and have no complaints.  Service is good.  I like the buildings architecture outside and inside.  Also, location in the Presidio is convenient certainly if you live in Marin County and are coming over the bridge.  Will go back.
author: Kade L.

description: Went here for dinner in mid-December and absolutely loved the ambiance and service.  Food was good, but not as fantastic as the location.  Parking was a bit tricky as well, but worth the hassle.  I'd say this is a "business casual" restaurant that's a bit on the pricey side.  Good for groups though, especially the round tables.
author: Rick B.

description:
TAke a colleague to lunch and be hungry!! On my second visit to the PSC I took a colleague, the only saving grace was that we ended up laughing about the paltry amount of food and our wish to grab some other diner's burger.

The Dungeness Crab and citrus salad($ 16.50 (right up there with the highest pried main courses) is served in a bowl. No less than a child's hand full  of  baby frisé a couple of tangerene and beet slices and no more than an oz.   of crab.  

The service was good, the restaurant is charming, but someone is watching the pennies way to carefully in the kitchen, and it bespeaks a lack of concern about the customers.
author: maria B.

description:
We came here for brunch with some friends on a bright Saturday morning. The reservation was easy to make, parking was on the premises and smooth, and we were promptly seated --already leaps and bounds better than most weekend brunch experiences in the city! We got an order of brioche beignets with brown sugar hot chocolate for the table-- very tasty. The wife and I are both vegetarian, and we split the macaroni and cheese and the seasonal quiche. Both were excellent. The quiche had broccoli and fontina and had a perfectly baked crust-- it was not too creamy/runny as sometimes a towering quiche can be. The mac and cheese really hit the spot-- it was flavorful and had subtle heat.

Overall, we enjoyed our meal. It seems like this is a great place for larger groups (given space and the fact they they take reservations) and we would recommend it. Afterward, we did a little urban hiking in the Presidio from Inspiration Point.
author: T K.

description: I loved this place the two times I've eaten there. I have family and friends in the Bay Area and have made this a stop on my biennial visits here. I'll be heading back this fall and will definitely go here! The location is great and I've had good experience with service. I've only done dinner but I've heard breakfast is also very good.
author: Saul M.

description:
We came up here for one reason and one reason only - their special Bastille Day slider ( now sadly off the menu again ).  It was delicious.

Parking was easy and convenient out in front.

The place is a lot more modern and trendy than I would have expected, and they are actually doing some nice things here.  Small but well-curated selection of beer on tap as well as some well-made cocktails at the bar, where the service was friendly and prompt.
author: Albert H.

description:
According to the myriad negative reviews, maybe Presidio Social Club should stop serving foie gras that makes people sick (physically and morally).  I personally couldn't care less.  I hate foie gras.  What this place shouldn't stop serving, though, is bacon cheeseburgers.  I've had plenty and theirs is one of the very best.  I can't recall ever having eaten more perfectly seasoned ground beef.  I also can't recall a better marriage of bacon and cheese on any burger.  I loved the bun consistency and the patty was prepared a picture-perfect medium-well.

The fries were also excellent, but I doubt anyone is paying attention to fries with a burger that dynamic.

Other pluses:
The location can't be beat and the outdoor seating is paradise on a warm San Francisco afternoon.  They gave our dog water without us asking, and our server was friendly and attentive.  Oh, and he was also hot.

So take a pass on the fatty duck liver paste and dive into a burger from PSC.  You'll save your stomach (and perhaps your conscience) from hell and treat your taste buds to heaven.
author: Brendan S.

description:
Great location, but parking can be annoying depending on the time of day that you're there. We made a reservation online an hour before showing up. When we got there, the restaurant was fairly empty with the exception of a group of 8 and a few bar patrons. Despite all the empty tables, the hostess thought it was necessary to say, "I guess we can fit you in towards the center."

The food was above average, but maybe not great. We read on Yelp that the restaurant still serves Foie Gras (since they're on federal land), despite it not being on the menu. The server tried to make it a big deal by saying, "We only serve 5 per day and you're ordering the last one." Seeing how this was the start of dinner service, I highly doubted that. The serving was small, but delicious.

Their menu items are typical home meals that are spruced up (ie. mac and cheese, meatloaf). Their dessert spread was intriguing. They had strawberry shortcake (yum!), a cookie platter and a bread pudding type thing that looked great. Price is a tad high for what it is, but probably expected for any clean SF restaurant.
author: Mae M.

description: I ordered the meatloaf and it was amazing!!! Large portion too. also had a salted caramel ice cream sandwich and it was amazing as well. I'm taking one star off because they screwed up our burger orders, bad service.
author: Katelyn N.

description:
Setting, ambience and service great.  The food not so much.

Had brunch there this morning.  I had the "chef's fire roasted special" which was brisket and prime rib hash. The ratio of potatoes to meat was about 5:1, and the meat that there was? Very fatty, which made the whole dish a tad greasy. And it was $18!  My wife had the huevos dish that she thought had almost no egg, but lots of tortilla strips.  The coffee was cold.   

But the service was great and the setting is terrific. Just don't expect too much in the food department.  Probably won't return. At least not for brunch.
author: David W.

description:
I LOVE FOIE GRAS and I am so happy that PSC has found the loophole and we can enjoy it each and every time we go.

We went over the weekend and it was hopping with people eating delicious, fattened liver!!!!

Way to go, PSC.  We will see you next week.
author: James S.

description:
My sis said making the reservation was a bit on the icky side....

Our folks were in town...the husbands were busy, just our folks with us (3 grown girls) and my little girl...

They were not busy...but there's that air of "we are very sought after..."

We had lunch...it was delicious....the service was a little spotty....but the dessert!!!!!
Ok, let's say that I am NOT usually a dessert person...their brioche beignets with hot Mexican cocoa was AMAZING!!!

The 4 stars are for that.....
author: Barb L.

description:
We went to this place after half day of community service of manual labor. It meets all the standards of American restaurant like clean table, great service, and delicious food. The mac and cheese from Appetizer's menu was especially good. 

Nice place to hang out!
author: Jun W.

description:
Presidio Social Club is a decent place for decent food. Price is a little on the high side for what you get, but the view and the ambiance makes up for it. 

The burger with all the toppings set me back about $15.00 but it was cooked to perfection. The Gruyere cheese, onions, and bacon bits tasted absolutely marvelous together. 

The pot roast sandwiched looked a bit greasy but I heard it was delicious. Who doesn't like a little grease?

Overall, good place for first dates, possibly seconds. 

Prepare to pay a pretty penny, especially if you are ordering cocktails and drinks.
author: Scott L.

description:
I've been here 3 or 4 times now. Not sure I'll be going back.

Drinks and food are decent. Price tag is pretty steep for "decent." Save your hard earned cash and head elsewhere.
author: Yum N.

description:
I'd have all but written off PSC, if not for my running buddy who adores the place.  Much relieved to discover that brunch has quite improved since my last visit.

The space is as gorgeous and relaxed as ever.  And they're excellent at accommodating large groups as well as children.  

The brunch menu is limited (no pancakes), but everything I tasted was really good:  chicken and sun dried tomato frittata, challah french toast with bananas, and a side of breakfast potatoes that they brought out for free.   No more complaints about portion size and $10 for each dish was reasonable.  

$12 bottomless mimosas on Saturdays.

Service still needs some help:  the waitstaff filled up our waters and coffee every ten minutes, yet it took forever and a day for our food to arrive.  Brunch took two hours- don't come here if in a hurry.

Oh, and the oxtail hash is no longer on the menu.  Huzzah!
author: Joanne G.

description:
It was time for a girls' night. And in an effort to try somewhere cute, fun, and fresh, we made a reservation at Presidio Social Club. Wore a dress, put on heels, and even smacked on some lip gloss.  Pulling up from the outside, all you see are lights twinkling and faces smiling - very charming. 

Unfortunately, despite arriving 5 minutes before our reservation, we still had to wait an additional 20 minutes before being seated.  As the hostess showed us to our table (located within smelling distance of the back restroom), I couldn't help but admire the many empty tables lining our path... 

Once seated service was relatively prompt, but I was disappointed to hear that my favorite dish had been switched to the lunch menu and could not be made at dinner time. Bummer. There were a few other memorable moments, including soup brought without a spoon, a loud table of drunken men to our right, and Sprite instead of sparkling water.  The food was mediocre.  I get that they're going for the southern, 60s vibe, but even adding just one dish not covered in gravy to the menu would have been awesome. It's San Francisco and dousing my $30 fish with a can of cream of mushroom was probably not necessary. 

So it wasn't the perfect experience, but despite the gravy, the atmosphere was light and my company was fun. I may try again,... but probably not.
author: Zoey S.

description:
Just got home from dinner.  The food and location are great.  But service was inconsistent and irritating.  The main courses came out in two waves with about a 10 minute delay.  We would have been OK but the same thing happened with desserts and most irritating was that the final dessert also came 10 minutes later than the rest of the table and the check was dropped at the same time.

The PSC is not "starred" territory but it's a nice restaurant and the prices are just high enough that service should be better.  Normally I would have tipped 20% but in this case I left less than 10%.  The waiter did not acknowledge the gaps and seemed far more interested in "turning the table."
author: Mark D.

description:
For Bastile Day - belated celebration, we went there last night with some friends who wanted to show there support for Foie Gras being served on Federal Land. The dishes are all very delicious and we especially enjoyed the Foie Gras. Thank you for continuing to serve our favorite dish. 

My husband and I split a rib eye steak for 2 that was perfectly prepared. It's highly recommended also.
author: Chris M.

description: A classy spot for an out of the way drink with someone special.  Especially if that someone special lives way the hell out by the Presidio.  Some of the finest bar tenders in the city.  The food looked amazing, but I was not in the mood for modern southern decadence that night.
author: Patrick S.

description:
I really just wasn't wowed.  The location and the atmosphere are really nice, but the food was only ok and the service also only ok.  We ordered everything at once because the server took a while to get to us and the way things were brought out was kind of weird- we got our starter first, then our entrees, then our drinks?  I was not a fan of that.

we ordered the beignets to start which were really good- you got 4 huge beignets with a delicious mexican hot chocolate dipping sauce.  for our brunch entrees, we got the gruyere toasts with tomato dip and the seasonal vegetable sandwich.  the toasts were good but nothing amazing and the vegetable sandwich was good, too, but overpriced for what it was.

I might come back here if others wanted to, but i just wasn't wowed.
author: Lisa C.

description:
The plusses:

1. Beautiful facility and location.
2. Great staff. Servers and bartenders friendly and professional.

The minuses:

1. Dish quality just okay. With the competition in SF that faint praise can be deadly. Ingredients are fresh, it's just that there is no imagination in the prep and presentation.
2. Somewhat overpriced for what you are getting

I have eaten here twice. Once with a buddie for a burger (good but not worth $16) at the bar, another time more formally at a table for dinner. No reason to go back a third time until there is a new chef.
author: E F.

description:
We had a fantastic experience for the Bastille Day special, which included FOIE GRAS!!  The foie gras was seared and prepared on a slider bun with a slice of pineapple.  The menu also included a two-person fillet of beef with frites (fries) and a bottle of wine.  

I applaud the restaurant for its daring decision to push the envelope and go for the interesting.
author: Informed C.

description: Food was subpar to say the least. Dry duck confit, disgusting tomatillo salsa, and a ridiculously overpriced, and over cooked burger. The service was even worse than the food with a wait staff that seemed incredibly confused, and disorganized not to mention a waitress who was rude, and forgot to put our food an drink order in, but beyond all of that the fact that the waitress had the nerve to charge us for bottled water when we asked for tap I just outrageous. This restaurant should focus on making better food and training their staff rather than penny pinching,and fooling their customers into buying things they didn't ask for.
author: Doug H.

description:
The ambiance and beauty of the surrounding area somehow is not reflected in the quality of dining experience at the Presidio Social Club.  We arrived on a Saturday evening about 6PM and found some parking in a nearby lot.  Our table was available for us as we were greeted by a charming hostess.  Our waiter was attentive and cordial.

The atmosphere was loud and one could barely hold a conversation without shouting. The thumping background music did not add to our dining experience.  We had a sturgeon dinner ($27.50),  tomales bay mussels ($14.00), market salad ($11.00), plain burger ($12) and 4 glasses of wine ranging from $8 to $9 glass.  

The mussels and sturgeon were good, though the sturgeon dish looked pretty skimpy for the price.  Since I wasn't very hungry, I ordered just a plain burger and the waiter promoted it as being a "super" burger.  It was nothing liked he described.  I've had better burgers at Burger King.

I would not come back here as it is not a good value.  Pricey and a loud atmosphere is not conducive to pleasant dining.
author: Robert J.

description:
What a great spot! From the gruyere toast to the chocolate sundae, our meal was superb!

The atmosphere of this place is great - cozy and modern with clean lines and a very bright, airy space. And the food was well worth it! everything was delicious. Our table started with the gruyere toast (basically adult grilled cheese with a tomato bisque dip) and then moved on to the entrées. The pork chop and salmon specials were perfection and the roasted chicken was a delight. I don't typically order desserts, but we had to try the fresh peach cobbler and the chocolate sundae. Both were the perfect conclusion to a great evening.

Enjoy!
author: Grady B.

description:
My sis dragged her whole entire family (meaning her hubby, son, nanny), their guest from London and me -- we all went to dinner here last Sunday.

She made reservations (though I didn't see a point why b/c it wasn't packed) but a res is always a good thing. 

Got seated....I noticed right away the old-school feel and ambiance of the place. I loved it. I felt like I was in the "Back to the Future"

My sis ordered me a drink, I think it was a pink lemonade or something like that, but it was GOOD. 

I had their sloppy joe's -- but it wasn't what I expected. It tasted different from what I used to eat in the school cafeteria! LOL. I know I shouldn't compare, b/c there is no comparison. 

Anyway, I forgot what the rest of the part had b/c they served Hanger One Vodka there -- so of course I had to get my Mandarin + OJ. After that, it was lights out. 

Overall, a really cool spot tucked in the Presidio. I might bring my girls here for drinks =)
author: Cath M.

description:
Yikes, I hope this was just an off-day but this place has seemed to really go downhill. I stopped in for brunch this weekend and went with the kobe beef sloppy joe, which turned out to be relatively bland (although the fries were crispy and decent). My friend ordered a pisco sour, which took over fifteen minutes to arrive, and overall service was pretty non-existent, even when I asked for the bill (much more than food of this quality should be, I'm afraid). 

I will say the manager, well he seemed to be one of the only people who really cared about our table. It's too bad, I really still love the location and environs... maybe I'll just stick to dinner here.
author: Nish N.

description:
Have come here twice now, once for a group dinner with the mom, and the other for Valentine's dinner with the husband. I must say their pork belly is one of the best in the city. Our group dinner was fantastic, and the dessert- apple fritters were heaven. Also, be sure to try the PSC treat- it's worth it ;)

The Valentine's dinner was a solid meal, but I thought the service was a little lacking, and I generally dislike V-Day dinners since they tend to be over priced. All in all, definitely worth it for a one off, but I wouldn't do it again next year.
author: Nina W.

description:
Beautiful space.  Decent food, for the most part. I expected much more in their service.  First, the hostesses - not the warm, convivial greeting you'd expect from such professionally dressed people ... and we're a very friendly bunch.  The kicker was how s-l-o-w the service was.  I'm talking glacial.  To be fair, we had a party of 11, but that's no reason to take 15 minutes to get our drink order and another 10 to deliver.  20 minutes later, our meal order was taken.   Months went by before our food came.  In the meantime, two of us got promoted, my friend had a baby, and I grew a Grizzly Adams beard while we waited for our food.  We had a reservation, but it didn't feel like they were expecting us. 

I had the sardines for an appetizer ... it had what tasted like Big Mac "secret sauce" between the fish and the crostini.  My colleagues had the tortilla soup and stopped after the first couple spoonfuls.  After the ever-inviting "this is terrible, here, taste this," I agreed that it was a bit flat in flavor.  I had the fried chicken sandwich.  Though it was a bit small, it was delicious.  Chick-Fil-A move over!

Like some reviews have already said, you're paying for the view.  I might come back for that fried chicken sandwich, though.
author: Ike K.

description:
Just now updating my review.  I got a message in my inbox regarding my original review, here's the message:

"Better make your reservations quick before they go out of business over this which would make my day!! LOL!!"

I let the DB know that I made my reservations and the food was delicious...It's a little loud in the place but it's a former military facility, it wasn't designed for ambiance.  I wish I got to order some foie gras but it wasn't on the menu that night, maybe next time.

The portions were a little smaller than I'd like but the flavor of the food made up for it.  We left feeling satisfied can't wait to go back.
author: The E.

description: Is the glass half full or half empty?  Not even close.  Party of three of us were seated for dinner and after a long wait, were greeted and drinks ordered.  I received a glass of cabernet that was wholly lacking in volume and brought this to the attention of our server.  She proceeded to leave our table, return with a pint glass, stand it next to the wine glass and point out that it was an exact measure and that was their standard pour(l no more than a third of the wine glass), the rim of the wine parallel to the rim of the pint glass.  I suppose that if you have a tall enough stem on the glass, you can pour less.  Instead of bringing back the bottle and adding to the original weak pour, she taught this patron(never again) a lesson on what her establishment's customer service policy is.  Apparently adding a splash and making the customer happy isn't as important as stretching the contents of a wine bottle for maximum profit. Typically, I would have had at least two glasses with dinner, dessert, coffee, but after that interaction there was no way I would have another.  In retrospect, I should have sent the glass back, grabbed my jacket and hit the door with a few choice words for the manager, never to return. They'd have lost our $150.00 tab, but they'd have stuck true to their standards.
author: David F.

description:
We had our work holiday dinner here this year.  I'd never heard of this place prior to finding out where the dinner was, so wasn't sure what to expect.  A and I were the last ones to arrive for our 6:30pm reservation so we got the last seats at the long, 12-top table.

The waiter came by right away to get our drink orders since he had already gotten everyone else's drink orders earlier (although their drinks had not yet arrived, so we must not have been THAT late).  I ordered a Mai Tai and A ordered a Gunpowder.  The waiter came back a little while later to tell me they were not doing Mai Tais that night and if I wanted something else - so, I decided to go with the Gin Fizz.  It was good, but I definitely liked A's Gunpowder better.  Tasty!

As for entrees, I decided to go with the special of the day, which was a Rock Cod with Gnocchi and spinach.  A ordered the Meatloaf - classic, with mashed potatoes.  We love mashed potatoes!  When our order came, the server put a plate with a whole fish on it right in front of me.  I was a little perplexed.  How was I going to eat a whole fish with bones and all?  And neatly?
