I sat there watching it for a while and was just going to start eating it when another server comes over and puts another plate in front of me.  It turns out they had given me the wrong dish first.  The second plate of fish was much less intimidating.  Just a portion of fish with the spinach and gnocchi!!!  The whole Tai Snapper looked much too difficult for me to eat.  

For dessert, A and I were going to order the beignets, but our waiter said he was going to bring out something called "The Dirty Dozen" which were donut holes that are very similar to beignets (on the house) and if we still wanted beignets after eating those, then he'd bring them out.  We were fine after eating the donut holes, so really appreciated the waiter's input in the matter.

The whole dinner took about three hours.  The food was good.  Service was excellent.  Really great location.  I'd go here again.
author: Kris L.

description:
Went on a Friday night with the Hub and it was predictably busy.  Services was good despite the busyness. 

I dig the stark, Officer Club decor. It has a sleek vibe, however, my butt prefers a cushion and sound bounces everywhere so conversation takes some effort. 

I thought the menu a bit limited but everything we put in our mouth was delicious.  The Petrale Sole was artfully deboned before my very eyes. Buttery and tender. Hub had ribs with meat falling off the bone. Portions are big..at least to us. Lots of it went into a box.

Overall, I'd make this a destination to hit in the City. Kudos for easy parking.
author: East West Coast Girl C.

description: We had 20 guests for a 30th birthday brunch here and we're very excited since we heard wonderful things about this place.  Starting with the positives,  our Waiter was amazing very attentive, great personality, we're off to a great start! The food was good.  The beignets were a highlight, the bloody Mary's definitely need some work! Especially the glassware, who serves a bloody Mary in a coffee glass??  Everyone seemed happy for the most part though, we're definitely not that hard of a group to please, until our check arrived.  Now we expected a hefty price tag, after all drinks were flowing and it's brunch in the city.  However a $150 dollar charge for a semi private room?? WTF! sharing (2) tables of 10 in a room with 5 other peoples tables, hardly warrants a $150 charge for "Privacy" that we didn't even have.  I cannot believe after our $1,596.00 bill that they have the audacity to charge this price for not even an ounce of privacy, let alone we were not even seated all together.  There are way to many places to have a good brunch in the city that would never think of charging this price, so we definitely won't be back!
author: Angela T.

description:
Not a bad spot. They have parking and staff were friendly. It's a nice space and good atmosphere. What a shame I had to drag my stroller up the front steps as I couldn't find a ramp. 
But the food is overpriced for what it is. For Sunday lunch I had the frittata of the day which came with a few green leaves. It was nice enough but I had hoped for more for my $14. That said, the desserts were delicious, even if they were expensive at $8 for a tiny serve. 

This place is always busier and noisier than I expect. I'd come again but not in a hurry. Oh, and they do have a small outdoor area out the back.
author: Izzy A.

description: I'm always so impressed with this restaurant. I sincerely love the ambiance, the drinks, the food, the location. The lobster spaghetti is superb and completely mouthwatering tasty. My husband loved the hamburger. Thanks for making our romantic evening experience so very memorable PSC. You don't ever disappoint us.
author: Mei F.

description: We had a totally marvelous dinner last night.  The food and service were great.  We were meeting some friends who we haven't seen in awhile and they let us talk, never rushed us, and our server suggested menu items that were wonderful.  The restaurant is a gem and the location was different.  Parking was no problem
author: Rich B.

description: This is one of my favorite places to come for brunch. The service and the food have never disappointed us. We never waited in crazy lines. I am a fan of the cocktail called the painkiller. It's super yummy tropical rum drink! Their kale salad is really good too. It's in Presidio Park which is so green and beautiful. The building is old and tastefully decorated. I highly recommend this place for brunch if you have friends visiting out of town. It represents San Francisco well!
author: Tumay A.

description:
Stopped in last night to have dinner before a screening at the Letterman Digital Arts Center, because, dear reader, we are fabulous like that, as you know.

My companion and I both had liver and onions with a side order of brussel sprouts. Some of you might think that sounds pretty awful, but they are some of our favorite things. The waiter asked if we wanted the liver cooked medium, to which we both said yes....but mine arrived well done, and hers more on the rare side....we switched plates as she preferred the more done. 

The sprouts weren't cooked well enough to eat-they were hard. So now hear this: If you want a delicious perfectly cooked liver dish go to Poggio in Sausalito, and if you want perfectly cooked brussel sprouts, visit Luella on Russian Hill. The best thing about our meal at PSC was my glass of Merlot but honestly you can't swing a dead cat in this town without finding a great glass of wine so.....NEXT
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
I gave a 3 as I think the atmosphere and decor could do with improving.  I also sat by the kitchen and the door was obviously open and we were freezing!  We did ask to move but couldn't.  Having said this the food exceeded our expectations and the chocolate cake we had was one of the best. 

I also had a great cocktail here recommended by our distracted and busy waiter.

Update- I've since been back 2 times as it's close to where I live.  I love cocktails and the gruyere cheese starter is awesome.  I really want to love this place.  I will go again but something is missing each time I go.  The last time at lunch we were told there were no tables so we could sit at the bar instead...those tables remained empty throughout our time there so all in all a bit if a weird thing to say to us - not a great impression!
author: Harriet P.

description: Great feel inside with the black and white decor.  Large marble bar with an excellent selection of wines, beer, and various cocktails.  Food is done well and nicely presented.  Gotta say we tried various items but the standouts were the grilled cheese with the tomato dipping sauce and the mac & cheese.
author: Dale G.

description:
I ate there for brunch on a Saturday. Good ambiance, good food, but you're really paying for the location. There's nothing like the presidio on one of those fabulous SF days. The place wasn't full, so while our waiter was quite attentive, I can't attest to whether that's the case on busy nights. 

The portions were a good size, and the food tasty, but we're not talking about something to write home about (at least for the brunch menu). I had (essentially) huevos rancheros with perfectly poached eggs, and my grandma (she's darling, you'd love her!) had crab cakes which she enjoyed. 

I don't think this is a place where you'd ever be dissappointed, but I wasn't wowed by the menu either. If you're going there during the day, I'd reccommend taking a walk through the presidio before or after your meal- it really is one of our city's gems.
author: Amy M.

description:
Pros:  great burger, wonderful fries. Really great fries.  

Cons:  Service. Although our waitress was really nice, she disappeared. I had to go into the kitchen with my coffee cup to ask for a refill after waiting forever. 

Although I really enjoyed the food. The place is pretty. Very clean. But with so many places to pick from in SF, I shouldn't have to go find my server. :((((

Doubt I can talk my husband into going back. Darn it.
author: Samantha Y.

description: The location is a little off the beaten path, which means easier parking and less hustle and bustle. Inside it feels like a 60s country clubhouse which I always find amusing (note the bartender uniforms). Last time in, I went with the trout which was perfect. Great option for a relaxing meal, I'll be back.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
My nieces love the mac and cheese so we take them there, but I ordered the burger, hoping for a delicious or at least better than average burger. Was pretty disappointed - the bun was sort of blah, fries were average, and the meat was forgettable. I asked for well done and got the meat completely red inside. Didn't want to wait to have it recooked, but I actually got a small bout of food poisoning from it so was unhappy about that. I assumed the meat would be from a high quality organic farm or something, definitely did not taste like that.

The brussel sprouts were tasty, but the kale dish was also extremely forgettable.

The setting and ambiance is AMAZING! The service is excellent! I just wish the food matched.
author: Monica S.

description:
It would have been cool if this was the actual social club that officers used to socialize at back in the day.  There may have been some shenanigans in these barracks turned restaurant, but only being 3 years old you'll just have to imagine the history they are trying to recreate.  Nice mixology.  Solid menu of old time favorites snazzed up with new school culinary techniques.  Your best bet if you find yourself in the middle of the Presidio during dinner time.

Gruyère Cheese Toast: They should just drop the pretense and call this grilled cheese and tomato soup.  Four petite triangles with an amazingly smooth toast seared exterior.  Kudos for making the tomato soup dip in the espresso cup warm (hate when tomato based sauces besides ketchip are cold!).  Perfect pairing and just the right ratio where the grilled cheese dominates the soup.

Macaroni and Cheese: Shells in a creamy sauce with loads of crunchy bread crumbs topping.  No fancy $20/lb imported cheeses or equally fancy pork products here, but still satisfying.  Probably what homemakers who disdained Kraft would cook for their families... nice throwback!

Côte de Bœuf  (for two): 30 oz. of ecstasy (but without all the repetitive rave music)!  We ordered it medium rare  and did not sacrifice on tenderness at all in this fat marbleized ribeye.  Seared crispy on the inside and juicy on the outside.  They provided three dipping sauces but I preferred not to taint this awesome bovine inspiration.  Two of the sauces were negligible, but the onion based chutney was decent. 

Roasted Corn with Basil Butter: A corn on the cob boiled, cut into four pieces and covered in basil infused butter.  Not quite as complex as pesto, but better than the standard.  Might have been nicer if grilled.

Smashed Peas with Mint: Texture was awesome, but mint was not a good pairing.  Would have been better with butter/cream/cheese/yogurt.  The mint adds freshness, but more freshness is not necessary when you start with freshly shucked peas.

Chocolate Cupcakes: Had to order these because they were baked to order.  Was expecting full sized and topped with creamy frosting.  Received midgets with no frosting and some crunchy top.  There was a shot glass full of whipped cream a little chocolate pudding.  Ok to dip in, but no frosting.  They should make these more big boy sized...
author: Adam B.

description: Great atmosphere! Good quality food, nothing too fancy but it's a great place for a business lunch. Also a bonus is that you get to escape the city for an hour or so!
author: George S.

description: I have only gone here a couple of times, but when I have gone, the food was divine. Even though it was loud and busy, it was still family friendly. My only complaint is the service.
author: C B.

description:
This review is for weekend brunch. We enjoyed the food experience and the space is endearing to us as our ties to the Presidio goes back to the days it was an Army post. We sampled the beignets and they were to die for but they really reminded us of yummy hot doughnuts, not beignets and I'm not sure what the  chocolate dipping sauce was all about--just not necessary.
We did enjoy the huevos Rotos, and the special which was short rib hash. The Croquet Madame  was boring and not sure why the Texas toast with such skimpy filling within. 
The big complaint was the service. So uneven and spotty. We literally sat for over 10 minutes before even getting menus. There were huge gaps in how our meals came out.
author: Jane V.

description: So many wealthy whites in their 30s with kids.  I generally felt like I was in a country club even though it wasn't a country club, which I believe is their mission. So kudos!  The food was all pretty tasty.  I particularly enjoyed the beignets my friend got that I had the pleasure of tasting.  The hot chocolate dipping sauce was a perfect compliment.  I definitely dug my burger, but the actually meat itself didn't have much in the way of special flavor.  For a $17 price tag, I expect a little pizzazz in my meat.  That said, I would be down for coming back if ever in the Presidio or when I upgrade to life with a tyke.
author: Jeremy G.

description: Decent brunch spot but overpriced for what I was expecting. The chilaquiles were very tasty but its a tough dish to mess up when you use that much salsa verde. The beniets were also good but overall I think my expectations were a bit too high for this place
author: Gautam S.

description:
The Social Club is a very comfortable place for a slightly-upscale-level of lunch or dinner.  The building is historic and the layout is a bit more formal than many local alternatives (e.g. cloth tablecloths, wait staff in uniforms, etc.)  I've enjoyed several meals there and never had any objections.  

The beef liver is very well prepared and the appetizers (cheese toasts with tomato soup dipping sauce) are all good.  The salads are very tasty.  The presentation is a little less dressy than the atmosphere might suggest: plates are very straight-forward with little added attention to the art of plating.  

Service is very good.  Prices are a little higher than average, but in keeping with the nicer atmosphere.  

The only real downside is parking; which can be packed at peak hours.  Area requires you to walk to a vending machine to retrieve a printed ticket.  Unfortunately, I've never been there when at least one wasn't out of order.
author: Bill M.

description:
Went here with two out of town guests for dinner last week. We started with tuna poke which was delicious. I had the chicken which was nice, juicy and tender. My friends had the trout and meatloaf. The food was good, our plates were mostly clean. The highlight of the dinner was desert. We ordered the strawberry shortcake, malted milk ice cream & cookies, and the 10-minute chocolate cupcakes. The strawberries were fresh, but the shortcake was a little dry. The cupcakes were by far the best thing we ordered all evening. 

Our server was friendly, and they had our table waiting for us as soon as we got there for our reservation. I wish I could give them a full 4 stars, but there were a couple of little things that prevent me from feeling the 4 star "Yay! I'm a fan" feeling... 

The music was turned really low, and the lights were bright. It felt a little "last-call-ish." Also, the restrooms were a little messy. (A couple pieces of paper on the floor type of thing. I don't want to give the impression that they were gross, because they weren't.) My chicken came with corn on the cob. Since it's impossible to eat corn on the cob in any lady like fashion, I asked the waitress if the chef could just go ahead and cut the corn off for me; she said sure. When the food came, the corn was still on the cob. 

I realize that I'm being critical, but again, it's all the little things added together that knocked a star off. Overall, my guests and I enjoyed our meal.
author: Chloe M.

description:
I visited Presidio Social Club last week with my work colleague's for a team dinner and really enjoyed it.  We were seated near the window in the bar area which is perfect if you like things lively and fun.  

The first server (female) that approached us was a bit abrupt and unable to answer our initial questions about the menu.  Not sure what happened but next we had a very friendly and capable server (male) who took great care of us throughout our evening.   

Altogether we had both the kale and the butter lettuce salad and both were fresh and full of good stuff. Four of us ordered the swordfish special, it was perfected cooked and very flavorful served on a bed of brussels sprouts.  There was also the bone-in rib eye for two which was literally a feast on a plate with incredible truffle shoestring fries and also a full size bronzino that was also a special and perfected executed.

We also sampled the deserts and declared the lemon pie as our favorite.

All in all, a great dinner, good atmosphere and friendly, efficient service.
author: Marilyn M.

description:
Eating at the PSC is like taking a step back in time.  It's in a former Army barrack.  The interior is of the period with a long bar and dark furniture.  Reminds me of when only men were servers dressed in white jackets and ties.

Food is very 21st century with great gourmet cheeseburgers with crispy french fries, and warm beignets with Mexican hot chocolate for dessert. 

Great location in the Presido with ample parking.
author: Shirley N.

description: I am always disappointed when a restaurant nickel and dimes you, especially when the meal is expensive.  I can't stand it when the restaurant charges you for a refill on ice tea.  Don't you get at least a pitcher of ice tea from a couple tea bags?  If the ice tea costs $4, is it really necessary to get another $4 for a refill?  This really leaves a bad taste in your mouth!
author: jaylin c.

description:
I very much appreciated the service- he knew how to pace us, since my girlfriend and I were catching up quite a bit.  Server was totally unhurried.  

I also love the location and decor.  I would definitely come back here.  That being said, the food was just 'fine'.  Not bad, not great.  I guess like I felt there wasn't a point of view on the menu- is it comfort food?  If so, it's kind of over-priced, but I'm okay paying for the location/location/location.
author: Kathryn F.

description: Wonderful space.  Been here for lunch a number of times (a short walk from my office) and also for special dinners.  Airy and flooded with light during the day, festive and energy filled at night.  Generally good food though its the bar and ambiance are what separate it from other nearby spots on Union or Chestnut.  And parking is a breeze.
author: John K.

description:
My wife and I had a good lunch on Sunday there. Food was good but nothing exceptional. We enjoyed the fact that it is at the Presidio and there's a history at that location. The service was slow (but our waiter was nice). It took over 10 min to get some cocktails and we were seated close to the bar so I could see that the Bartender had time to make it, but he was in no rush. 
We might give them another shoot next time we go to the Presidio.
author: G R.

description: Even though the food was good (nothing too special) the service was horrible. We got here as soon as they opened and were seated by a hostess who not only didn't  seem happy to be there but who was extremely rude when we told her we had an extra person compared to what our reservation said. Finally, the budding of the table took forever. Our waitress seemed disinterested in helping us out and we had played accumulating as time went by. It's a nice place but don't expect friendly and good service.
author: Isabel R.

description: The Presidio Social Club is by far one of my favorite brunch places in the city. However, today, I brought my boyfriend's parents to the restaurant under a reservation and it was by far the most horrible experience. They forgot to provide coffee. The brunch special that my future mother-in-law had ordered took 1/2 hour for the serve to come back and tell her that the special was no sold out - horribly disappointing her. Our food took over 45 minutes to arrive at our table after we ordered. And to top everything off, the bacon, which I ordered "burnt" was under cooked and had to be sent back 3 times. It was a very hot San Francisco day and the room that we were in was horribly stuffy with poor ventilation. We did get an apology by our server, but no excuses by our server on the poor service. Overall, my in-laws were unimpressed by my favorite brunch place. Very sad :(
author: Sue M.

description: The restaurant has a very modern and clean feel to it; great atmosphere.  The food was ok.  I'm only giving this 2 stars because the service was really bad and the food is way overpriced.  We were seated and it took the waiter another 20 minutes to come to our table and take our orders.  Problem is a lot of the menu depends on specials and none of us knew what we wanted since no one told us the specials.  After ordering an appetizer, my utensils were taken away and the waitress didn't replace them for me and quickly disappeared after she gave us our main course.  The only thing on the menu reasonably priced is the $12 burger, everything else is either extremely small portions or extremely over priced.
author: Zoe Z.

description: Although the food was good the customer service was awful. When asked to speak to a manager both managers were incredibly rude and did not take any responsibility. I've never been treated so poorly by management and wait staff and have never taken the time out to write a review such as this. I'm sad to say that I would never go or recommend this establishment again.
author: Miranda P.

description: I give it two stars because the food was pretty good. But the service was terrible. We waited 45 min to make our order and then another hour before the food came. We had been told that our large group had to be done by 8 which I thought was rude in the first place. The restaraunt was extremely loud and the people at the bar kept pushing into the backs of our chairs. I would not come here again.
author: Katie A.

description: I was a bit unsure about catching dinner at the Presidio Social Club based on uneven reviews, but it was within walking distance of both my hotel and my son's house in the Presidio, so I thought it was worth a try. To be fair, my son enjoyed his oysters on the half shell and lobster spaghetti, but my chicken was overly salty and otherwise bland, and my cocktail was forgettable. (In fact, I have forgotten what it was.) I enjoyed the kale salad, which I ordered based on review recommendations, but I did not enjoy paying $12.50 for a plate of chopped kale. Our server was fine, though he used the odd "we" whenever speaking to us: "Are we ready to order?" Okay, that wasn't a big deal, but the bill was. It turned out to be a splurge meal that wasn't all that good. Don't get the chicken!
author: Jane H.

description: Great brunch - nice cocktails.  I wish the menu was so limited though.
author: Sarah N.

description: Great food.  Good service. Prices are a bit steep ($18-$25 per plate for adults).  A bit loud if you sit inside.  The Presidio (a former military base in which this restaurant sits) charges for parking until 6:00 p.m.
author: Martin A.

description:
My husband and I met some friends here for dinner while in town. I really enjoyed the atmosphere. Low-key and not stuffy. I ordered the PSC gruyere cheese toasts with tomato fondue.   Delicious!  My husband really enjoyed them as well.  I also ordered the market vegetable salad which I don't remember that well, so it must have been ok.   For dessert, we split the salted caramel sundae. 

It was a bit far from where we normally stay (Union Square), so I'm not sure that we would return here. It is on a former military base with parking, which was a plus. Overall, a very good experience.
author: Alexis S.

description:
The venue and food are delightful, but I feel obligated to share an experience after holding a private event at the PSC.  The private event planner is out to nickel and dime every cent out of you.... which she even told me before we had the event. (In hindsight I should have taken her comments to heart, but I laughed it off).  Our bill was incorrect and did not reflect what we had agreed to in the contract!  We were several hundred dollars off.

The food, wait staff, and location are fantastic, but if you are holding a private event be prepared for them to up-charge/overcharge the heck out of you, and when you bring it up be prepared for extremely passive aggressive and rude behavior, and ultimately denying reimbursement.  Not worth the hassle....
author: Heather H.

description:
I talked to the manager of this place, and he confirmed what I had suspected -- the macaroni and cheese has CRACK in it.  I had long heard about the mac and cheese, but it took me finally moving to the Presidio before I actually came!  It's a cool space, and the menu fits the very homey surroundings.  It's almost all comfort food, and everything we ordered was delicious. The meatloaf was meaty and tasty, the roasted chicken was moist and delicious, the vegetable soup tasted fresh and light, and the mac and cheese was AMAZING!  Nothing fancy about the mac and cheese -- just good ol' mac and cheese.  It was cheesy without being too heavy, with a nice crunchy bread crumb crust on top.  We got the beignets and Mexican hot chocolate for dessert.  It was good, but not as good as the rest of the meal, probably because we were already really full.   

They also have a daily supper -- $25 for a salad, entree, and dessert -- which looked like a great, as well as a nice cocktail list, which I am excited to try next time (along with more mac and cheese).
author: Pilan C.

description: 2nd time around, not so great. Service was rushed and unfriendly. They tried to take our entree plates when we had about 1/2 our food left. I had the polenta with veggies and cheese. It was bland and felt like they know they need a veg entree so lets just throw a few things together and call it a meal. So many amazing places to eat in SF. This isn't one of them.
author: S T.

description: Start with ok food - no kids menu -  rude and snobbish service + great location = 2 stars.
author: D S.

description:
WOW !
Really wow !!!
Amazing food with professional service.
The best place for a great night with food and drinks in sf.
author: Michael B.

description: Such a disappointing experience. Such mediocre food at gourmet prices. Chicken was tasteless, veal piccata was fried and breaded rather than sautéed and the coffee was cold. The dessert was the only enjoyable thing that we ate.
author: joan G.

description: First time here and it will be my last. We walked in the door at 1:15 on a Monday and the place was nearly empty. Still, we had to wait a few minutes before the hostess appeared to seat us (she wasn't seating someone else, so what was she doing???). We were seated outside, handed menus and water, then were never contacted again. The waitress came outside a few times to deliver drinks/food to the few other customers outside, but did not make any effort to stop by our table. 10 min later, we were done being ignored. We got up and left. The kicker is that as we walked out, we passed the hostess and she was just standing there chatting with another employee! I guess they would rather socialize with each other than help customers. Have no idea how the food is, and I'll never know - I don't go to restaurants where the employees and owners don't care about the customers.
author: June L.

description:
Really really good.  Even though this place has been around for a few years, it still is great.  And my experience Saturday night was great.  Although it started bad, it ended amazing.  First, we had a reservation at 8pm, but by 8:30 they still hadn't sat us.  The manager was clearly upset! Because the place was packed and tables weren't moving.  He moved us to the bar (6 of us) and compted our drinks and sent us some amazing appetizers.  By 9 we still didn't have a table! But the manager stepped up and asked a group of 6 to move (they had been hanging out for 30 minutes while we waited, already having paid for their dinner). So we sat down and our corkage was waived, and more free appetizers.

The dinner was amazing and even the dessert was fantastic.  In all, a great experience, and even though we waited a long time for the table, they took care of us.
author: Garth O.

description:
Went here on Sunday for Brunch and had a GREAT time. 

Good mimosa's and GREAT food. I may be biased because i ordered what seemed to be a HIT at the table (Mission Style Chilaquiles). The birthday girl liked it so much she boxed up her first choice and ordered a second round of them because she enjoyed them so much.

We also ordered the Gruyere cheese toast with tomato dip which was OK, i seem to remember it being better about a year ago when i ordered it the first time i went there. 

I'd definitely go back, good spot for a bday celebration.
author: Alison M.

description: The PSC seems to never try to rise above competent and predictable.  This includes the food and service and gives one the feeling of  the restaurant relying on location charm to deliver a fuller package than it actually does.  Recently had brunch with a group of friends here and have to say the Mission-style chilaquiles qualifies as the single worst restaurant dish I've had this year; soggy tortillas in tomatillo sauce.  This was the experience that made me think  "meh, why go back?".
author: Greg L.

description: This was soo good! The poke appetizer, and the beniegts for desert! YUM YUM
author: Jennifer T.

description: My buddy and I made a lunch date at PSC for Dine About Town.  He ordered the roasted half chicken with butternut squash, escarole and pancetta, and I got the fall vegetable gratin with shiitake mushroom vinaigrette and an herb salad.  For dessert, we had orange sherbet with a gingersnap cookie.  The chicken was on the plain side for me, but I was very happy with my vegetable gratin.  It was flavorful and filling.  The dessert was refreshing.  The food and service were solid (I was definitely jacked on caffeine thanks to their attentive and generous refills) and their bathroom was immaculate.  I wouldn't say any one aspect was extraordinary, but overall, it's a good place to gather in a beautiful area of SF, as it seems so many Marina moms do on a regular basis.
author: Jenn C.

description: What a great find in the Presidio - this place is like an old school men's drinking club with a twist of hipster. Met a client here for lunch however so didn't get to partake of the fun drinks menu. The food itself would probably get 3 stars but the setting is so unique and classic that I had to raise my review by 1 whole star. Bring your out of town friends here - they'll love it. Go with your parents when they're in town...or take your boyfriend/partner/husband/wife here on a foggy weekend morning for brunch. Am looking forward to going back, maybe in period appropriate dress.
author: Erin W.

description: Classic, yet fun/lively atmosphere nestled inside one of SF's crown jewels in the city - the Presidio.  Afterwards you can take a stroll through the Presidio (eucalyptus anyone?) or venture to the Palace of Fine Arts.
author: Grant K.

description: Not only was the brunch delicious... But Scott and Chris (bartenders) took such great care of myself and 3 friends at the bar. Amazing service will bring me back along with the tasty food!
author: Molly A.

description: This restaurant is still one of the prettiest settings for a lunch or dinner out. But the food has become lackluster, even drab. I remember the first year, there were some fabulous dishes. My favorite place to eat liver and onions. Ordered that same dish last night and wow, was it different. The meat was tough (even though cooked med rare as requested) with quite a bit of chewy bits. Plopped on a bed of rather watery mashed potatoes, topped with grilled onions and a tasty sauce. That't it. Not impressed. It was an appetizer size portion too. Watermelon and Tomato Gazpacho was good, but why do we have to ask for bread to go with soup? And why wasn't it warm? Oh, well, won't drive 45 minutes to go there any more. Good Moscow Mule! Companions enjoyed their kale salads and fish. Where's the sparkle?
author: Linda B.

description: We went to this place for brunch. It is in the Presidio and has an extensive menu, including fois gras, if you are into that. Solid service and solid food. A good place to take your parents when they visit.
author: Charles L.

description: Tonight I had an amazing pork chop that I think I will be dreaming about for a couple of weeks. Sigh... Waiter, I think I'll have another :)
author: Patrick W.

description: 5 stars for their Mixologists and drinks!  Chris was AMAZING today at the bar, mixing just the right combination of lime, mint, cucumber and gin--fantastic work Chris!  Plus, Chris was great company & exceptionally friendly.  Had the chicken & arugula salad, which was the best I could do on a low-carb eating plan.  Watched my husband chow down on a big fatty belly cinnamon bun--so jealous!
author: Nancy W.

description:
We kind of suspected we were about to walk in to Early Bird dining hour. After a walk through the Presidio and some lovely views of the bridge, we cruised over around 5:00PM and made fun of ourselves for going out to dinner so early.

Well, I also had a rush of deja vu. Entering the Presidio Social Club reminded me of a Saturday afternoon circa 1992, riding in the backseat of Grandma and Grandpa's Buick and heading to 5:00 mass. The crowd was as we suspected, senior citizens in their Sunday best, a few families, and us. Our sever had a peculiar accent that we couldn't quite wrap our fingers around (French, maybe?).

The mussels were interesting- never thought to put meat in the mussel broth. Very good nevertheless! I probably stared at the drink list for 10 minutes before deciding what I wanted... I toyed with getting a mojito but settled on a Hendrick's and tonic. Stuck to my original. I then got the trout, he got the burger, both pretty solid. However, when does gruyere magically become white cheddar? There was definitely cheddar where gruyere should have been.

I'll come back. I like the Presidio since it's so pretty, and I enjoyed myself when I came here for a Yelp event last fall. I'm a little surprised at the negative reviews... but then again, our waiter confused "rocks" with "up" and cheddar with gruyere.
author: Kristin F.

description: Brought my mom here for her birthday on a Sunday. My family has a history of coming to the Presidio, they loved it. It's great they kept so much of the building original. Service was excellent, the food was great. The meatloaf was the table favorite. We didn't mention the birthday to the staff, however after watching gifts being opened they brought out an extra dessert, very thoughtful. It can be a little noisy, but it wasn't that bad. Will definitely be making the trip into the city to enjoy again.
author: Noelle R.

description:
Presidio Social Club is in a great location and I love the ambiance, so that is why I am giving it 3 stars. I've been here several times, but felt compelled to review it today for some reason.
Food and service are 100% mediocre. I went here for brunch today for the first time (I usually go for dinner) and ordered the chilaquiles. Shmeh! I could barely eat it even though I was starving. Not to mention if you want to add meat to your $14 chilaquiles it becomes $20! So ridiculous. 
I like PSC for cocktails, oysters and sitting at the bar.
author: Eliza V.

description:
My brother took me there. He knows that I like martinis and thought I'd enjoy this place. Was he ever right.

First, the ambience.  The Presidio was a military base for many years and the buildings are all wooden structures of that era.  This was no exception and had much of the feel of the officers club for that base.  The bar was made of a thick slab of well worn, gray veined marble. The lights were the warm yellow glow of a bare bulb.  It was like going back to the 1940s and the WWII era.  Exceptional.  

I ordered my usual (Hendricks, up, with a twist, very dry) and the bartender made a perfect drink without any coaxing at all.  There was no hard shaking of the container, it was gently stirred and strained into a cold glass with a large peel of lemon. And filled to rim. Really perfect.

It was also $1 oyster night (Thursdays after 5p) and they had the most amazing oysters (they called them Chelsea Gold). Small, plump, briny, and exquisite.

The meal was also good.  Rock cod, calf's liver, and a whole red snapper.  Well prepared.  And the service was exceptional, like a fine supper club.

Thank you PSC (and brother James) for such a memorable evening.
author: Mark P.

description: Such a great atmosphere. We come here for work lunches pretty regularly, and the food and drinks are always delicious! I've also come for drinks after work, and while there's not exactly a happy hour pricing, the patio is a great place to sit outside and enjoy the weather. The patio is dog-friendly, which is an added bonus for me :) I've even had servers bring my dog a plate of bacon before - superb service!
author: Aly G.

description:
Short of it.
Went with 5 friends for a b-day dinner Feb 13.
Service was great.
I like the atmosphere, although it was a bit quiet, which I'll chalk up to the night before Valentines day.
Very nice martini.
Kale salad was really good.
I had the meat loaf. Big portion. Very Salty. It was good but not gourmet by any means. 
Everybody seemed ok with their meals. No complaining, no raving.
Two of my friends got food poisoning....
The end.
author: C. S.

description: Outdoor seating is great and our service was good, helps that the waiter was cute and funny! I had a very tasty burrata heirloom salad and tuna poke appetizer - a surprising filling lunch. Must've been all that cheese.
author: Tatyana K.

description: PSC has a new menu, get ready for sticker shock. Half chicken is $26.50 and steak is $34 (not a choice cut). Also, cocktail prices are up. I live nearby but will go to the mission for better food at better prices. Sorry Charles, I'm not paying $17.50 for a slice of your meatloaf.
author: Mark D.

description: The Presidio is a great place to hang out a Sunday morning and the social club is a great place to start exploring the area. But the brunch menu is not really anything interesting. Sloppy coffee and so so food. And not a place for kids.
author: Peter T.

description: Saturday brunch; four people. Service excellent. Menu small and manageable. Food truly good. Easy to get to and park. Pretty setting. Unpretentious but not neighborhood or folksy. Somewhere in between.
author: Mary M.

description:
The food, service and decor were excellent!  There were 3 of us and we all had what was on the special menu that evening.  The heirloom tomato mint gazpaccho was a
perfect blend of flavors.  The servings are of good size.  A good bar choice as well.
My dining partners said they had never had such a perfect martini.  Two of us had the fish special and one had the pork special.  The seasoning was perfect as none of us needed to add any seasoning.

We look forward to our next dining experience.
author: Norma K.

description:
Had a group dinner there last night.  They did a very good job of (1) accommodating a group of 30 and (2) serving tasty food.  The appetizers that we had upon arrival were great.  There were mini-crab cake sandwiches and grilled cheese sandwiches that you dipped in tomato soup.  Very good all around.

The ambiance is great at this place.  Very cool.  Great location.  Easy parking (yes...parking in SF!).

I can't wait to go back and have a proper dinner off the menu there.
author: Eric S.

description:
We have been eating here going on two years now.  The most recent time was last week.  The food continues to be great, and the staff very friendly and accommodating.

We've sampled most of the menu, and have eaten there for dinner, brunch and lunch.  The ribeye for two at night is great, and their seafood is fresh.  One of the things we liked about them from the start was using locally sourced produce and protein.  

Their building is perfectly situated and has great parking.  The glass cases behind the wall were recovered from the old Letterman Hospital where Lucasfilm is located now.  Parking is great, with Saturday and Sunday Free.

Prices are reasonable for San Francisco, and good portions abound for favorites like the Meat Loaf and Mac and Cheese.  Also, ask for the "dirty dozen" for dessert.  Its not on the menu.


We will keep going back, as this is one of our favorite places to eat in San Francisco.


(on a side note, what's with these people posting "ones" without ever eating at the place. Or more recently 5/2013, being so timid that they can't get up and flag a waiter.  We've of course come here at change of shift and they are SLOW at times, but we know the drill.  Lots of "Yelpers" seem unable to function and helpless.  They need to either "get a pair", or "grow a backbone" or both. )
author: Philip M.

description:
Being a fan of Cap City Diner (in Columbus, OH), I've always liked the some what upscale diners. The Presidio Social Club reminds me of one of those places. 

It has a hip, upscale feel but is a totally casual spot. Also I've got 3 words for you -- Gruyere Cheese Toast! Sorry for yelling but this little appetizer made my brunch. It's just a simple grilled cheese YET it is so good, especially with the tomato dip. I mean I've had daydreams about that devilish little treat and just to be honest after that I was set on giving this place 4 stars. That's right! Presidio Social Club you had me @ cheese toast.

The service was excellent and no one gave me a funny look when I asked for fries with my "homemade biscuits and gravy"...well, my gf did but she always gives me funny looks ;)

Everything we had ranged from good - excellent.  I even cleaned my plate(s) and washed it all down with a tasty PSC Bellini --MMmmmmmmmmm I love Saturday brunches with tasty food and even tastier bubbly and I think I could fall in love with this place. 

In addition it's right across the street from a small dog park. So to my fellow dog owners, on a nice weekend morning you get breakfast-to-go and let the dog play but be warned your dog maybe more interested in what your eating than playing with the other dogs.
author: Troy R.

description: The restaurant location was beautiful and peaceful. The food was usually very good, however this was not a cheap eat place. The decor Inside the place was simple but delightful. The wait staff was pleasant and courteous.
author: Rita L.

description: Ohh my goodness! This place is super yumm! Prices are a little high, but we are in SF. They have a great menu selection and the dessert- woowzers! Everything I have tasted has been phenomenal. The patio is super quaint and chill, more of my style than sitting inside. You will not be disappointed so go check it out for yourself
author: Ladybird G.

description:
Ok, so was I the only one that didn't know that the Presidio in San Francisco was actually named the district name for the Army base that it used to occupy? and that there is gorgeous property houses that are former officer houses all over the former base that are now occupied by non-profits (swank digs), and this is all seated comfortably right next to Lucas Films Special Effects Studios - Industrial Light & Magic? No wonder this place is known for having some of the most high priced real estate in S.F and is the district where the likes of Dianne Feinstein and Sharon Stone shack up!

The main eatery in the central hub of this once occupied this Army base, and what was also once the officers barracks (oh my) -- is now the home of the Presidio Social Club. This place is right out of the 1950's without even trying; from the bar that was made from medicine cabinets, to the table of "ladies-who-lunch" taking in their lunch and cocktails from 11:00 am - 3:00 pm, to the 50's style classic cocktails, and a very simple menu that is offered from lunch to dinner with mid-century classics. 

So how do the eats from the 1950's fare in a 2011 world? Not surprisingly all the food and cocktails are very familiar to our comfort-style food that's been running rampant through the country since our depression-recession hit in 2008 - but while familiar dishes in style, my question was could they pull them off? Could they make a really good mac n' cheese? a solid meat loaf?

fried green tomatoes housemade ricotta, olive tapenade    11
So if you've ever had great fired green tomatoes you know the breading is light, but crisp, the tomato taste comes through, and if you're lucky their topped with a spicy aoli or remoulade - this wasn't quite that, it was a thickly breaded tomato (so less flavor comes through), and the olive tapenade although good, overwhelmed the taste of the tomatoes - though the house-made ricotta was a nice touch for a creamy textural difference

duck rillette roasted cherry mostarda, rye toasts    8
this was my favorite dish, I love the ducky liver, so this duck pate, topped with a layer of duck fat and cracked pepper was fantastic then finished with the cherry mostarda - a deeply flavorful garnish, and eaten on rye toasts (the only change I would have made would make these toast points instead of Lincoln logs of rye bread that reminded me of dunking toast my mom used to give me with chicken soup when I got sick - presentation, and texture, nothing more) - other than that this was the cheapest and best part of the meal, and I'd like to think it was as 1950's as apple pie!

macaroni and cheese topped with bread crumbs    10
so we already know how hard a sell a good mac n' cheese is for me, given how great my sisters's is, and how MANY people attempt to make this dish (it's like the quick go-to comfort food dish for every restaurant), so I was surprised how good this one was. With 4 cheeses, and what tasted like a herbed bechamel sauce it came out pipping hot and completed our time travel meal

meatloaf shaved rainbow carrots, mashed potatoes, fried shallots    17

so if mac n' cheese is hard sell meatloaf might be worse for me, I'm very specific in what I like - I used to work with some real old school cutters (butchers) from David Berkeley that were local legends before the big box stores, so after finding the perfect combination of meats it's hard to taste anything else and find it good. I'll depart the secret to you: 1/3 82% ground chuck, 1/3 Italian pork sausage, 1/3 ground veal - finish it with tomato paste, mashed potatoes and greens. Every butcher I ask for this at Corti's, Whole Foods, Taylors, and Sampino's knows exactly what I'm talking about, this is what REAL meatloaf tastes like.

This wasn't quite that, as it was a full beef meatloaf, so a bit light on flavor/seasoning, but I loved the touch of the shaved carrots, and fried shallots, this made the meatloaf uniquely great for me.

Presidio Social Club
563 Ruger St (near Lombard Gate, in the Presidio),
San Francisco, CA 94129
(415) 885-1888
author: Charlotte K.

description:
Cool, fun, historic, and a bit loud.

I hosted a party of 14 at the large table by the bar on this my third visit here.  And while the third time may not have been the charm, it was still a good evening and fun was had by all.  We came here after a couple of hours hanging out at the Presidio Wine Bunkers drinking a few bottles from my stash,

The crowd is an interesting mix of locals, young singles meeting and greeting, formally dressed adults on the way to something else, families, couples, and maybe a hen party or two.  All through dinner the mingling was going on at the bar.  A small group of women met up with small groups of guys (I think one of the women approached them). A nice looking brunette in a black dress sat by herself for 5 minutes until a tall handsome man joined her (looked like a first date).  Two couples in tuxes and black dresses came in for a bottle of champagne before heading out.

The drinks are well made and one of the bartenders has been around the bay area a bit.  He's been written up in some local papers for his great martini's (with gin of course) and his unique Manhattans.

Food is comfort food with an SF twist and has never disappointed.  We ordered off the menu, not sure why some people say they had to order Prix fixe.  This was the second time I had a party of 10 or more on a weekend night, and both times we ordered off the menu.  Maybe their host was trying to control costs or something. And both times we were seated promptly, though our reservations were earlier (7 the first time and 6:30 this time).  And I made these reservations weeks in advance.

At our table we had trout, pork tenderloin, chicken, mac and cheese, sand dabs, flatiron steak, and a few other dishes.  All were good (according to those that got them).  We went for a few bottles of the house PSC Red after some cocktails and champagne.  Not bad.  And the bill was reasonable for a group that size.

The building has been around for a while and the placards outside share some of it's history.  And if you arrive in the early evening, park in back and walk in by the tennis court out back.  Someone will likely be playing.

The main room is pretty loud.  If you are here for some intimate conversation I would recommend asking for a table in the side room.  Not as good of a view of the bar, but a few decibels quieter.  And in nice weather they have a few tables on the patio out back.  Haven't sat there yet, so not sure if it is full dinner service out there.  

The only other issue was that service was a little slow.  This is mainly because the same waitress served the other large table of 14 up front also.  A little much for one person.

So only 4 stars, but 4 very well deserved stars.
author: Jeff H.

description:
I look forward to the old-school drinks, glassware and ambience here.

Their international nights have featured good food on the nights I've eaten there.  Overall, however, the daily-menu food for myself and my friends has been a bit bland or salty.  And even for SF, it's a little overpriced.
author: Mike H.

description: Disappointed to find the menu so reduced.  Salad of avacado and citrus was delish.  Meatloaf with mashed potatoes was only so-so.  The onion rings served on top were dreadful - canned would have been better.  Dessert only 4 choices.  Lemon cake with meringue frosting was the highlight of the meal.  Our server was only sighted a couple of times
author: Jeanne B.

description:
I had a chance to talk to the real manager (apparently Clay mentioned in my first review is an assistant... or something) and she was very apologetic, comped my dad's bill, and invited us back for another meal. We won't be returning anytime soon, but I really appreciated the gesture.

Although my interaction with the manager was great, I can't bring myself to upgrade from one star. Sorry PSC.
author: Kelly C.

description:
This place is our "Go To" brunch option. Due to its size, you're normally able to get a table right away. Lately we've found ourselves having to wait a bit, perhaps because it is gaining in popularity. You could always make a reservation if you don't want to wait and do a better job than we do planning ahead.

I would have given five stars, but they took our favorite item off the menu: biscuits and gravy. They also removed the biscuits from the Traditional Breakfast. :( PSC - please bring back the biscuits!

Its beautiful location and patio out back make it ideal for a sunny morning. All in all, it's a gem.
author: Alison K.

description:
We regularly eat Brunch here on Saturdays, before attending an event at the Walt Disney Family Museum.

Their food is always fresh and presented well.  I would not plan to eat here if you are in a rush, as the service is sometimes slow.  I'd also warn you that you pay per cup of coffee and glass of soda.  Everything we have had there is extremely tasty and has always met expectations.
author: Dave B.

description: Been here a number of times.  Truly overrated, don't get me wrong the food and service isn't bad it is just mediocre, hence a 3, but this is higher-end service of diner food which is sold at higher prices with ingredients that may not always be as up market.  The menu is ordinary, I looked it up and down multiple times and truly it is diner lot of basic fair, nothing wrong with that, but nothing stellar.  If a high-end diner is what you want with high prices, this is your place.
author: Des D.

description: It is my first time here and I did not know what to expect. Bartenders are great, i wish I could say the same about the host. I was planning on having a surprise dinner for my fiancee but that lady completely turned me off. Too bad. It could have been a great experience. We will be back, because the bartenders were good....
author: Thierry H.

description:
I went here for brunch and was pleasantly surprised by the ambiance, service and food. My table ordered a $30 bottle of Spanish white wine which was awesome and a few dishes for the table. The chicken and apple salad was our least favorite - there wasn't much chicken and the salad was like dry bristles. The eggs florentine was probably my favorite but the fried egg sandwich was also good. I really liked the fries. 

The best part was the beignets with a nice chocolate surprise in the middle dipped in white sauce. They were delicious!

Overall, the food was good and the restaurant on a nice day kind of makes you feel like you are on vacation. I would definitely go back.
author: Jenna Q.

description: Wow what a great place!! Food, Service, atmosphere, all great! $29.00 Wednesday crab special 3 course meal... Fresh cut "live" vegetables. Everything was outstanding!! Will be back for sure!!
author: Mr R.

description:
Well--I just popped in tonight for a glass of wine and to check out the atmosphere for future dining.  I sat at the bar and was greeted well by the Irish or Scottish (sorry I couldn't place him better) bartender.  I wasn't given a menu of wines by the glass but thought it would be safe to simply order a sauvignon blanc--only to find later it was far more pricey and less palatable than one I would have selected otherwise.  I decided to order a bowl of the soup of the day.  It was a very tasty vegetable soup...the only problem was, it was served in a plate with the edges curled up a bit.  I had a very difficult time eating the soup and if I hadn't been in a public location, I would have just drank the soup out of the plate/bowl.  I advised the bartender that the soup was wonderful but the bowl was a bit to be desired.  He seemed offended and stated that the bowl was the one the restaurant had selected and that it was "utilitarian"...to the contrary--I was advising him it wasn't.  So, other than being argued with over my suggestion of perhaps a better (or an actual) bowl, the atmosphere was wonderful and the soup tasty...if you can manage to actually partake.   

If the Presidio Social Club reads these reviews, they could offer this suggestion to their staff --when a patron makes a little comment, staff could very simply state that they'll advise the management.
author: Tess C.

description: My family rented out a private room at the Presidio Social Club for my post-City Hall nuptials. The restaurant itself is so fun! Very bright and open and the partition really helped to make the party feel as though we were in our own space. Everyone chose from a prix-fixe menu which had some very yummy options. Plus you can't beat the location. It's in the Presidio which means it's walking distance to some of the City's most beautiful sites. All-in-all my family had a great time and were pleased to have found this location.
author: Melissa P.

description:
THIS IS A REVIEW BASED ONLY ON THEIR THANKSGIVING PRESET MENU!
My family visited for Thanksgiving this year and I thought it a great idea to make rez at PSC for our holiday meal, as last year, my husband and I ate here and were perfectly satisfied. Not the case this time. My potatoes cold here and there, which made me think it was microwaved, the stuffing portion was really small and dry, the wine pairing was simply not good. The "family style" sides were also small, basic, bland.  I feel like we purchased cafeteria food at a very high cost...$50 a plate, plus $30 for wine pairing. Can't even call this meal mediocre. I feel guilty to have paid what we did for a family of 5....we could have fed an army of homeless and hungry with that money and honestly, we should have. I feel like a terrible person. 

I don't like to write bad reviews--but in this case, I will make an exception. I am really disappointed.
author: Rebecca R.

description:
I love the PSC. We come here about 4 times a year. 

this review is specifically for two things...
 - the pork shoulder - the meat falls apart as you cut it and just melts in your mouth. The most tender cut of pork that i have ever had. the flavors were spot on.
- the lemon meringue cake - light tartness paired with the sweetness of the meringue. the cake was moist, not heavy or dry as some cakes can be. this dessert was perfectly balanced.
author: jamie b.

description: This is really good comfort food. Nice ambiance. Nice service. Nice limited menu. We loved the mac & cheese. We really liked the pork - mmmm. Overall, we were very impressed and would happily return.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Every time I eat at this hidden gem it's a treat.  Great drinks, lovely staff, beautiful setting, and great food. I love the steak for 2, the vinegar chili sauce is O'mazing.  If you can make it for one of their clam bakes in the summer it is a must.  

PSC staff is also amazing at servicing a large groups.  If you have a large group of people and want a top notch experience look no further.
author: patrick m.

description: Presidio is a really cool place to go!  Very unique and great atmosphere.  We had a birthday party there and the manager was nice enough to give us some delicious donuts.  The staff was friendly and the food was delicious. Limited food choices...hard to decide and i'm not sure what exactly their 'theme' was.  But everything was pretty decent.  Drinks were good.  made an old fashioned pretty well and they had a lot of creative liquors.  All in all pretty good!
author: Phillip P.

description: Cant wait to go back and try more food and drinks! I love the atmosphere and the service is great. The food was fantastic but the cocktails are really where its at!
author: Amber M.

description:
The food here is delicious, it is billed as homestyle american cooking. Unfortunately, our service was extremely slow and I don't think it was because we were a larger group (we were 7), because the table of 3 next to us, didn't seem to move any faster. Our server was not as attentive as she could have been, there were definitely times when we were looking for her and she was clearly not knowledgeable about the wine, which was fine because instead of guessing she would go and find out the information; however, this took more time.
The food is delicious, I had a salad and the seabass special which were very good. Everyone was happy with their food.
author: Sharon R.

description:
Wow!  I live so close and I wish I had come here sooner.  We started with the sardines... from then on Macario took care of us.  They have great nightly specials.  We had the prime rib with a lovely bottle of Petite Syrah.

I want to point out how seamless our service was, we had a few courses, took our time and drank with each course.  Our bartender Macario was amazing!  My advice... check out the food and order a cocktail.  The ambiance is lovely.  Great view, great decor and music.

We will be back!
author: Laura G.

description:
Love this place! Old school, and classy. 
The hostess is pleasant and they do strive to accommodate your seating preferences. Some of the tables are very close together and conversations loud, so you might want to take that into consideration if you want to talk.
Great cocktails and comfort food with large portions. The specials are consistently good. I am a fan of the chicken livers which are not a common menu item. Meatloaf is popular and too much for one person to eat all at once.
The servers may "hover" a little too much if you take too long to order and frown if you just start with appetizers to share. 
Anyway it is lively, lovely, comfortable and I will definitely go back as the pros outweigh the cons.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
I love to stop in here after walking around the Lovers Lane trail in the Presidio. 

Staff and management are personal and friendly. The ambiance is warm and inviting with a touch of the city life combined with a hint of a Marin vibe. 

The appetizers are my favorite such as; crab sliders, kimchi pork minis, grilled cheese with tomato dip. Their homemade soups are  yummy. 

They have seasonal menus, always a plus. One unforgettable evening my husband and I split a whole fried chicken which was perfectly cooked (not greasy.) If you go for brunch I always opt for the bottomless mimosas!

Be sure to ask for the Dirty Dozen... no joke, its not on the desert menu but if its available its well worth the extra calories.
author: Danica S.

description:
My coworkers brought me to the Presidio Social Club for my goodbye lunch.  I had never heard of this place before, but I'm glad I got to enjoy this hidden gem before leaving the city.  

Although the view doesn't necessarily showcase mountains or water, the big windows along the dining room allow for a quaint look at the nearby buildings, roads, and nature of the presidio.  It's got a retro vibe to the place and looks like they would be able to serve up a mean cocktail.  

We certainly took the opportunity to indulge for this lunch and I don't think we had a single bad thing.  We shared an order of fries, cheese toasts with tomato soup, and chicken pate as appetizers.  We can't get enough of fries and I certainly can't get enough of delicious aioli, so +1 for PSC.  I'm a fan of grilled cheese and soup served in an espresso cup, but I could tell my coworkers were loving it more than I so I let them get the most of it.  But the pate.  I love pate.  I devoured those toasts covered in it.  Yes, it's an acquired taste, but if you're a pate fan, this one doesn't disappoint. 

I also had a bowl of their soup of the day (it was potato and was garnished with bacon, how could I say no?).  Also delicious.  Clearly homemade, clearly fresh, but also unique and so worth it.  Then I went for the mac and cheese as my entree.  Another hit.  Super hot, but super creamy with the right amount of bread crumb crunch.  

It pretty much sounds like we devoured a feast, which we pretty much did.  Coworkers tried the burger, beef carpaccio, and open faced crab melt which that all loved.  I definitely recommend checking this place out for a nice leisurely lunch.  You're in a historic building, out of towners would probably love this place, and for a moment you get out of the hustle and bustle of the modern day city.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
Many restaurants in San Francisco can boast consistently great food.
There are only a few, however, that can boast consistently great food and consistently fabulous service.

I had a friend that once said, " You can cook almost anything better at home; you go out to eat to be served."  This of course was long before we felt a need for the slow food movement.   For those of us who cook at home, and for those who are just starting to do so, we deserve great service to go along with our meal.  

The Presidio Social Club is the place to go for both.  If you request anything regarding your food or your seating arrangements, the service staff will do everything they can to make sure you get what you need.  What's more important, they always act anxious and happy to do so.  You don't feel that at any moment they will be running back in the kitchen to complain about you.

The menu is a delight.  Along with their own more sophisticated creations, they  offer many dishes that are at home favorites.  These are dishes that most San Francisco restaurants would feel beneath them to serve.  One of my favorites, are their deviled eggs.  They are a great way to start your meal.

I once saw a television restaurant make over show  host  yelling at a restaurant owner for offering deviled eggs on his menu.  He claimed that they were something your grandmother would serve.  I wonder, whose laughing now? ----certainly not Grandma.

A couple of my friends and I had lunch there today.  Two of us ordered a tomato fondue dish that was essentially marinara sauce with Burrata cheese and basil.  It was served with toasted bread, cut into long sticks.

Both of us are Italian-Americans, so this dish reminded us of a treat our mom's would give us when they were making tomato sauce  (gravy to my friend from the East Coast).   

When the sauce was simmering away Mom would give us a few spoonfuls on a saucer, along with a piece of bread for dunking.  What a surprise, to be served one of the tastiest dishes on earth, in a San Francisco restaurant overlooking the beautiful Presidio!

Our other friend ordered the PSC Hamburger.  She asked them to hold the bacon, and since the servers are  good listeners, they did.   The burger came with lovely thin cut French Fries, which we all agreed were delicious. 

I am giving the Presidio Social Club the MMF  Four Star Rating.  That translates into four stars for all four categories, food, service, ambiance, and pricing.  In Yelp terms that is 5 stars. When you decide to leave your kitchen and the dirty dishes behind, the Presidio Social Club is the place to go.
author: Michele F.

description:
I'm in love.

I cannot comment on the food, but OH! the bar!!! Every city needs one of these but I have a feeling it just wouldn't export very well.

We walked into the Presidio along the winding road under the lush, mature trees with the new but carefully and respectfully designed brick facades of the George Lucas Studios on the right. Then up the little rise to the low and unpretentious, yet confident Presidio Social Club presiding just that important little bit above George's newbie addition to the neighbourhood.  You know the Social Club owns the place.

So cool.  Looooong bar.  Palms and fans and stainless steel, slatted windows and white-jacketed bartenders.  Oh so cool.  I could hang here for hours.  EVEN by myself!  I know they were different eras, but it was like walking onto the sets of Dirty Dancing and Top Gun and something from 1940's Hollywood all at once!

The drinks.  I couldn't decide, so committed early on to ordering 2 (I'm an unfortunate light-weight).  But then it was so good I ordered the same one twice!  I had a pink lemonade - I recall limoncello, a dash of campari, myer lemon vodka - or more precisely, 2 of them.  Perfection.  

I needed an order of fries to manage the 2 drinks and they were respectable.  I'd like to try the menu, too.  Gotta love any menu that has drinks like this and the option to chase them with Sloppy Joes...

I'm in love.  And since I don't live in the city, it goes unrequitted...
author: Littlefish B.

description:
I really liked Presidio Social Club.  I wasn't sure what to expect but the food was all really good, great drinks (maybe on the smallish side), cool bar and decor, and really great service.  We went for dinner and we'd like to try brunch sometime as well.  I think we could take our 16 month old son here for brunch or early dinner.  I don't know why it wouldn't be good for kids.

We tried the fish and chips, pork shoulder, and special etouffe.  All fantastic.  The desserts were great too - especially the beignets!  Yum.  I want one right now.  The strawberry shortcake was really good but kind of a weird delivery system - it was in a bowl with way too much whipped cream.  Still delicious, just a little awkward to eat.

I would recommend it to anyone who wants some really nice comfort food or some good drinks in a cool atmosphere.
author: Karen N.

description:
AVOID LIKE THE PLAGUE!!

I have never been as underwhelmed as I was on Thanksgiving at Presidio Social Club.

The food was prepared so poorly that we left hungry and ordered a pizza from home later in the evening.

Coupling absolutely horrific food preparation (the pork in specific was at least 80% fat-the remaining 20% was poorly flavored and tough to chew---I can barely talk about it without gagging) with the temperature (must have been close to freezing in that building...my poor mother had to wear 3 jackets while we forced down the meal that will go down in history as the worst served to any of us collectively at the table to date) made for a very bad night of giving thanks.

I am so disappointed. There were SO MANY other fine establishments in Sf that could have happily housed us and fed us edible meals...but alas.
I am determined to let the world know how BAD of an experience we had.
I will never step foot in that restaurant again, I pray the same for you.
Still frowning...

Please make note.
author: Brooke H.

description: Another great dinner....chicken was wonderful! Thanks Mo! Another great evening, and so nice after a crappy day, to be treated with such generosity! We'll be back soon!!!
author: Thom S.

description: Breakfast was good, but it was a little pricey for what we got.  The menu was pretty limited and the scone was somewhat disappointing.  Nothing in particular stands out to me about this place.  It would probably be a fine place to go to with family or a group of people if you are able to make the reservations ahead of time.
author: Stephanie F.

description: My husband and I came for dinner on Thursday night and enjoyed our time immensely. The restaurant is one of my favorites because of the design and all of the pieces inside that contribute to the history. The cocktails were awesome. A friend recommended the Gunpowder, though it was not on the menu, the bartender made it anyway. We had the crab salad, excellent, the PSC steak, also delicious, and my husband had the beef liver and onions which he loved. To end our gluttony we washed all of this down with sea salt caramel ice cream sandwich. It had homemade marshmallows and plenty brittle. This dessert was a little piece of heaven. All of the staff were every friendly and warm. Even the hostess said thank you on the way out and I thought it was a nice way to bid us good bye. We will be back with our friends.
author: Jenna O.

description: 1 star. Underwhelming food, mediocre service for a crazy price. The hostess wouldn't seat us away from the kitchen door when we asked, even though the place was 80% empty. The server took 15 minutes to come to the table to introduce jomself and get our drink order. Then $18 for a shrimp salad that had so much mayonnaise that I physically couldn't eat it.  Then the server had a problem with our giftcard and told us we can call in to talk to the manager the next day. So for $70, we left hungry, feeling a little sick and quite depressed. As a local in presdio,  I will not be coming back. Very sad time. Was looking forward to brunch today. I'm not sure in what area I would ever be able to recommend this venue.
author: Jefferson T.

description:
I came here on a Sunday around 2PM after a recommendation from a friend (and prolific Yelper).  I wasn't really looking for anything in particular, the name had me curious so I really had no clue what to expect.

The atmosphere and structure of this place definitely made me feel like I was in another place or time.  I came here alone and sat at the bar, the bartender was friendly and made recommendations with prejudice- he essentially ordered my entire meal which consisted of:

Gin Fizz - some egg whites and other goodness that they serve in the AM- quite tasty
Gunpowder - Essentially a gin gimlet with ground cayenne pepper, tastes exactly as expected
Hamburger - He also recommended I get the bacon and onion saute - at $14 dollars I was sure to be disappointed and actually was not, one of the better hamburgers I've ever had- I was impressed

So I spent an hour and $41 and walked away full and happy. I'd definitely go back.
author: Jeff M.

description: It's really a shame that the Presidio Social Club has decided to continue to serve foie gras even though the ban has taken effect in California as of July 1, 2012.  We would stop at the PSC for drinks on occasion and have eaten there (though we were never that impressed with the food actually) and always thought it was such a nice little spot in the Presidio with a pleasant atmosphere.  Oh well...it's not like there aren't any other restaurants around.  So goodbye, Presidio Social Club.  We will be taking our business to restaurants that obey the law. :-)
author: Rabbit B.

description:
Almost as friendly as family, the Presidio Social Club offers hearty hellos from the beginning, delicious food, and the most undeniably wonderful back-to-the-past experience. It's pricey, but a treasure of an experience. I especially recommend dinner for the subtlies of the restaurant to be heightened.

 If you are as enamored with the 1930's (as I am), you will LOVE the room -- a long barrack decorated with large Palms, the subtle clink of glasses, dim lights, and attentive waitpeople who replace forks faster than you can bite. 

The row of windows which overlook the depth of  trees as well as a  free parking lot (a true luxury when you remember that the Presidio is inside the city) is really nice.  

There's also a long lovely bar which can be a waiting ground or a destination, and a back room for parties. Fancy drink menu with the old traditional 1950's-esque drinks support the atmosphere.
Now, the food: Not much for vegetarians, but there is seafood if you're one of THOSE vegetarians. 

There are several mainstays on the appetizer menu and a special of the night, (which in our case was abalone with black radishes, which was surprisingly delicious). We also sampled the small gruyere cheese toasts  with tomato dip: which is a fancy and delicious version of grilled cheese with tomato soup. Kind of like at Lime, (which I also love). Of the sandwich section, the winner for us was the Sloppy Joe -- sweet and tangy, and hearty: the BEST sloppy Joe ever! 

 Of the entrees which come with a side dish,  the fire roasted chicken with tomatoes was tender and juicy, but the winner for all of us was the side dish of mashed peas with mint. OHMYGOD, if you go to taste anything, get their peas with mint: a startlingly comforting and unexpected mash of fresh peas softly combined with just a few sprigs of mint. Amazing! It stole the show. 

And, that includes the way we felt about their desserts: esp. their chocolate made-to-order cupcakes (which have a fudgey hot center) or their Brioche Beignets (fancy doughnuts) which were piping hot  with cinnamon and sugar. Really good.You can get a mix and match of desserts like their (small) cookie plate for $10.

We loved our experience, but what boggled us, were the final questions: Which was better: the service, the food, or the atmosphere?  A lucky question to ask, now isn't it? It was an evening which filled our need for joy and not just our bellies.
author: Heather S.

description:
I liken my experience here to a first date that I'm REALLY excited about. Maybe it's a set up and I've heard all these GREAT things. I'm expecting to show up and just fall in love instantly, like Lady and the Tramp.

Kinda not what happened. I will say the atmosphere is ridiculously cozy and warm while still sticking with Presidio charm (I'm an ex-resident, I can appreciate). The service was very good. The food: I just wanted it to be soooo much better than it was. I dug the tiny grilled cheese sammy, the avo-feta dip was just ok and I chose the sloppy joe, based on its reputation, much like my friend who'd set me up would say, "You'll love this guy, Joe, I prommmise!" Sloppy joe was just average. The slaw on the side was awful: it tasted like it was attacked by Bottle of Vinegar and his accomplice Salt Shaker in a dark alley. 

I applaud the dessert tactic: very creative. Pick your own two or three or even order a side. Not the most inventive desserts (I vote Lime in the Castro for that) --- but A+ for theory and presentation. OK, the banana creme pie was awesome. 

All in all ... I just liked this place. *Maybe* I'd give it another try. But really, if you're not into the first date, is it worth a second???
author: Meredith R.

description:
We reserved the party room for our wedding reception without ever having tasted the food. We visited the restaurant and loved the space, so we went out on a limb and took our 25 wedding guests for what turned out to be a wonderfully amazing dining experience. Rather than over-cooked, dried out beef and salmon - which I would expect when preparing food for 25 guests - we received delicious meals that were perfectly prepared. The service was impeccable, and they even accommodated a friend with a chocolate allergy by bringing her an individual sorbet. My mother made napkin rings for the event, which the staff generously presented as part of the table setting.

I really could not have asked for a better experience, particularly considering we had no idea what to expect. The restaurant has a classy atmosphere that will impress even the most plebian diner. I highly recommend the space for special events.
author: meredith r.

description: Shitty food in an awful atmosphere with bad music. Menu is all over the place and the food is indistinguishable from a low-end chain diner. Don't waste your time here.
author: Faye S.

description:
Overall...underwhelmed and over priced.

Last night my husband and I went back to the PSC for our 10th time and was majorly disappointed.  The fried green tomato appetizer was fine.  But my main meal was lame!  I don't eat a lot of meat outside of Chicken and usually always go for the fish dishes.  Their ONLY daily fish dish was SOOOO blah.  I could have made it at home, and I am not a great cook!  I mentioned my disappointment to the waitress and she was nice enough to comp a small dessert.  My husband got their Fish of the Day which was better but still it was just ok.

Overall, I am sad to see the quality of their presentation and taste going down hill after so many great years.

The vibe and decor have always been a huge perk to their overall dining experience.
author: Sue W.

description: Great restaurant to keep in your back pocket when looking for a good meal in the area (and there's a big parking lot!). I've been here a few times and it never disappoints. The waitstaff is friendly and attentive and the food is always good. I really like sitting up at the bar because it's a little more laid back. Recently had the cheese toasts with tomato fondue which were really good.
author: Gina C.

description: Great place friendly efficient service. The food was great and the bar very nice. The building was a bit cold so have a sweater with you.
author: Steve T.

description:
