I love the whole concept and decoration of this place.It reminds me of " Restoration Hardware- furniture store", a bit vintage, a bit classy, a bit upscale. 

  Our server was very polite and neat.We came here for lunch which comes with lunch special menu. It was very reasonable (price).

We were a bit confused about their parking' signs and not even sure at first if we could park next to its building but later on we learned that the customer can park there.
author: Dom G.

description:
Really enjoyed the atmosphere of this place...not that I have any idea what a social club would be like back in the 40s...but I feel this place does effectively timewarp you back several decades.  Lighting is warm and the overall ambiance is airy and comfortable.

Waitstaff is friendly and attentive.  Menu is filled with good old-fashioned American fare. We had the chance to sample several items:  Tomato Bisque, Mashed Potatoes, Mac-And-Cheese, Flat Iron Steak...Everything was quite tasty.

The desserts however were really the highlight of the meal.  The frozen malt parfait and the chocolate cupcakes were mmm...mmm good!

Overall, this is a great choice for a mellow, laid-back evening...Check it out!
author: Justin L.

description:
We came here for brunch this past Sunday, and was not impressed. From talks of great food at this place through friends, I expected a bit more.  I'm all for simple dishes, but only if exceptional ingredients are used. Good ingredients make good food, and of course, a touch of technique and skill make the dish exceptional.  I feel like the ingredients could have been fresher, thus, making the dish blan and... typical - a couple stars.

If you're looking for a breakfast place around the Presidio, walk down to chestnut and go to Judy's.
author: Chieko H.

description:
This place could be so much better.

Went here for dinner with a group of 8. so I got to sample lots of different food and drinks.

Appetizers:
gruyere toast with tomato sauce - best dish of the night for me hands down
artichoke and feta dip with crostini - pretty good but didn't leave me wanting a second
shrimp fritters - also good

drinks:
gin mojito - meh i'll stick with rum
pisco punch - surprisingly good because of the refreshing factor
mai tai - bleh! strongest mai tai i've ever had
caiprinha - good but i've also had better. the ones my husband makes me at home is waaaaaay better
stella - probably the best drink i had there (haha!)

main courses:
scallops - sandy and sort of rubbery
prime rib - house of prime rib is better
oxtail burgers - i couldn't eat it because they didn't use burger buns they used buttermilk biscuits and it kept getting stuck to the roof of my mouth. they also had some salty fried stuff on the side with thousand island dressing on top that i wasn't fond off.
beef bourginonne - this was really good. i'd recommend ordering this for an entree if they have it on the menu

I was so full from sampling everything I didn't get a chance to try any desserts but many did sound appealling.

The service here was ok. Our waiter was inconsistent. He paid a lot of attention to certain members of i our party and tended to ignore others. I couldn't tell what he was up to. I asked him to take a pic of our grip and it seemed to annoy him. Whatever. The busboys though are really good.

I would recommend at least trying this place once since it is a bit different than the average restaurant.
author: Charlene C.

description:
This place is odd, and out of place.

We gave it a try for weekend dinner, but don't think we will be back. 

We were very surprised by the atmosphere as it felt very high schoolish.  A patron was on the phone at the table next to us for most of our meal, a third friend joined the two and squished into the two-top, like they were at a bar or a cafeteria. Service was casual as well, with a bit of attitude.

This place is so ultra casual, it is practically a university dining area. If you like that, you will like this restaurant. It's just not my cup of tea..
author: Mary W.

description:
We visited on a Sunday morning.  

Best Bellini I've had in the U.S. - hands down.

Best poached eggs florentine.

Love the well-thought out retro urban decor!

The bad news is the staff at the front desk x 2 were deeply involved in a scheduling matter, were both looking down intently so. and did not acknowledge us for about 5 minutes.  It wasn't until a 3rd hostess approached to ask if we needed to be seated that we went off with her.  The two at the hostess stand were unaffected by us standing there, and we were close to walking out.  

What recovered the lack of initial hospitality for us, was the service after that, the perfectly prepared food, and the surprise gesture of one of the bus staff.  He was so polite and gracious and not only asked how we enjoyed our meal, but thanked us for coming in and asked us to come back.  Well done.  He needs to be promoted and possibly replace the two ninnies at the hostess stand.....I'm just saying.

One star off for those initial lack of warmth in an otherwise ideal restaurant.
author: Molly C.

description:
This is the kind of place I would bring my parents to brunch since it's in a nice setting, spacious with plentiful parking and no wait.  The menu is small but covers all the basics.

We had the eggs florentine, frittata, beignets and bloody marys.  The bloody marys were nice and spicy.  The eggs florentine were on a biscuit that had a flavor I didn't care for.  My sister thought her frittata was good but had too many potatoes.  The beignets were ok but the chocolate dipping sauce made them much better.

Overall, the food was average but it was an easy and pleasant dining experience and sometimes that's enough.
author: Seong P.

description:
So hubby booked us for a Valentine's dinner here, and I had no real expectations. I totally saved my appetite, but our reservation was for 9pm (which is really LATE for dinner!) since we had to wait for the kids to be in bed before we could leave (and umm, no, we didn't leave them home alone). 

I came really hungry, and then kind of lost my appetite when I saw the actual prices on the menu. But hell, whatevs, it was V-day, so spending $ is probably OK just this once.... 

I ordered the salmon dish, which came with the oyster for appetizer. Well I don't even eat oyster at all, but I was so hungry that I had to eat it. It wasn't so bad, but looking back, I can't believe I did that. 

The salmon was VERY filling, it also had artichokes with it. I don't eat artichokes either but that damn hunger got me eating most of it off my plate. 

The dessert was OK but I don't like tart either, and that's what was in it. 

Hubby ordered some beef dish, and his was actually better. I would probably order that if we were to go back. 

We each ordered a pricey drink as well. Now I'm looking at the menu as I write this so I could be more specific with what I ordered but their website has a completely different menu from V-day. So it seems there is MORE food available! 

Actually, this menu on the website looks very appealing that I might want to come back again. 

And lastly, I just have to say the table arrangements in the small dining area we were seated in had a weird feng shui to me. We were seated right in front of the entry way to the dining area, so the traffic from the servers just kind of bothered me. I know they had jobs to do, but I think we could have been seated at another table (it wasn't crowded at all) or that table shouldn't be placed there at all.
author: Anio D.

description:
I recommend checking it out on a Sunday, when Off the Grid is happening on the lawn outside.  Located in the east part of the Presidio, this under-the-radar establishment is nestled and nearly blends into the Presidio-style white military housing. This one level restaurant doesn't look like much when you're walking up, but the moment you're inside there's a warm, homey but still classy ambiance. If you have to wait for a table, saddle up to the long bar and grab one of their classic cocktails. We stuck with the wine last time, which isn't the longest list of options but has some good West Coast choices.

After being seated, we started with a variety of the small plates. One of their best offerings is the deviled eggs, topped with caviar. Nothing makes one feel more decadent than a little caviar! We also got a half order of the oysters, which vary by week. The island style tuna poke doesn't seem to fit with the rest of the menu, but is pretty good. Unfortunately it's took many chips and not enough poke. Outside of the eggs, my top recommendation would be the grilled cheese, made with gruyere and buttered. It comes with a little soup cup of warm tomato fondue to dip. While this sounds simple, it's hard to hate a classic comfort dish prepared by professional chefs. Before the meal we also tried the chopped kale salad (we're in California, it's not a meal without some kale). With carrots, radish, golden beets, toasted sunflower seeds and topped with sherry vinaigrette, it was far more flavorful than it sounds.

For dinner, I split the oven-roasted bone-in ribeye, which specifically says it's for two people on the menu. Now, being from the Midwest I can take down my fair share of meat. However, I feel I can safely recommend that this dish be easily split by 3 people. They come present the ribeye to the table before taking it back to the kitchen. Bone-in, it looks like something they toss the T-Rex over the fence in "Jurassic Park." Sliced up and served with roasted potatoes and glazed sweet onions, it fills up a large serving platter.  The quality of the ribeye is superb and the seasoning rub on it protects that quality while adding flavor. I highly recommend this for any meat lovers. I actually found it to be much better than the meat I had at the famed House of Prime Rib. We ordered some sides for the meal, as we clearly did not already have more than enough food. The French fries are good but nothing to write home about. The mac and cheese, topped with bread crumbs is a much better option. As far as vegetables go (have to be a little healthy), the whole carrots done in sherry and honey are sweet but not overly so. Because when it comes to sweet, you have to save room for a bit of dessert. We finished up with the blackout sundae, which feels like a deconstructed s'more platter with ice cream and homemade marshmallows.

For diners on the lookout for a more affordable meal, they offer weeknight supper specials, which is 3 courses for $29 but you have to go with the entrée of the evening. Right now I recommend Tuesday, as it is simply described as "small fried things."
author: Larisa J.

description:
I've heard they have new owners - so we went again to see what the fuss is about.  Unfortunately, it seems that the new owners don't really have a grasp yet :-(  The service was way slower/less attentive than what we've had before.  The worst, though, is that the menu was sliced in 1/2 - maybe more!  It's sad, we really loved this place and loved taking people there for delicious dinners.  

Luckily, I can get regular updates as to their progress since they have Tuesday happy hours that my fiancé attends regularly.  If they get their business straight, we'll be back.  It's a shame b/c their food was so delightful.
author: Heather L.

description:
-Disinterested, extremely slow service. 
-Solid fried chicken but not worth $19. 
-Overpriced cocktails and wine...hell, the entire menu is overpriced across the board. 
-And did I mention they were out of their famous cupcakes? 

Yeah, I won't be rushing back to Presidio Social Club anytime soon.
author: phil h.

description: Lovely location, parking is great, and the food has improved enormously over the last two years or so.  Nice deck for when the sun is shining.  Very friendly staff...
author: Martin B.

description:
Like taking a cab into the Presidio, you're more likely to get lost than be taken to just the right spot. Aside from the historical significance, it's monochromatic, boring... and $$.

My Mom's Sloppy Joe's drove a fondness for mouthfuls of meat.... haha, too bad PSC just can't deliver the same goods.
 
I'd spice your own sloppy meat and use the $17 @ the REAL Presidio Social Club... a.k.a. The Presidio Bowl... at least you'll play with some balls, maybe a little dance-dance revolution, and drink out of bowling-pin shaped Bud Lights. 

Save the mouthful of meat for home, and bring on the balls and beer!!!
author: Courtney B.

description: Outside seating on a sunny day; also try the Painkiller drink...
author: Ryan K.

description:
Ugh! My mom really wanted to check this out as a wedding venue so I thought alright why not? The social director was outrageously snobby!! We met with her and discussed the event looked at the venue etc etc. The rooms were dark and smoky smelling. The bar was small and sad, the table settings were hideous and everything looked like it was in a retirement home. 

Then at the end of the meeting she says, "Well for the date you've chosen, you would have to spend $XXXX to meet our minimum and I don't think that would work for you." Umm is she implying we can't afford it??

 So she takes our info and says she will call us if our event is approved then we would need to be sponsored by an "actual" member of the club. What is this? Is this a restricted club? We are here to give you business, I looked at your "event" book and lady you don't have any "events" booked.

Then a little over a month after that meeting, with no calls no emails no response from my emails, she calls and says "We have another event planned that day so we could squeeze you in along with them" also she said something to the effect of we wouldn't have to pay as much now that they were taking the hit. 
Lady get a grip you work at a retirement home with a bar.
author: sophie p.

description: My rating has changed because the menu has changed since back in the day. The best items are still desserts :) Ask for the "dirty dozen." It's not on the menu...
author: L L.

description:
I thoroughly enjoyed my experience here, it was incredibly relaxing.  Surprisingly not too busy on a Saturday, despite the fact that when I went, it was Labour Day Weekend.

The atmosphere throws you back.  Solid wood tables and nifty little lightbulbs, with this bright yellow neon filament.  So cute and kitschy!

The lemonade: perfectly refreshing and not cloyingly sweet.  Free refills?  Oh yes, please!

For lunch, I ordered the Grilled Cheese and Tomato Soup.  I wish that grilled cheese was a little bit larger.  Was so hungry for more and my lunch was over much too fast.  It comes with a side salad, which I thought was a little sour.  Didn't matter much though - was much more entranced with the real stars of the show.

And DESSERT.  Oh!  Brioche Beignets!  With that Spicy Mexican Hot Chocolate!  MMMMMMM.  Warm and sweet, good airiness and chewy texture.

My group also ordered a second dessert, the Warm Blueberry Crumble Tart.  Still good, as I recall, but I was too busy lapping up those beignets and downing the rest of that Hot Chocolate sauce...
author: Carolyn L.

description:
The restaurant (that was once one of the old barracks) was filled with all kinds at PSC. People in business suits, bicyclists, old , and the young so that has to be a good sign. 

The cuisine is more of a comfort food here. There are healthier items on the menu but the stuff that screams your name are other items like The Kobe Beef Sloppy Joe with the club fries and pickled cabbage.
The bay shrimp corn fritters are also very tasty.
The PSC is a throwback to an earlier time when the bartenders wore white coats and martinis were served in smaller glasses.
Very cool decor and also some one of a kind art displayed around the restaurant. 
We were too full at the end of our meal to try the desserts so we will have to go back w/ a bigger appetite.
author: Emily B.

description:
Went here for dinner with some colleagues last week. Great ambiance, great service. Food was good. Nothing spectacular, the menu isn't very vegetarian friendly, but great selection of fish. My colleague had a car, but we took a taxi back to my hotel.

Worth another trip back, when I have access to a car. I really wish the weather in SF gets above 80, this place would be amazing to enjoy outdoors for a late summer evening dinner.
author: Helen B.

description: Absolutely exquisite brunch.  Eggs Benedict, Croque Madame and Crab Salad were all fantastic.  Off the menu "dirty dozen" are also great for a group - warm doughnuts filled with chocolate (although the name is a little misleading - there's only 6).  Highly recommend.
author: Brandon B.

description: I have been going to PSC since it opened...a SF fave.  Last night I went to dinner with friends and my feelings are now mixed.  The food was very good, but the service was sloppy at best...all forgiven since it was a busy night.  The manager at the front desk however was so rude-from the way he addressed us upon arrival to the way he answered me when asked a question about the bill-we were not charged correctly.  Why work in this profession only to treat regular customers poorly? Thinking he's a new addition to the staff, but I felt so unwelcome, I won't be back.
author: Stella J.

description: Hadn't been there in a while so thought we would try it. Took 11 minutes from being seated for anyone to come over with water or drink offering.  Server put off when we ordered, but as we returned attitude, she lightened up.  Unfortunately, she remained inattentive (had to flag her down for 2nd drink, dessert order, etc.).  All food served lukewarm, which was surprising, but flavor very good.  Two stars for service and lukewarm food.
author: Jim B.

description: Salad was the best I've ever had (avocado vinaigrette with arugula and chicken was AMAZING). Service could use a little improving (wait staff was too absent and then too present, chef forgot our food at first, and the "smile" factor of the hostess was not great... She helped out in the end, but wasn't very nice about it). Nice back patio area. Great for brunch.
author: Katherine L.

description:
Gosh how chill and yummy! Never heard of this place until UrbanDaddy sent out the clambake info (every Monday for the rest of the summer). So we hopped on over there for the clambake and discovered other yummies too. The structure is the enlisted men's barracks. It's so very 'Dirty Dancing' on the inside, like a hip summer cabin. Service was good.

The chile spiked roasted corn was yummy, the calf's liver was excellent (watchout, it comes with ginger even though that's not mentioned on the menu). The clambake is mussels and clams and potatoes steamed en papillote with corn on the cob and half a lobster. Everything was tasty but the lobster was outstanding - super juicy and tender. 

Loved the brioche beignets (although the mexican chocolate they came with tasted like sour milk) and the butterscotch pudding was fine.
author: Marina N.

description: I went here recently for a holiday lunch. The space was nice and felt open and you didn't feel like weren't sitting on top the the next diner. It was the day after a Xmas feast and I was in the mood for something lighter. We has the Citrus Salad to share and honestly, it was just ok, kinda small. I had the kale salad with chicken for my main and I was delighted with my order. It was light, and had the right amount of crunch (not too crunchy....as many kale eaters know kale can be a little tough if it isn't handles well) Overall, I'd return just for that salad.
author: Mimi N.

description: Had dinner at the bar, Danielle,the bartender, was fabulous. We had the lamb shank special and sole, sautéed spinach and a butter lettuce salad. Food was great, drinks exceptional, service the best.
author: Walt P.

description: A class act all the way. Fantastic service and delicious food. The ladies room is freezing!
author: Molly E.

description:
Spruced up army barracks that retains some of the original archtectural feel. 

Bartenders are pros & the mixed drinks are good. No blenders at the bar, the House Margarita is on-the-rocks. 

We had just a few plates of appetizers. All were tasty. 

We got there at 4:50 pm on a Monday, so there was parking available in front of the building and the dining room was just starting to fill. By 5:30pm the place was crowded pandemonium. 

Michael Bauer just reviewed this place in the Chronicle Sunday Magazine with several photos, check out his review on line. 

I'm not Ga-Gah over the food, the scene, nor the location, but it is a fun destination IF you do not have to work too hard to get inside.
author: Tom S.

description:
Horrible service. Rude staff.  Awful experience. 

7:00 PM reservation.  We did not receive our drinks until after 7:30 PM. The waiter said that the bartender was "behind" however the restaurant was not completely full. We had not even been asked for our dinner orders until 8:00 PM- 1 hour AFTER our reservation.  The hostess also THREW an additional menu at one of us as she arrived a few minutes later than the rest.  We decided to leave after an hour of horrible service and had an AMAZING dinner at Liverpool Lil's across the street. Would not recommend.
author: Kate L.

description: Good service, beautiful outdoor dining on sunny day in SF. Strawberry Bar dessert was like eating a ice cream cake. Hope it becomes a regular dessert item. Meat loaf was a hugh meal and comforting.
author: LQ W.

description: Maybe we just ordered the wrong thing but then again, none of the entrees should really be "wrong".  I had the liver and onions and my husband had the burger - both were listed as PSC classics.  While the chef accommodated my request for a vegetable instead of potatoes, the liver itself was very unevenly cooked.  Several bites were so raw and mushy that I couldn't get them down while the other end of the liver was overcooked and dry.   It was a busy lunch time so by the time the waiter checked back with us, I didn't have enough time to request a refire of the dish.  My husbands $15 hamburger was more like a $5 hamburger - small in size so that without the generous portion of fries, he would have left hungry.  Expected something a little more gourmet for $15 and certainly a more substantial portion.  It is a difficult location to get to so I don't think we'd go out of our way to give it another try.  Too many really good restaurants in nearby Cow Hollow.
author: E A.

description:
I came here first with my bf and some of our friends.  I had heard such good things about this place but became skeptical upon reading yelp reviews.  I mean one of y'all compared this to Applebee's!  Seriously? Have you been to Applebee's?  No.  PSC has great food, killer cocktails, and a relaxing atmosphere.   Applebee's has a microwave and little league baseball team screaming in the corner.  

Anyway, we walked here from our friends' place in the marina and had a drink at the long bar while waiting for our table.  The bar had a good vibe so we decided to enjoy our cocktail there before being seated.  The hostess had no problem with this.  Once seated, I felt like I was so far from the City.  The airy feel of the restaurant and the lush green of the Presidio is a nice change of pace.  When it was time to order food, the hits of the table were the meatloaf and the brioche beignets ( we would skip on the lobster bisque and chocolate cupcakes).   And oh-so-many "Preakness"  Manhattans.  

We actually had such a great time that I booked another reservation a few weeks later when my family was coming to town.  My sister is in a wheelchair and this was such a good option for us as we were able to drive to the restaurant.  Our group of 9 were seated at the awesome wooden table towards the front of the restaurant.  As my sister's flight was delayed, 3 of the 9 in our party were about a half hour late.  The hostess didn't get upset and we still got excellent service even though we didn't sit down till 9 pm.  

Overall, I love the food and have had great experiences here.  Good for friends, dates, and family (sans kiddos) get togethers.
author: Meagan C.

description: Good service and wonderful food.  I loved the meatloaf and the mac & cheese was really good, too.  Comfort food seems to be a strong suit here.  I also had an excellent glass of cabernet from Rutherford.  Eating outside on a sunny day with all the trees, you almost forget you're in San Francisco.
author: Otto D.

description: they had foie gras, but didn't they didn't know how to prepared it, too salty, not seared, mushy http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/U1nNL9ur-0RO7gROm9PpOw?select=w3YtX0LbPcf0XsdQWGXKXw#K-YI5qbbSJshxw0EY_ROtg. other food was okay. prices were high.
author: Phuc B.

description: The food was nothing special. I should have sent back the veal piccata because it was heavily crusted and cooked to cardboard. It had a little drizzle of lemony butter on it. The English pea soup special consisted of overcooked gray peas with little ginger or curry flavor. Our waiter had to go around the table and repeat each person's order for every drink and course. He then kept interrupting our conversation to ask if everything was OK. We did send back the lukewarm coffee for a hot cup of joe. A further complaint is the ridiculously high prices for such mediocre food. I hear their specialty drinks are good so just enjoy the bar and go somewhere else for dinner.
author: Barbara F.

description:
Great place to escape the city hubbub amongst older Presidio-ites on weeknights and for early inners.  Later in the evening, it becomes a chill, classy place for a date or a quiet-ish dinner.

Wait service is professional and friendly in a way you don't see very much.  Foos is good.  Sometimes, there's not enough of it (as with the clam bake).  Not speedy with getting the food out, but you're supposed to talk, relax and have a drink first, right?

Just don't show up starved:)
author: Lauren J.

description:
My Dad is from France and he and my Uncle used to own a successful French restaurant in downtown San Mateo, so I grew up around French food, foie gras, and celebrating Bastille day. I have to say that the food I got was amazing. Like, " Hmm, would I remain in forced celibacy just to have a chance to eat this again?" kind of amazing. And yes. Hands down. My Mom and I got the Bastille day special- rib eye for two with foie gras on top. Yes, as someone else posted, seared foie gras would have been better, but considering you can't get it that easily anymore and they only serve it underground at various restaurants, this beggar was not a chooser. It also came with a butter lettuce salad with the dressing done very nicely, just like how my family used to make, and a bottle of rose ( the accent on my keyboard doesn't work) and profiteroles. Now I don't really like rose or profiteroles AT ALL, so I wasn't looking forward to them, but the rose really wasn't that bad, and the profiteroles which came with and were filled with candied pistachios and caramel sauce were also delicious, and made me think that not all cream puffs were created equal after all. The rib eye was cooked perfectly to order, and the demi-glace... oh my the demi-glace. It made me question how every restaurant I'd eaten at in the past year was doing their's because PSC's was perfect. It wasn't too thin or watery, or too thick and gravy like, and had the beef flavor perfectly infused. You know, like demi-glace is truly supposed to be. It also came with a portion of frites that were light and crisp. They offer you a bunch of sauces but between the delicious flavoring of the meat and the glace, I didn't even use mine. 

I also found the service to be just fine. It was easy to make a reservation, and they called me the night before to confirm. Overall they were just really pleasant. There was a significant period of time in between courses, because there were 3 of them, but they include a bottle of wine, so my Mom and I actually appreciated the time in between, to talk and catch up, without feeling rushed or pressured. The whole experience really reminded me of my time spent in Europe and with family, and it was truly perfect. Seeing as how some other people went on the same night and are giving it one star, I really can't speak to how consistent PSC is between tables, but I know I will definitely be back at some point.
author: Hannah W.

description:
The PSC boasts a beautifully classic vintage atmosphere. You really do feel like you've been transported to a bygone era of elegance and class.
Coming here for a friend's birthday brunch celebration, we were treated warmly by the staff, who took care of a couple of our special needs with no problem. I ordered the biscuits and gravy which came with the most delicious gravy I may have ever had. The mix of chorizo and rosemary just made it perfect, and my bloody maria (with tequila and jalepenos for extra spiciness!) was a fantastic companion beverage.

Lazy Sundays were made for places like this!
author: Caddy M.

description: Went to this establishment with our daughter and son-in-law tonight.  We had a 7:00 reservation and were not seated until 7:45.  There was no place to sit while waiting and the only thing offered to us was a stale plate of nuts that we had to hold in our hands.  If you're hungry, don't bother going.  Never again.
author: anne l.

description: On the pricey side, but very good food. Fun, upbeat atmosphere if you're just interested in drinks and hanging out. Their mac and cheese is delicious!
author: Kim T.

description:
Went here on a sunny Thursday which is great - has great large windows to let some light in.

I had the feeling this is an older crowd place (I'm 26).  Just didn't have a hip/foodie vibe to it.  The food did not impress, but the drinks made up for it.

Moscow Mule - Ginger beer, vodka - delicious

Fish of the day - marked at 'market price' - when we asked - halibut for $28 which is FINE, but not when everything else on the menu is below 20.  It bugs me - you know most people are embarrassed to ask price, so they don't and they assume around the avg of your menu.  I get if price changes day by day here, but then buy a fish and mark it close to yoru menu prices.

There wasn't a lot of options - wanted seafood so looked at crab louie sandwich - i saw it come by and looked like it was served on a hot dog bun.  No thanks. I had hte crab cake sliders with a side order of fries.  The two star description sums it up nicely - meh, i've expereinced better.

Service was fine - good friendly host.  Just was not blown away here.
author: Sarah G.

description:
Alright so maaaaaybe it wasn't the best pick for a romantic dinner date. And maybe it was more of a family style place.

But it was damn good people watching! Between the cocktail menu, groups of twenty-somethings, elderly group to our left and kids coloring to our right we weren't sure if we had come to a cool place for cocktails and a bite to eat or an upscale Applebees.

The fish of the day (rock cod) was light and fresh, as were the mojitos. And I'd say the Mac n Cheese ranks better than Liverpool Lils and Jovino, and might be either on-par with or better than Tipsy Pig's.
author: Brianna H.

description: Great location, but mediocre food and service. Menu is boring and unfocused, food is bland / tasteless. Service was terrible and slow despite having ~50% of tables free.
author: Michael B.

description: This is a great place.  I've been for an afternoon lunch with a friend (very tasty) and for a wake following another friend's passing.  They did an amazing job for our private party and I would recommend them for small or large events.
author: Leigh F.

description:
What happened? This used to be one of my favorite restaurants, but the new menu, and the overall quality of the food, were a big disappointment the last time I ate here. 

PSC was all about serving 1940s/1950s classic supper club dishes. (Think liver & onions, sloppy joes, and smashed peas.) Well... no more. Instead, the menu is a much smaller, and boring, selection of dishes that could generically be described as "American." As in, I can find it anywhere. A few token items from their classic menu are still around (endive salad, meat loaf), but the dishes that made PSC unique are gone.

The food itself was mediocre at best. I ordered the hamburger, and it was dry and mostly flavorless. (How is it even possible to wreck a burger?) My partner ordered the sole, a dish that would never see the light of day in the classic menu, and it too was bland and uninteresting.

The bar, thank God, maintained is usual standards of cocktail excellence and the service/ambiance were as great as ever.

I'm going to give PSC one more try, but really hope to see a revived menu and kitchen on my next visit.
author: Mark S.

description:
I had the hamburger and fries.  The fries were crispy and perfectly seasoned.  The burger and carmelised onions were very good.  My wife and daughter had eggs.  Each commented how perfectly cooked they were.   Bacon was ordered crispy.  Amazing how many places can confuse crispy bacon with "burnt".  Crispy bacon was perfect.  Also had fresh granola that was just that -fresh and fruity.

Nothing we ordered was complicated, but my conclusion is that the folks in the kitchen here know what they doing.  We will go back here.
author: Bill F.

description:
What a fabulous day to sit on the patio with Asta (my dog) and friends sipping a wonderful Bloody Mary!  

The Presidio Social Club makes their own bloody mary mix, and - having had my share of Bloody Mary's - this one definitely ranks at the top of this list!

I am not a big meat eater, but I had the burger with gruyere cheese - excellent!  and with a sour pickle! 

Notably, they have a very nice patio (in the back garden away from car fumes and traffic noise!) that is dog-friendly!  Wonderful on a sunny day like today!

The tomato soup and gruyere grilled cheese sandwich combo also is a favorite.

The music is 1940's and 1950's style to help put you In the Mood!  That's a good thing, as the service was a bit slow.
author: Laura P.

description:
Congrats to Pat & Jen!!!
Dinner Rehearsal was amazing. Service was outstanding. Let me tell you about the food...

Clam Chowder - it was okay. Needs a shake of salt & pepper. 
Fries - AMAZING!!!!
Chicken - omg...seriously its a serving for 2. The chicken was tender & juicy, served with mash potatoes.
Seared Tuna - omg...again its a serving for 2. The tuna was cooked right.
Chocolate Mousse - too sweet but I love the candied nuts on top. 

enjoyable & intimate for the occasion
author: K L.

description: I recently had a big dinner party here for my husband's birthday. The reservation was originally for 14 people, but 3 extra people decided to come last minute. They were very accommodating and added a side table to the end of the main dining table we had reserved. Overall it was a great evening. We had the table for several hours and did not feel rushed. The food was delicious, although not a lot of choices on the menu - especially for the few vegetarians and vegans in our party. The one drawback was that the service was a little spotty. We had one waiter who would disappear for long periods of time. We probably would have ordered a lot more drinks if we could have found our waiter!
author: Daria H.

description: Very nice atmosphere and awesome outdoor deck. The brunch food was decent, but nothing amazing. Pretty sad looking fruit plate for a nice restaurant like this. I think the dinner menu may be better here, but I will have to come back and check that out.
author: Scoot S.

description: My boyfriend and I live close to the Presidio Social Club and have walked over often for brunch and dinner and have frequently recommended the PSC to friends.  We invited guests from out of town to dinner on Friday night.  I made reservations for four.  Upon arrival, our guests were spoken rudely to by the hostess because they were unsure if I had made a reservation and then, upon confirmation of the reservation, they were denied a high chair for their 9 month old because a baby had not been included in the reservation.  We spoke to our server and she provided one for us.  The service was slower than usual and the food was just okay this time.  I don't think I will be recommending the PSC in the future based on our experience on this occasion.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Headline: Some highlights, but overall just another average place.

We were getting a group of old friends together for dinner.  I blame my friend Chris for this choice.  This place did not live up to the billing.  It's meant to be a supper club without the membership fees, but it was not really a supper club ambience, and I could have purchased a membership for the price of a meal.

Since Chris is always late, we started at the bar and ordered roasted calamari.  This is a nice alternative to the fried calamari that is almost always greasy.  This had bold bright flavors.  There was a little too much vinegar in the sauce, but overall a very good dish.  The service at the bar was wonderful.  We loved the chit-chat that the bartender engaged in with us.

Once the other three friends arrived, we ordered gruyere cheese points.  Think a grilled cheese sandwich, and it came with a small expresso sized shot of tomato soup.  Five stars for this dish - it was warm, gooey, and oh so good.

I ordered cream of asparagus soup to start - nice enough, and fit the bill, but the croutons were soggy, which was disappointing.

For the main course, I ordered calves liver.  This is normally a mistake because most places over-cook it.  Here it was a nice medium rare, served over mashed potatoes and had a very tasty chimichurri sauce spooned over the liver.

My wife had the lamb special of the month - two roulades, which were overcooked, and wrapped without trimming the fat.  This was a major disappointment.  It was served with farro, which was soft-cooked and tasty, and smashed peas with mint - way too minty - it was like eating toothpaste.

To finish off, we ordered a bunch of desserts.  I had the strawberry rhubarb tart with honey ice cream.  The ice cream had a very very strong honey flavor, but it was grainy.  The tart had a nice flaky crust, but the filling was tasteless.

So, there were some highlights, but this doesn't rate anything special - too many problems with the dishes.
author: Adrian H.

description: My sister and I took our parents for dinner to PSC on Saturday night. We were a party of 5 with a reservation at 6:30pm. We were seated in a noisy dining room. My father is hearing impaired and has two hearing aids. My sister asked if we could be reseated in a quieter place. The hostess told us we could not because the restaurant was booked solid for the evening. When I went to the ladies room, what did I observe but many, many empty tables in the quiet main dining room!!!  It's this kind of lack of accommodation and generally poor customer service that is so disappointing.  The food also was not very good.  My sister ordered the "whole fish of the day" - a grilled petrale sole and it was not even filleted!  She had to pick the meat off the bones! I could live with the bland food but I will never recommend PSC after they way treated my father.
author: Elizabeth M.

description: After entering a near empty restaurant on a Monday afternoon we stood waiting 3-4 minutes waiting for someone to acknowledge our presence. Finally we were seated. After waiting more than 10 minutes for a server we finally gave up. You can ignore someone else with your rude inconsiderate EMPTY restaurant.
author: Bryan C.

description: A fun place that has great food and good service. I ordered the mac and cheese (odd, I know) and it was terrific! It had a nice breaded layer on top and everyone from my table made sure to have a bite. Not sure if I would eat here again considering all the possible options in San Francisco, but definitely not a bad experience.
author: Sophia D.

description: Worst brunch food I've ever had in SF. Challah bread tasted like it was a week old. Chilaquiles tasted like raw lime juice. Crappy cappuccino. Friendly service though.
author: Rahul B.

description:
Oh Presidio Social Club. I do love thee.

PSC has become a staple. Mostly because I hang out a lot with my friend Sacha. And Sacha is practically married to this restaurant.

I get it. There's ample parking, great cocktails, and great comfort food. Kind of makes you feel like you're back in the '50s.

Brunch on the back patio, when it's sunny outside, is divine. And, it's the kind of place where you can actually hear people. I like that.

My boyfriend and I did get food poisoning from a burger we shared there, though. So I've got to deduct a star. But to be fair, we ordered it medium rare. 

In general, the reliability of this place makes it a go-to.
author: Alicia K.

description:
Finally, they decided to open for lunch. My friend and I hopped over here for a quick bite. So entice by their mouth-watering menu, that we decided to share the entree items. 

I started with the Blueberry Lemonade. Cool, great refreshner for a warm sunny day. We shared the Pull-Pork Sandwich and Open-Face Tuna Melt. The Pull-Pork Sandwich was just ok for me. Plenty of shredded pork but there was too much bread. I felt the pork could of used a bit more flavor. The Tuna Melt was delicious! Melted cheese, over tuna salad topped a buttery-grilled toast. Yum! Both sandwiches came with home-made chips which were very good and not greasy. 

Ended the luncheon with the Benigets (fried doughnut type treats) w/ a shot of chocolate goodness...HEAVEN!

Will definitely come back again for their comfort food dinner menu...
author: Dee T.

description:
I can't believe this place isn't more packed! The parking is insanely good. There was no wait. The prices were right. The food is good. What else could you want? My only criticisms: the brunch menu was very limited (though okay) and the coffee is that strong sort that everyone except me seems to prefer. The decor is great...it's a former barracks! The chairs are even comfy. Seriously...this place should be JAMMED. What's up SF? 

I had the GI Jose Special and my dp had the Cream Biscuits with Sausage Gravy. Both were good. 

The lunch menu looked appealing, also. I'll definitely go back.

We were practically the only people in the whole place. Seriously...this place deserves more clientele. Give 'em a try!
author: Karen Z.

description:
Oh my - - I love this place for lunch but I swear every time I go for an alternative universe (aka meal at any other time) it's  a C-.  Boo.  

Location is great, vibe is great, you always want this place to be a home run and then it disappoints. Unless it's lunch.   Went for dinner about four months ago with out of country and state guests - 'meh' as yelp says.    Came in from a cross-country flight last night and we decided hey - it's Valentines' Day - it's gorgeous in SF - lets' take along walk and enjoy an amazing morning and brunch.  So far so good. but then Meh again.

No reservation, they take us only if we sit at the bar. Ok - we can accept that.

We sit down at the bar and the bartender proceeds to serve water before we can say no. He doesn't ask if we want it and  he has no clue there is a drought going on in CA. WRONG WRONG WRONG.  Maybe he doesn't care.  Before I can see the water arrive without being asked I say - no thank you, hoping he'll take it back before i accept it.  Instead he says OK and throws the water down the sink and puts the glass to wash. Geez - I'm thinking = really?  You threw water I didn't ask for down the drain and then threw the clean glass for a wash. Aren't there plants that need watering somewhere nearby at least? Must you waste? If every restaurant in CA did this our drought would be 10x worse. It makes me sick to my stomach to see how he wastes. 

We ordre a belini and bloody mary - delish.

Then we review the brunch menu (mind you it's 10 a.m.) and it reads like a heavy lunch. Where is the fritttata? Where the omelet?  awful.  Lamb, hamburger, no items that resemble anything like a morning meal.  We persevere and make shift. 

Hubby orders green eggs and ham (kale, ham, poached egg) I order the croque monsieur.  They arrive in 5 minutes.  His poaches eggs are kinda warm - (made beforehand) my croque is something to croak over.  I'm sorry - nothing lightly battered. I had two pieces of white bread with no toasting whatsoever, with a fried egg on top that also looks like it was pre-cooked and super crusty edges, barely warm.  The béchamel sauce tastes like glue - white flour gravy-like that felt like a truck stop.  I look between the two slices of white bread and find ONE - slice of finely sliced ham and one slice of swiss cheese. Nothing melt in your mouth and nothing that resembles anything I've had anywhere near France or in France including in NY. Not being a food snob but if you are going to serve a french dish do it right.  Normally lots of finely slices yummy ham, some cheese, the bread dipped in egg and deep fried, melt in your mouth, some powdered sugar, egg. - all gooey and yum. this was awful. Starting clue was it came out about 2 minutes after ordering and all felt contrived and pre prepped. Shame on them. A thin slice of ham, gluey, swiss, béchamel that was like a chicken fried steak gravy (and I'm the first person who loves Chicken Fried Steak - but get me to wyoming or CO where I have had the real deal)  hard crusty egg = kind of luke warm - ugg. 

I am not going back for brunch any time soon. Go back to Plow or head to the Farmers Market at the Ferry Building and restaurants inside. - too many other places for brunch in SF to put up w/ this.  Even a great hotel breakfast would be better than this.  Awful
author: A C S.

description:
This is a neighborhood gem that took us 2 years to try. Finally got around to it on a friend's dime and I'm so impressed!  I love being in the middle of the gorgeous Presidio, in an old barack updated with such great flaire. 

The food was marvelous.  Went for brunch with 5 others and we each "ooed and ahhed" in delight.  The brunch menu has a lot of options, including one of the best burgers I've ever bit into!  I mean it was just perfect.  Can't wait to go back and try some of the other options.

I love the outdoor seating option, but on our next trip I most definitely will sit at the bar.
author: Tamz O.

description: I love Presidio Social Club.  Good food, good drinks, great location and historic.  Can't beat that!
author: Jennifer C.

description: Even worse this time.  2 hour wait for food!  Lunacy!  Gee thanks atteetude servers!  The place needs management change tomorrow.  I should picket outside for fudge sake.
author: Anon A.

description:
This review is for the Presidio Social Club as a wedding venue. We had both our ceremony and reception here, and it was completely unforgettable.

A few details about the wedding, for couples who are planning and curious about how the wedding was structured: we had a total of 96 guests, which was the perfect amount. I would not recommend going over that, as it will be difficult for folks to be comfortably seated. We specifically wanted a venue that wasn't too big for our guest count, so that's in part what made PSC perfect for us. Our ceremony was out on the back porch, which seats only about 70-80 guests, so you have to squeeze folks onto the benches on the side and then there might still be a few guests that need to stand. After the ceremony, people moved inside to the bar area for cocktail hour and then a seated dinner. The private dining room was left empty so that we could use it as a dance floor. During the dancing, the back porch was left open with the addition of some seating and a fire pit--sort of like an outdoor lounge area.

Veronica Romeyn was the event coordinator when we initially signed with PSC. However, about 4 months prior to our wedding, we contacted Veronica to schedule a meeting and received a notice that she was no longer at PSC. A few weeks later, we were introduced to Gail Lee, who was formerly the event coordinator at the University Club. To be honest, it was really touch and go in the beginning--emails would go without responses for days and even weeks, and we had a ton of issues trying to get on the same page. But when we had our tasting at the end of July, that's when everything started to fall into place. Once she got into the groove of things, Gail was so responsive and organized. She was pretty much a full-on wedding planner for us, despite really only being responsible for the venue. When there was confusion over the bill of estimates and policy changes, she was very fair and helped waive some of our costs.

Everything was so smooth on our wedding day. Our friends commented that it was the best wedding they'd ever attended. Many people commented on how smooth the transitions were and how well organized it was. And EVERYONE commented on the absolutely AMAZING food. I have to spend a few words here on the food... PSC was kind enough to accommodate our unusual requests. For dinner, which we served family style, one option was linguine with clams (bride family favorite) and the other option was Wiener schnitzel with potato salad (groom family is from Austria). Neither of these is on the regular PSC menu or catering menu. At the tasting, I wasn't satisfied with the schnitzel and almost nixed it from the wedding. It is almost impossible to get good schnitzel in the US that is made from high quality veal, pounded very thin, and very crispy. What's even harder is to make schnitzel in mass quantities and serve it at the perfect temperature at every table. And let me just say this, the chef really pulled out all the stops... my old-school Austrian mother-in-law is a very picky person and she was the schnitzel was pretty much perfect. :-) Multiple people said the food was the best wedding food they'd every had. Thank you Chef!!!!!

I admit that I had my doubts at the beginning when our event coordinator was suddenly replaced. And I had my doubts about the food when reading the reviews and even at the tasting. But Gail and the entire staff at PSC made our wedding day more special than we could have imagined. Thank you SO so much.
author: Cat U.

description:
They have a limited menu, but everything that I have ever had is really good. The decor is sophisticated without being overdone.

The only drawback is the dish towel napkins that can leave behind lint. So beware if you're wearing black!
author: C B.

description:
Love the decor, the style, great atmosphere, the old movies on the TV... I can't speak for the food, but this place get's an auto 5-Star as Tim served me the best of drink of my life.

Ever.

And I've done my share of drinking...
author: Bryan M.

description:
The location, and setting are superb! However the food quality was sub par. I will go back don't get me wrong. The location is really cool. 

Pros: Location, Decor, Setting, The Drinks/Bar, parking 
Cons: the food 

This place definitely has character, and it has a place on my return to list.  However it'll be for a pre-dinner or post-dinner cocktail.

It's set in the Eucalyptus trees of the Presidio in an old Enlisted Barracks, converted to a restaurant. 

The food?  Well I think they still have the same kitchen they served the enlisted men with, just with fancier names on the menu.

Go enjoy a cocktail here!!
author: Steve B.

description:
Yesterday, Sunday, we were lucky to walk-in just after 5 pm, and get a little table - it was our first time dining at PSC. It took a bit to get our waiter's attention at first, but after Natalie brought our wine order, the service was super-attentive (my guess, they read your reviews, people!). The water was filled almost after each sip by the busboy, bread + oil plate  was filled three times! and the manager was spinning around asking if we need anything else... Our food order came in an appropriate time, and extra plate was offered by our waiter to share my salad.
My butter lettuce salad was a bit disappointing - nothing but green leaves (some of them i never put in my salad at home - the top damaged leaves), and only 4-5 very thing peach slices. for $9! I would not order this salad again.
My husband ordered local salmon - and it was great! mid size piece cooked to his order, on a little bean salad (not much, but still) - $30, but made him happy (local catch!).
I ordered a bowl of soup (chicken dumpling) for my mane course and it was very delicious and filling.   Together with two glasses of wine, total came to $76. We'll come back again when in the area b/c we like the ambiance, easy parking and want to try some other items on the menu.
author: NINA V.

description:
I had a great time! The bottomless mimosas didn't hurt either ;)

We came here for an early bday celebration for brunch. It was gloomy and rainy out but the food brightened up the day. Everything we had was delish and the waitress was fantastic; very knowledgeable, accommodating and speedy with the refills! 

My suggestions on the brunch menu:
1. eggs florentine 
2. crabcake sliders 
3. PSC burger (mouth watering)
4. rum soaked french toast with bananas
5. pear salad and butternut squash soup (soup of the day)
Everything was on point...so good!

For a little extra birthday desert we got the dirty beignets (chocolate filled) which were so very very good. Matched with coffee, I couldn't have asked for anything better.

The reason for the 5th star was unlike other bottomless mimosa joints where you have to continuously order more drinks...here, the wait staff comes around with pitchers to refill your wine glass (not a champagne flute) which in my opinion is how you should do it if you are going to offer bottomless. I just find that great customer service. (can you tell I'm a fan of the sauce? ;) 

All n' all...it was a great afternoon and I would definitely return.
author: Jocelyn J.

description:
Mediocre food and service. When I was greeted by the hostess she said the only table available was on the patio. I asked to wait for a table and she gave me a confused look which I returned to her because it was a foggy Sunday afternoon and I didn't want to be out in the cold. I waited for a few minutes before she talked to me again, all the while unsure of the wait time.
I ordered an appetizer, salad and entree to split. Everything was brought out al the same time. I expected the server to course the meal or ask how I would like it coursed. I had the shrimp Louis Salad for $17 which consisted of bay shrimp (fresh) flavorful dressing and butter lettuce. The portion was small and the price was high for a brunch salad.
I love the medicine cabinets behind the bar, planted palms and vintage details. At Presidio Social Club I felt like I was paying more for the ambiance. I would love to give this place 3 stars because the drinks are a good value. The staff was kind but my experience was like my greeting, a little unpolished.
author: Nicole S.

description: So we 6 girls had a reservation for 6:30. The waitress FINALLY took our order at 7:35 and our food (one steak, 2 pastas, 2 veal picatta) was served 45 minutes after that. We actually had to go find our waitress to take our order. It is now 8:40 and they just took our plates. While the food was good, don't come here if you aren't planning to stay the entire evening. P.S. We've been really nice but still haven't been offered a dessert menu, coffee, more drinks or the bill...
author: Barbi Y.

description: We came here at the end of happy hour on a Saturday. The Presidio Social Club is at the edge of a beautiful park and in a timeless building. They have great food options for happy hour and delicious drinks. Highly recommended!
author: Amanda B.

description:
Have had brunch here a few times. Slightly pricey, but worth it for the food quality. Service can be hit or miss. Wait is generally not bad, but they take reservations for brunch, so you can call ahead while you're on your way to ensure a spot. Great alternative if Ella's wait is too long. 

Food:
Get the beignets. I repeat, get the beignets.  

Dranks:
The selection here is better than your average brunch spot.
author: Louis A.

description: We've come here once before for a family dinner on a larger scale, so I thought tonight's intimate dinner with our family and grandparents would be a great experience.  I should have known that when we walked in and I saw the manager and server ROLL THEIR EYES at the sight of our family entering (was it the children?) that it would be a horrible experience.  We came in at 5pm.  We asked to please bring the children's meals right away and also provided the grandparents' low sodium requests.  We were assured this would be no problem.  Lo and behold, the children's meals did not arrive until almost 75 minutes later--75 minutes!  We sustained on french fries though the poor grandparents coudn't share in this appetizer.  Then the $100 steak rib eye came I was going to share with my husband -- a ONE HUNDRED dollar beautiful steak was suffocated under at least 2lbs of GARLIC fries.  The whole meals was the saltiest meal ever.  They knew how upset we were and offered a free dessert - no thanks.  We couldn't get outa of there any sooner.  This place sucks in service and unappetizing food.  Go spend your money on another restaurant with better service and way better food.  Presidio Social has gone down the toilet.
author: Bellsey B.

description:
The scene:
It's the first stormy day of the season in San Francisco's charming Presidio District, and three of my fellow friends and I descend upon this venue to celebrate the yet-unborn child of one my friend.  We walk in and are seated promptly (well, two of my friends were seated promptly, while my other friend and I strolled in 20 minutes late).

The food and service:
For the most part, the food is simple but tasty.  We kicked it off with an order of the beignets accompanied by melted chocolate sauce.  They were very tasty little nuggets of fried happiness.  Everyone (with the exception of the mother-to-be, don't fret) put in for a cocktail order:  Bloody Mary for me and Mimosa's for the others.  At the same time, we put in for our brunch orders.  And then we waited, and chatted and waited some more.  After about 15 minutes, we stopped our waiter to ask about our drink order, and he realized that he hadn't actually put the drink order in.  Within a few minutes, we received our cocktails.  The world had been slightly righted again, as I sipped my very spicy, tasty drink.

The food arrived and we dug in.  I had the basic two eggs over medium, potatoes and sausage with biscuit.  Everything that I ordered was OK, though I wouldn't say that I was blown completely away.  My one friend got the biscuits and gravy, and this seemed to be the winner.  Another friend had the quiche, which also seemed pretty solid and tasty.

All in all, it was a pleasant way to spend a rainy Sunday brunch with good friends, good food, but not the greatest service, though I think that our situation was not the norm.  I would recommend this as a nice place to go for a few leisurely lunch or brunch.
author: Jane N.

description:
A dazzling experience. Beautiful location with high ceilings that transports you to a whole different world. Suit up, order a classic cocktail, and enjoy the ride. 

There should be more restaurants like this everywhere. The menu is very reasonably priced with most entrees going for less than $20 and generally focused on modernized versions of classic American comfort food - meatloaf, mac and cheese, even liver and onions! I will say that the pricing on the appetizers was a bit weird as they aren't significantly cheaper than the entrees so it's tough to really explore the menu unless you go in a bigger group. If only PSC wasn't located in the middle of nowhere, it'd be the perfect place to stop off for lunch or after work or late night. Or, whenever. 

Make sure to save room for the diner-inspired desserts - lemon merengue pie or butterscotch pudding. You'll feel like you should be getting served a cup of weak joe by a waitress named Mabel. And, that ain't home cooking, I don't know what is.
author: Manesh P.

description:
Four of us recently celebrated a birthday lunch. The service and quality were extremely disappointing.Being a MOnday at 1pm, the restaurant was less than half filled. Only four people were sitting at the bar.  Drinks were ordered and 15 minutes later still hadn't arrived, although the bartender lady was chatting up 2 bar guests at the other end of the room. After FINDING and asking our waiter about our drinks, the bartender finally started making the drinks and they arrived more than 20 minutes after being ordered. The waiter then had to be "found" again to take our lunch order. One in our party ordered soup, which arrived without a spoon. A glass of ice had been requested when drinks were ordered and arrived after the meal was served. One guest commented that the liver she ordered was charred crisp on one side and barely browned on the other. 
It is doubtful that any of us will ever go back to this restaurant nor recommend it to anyone else.
author: Jean M.

description:
Went there for the foie gras slider, delicious. Glad this place has decided to flout the ridiculous, unnecessary, and over emotional law that the PETA nuts pushed through. 

My friends and I will make this a weekly excursion as long as it's the only local place serving foie.
author: Brian S.

description:
After a disgusting meal and terrible night there about a year ago we have no been back..until today!
The best part about it was the amazing blackberry bushes in the parking lot.
Our server acted as though we were doing him a favor. He forget our first course and because he never came by to see how thigns were we approached a manager asking about our first course. Our waiter showed up and said, "you dont need appetizers".
author: Jennifer K.

description:
Presidio Social Club is a fantastic little gem tucked just inside the Lyon Street gate, with gorgeous views of the POFA and GGB close by. My second trip to Presidio SC last night was with 9 other friends, for a birthday party. Our large party was graciously accepted and catered to, which is a breath of fresh air as many SF restaurants begrudgingly take on large groups. 

The barrack-esque restaurant has a classic feel, from the airy, crisp decor to the white-coated, bow-tied bartenders and the stainless steel bar. While this could be hokey in another context, the vibe is genuine and tasteful. From the moment we entered and all the way through our much extended dinner, the staff was friendly, hospitable, and accommodating- we brought a birthday cake, and the hostess and server were more than happy to whisk it away and bring it back post-dinner for the perfect, candle-adorned surprise. 

The food is well done, and the list of "throw-back", Mad Men style cocktails rounds out the menu. Be forewarned, however, that the menu is extremely (read: almost entirely) meat heavy: as a vegetarian, I found little more than salad and brussle sprouts to dine on. Also, while I appreciate the "classic" theme of this place, I like to see local SF spots supporting local/organic farms- I didn't see any of this on the menu, even with all the meat that is being served. 

I recommend this spot for a date that is a break away from the crowded wine-bars and swanky, uppity restaurants of the surrounding area, or for dining with your parents when they are in town. Take a post-dinner stroll up the hill in the Presidio for a breathtaking view to round out the night.
author: Kat D.

description: We had a dinner there two weeks ago with three friends and I loved it. The food and service was great and guess what the prices are the best value I have seen. In some time, and the ambiance was excellent with many old photos of soldiers and officers at  the Presidio for the 1940's. I will declare this the best restaurant value I have seen in the Bay area and love it too bad it is so far away from us. The bar is large and fun and people friendly because they are getting a great value and well prepared food. I am indeed a fan yes!
author: Peter A.

description:
I can't believe I have never gone to this place before, great place tucked away in the Presidio, even has a nice outdoor patio for the few days with great weather in SF. My usual brunch buddy and I went there instead of one of our usual spots which is something a bit out of the ordinary for us. Anyways we were seated right away by friendly staff inside since the outside was full. We ordered up the crab sliders which were really good, we even got a second order of these bad boys! We also bot the grill cheese and tomato soup which was about what you would expect  when ordering such a thing... The biggest disappointment was the fish and chips, we both agreed that the fish was cooked well enough in the batter and it was mushy, granted I ate it but wouldn't order it again. 

I am open to coming back as there was a few other good things on the menu I didn't get to try out and I think it would be a great place to go for dinner and have a few drinks.
author: Bobby B.

description:
Life is full of disappointments, like the Presidio Social Club.

The building is absolutely gorgeous, as was the extremely good-looking maitre d'.  However, things quickly went downhill from there.

Rule #1 at brunch is not to keep a man waiting for his drink.  We waited about 10 minutes until we finally had to flag down a server to get her attention.  She apologized and said that it was her first day, but that's no excuse for not taking out drink order!  I had a Ramos Gin Fizz, one of my favorite cocktails.  However, I watched the bartender make it and was highly disappointed.  He seemed to use pre-made egg whites, which were sitting on the counter.  He didn't shake it enough, which meant that it wasn't as frothy as it ought to be.  I tasted a Bloody Mary that someone else had received and found it to be terribly bland.  

The food was incredibly mediocre.  I had the crab melt, which was totally bland.  The crab had no flavor, the cheese was so-so, and the rye bread was over-toasted.  I substituted a fruit cup for the fries and was equally as disappointed.  I also had a friend's biscuits and gravy and found the biscuits to be too dense and the gravy to be too salty.

Overall, I wouldn't make the hike all the way out to the Presidio again for such a middle-of-the-road experience.
author: Mark J.

description:
This Presidio treasure is a couple of blocks away from my house and I am glad about it!  I went for dinner to this place for the first time last night and was extremely impressed.  Tuesday nights apparently have half off glasses of wine and beer.  (NOTE to self to remember that one!)  Everyone else did, and the place was packed, but we had quick attentive service.

The food was delicious- I had the friend chicken and it was amazing, fried yet juicy chicken inside.  There were pieces of pure chicken and a piece on the bone.  Good job!  My date had chips and fish, and I had a bite of that as well.  The fish was light and the crust light and crispy.  A big fan.  

Dessert- wow get that banana cream pie.  It's like nothing I've had before and is more a round tart shaped not pie shaped.  YUM.

Overall, the view, was great both inside and out.  Will definitely try their brunch! Four stars because 20 bucks for fried chicken does seem a bit much.
author: Jessica G.

description: The food is subpar and the management / service are the worst of the worst!!!  I had the most horrific experience for Thanksgiving this year.  My family was in town visiting for the Holiday and I begun looking into restaurants for Thanksgiving two months in advance.  When I made the reservation in September I was assured that the standard menu options would be available as my father is an extremely picky eater.  Well sure enough they weren't and to make matters worse when I asked about such I was schooled on how I should've called to confirm and the proper protocol for such (which of course I had done).  We did find a vegetarian option was available however didn't learn that they charged the full $60/plate for such despite the fact it didn't include any sides or desert with it until we received the bill.  And to top it off they brought out the desert for the table on 5 small plates with a small slice of pumpkin and pecan pie on each.  It wasn't until we asked about the deserts for the three people at the table who hadn't been served that we learned they were meant to be shared amongst the table.  We explained to them the misunderstanding however they would not serve us any additional pie.  I was so embarrassed to have brought my family there.
author: Ariel P.

description: Had the meatloaf, was good. service was good except needed to come around often for drinks. I thought the Poke appetizer was good as well.
author: Matt K.

description: Not sure what all the fuss is about!  I agree with those that said service here is spotty, inconsistent.  For lunch I had three oysters and a very small salad that was more of a side dish.  For this I paid $26!  Food was good but not noteworthy; there are better places for lunch in the city, with just as much charm.  I'm not sure I'd go back.....
author: Donna R.

description:
After a lazy afternoon of roller blading in Golden Gate Park and taking in some culture at the De Young Museum, we headed over to the Presidio to get some dinner.  Thankfully, I was at the mercy of friends who knew the City like the back of their hands and was escorted to the Presidio Social Club.  

As if my good fortune couldn't improve, Sundays at this fine establishment are pork day!  The chef throws a whole pig in a custom smoker at 5:00am each Sunday and the result is an incredibly tasty dinner.  The porky goodness was offered two ways.  One of us had it was kimchee.  I opted for the standard pork dish on the everyday menu, which was braised and served with a delicious sauce and sides.  Moist, succulent and flavorful.

Service was fantastic, the server was knowledgeable and very approachable.  The cocktails were simple, yet tasty.  The setting is across from the Lucasfilm campus amongst the old military barracks and housing, surrounded by eucalyptus trees.  The interior is bright, lined with windows and very cozy, yet modern.  Despite the name, no membership is needed, an even better excuse to make your way to this fine establishment.  Even if you don't come for a meal, stop by and hang out at the long bar and enjoy a cocktail.
author: Khuyen H.

description:
I am so fond of this place...My BF and I go pretty often, and although it's not a hipster-foodie place, it's earnest and independent--almost a tiny bit amateur--but in a good way.

My BF swears its the BEST burger he has ever eaten. I'm a pescatarian, and there is plenty on the menu to keep me happy! I LOVE the crab cake sliders and the fresh sardine crostinis. The trout is absolutely yummy and feels so much healthier than the burger and fries my BF always gets. (I was bummed when they took the whole roasted fish off the menu because that dish was one of the yummiest ever!)

Drinks are awesome. I try a different classic cocktail every time we go. Moscow Mule is delicious, as is the Pink Lemonade cocktail. BF loves their rye manhattan.

You really need to go and experience the warmth. Staff are almost always so warm and helpful. We seem to always get the same server, Mary, who remembers us and always chats with us for a few minutes. Everone bends over backwards to be friendly and helpful.

Just go a couple of times. You'll feel right at home.
author: Defender G.

description: Beautiful location in the Presidio. Exterior is a bit threadbare (peeling paint) but don't let that deter you from trying a meal here. Food is excellent, service terrific. If the weather cooperates, the patio is a delightful dining area.
author: Chris E.

description:
I can't believe I've never heard of this place.  Seriously, and I LOVE food.

My date suggested this place because a few people recommended it to him.  So we met for drinks - a gin and tonic for him, and a Pisco Punch for me (what's Pisco?  I have no idea, but the drink was pink and good).  After an hour of sitting, chatting and sipping, we got hungry and decided to move to a table.

This place is seriously cute.  In his words, it was like a time warp.  In my words, it was like South Carolina, Derby Days with palm trees and breezy weather.  Except it was freezing cold outside, thank you San Francisco.  The service was friendly but sparse (we only got checked on once throughout the almost-two hours that we were there).

He had the meatloaf (it was a Monday night special) and I ordered the Macaroni and Cheese, because it had its own separate category on the menu.  When something has its own class, you KNOW it's good.  And it definitely was - it had that homemade taste with the bread crumbs on top.  I ordered the large size, and although it didn't look like a very big portion, I almost couldn't finish it.  Absolutely delicious.

Although I'm more into the hole-in-the-walls, this place is definitely super cute and kitschy in its own sense.  Love it!
author: Tori S.

description:
Some friends of ours chose this place, we hadn't heard of it. Great atmosphere and the food was exceptional, though it took way too long to get to us. The service staff were very apologetic and preemptively offered us dessert on the house...nice recovery!

We'd go back in a heartbeat!
author: Marc T.

description:
Our dining experience at the Presidio Social club was, to put it bluntly, awful.  

The noise level was so high, my wife and I gave up trying to talk with each other.  Yelling during a meal is no fun.

My wife's overpriced piece of swordfish was okay, but nothing came with it and the waiter didn't tell us we had to order 'sides' extra...at $6 a pop. My shortrib was mostly fat, sad and forlorn on it's otherwise empty plate with its cloyingly sweet glaze.  The waiter also told me he would have to charge me for another drink to refill mine with .09 cents worth of root beer.

My best advice.....if you're in San Francisco, go someplace else.
author: Mike H.

description:
We had a lazy lunch sitting on the outdoor patio, and we shared a caesar salad, a burger with fries and a plate of mussels finished in broth with sauteed onions and sausage.

The burger was the absolutely fantastic, it was juicy and perfectly cooked, 
i thought the caesar salad was delicate and no overdressed
the only thing that it wasn't incredible was the mussels dish

the server was efficient, attentive and polite, he was a tall guy with a ponytail 

we will be back soon

thank you
author: Giu G.

description:
Cool little place right in the Presidio.  I wouldn't have guessed it was an actual establishment by the way it looks on the outside.  Looks more like a  senior citizen rec house.  

Its a good bar with lots of old school cocktails they can whip up.  I always enjoy a place that has knowledgeable bar staff.  The 50s diner motif and fancy uniforms add some unique un-California charisma to the environment.

I've never had the food, but I hear it's the bees knees.
author: Sean M.

description:
Yum, yum! Been here a couple of times and always had a great experience.  Service can sometimes get a little slow for the bottomless mimosa weekend brunches on a warm day - but that's expected.

Have sat outside, inside or even at the bar to watch some sports with a few beers, - is overall a yummy, friendly experience.  Waitresses and bar staff are knowledgable about the menu, and will definately be back there again.

Usual brunch/breakfast fare of eggs, sausages, french toast, and burgers (probably not THE best, but very yum nonetheless!)

Don't forget to write a postcard to someone and they'll post it for you!
author: Beekay M.

description: The place is nice and kind of old fashioned. Some of the food seems expensive for what it is,  but is good.  The service is nice.  It is a relaxing place to go and out of the hub of the city.
author: Alexandria H.

description: Had been wanting to try this place for a while but every time we went, it was closed for a private event. So when Mom came to town, decided third time was the charm.  And happy we did.  Sat under heat lamps on the back porch, which was lovely. And the food did not disappoint. Had the pork belly and mussels which were both excellent. The Man had the meatloaf, Mom had the Bavette steak - and both licked their plates clean. All in all a great meal, but was surprised at the lack of inventiveness in the menu. And I wouldn't recommend this as a place to bring vegetarians.
author: Victoria L.

description:
The first time I walked into PSC I tripped over the step at the front door (so be careful for that) but after hiding my embarrassment of falling on my face infront of a restaurant full of people I was greeted with friendly (and apologetic) staff, great food, and a really nice atmosphere. 
Me and some friends gathered at a table by the window and enjoyed appetizers and drinks and the place really exceeded expectations. From the outside it looks pretty average but the vibe is just right for a casual dinner. 
Wasn't cheap, wasn't expensive. Fell somewhere in between. I left with a bruised knee, a little less money in my bank account, and a satisfied stomach :)
I'll be back!
author: Maggie M.

description: I have gone a few times because it is close to my house and convenient. It gets a bit noisy, so I recommend earlier dinner reservations. In general I think the appetizers are very good, and prefer ordering a couple of those for dinner.
author: Hilda V.

description: PSC mixes great food and a great environment. The ambiance is at once old-timey san francisco (in a neat military clean and proper kind of way), and modern craftsman. If you're not into the ambiance, then this is probably not the spot for you as part of what you are paying for is definitely the environment. The food is quite good, but not usually amazing. I'm still a little upset that they took their biscuits off the menu, but then again, you can order pork belly to accompany almost anything, so I'll cut them some slack.
author: Jon W.

description: Food was delicious, quality ingredients. Good service, positive atmosphere and ambience. Overall a great experience.
author: Jay G.

description:
We dined here last night for the first time and loved it.  It's a lovely space, and parking is free and plentiful--huzzah!!  (I noticed that the 43 Masonic goes right by the restaurant, in case you're on Muni.)

We shared three of the antipasti (3 for $10):  the pesto carrots, caponata, and the chili-spiked corn.  Mature and generally well-behaved are we, but we very nearly began wrestling over the last of the corn.   All three were terrific, but the corn was To Die For.

We each had a Cesar salad (great white anchovies, if you like such things).  Next time we'll share one--it was just too much food.  He had the meatloaf and mashed potatoes and I had the braised pork, with liberal sharing back and forth.  The meatloaf was very good, but the pork--oh, the pork...!  Served on top of green beans and stewed heirloom tomatoes, it was light and full of flavor, and the pork was tender as a mother's heart.

Dessert for me was the lemon meringue cake (yum) and for him was the malt ball ice cream thingy, which came with three chocolate chip cookies.  All divine.
