The host and our servers were terrific--friendly, flexible, efficient.  I love good service, and PSC provided that.

The one wrinkle, and it was a small one, was that whoever retrieves the wine for the server sent us the wrong wine (both wines were French).  It was rectified before the bottle was opened and apologies were duly made.  In a similar vein, PSC's wine list could use some spiffing up to match the quality of their food.  In mitigation, though, I did notice that they had some offerings last night that were better than those on the wine list on their website.   Corkage is $15, which is quite reasonable.

I'll have another chance to dine there on Saturday night, and I'm looking forward to it very much.
author: Earline A.

description: This restaurant is discriminatory and ANTI FAMILY!   I just spoke to two people about a reservation for 10 people.  After they TALKED ME INTO the patio, a young man came back and asked if there were any children in the group.  I said 4 children and he replied "Oh, actually, we don't have anything!"  This was all very blatant!!! I recommend that families AVOID this place in protest of these policies.  AND, this was for brunch, so we wouldn't have been disturbing any romantic dinners.
author: Yvonne M.

description: I really liked this place. Beautiful location in SF Presidio, lots of parking, sunny deck, yummy cocktails and great food. We were there for brunch, ordered a lot of different plates and shared and everything was great. Service was good too for our large group. We'll definitely be back!
author: Jen G.

description:
We brought my grandma out to lunch here because it was a beautiful day in the city. There was a long wait to sit outside so we sat inside. There were big, beautiful windows so we could see out which was nice but it was very loud indoors. It probably has to do with the fact that this building is a converted barracks, so it is mostly just a large wood framed room, with high ceilings. The restaurant is also not easily accessible for people who are not good with stairs. There was no ramp up to the front of the restaurant and the stairs were fairly steep (a problem for grandma). 

The food was very good, although the menu (Sunday at about 1pm) was fairly sparse with some strange offerings (Vietnamese sandwich, macaroni and cheese, and vegetable scramble all made it onto the list).
author: Meaghan N.

description: Had another great experience.  Every bite of everything was great, gruyere toasts were awesome, still love the smashed peas, and got the cod fish special which was light and delicious.  Made up for my pregnant indulgence of the beignets which were great, not Cafe Du Monde but really really good.  Love this place and parking was a snap!
author: Andrea R.

description: It's getting better and better - menu, service, bar - all quite exceptional the last few times I have stopped in. Well done guys, and keep it coming!  The menu is still a little confusing to me, and I like to think I am foodie hip.... but you will work it out. Plenty of options for every size of hunger and taste.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
The pate on toast was quite good.  So was the crab bisque.  However, the "pork chop" with greens entree was so extremely salty that I couldn't eat it.  Btw, I don't know what part of the pig it came from, but I've never seen a pork chop that looked like that.  

Another diner and I wanted to order the ribeye steak for two, but he wanted it cooked rare, and I wanted it cooked medium well, and the waiter refused to cut it in half.  

A  dessert of apple crisp, must have been made with dried apples, because I've never tasted anything so dry and rubbery.  

I don't mind paying a  high price for an excellent meal.  But, in this instance, the mediocre (and, sometimes, inedible) food certainly did not justify the extremely high cost of the dinner.  I will never eat here, again, and I certainly will not recommend it to anyone else.
author: Eddie W.

description:
I came here for my friends 30th Birthday.

The place is really nice and spacious. Our table was decorated with flowers that a friend had brought in earlier. The restaurant staff was really accommodating to us and the bottles of wine that we had brought into the restaurant. 

I guess their specialty is their fried chicken, almost everyone got the chicken. But I ordered the steak which was made exactly how I wanted it. Most of the time I get a steak that is overly cooked, but this was just right. The mini banana creme cake was heaven! 

I would recommend this place for a big parties. We came on a Monday evening so the place wasn't that crowded. If you have enough money to drop on this place I definitely recommend it. Plus they have a parking lot!
author: J B.

description:
Stopped in at about 4:30 on a Sunday, before the dinner service. The very nice floorman told us there was no table service until 5pm but that we could order from the bar menu and take our stuff outside. It was a gorgeous day.

My dad went out to sit at the table while we ordered drinks and food at the bar, from the man behind it. When we got the drinks we closed out our tab, paid for the food and tipped about 20%. After about 25 minutes waiting at the bar for our food while my dad sat outside, we decided to ask about our order. This is the exact exchange:

My companion: "The tuna melts are coming out soon?"

Bartender: "I have no idea, I'm not the chef, I'm the bartender. I would assume they are on the way."

Then he turns around and does other things.

Charmed. Unfortunately we had already left that decent tip.

This place is too good to have people like that serving. If it's  a problem serving at the bar after brunch and before dinner, then don't do it.
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
4 1/2 stars.  I'll explain the half star deduction later. 

We arrived at about a 15 minutes before our reservation and they were packed.  The polite hostess said that we would be seated shortly, but unfortunately that turned into a half hour after our reservation time.  I guess the table that we were to sit at, the diners were just hanging out at chatting with their bill on the table.  No problem, they were apologetic and compt an appetizer.

The appetizers: 

grilled calamari with vermicelli noodle: good, but not enough calamari
grilled cheese toast points: delicious. Ooey, Gooey and cheesy

Main entrees:

Grilled steak for two:  Nice Medium rare with crispy french fries and a really citrusy and garlicky broccolini

Pork chop: Moist and slightly pink with a flavorful roasted apple sauce.  Only wished the greens were a little less salty

Mac and Cheese-  Yum Yum Yum...with 4 different types of cheese.  Crispy top, hot al dente noodles and a silky smooth chese sauce.  

Desserts:

Beignets-  4 unbelievably fluffy and warm puffs or deliciousness.  A must get

Apple crisp-  Came out just barely luke warm, but everyone else at the table thought it was good.  

Our waitor was friendly and attentive.  

1/2 Star Deduction for: When waiting for our table we were waiting at the bar.  The bartender did not look once over to us.  I had to flag down the other bartender working the other end of the bar for service.  The bartender on our side was completely rude.
author: Danielle E.

description:
Dined here for lunch today - first visit.  The service was good, the menu had some good choices.  Alas my "medium rare" burger was more like steak tartare in the middle - undercooked.  For $14 (plus extra for salad instead of fries) they ought to get right.  (The side salad was also uninspired) and the ice tea was pretty weak.

This was a tough call.  I've decided that a 3* restaurant is acceptable and maybe worth another visit, as opposed to 4* which is a place where I would go out of my way to dine again.
author: Boris G.

description: Bartenders make my day!  We only ever eat here at the bar because service is fabulous and the food tastes better shared over drinks.  It's a happy place.  There are small, unobtrusive TVs there to placate my sports-crazed husband but not grab all his attention.  Great mojito's and they have a good selection of Irish Whiskey.
author: Susana S.

description: great service...liked the wines that are offered.  The food was just so so, although it may have been what I ordered.  Desserts are phenom.  I would go again tho, but be warned it is quite loud so if you are looking for a more romantic spot, this might not be it
author: Lauraine E.

description:
Disclaimer:  this review is just for the menu offered for large groups at lunchtime.

I'm not usually a supercritical person when it comes to food, but this place was a rip off for what we were served.  We came here for a family reunion, lunch was $28 per person, and they had 3 options for lunch to choose from (and an appetizer of mini grilled cheese sandwiches and a tiny cup of tomato soup, which was shared family style so each person got one of the four tiny sandwiches) :

Biscuits and Gravy:  the biscuit was pretty good, the gravy was creamy and had a little spice to it.  The menu said it came with scrambled eggs and bacon, but instead they brought out all the dishes with poached eggs and no bacon.  When we mentioned it, they returned a few minutes later with sides of bacon.  It was chewy and tough, not my favorite.  The house potatoes were probably the worst I've ever had.  They seemed old and looked like they'd been sitting around since yesterday.  The biscuits and gravy dish had the most amount of food on the plate out of the three options.  I wouldn't order it again.

Chicken Paillard:  basically this was a small salad of fresh greens with some sliced chicken breast scattered about on the plate.  This was the smallest of the three options.  When it arrived at the table, I literally laughed out loud because it was so ridiculously small and certainly not worth the price.  I couldn't believe that they considered this little side salad as an entree.  It was sad.  

Beef Brisket Sandwich:  This one looked decent, and my relatives said it was tasty.  Basically it was just some beef and sauce with some kimchi in between two really big slices of bread.  Not sure it was worth the price either.  

I would have been more satisfied if each person got a choice of an appetizer instead of sharing what was basically a grilled cheese sandwich that was cut into fourths.  Sharing it basically made lunch a one course meal for $28 instead of what should have been a 2 or 3 course meal, for the price.  I think they need to rework their banquet/group menu because it was just a joke.  

So overall, I would not recommend this place for groups in terms of food choices.  It just was not worth it.

I MAYBE would be willing to try this place again someday because the other food on the menu sounds good and the grilled cheese and tomato soup was good.  But I hope they fix that Chicken Paillard and their home fries first.
author: Jojo D.

description:
Delicious burger. It's just a burger and two buns (and cheese if you wish), but its full of flavor. I also really like the atmosphere here and that fact that there's plenty of parking around. 
The only downside was the French waiter kept trying to get me to buy wine, weird?
author: Joahnna M.

description:
This was one of my best place in SF for all the souvenirs and good time there as my previous comment showed it: food, drinks, service... but things change unfortunately....

However, my Gf and I were food poisoned as hell on Friday (no need to detail but our night was miserable) and the only things we shared during this day was her burger.... i am a meat burger and I guess my first time that I was sick because of some beef meat... I don't know what else to say. We have been so disapointed as we use (d) to eat/ brunch there regularly...

The only reason why I let a star is for the Mai tai and the service and the enjoyment with my friends. I don't know if I will be back honestly ....
author: Guillaume C.

description: Eh, this place is okay, but not worth the price tag. I came here with my Marina dwelling cousin and some other family members. We had their gruyere cheese toast appetizer, the clams, hamburger, and butter lettuce salad. All were decent, but not especially good. It struck me as an uppity overpriced Max's. There are too many good places to eat in this neighborhood to waste one's money on this substandard fair for such a fee.
author: Katie B.

description:
Yes yes yes! After a busy day of scrubbing, sweeping and shopping for a party my friends and I were doing to celebrate my birthday, we were tired and needed a good meal. No plans had been made, because I was too tired of planning. In fact, the only inkling of a plan I had was to go home and watch episodes of "So you think you can dance?" on YouTube while eating pickles and brie sandwiches (that's not a BAD thing). 

However. We ended up going for some food, and given our location in the Presidio, we went to the Presidio Social Club. Jeans and all. We had called while driving and they were very cheerful and said that they could accommodate a party of 3 on a Saturday evening, no problem. (Surprising!)

I've been to this place once before, for a vintage-themed cocktail social. We did not have food, just drinks, and I remembered them being delicious. The restaurant boasts a nice selection of old fashioned cocktails, like the Sazerac, Sidecar, or my new favorite, old fashioned Aviation - gin, lemon juice, creme de violette and a maraschino cherry. Yum.

We shared cheese toasts, mac'n'cheese and steak tartar with avocado. The mac'n'cheese was superb. For an entree, I had liver and onions, served with bacon. Again, fantastic - the texture was just right, crisp and browned to perfection on the outside, while the inside was well cooked through but still had a creamy soft texture. For dessert, we shared a butterscotch pudding and an order of beignets with caramel sauce (not the Dirty Dozen, I'll get those next time when I bring PB Cat here). My espresso was delicious with the dessert. It was particularly tasty to dip the beignet INTO the pudding. Nom nom nom.

Maybe we just got lucky, because we had a great parking spot, and were seated promptly, and the service was good and attentive (but not intrusive), and the food was very satisfying, and the drink got me nice and toasty. But as far as first impressions go, I couldn't complain.
author: Tanya F.

description:
I used to go to PSC about once a month since it's near my house, the food is decent and the parking is awesome.    

However...what has compelled me to write this review is the fact that in the face of the foie gras ban, these jerks have decided that they want to continue to serve it.

Don't get me wrong--I'm a carnivore; however, ethically I won't eat foie gras or veal since both are raised in abominable conditions.  The mgmt at PSC doesn't agree with the ban and rather than go along with the will of SF voters, tried to find a way around it by claiming that they weren't within jurisdiction because they are in a federal park.  

So they don't respect SF voters *and* they support torture meat.  They've lost my business forever.
author: David P.

description:
I walked in with two friends of mine last night. Nicely decorated, clean, open layout. I noticed that we were some of the youngest in the place; everyone else seemed to be older with old money. Needless to say, I was hungry and ready for some good ol' American food.

We got seated and after debating for a while, I finally opted to get the fried chicken. While we were waiting, we got treated to some incredibly fresh, tasty bread and butter. My chicken was fried to perfection; good amount of seasoning and the mashed potatoes were yummy. The spinach was less than impressive, but they DID give a very generous portion. If I go back one day, I'm definitely going to get the meat loaf that everyone seems to rave about.

Of course, we had to get dessert, so we actually ordered four: the banana cream pie, the chocolate cupcakes, the beignets and the butterscotch pudding.

THE BEST: chocolate cupcakes. They are made to order, and three mini chocolate cupcakes (served warm) come with a small dollup of cream and chocolate syrup. They have small krispy chocolate balls on the top of the cupcakes which give a good contrast of textures, and in the center: gooey melted chocolaty goodness. It was chocolaty enough, but not chocolate overkill. Definitely get this dessert.

Second best: banana cream pie. It actually came atop a type of flaky, layered crust. Good banana flavor and the pudding was creamy and not too over-the-top.

Close third: beignets. Coming from Texas, I would've expected something more crunchy and deep fried, but it's literally like eating a pillow. It's soft, fluffy and airy. They also provided a honey dipping sauce which was nice. 

Definitely last: butterscotch pudding. I think it had a bit of rum, and the consistency wasn't as creamy or smooth as I would've hoped. The alcoholic flavor was strong, and not as butterscotch-y as I would've liked.

Overall, it's pretty pricey to pay for american comfort food, but I wouldn't mind going again. It's a nice place to have some home favorites.
author: Becky K.

description:
Met friends here for dinner upon the suggestion of a friend.  We were all driving and needed somewhere with easy parking.

Parking: 5 stars
Service: 3 stars.  They let us linger.  If we weren't in the mood to linger, I would say the service was spotty at best.  Don't go here if you have limited time.
Food: 2 stars. maybe. We ordered some appetizers - cheesy toast (grilled cheese cut in triangles) and crabcakes (tasted prefab/frozen, imo).  Eh.  I was on a budget, so I ordered a small mac&cheese and a side of roasted brussels sprouts.  The mac & cheese was a big disappointment - thin, bland sauce and a crust that was not incorporated in any way to the mac.  It just lifted right off.  The brussels were good at first, with some nice roasted garlic, but they were SALTY!  Super salty.  

I don't know if I would come back here.  I also felt it was overpriced for what it was.  I'd rather fight for parking somewhere else.  I just feel like they were lazy about their menu and service because they are going to get the business because of their location.  :/
author: Michelle L.

description: Came here on a Friday night around 8:30 for dinner. By the time we left it was a little after 10pm. We were having a good time chatting with friends, but the service was painfully slooooow. The menu was extremely limited and very different from the menu shown on Yelp. There were no vegetarian entree options except for mac and cheese--in SF that just seems wrong. They did have side salads and we ordered the kale salad. It seemed fresh and healthy, but it was extremely simple and lacking in flavor for $12...just a bunch of raw curly kale, a small handful of sunflower seeds and a tiny bit of sliced radishes with a light, almost nonexistent, balsamic vinaigrette. The burger my bf ordered was tender and juicy, but the bleu cheese they put on it was totally wrong...it was a thick slice of dry and extremely pungent cheese--not melty and gooey as bleu cheese normally is on a burger. The fries were really good, as was the soup of the day (cauliflower puree with a bacon vinaigrette), but you don't spend over $50 per person so you can brag about french fries and a cup of soup. The wine we ordered was a tasty red blend, but we found out later when we got the bill that it was marked up more than double the retail price. I can't imagine how they can survive with such a high markup on their mediocre food and wine in a city that is famous for its seemingly infinite restaurants. I hope it's not for the atmosphere....the lighting was too bright for dinner and the general ambiance was lacking in charm--it reminded me of a brunch place at a senior country club that my grandparents would choose for mother's day or something. Wouldn't recommend.
author: Jessica G.

description:
Busy on Sunday morning with a line outside waiting for them to open.
Great brunch menu, loved the beignet with hot chocolate sauce. Service was efficient but not overly friendly.
author: Monica P.

description:
My wife and I really enjoy going here and having drinks and deserts.
Tim and John at the bar are great people and make us feel like VIP.
author: Jon S.

description:
Finally managed to get here for dinner! We started off at the bar with some Gunpowder ... yum. When we were finally seated, the food came out fast! The portions are huge here - so consider it carefully. The beef stroganoff was delicious - hubby hates mushrooms and even he liked it! The sloppy joes really is as good as you would expect. The sauce is true nostalgia and the beef yummy tender. (I'm getting hungry writing this...drool). The cupcakes were hot out of the oven and perfect! 

The service wasn't over-whelming but wasn't bad either. Just average overall. Try to get a seat by the window - many of the two-top tables are in awkward positions.
author: Sarcastic T.

description:
This place was nice to look at, but overall I had a terrible experience.  First off, our reservation was for 9pm - we booked it a month in advance- and we didn't get seated until 10pm - completely unacceptable.  We were all pretty starving despite the appetizers they sent out (grilled cheese wedges).

We finally got seated, and ordered. They were quick with the drink orders, but our appetizers didn't come until after dinner had arrived.  My boyfriend and I were splitting the meatballs & haloumi app, and the haloumi was cold and hard by the time we got it.  So were the fries that came with our meal.  My burger was okay, but the chicken fried chicken had no discernible taste.  None of our meal was comp'd despite the hour wait to sit down.

Pending a miracle, I would never eat here again.
author: Lauren K.

description:
The location is great, the atmosphere kind of reminds me of a southern old house.  However, the dinner menu is super small.  Not much to choose from.  I had read the Yelp reviews, and was hoping to get the sloppy joes, but I guess they only serve them for lunch or they're off the menu.  Instead, I ordered the hamburger, which was quite tasty.  PSC is a bit pricey for what it is, but again, the atmosphere is really mellow and nice here, plus parking is easy.  A great place to come with your family, or a small group of friends.  My parents would love PSC because you can actually hear each other talk.  I actually saw babies and children at dinner here, which I don't often see in SF.  

Eh- nice, but not sure I'll be back.  Kinda boring....
author: Sarah F.

description:
This is for Sunday Brunch: 4 Stars for location and ambiance, 3 stars for the food.

Honestly, I was pretty underwhelmed by the food and service, I had the daily frittata (cheese, tomato and spinach) which was nothing to write home to mom about. While well prepared, I couldn't tell that there was any cheese in it and since when do restaurants skimp on tomatoes?! I also slathered it with ketchup as it was pretty bland and stuck it on buttered and jellied toast (it was just eggs folks). The side of potatoes had potential, but were not fully cooked.

I understand this place is known for it's cute little gruyere sandwhiches and cinnamon/sugar beignets, which we had for a whopping $8 for 4 small pieces of fried dough. Also, hot tea (tea bag) will cost you close to $4.

It seems to be a cool place to get together with friends and family for brunch, with some classics to boast of. The prices for what you get  however, will keep me from coming back for more anytime soon.
author: nina B.

description: Nice ambience for a classy get-together. Smart casual attire, outdoor seating is nice for a lunch. Portions aren't huge but good quality.
author: a l.

description:
Very shocked that i havent written a review for this place before...i thought i had months ago when it was fresh in my memory!

I had wanted to try this place for AGES, but heard it was always booked, etc. so didnt even try...a group of four of us had planned to finally try circa brunch, and hadnt made reservations. upon hearing the wait would be eternal, we called presidio and they said sure to come on in!
The decor is cute, very old fashioned, typical presidio former military housing  yet social club feel, unfortunately the service was not quite so good.

The drinks and food prices were exorbinant for what they were, and our server was so vacant we probably could have all choked to death during our meals and she wouldnt have noticed...our drinks (including my wild boyfriends soda) took eternity, and she was pretty useless when asking about different dishes as well.  She never filled our waters, and we would wave our arms around to get her attention, all futile.

The ramos fizz was great-my first time trying it, the bloody was decent..and there was one other drink we tried that was pretty good (cant recall, but looked similar to the ramos fizz).

All in all, had it not been for the horrid service, i could handle the prices and would probably return...even with our waitress sucking i may give the place another shot, as i love the presidio!!
author: Danielle J.

description:
Recently enjoyed a meal here with my family...wow!  The food was spot on.  I had a local fish plate that was delicate and flavorful and tried some of my daughters NY Strip and I must say that the flavor was exquisite.  
The dessert was really, really good,  We had the beignets and chocolate pudding (more rich than mousse!).  

I loved our server and the manager Liz was really cool.

Compliments to the chef!
author: Thomas f.

description:
Service: Very good, called to remind us of our reservation, seated us early, cheerful and helpful and well trained. 

Ambiance: Casual, not too loud, very swanky decor. I very much enjoyed it. My only complaint is the very chilly draft from the front door. 

Food: Pretty plating. Overall pretty good. My beet salad was good as was my pork chop. My fellow dinners didn't like their beef tartare, and thought the fish in chips were okay. I think for the prices we expected to be much more impressed. Should everything been about 3 dollars less, particularly a few entrees, I think we wouldn't have had such high expectations. Everything was well cooked, but the highlight was desert. We got 6 excellent desserts to share for a 2 for discounted combo price. All were very good!

Summary - If you enjoy 40's updated ambiance, and well cooked homey meal, you will enjoy this restaurant, but you'll pay a bit more than you might think it worthy.
author: Kat C.

description: nice atmosphere - easy parking and delicious meatloaf! gave it 34stars because it is so noisy and service is hit or miss. Great place for comfort food and when you want to avoid street parking.
author: Ann W.

description: A couple of Fridays back, I went with some friends to Presidio Social Club for dinner.  Seated just behind the Lombard gate in the Presidio, the restaurant is housed within former soldiers' barracks.  Marvelously reenvisioned, it has the feel of an upscale country club with a spacious, open dining room with a bar extending nearly the entire length of the room.  The classic feel marries well with the menu which features old school cocktails like Sidecars and Mai Thai's and entrees like traditional steaks, pork chops, fish 'n' chips and a $17 sloppy joe.  All four of us had the sloppy joe and it was damn good.  I am all about the new American cusuine these days but PSC showed me the classic American still stands up.  Only downside was the somewhat pretentious service by the hostesses but that was soon overshadowed by the food and table service.
author: Saminda W.

description:
Something strange happened yesterday, I woke up thin. I watched Diet Tribe for the first time on Monday night and when I woke up on Tuesday, my jeans from two years ago fit, my friend asked what diet I was on, and I noticed my stomach shrunk. This type of science fiction does not happen to me, as I quit diets within two hours of starting and I only exercise sporadically. 

With my new excitement for life, I celebrated with a dinner at the Presidio Social Club. Not only was I impressed, but I see it as one of my new favorite restaurants. 

There drink menu is impressive. They have a great selection, including Pisco Punch, which I have only seen at Bourbon and Branch, which is not a restaurant. It is a cocktail with pisco alcohol and various juices, with a wedge of pineapple in the drink.

To start, my table shared an order of the Macaroni and Cheese. The only place it compares in the city is to Michael Mina's, which was my favorite, until I tried theirs, now there is an official tie in my opinion. It is creamy, but not soaked and has a wonderful crunch.

For my main dish, this is how the new thin me ordered, "Chicken Fried Steak please." I loved it. The steak was a fillet, not too fatty, dipped in bread crumbs and fried like chicken. It came with some of the best mashed potatoes I have had and a side of garlic green beans. This is the Tuesday special, so if this is what you want, go on a Tuesday. It was so good. 

Other dishes that I saw that I wanted just by looks were the wings a la buffalo, the fondue with toasts, the Sloppy Joe, and the mushroom soup. I could not try everything this time, as I think my stomach shrunk. 

I did not have dessert. I know I often talk about it, but I was too full. I wanted to have the brioche beignets. If you go on my suggestion, have an order from me. I love there dessert menu. They have main desserts and side desserts. You can get one of each for $10.00, which I like. If you just want one, a main dessert is $7.00 and a side dessert is $5.00.

If you are a glamorous socialite, a hipster, a senior, a student, or anyone in between, I think you will love the Presidio Social Club. There is tons of parking, but if you want a table, make a reservation.
author: Christopher W.

description: I loved this place!!!  Can't wait to go back.  Went with friends initially for dinner and drinks on a Thursday night. But I'm taking my husband next time for date night. So romantic and classy. Every thing we ordered was fantastic. Lots of different options on the menu to please everyone. I had the soup of the day which was a very unique cream of cauliflower with olive oil and bacon. We shared the deviled eggs for an appetizer.  I wanted more.  For entree, I had the pork chop of the day. It was seasoned and cooked perfectly. The vegetable of the day was sautéed broccolini.  It was so tasty and healthy that we got another order for the table to share.  We had a drink at the bar beforehand. Wish we could have stayed longer. Our waitress was excellent. Delivered perfect customer service and very personable.
author: Carolyne C.

description:
I just had my first experience at PSC and it was amazing! I came for the roast pig dinner and had so much more. First of all, the roasted pig was perfect! It was cooked perfectly and the skin was nice and crispy. It was served with some well made condiments such as house made kim chee and a chili pepper-vinegar dipping sauce. my wife and I split a salad, pate and some fries. Every dish had so much flavor! You can tell the chef and team really take pride in their work!

Vibe:
Airy, light, casual yet classy!

Portions:
Nice sized portions and great presentations.

The drum set at the entrance is unique and inviting!

The "NEW" PRESIDIO SOCIAL CLUB is a must!
author: James K.

description:
3 stars for great retro vibe, solid food, friendly bartender who crafted pre-dinner drinks to perfection, and killer view outside the window (eucalyptus and palm trees stretching to the sky). 

Bonus star for amazing brioche beignets for dessert - warm, coated in sugar and served with syrup. Om-nom-nom-nom. 

I'll be back :)
author: Jeska D.

description:
The beignets. Get the beignets.

You won't find it on the menu (they are NOT the brioche beignets listed). Oh no. These beignets are secret. These, my friend, are called the "Dirty Dozen." Filled with gooey chocolate. Crème anglaise on the side. Doughy. Warm. Rich. Heavenly.

So they're not that secret anymore. Whatever. The beignets. That is all.
author: Andrew L.

description: I have been here twice before and it was wonderful! Just left dinner and I probably won't be returning. The food is excellent - our waiter was HORRIBLE. The appetizers took FOREVER to come out, and after the waiter took our orders, he seemed to abandon us. We had to flag someone else down to refill our water, I made eye contact with him several times and he visited the surrounding tables several times, and still ignored us. Drinks never refilled, and we waited over 10 mins after eating when I finally flagged the busboy down for a dessert menu. We then couldn't order dessert bc still no one would visit our table. When ordering, my husband reminded him that a dessert came with his meal. Still, with our desserts coming out, he forgot my husband's dessert and only remembered once I reminded him (after all of us were already done). We then waited forever for our check and he dropped it back off without looking at us or speaking to us. So disappointing since the table next to us arrived halfway through our meal and still left before us.
author: Katy M.

description: There the two of us were, seated in the smaller room beacause the main dining room is junior high school cafeteria, without the monitor / adult in the room.  Into the smaller room enters a party of seven extremely young women celebrating the bride-to-be.  Merciful God!  The full-throated screaming insanity was unleashed in a room of six tables.  Management was asked and seemed powerless, or spineless, to end it.  For a down-home experience of junior high behavior without parental constraint or personal inhibition, The Presidio Social Club was made for you and your fondest memories.
author: Jamie M.

description:
This was my second time at PSC and another great experience.  My boyfriend and I went on a Wednesday, so it was extremely easygoing and mellow.  On this date we sat at at the counter to chat with the bartenders, but the tables looked cozy too.  The decor and ambiance is always nice here. 

Menu can best be described as comfort food with a twist.  I had the Presidio Pink Lemonade spiked with limoncello and Campari. Dangerously refreshing.  We started off with the Island Style Tuna Poke which can best be described as a ceviche type mix of cubed raw tuna and vegetables with some yummy chips on the side.  We also ordered a half side of Macaroni and cheese, and the crab stuffed trout.  Yes, that's right. The trout was split open and STUFFED WITH CRAB.  The trout was accompanied by rice pilaf and green beans that were cooked perfectly.  Seriously, I can't remember rice tasting this good at a restaurant.  

Make sure you order the dessert. My favorite is the banana cream pie which is served in a very modern way (circular, on a wafer).  The bartender recommended the lemon meringue cake. I'm not a big cake fan, but this is so well done it actually tasted like pie.
author: Lisa R.

description:
Really kinda like this place. It doesn't seem like San Francisco in terms of the weird mix of crowd (think lots of blue hairs), not very well thought out interior considering how cool the space is and could be, and awkward location smack dab in the Presidio, but all this quirk added up and combined with consistently good, straight-forward food, a kitschy drink menu, a seat at the soda-fountain-esque bar, and cool, old music playing makes for a great weekday night out. 

I've been here several times for drinks and bites at the bar, and just tried out dinner a few nights ago with the fam. We shared a really good grilled peach, blue cheese, walnut, and arugula salad. Simple, fresh, seasonal, and super delicious. The mac 'n cheese we split was nothing to write home about, but my mom sure seemed to like it. We also split the pork shoulder with polenta and flank steak with mashed potatoes. The flank steak was the stand out. Perfectly cooked (requested medium rare and that's just what we got), great flavor and texture. I've also tried the sloppy joe sandwich, tuna poke appetizer, and oxtail sliders all of which were good. Not outstanding, but good.

Their dessert menu is filled with all kinds of old-school, home-y treats but the banana cream pie is my favorite. It's mostly banana, on a thin crispy crust, topped with cream. I'd seriously eat this every morning for breakfast if I could.
author: Sarah M.

description: We went here for a Saturday lunch and it was very good. The weekend menu differs from the weekday, it is brunch inspired. Our server was very good, attentive enough, but not overly so (he kept on saying y'all and called all the ladies miss, he was brought up with manners). The fries were definitely worth the visit, crisp and warm, tossed with parsley and salt. One must save room for dessert here. The salted caramel sundae was crunchy, sweet, and salty. The lemon meringue cake was refreshing, a lemon cake with lemon curd and a meringue icing (I would go back for this). There is outside dining where those brave enough on a cold day can sit with their dogs.
author: Emily W.

description: I think the best way to describe the Presido Social Club is confused.  Its chrome covered, modern inside seems in sharp contrast with its comfort food-style cooking.  Brunch was decent, the eggs florentine featured fresh spinach and just enough hollandaise sauce to not feel overpowering, but the meal fell firmly in the middle of über-rustic and upscale.
author: Michael D.

description: Amazing food and better service. Wonderful ambiance and throw back style coupled with a solid officer style menu.
author: Michael K.

description:
This place is in a very cool location, in my opinion: between Pacific Heights and Cow Hollow, so it scores extra points. The decor is minimal-- communal seating, even!-- so I wouldn't recommend this as a good date locale. But, the gorgeous light flowing through the windows on an early spring afternoon is incredible.
The waitstaff is extremely friendly and polite. Some of the best service in a town not exactly known for the kind of service you get in, say, New York. 
The food is the only drawback. While it's very tasty and pretty reasonably priced for what you get, it's very simple, no-frills cuisine. I never leave here thinking, "wow, I just tried something new that I'll never have again." Instead, I leave thinking, "that was a great place to go on a Sunday dinner with my parents," because, you know, I usually go here at the suggestion of my parents. 'Nuff said, right?
author: Ross S.

description: I enjoyed the ambiance and restaurant environment. We order biscuits and gravy, fried egg sandwich along with the beignets which was delicious. The bottomless mimosas were a nice touch. I will be back again.
author: Cecile R.

description: One of the best pork chops ever.  Excellent Rib Eye.  This place it lots of fun.
author: Clarke H.

description: The waiter was utterly charming but the food was hideous. Absolutely disgusting. The wine was good. Again, the waiter was so nice that it is unfortunate that he is forced to serve that disgusting food. There is no excuse, there are plenty of people in San Francisco who know how to cook!  Gorgeous setting. Guess it is a good place for a drink, but don't try and eat anything there! Also, the menu is really bizarre.
author: Anonanon S.

description:
Popped in with a friend on a Sunday about thirty minutes before they started serving dinner.  

Sat at the bar and ordered the chopped liver, fries and beignets and had a couple cocktails.  The chopped liver was very tasty (lots of pickles served alongside, which I really appreciated) and the fries were delicious.  The beignets were more like donut sticks than beignets, but they were tasty, with a side of maple syrup for dipping.  The drinks were classic cocktails and were well-made.  The bartender was very friendly and made sure we were well taken care of (he paid attention to our food and put the order in for the beignets at a good time).  

The atmosphere is really nice (though the artwork seems a bit out of place) and I could see this place being really fun and full of life.  However, it seems the patrons tens to be on the older side (granted we were there between 5-6pm) and it's not really a "hip" hangout, which I suppose is both good and bad.  But, yeah, it seems like more young retro-lovers would come here regularly than do.

I enjoyed my food and the service here and would definitely go back and try a full meal.
author: Cristina S.

description:
Brilliant!

Wonderful wonderful drinks prepared by the master bartender Tim (formerly of the Majestic) and they are only $8!  I really can't describe how much better Tim's drinks are than the average bartender - you have to experience it yourself.

The food was very good, especially the Mac & Cheese.  Yummmmm the Mac & Cheese is amazing!

Plus I love the atmosphere and it is fun to drive through the Presidio on the way there (you can get there from Lombard street but it is more fun to come from the Jackson street side).
author: lisa g.

description:
I've been meaning to try this place out for quite some time.  Living in NOPA, I have a hard time heading down towards the Marina.  Anyway, the location is fantastic, and the interior has a nice feel to it.  After looking at the menu, I knew that I would have a hard time deciding what to order.  We started off with the gruyere toast and tomato soup dipping sauce (delicious), and the crab cakes (really small, and not that impressive).  After asking the waitress on what to order, I settled on the chicken fried chicken.  The portions are huge, so come hungry!  The CFC was good enough, although did not come with enough gravy.  I had to ask for a side of the gravy otherwise it would have been a bit dry without.  We also ordered a side of mac & cheese (delicious) and roasted brussel sprouts (bit soggy - overcooked).

The service was a bit slow, but good company and good food made up for it.  I'll definitely try it again...the short rib stroganoff looked delicious.
author: Vince B.

description: We went here last night for a girls dinner and I left happy. The place has a fun decor and the food was great! Service was fine, it seemed our server got a bunch of tables at once, so I think he was a bit busy, but he tried hard. We had the crab fondue (which was pretty small), the cheese toasts and tomoto dip and broccoli to start off with, all delicious, not the biggest portions but good! Then I had the fish of the day which was salmon and DELICIOUS! I recommend this place for a good fun meal!
author: Jenny I.

description:
Dining at the Presidio Social Club is like stepping back into the 1940's ala, the movie The Cotton Club.

The owners of this restaurant have done such an amazing job with the atmosphere, from the high ceilings and dark wood trim; to the stark white walls, marble counter top on the bar and the vibrantly green palm trees being blown gently by ceiling fans.

I loved the vibe of this restaurant.  So did everyone else in my party.

The food was pretty good, too... I had a glass of the PSC Pinot Noir (quite tasty,) fried oysters w/bacon aoli and prime rib/mashed potatoes for dinner.  Spark had the fillet of sole, Momma had fish n' chips, bro had the Kobe Sloppy Joe and sissy-in-law had Mac n' Cheese... they were all equally as happy with their dinner selections and I anticipate PSC being a repeat destination for the family Padak whenever we gather together in SF.

When we were done I was super full and could barely stay awake in the car as my brother drove me home...
author: Kate R.

description: We were nearby for a SAG member screening at the theater in the presidio and this was walking distance away. Food was yummy, atmosphere was lil cold, but drinks warmed us up. Id go again if hitting another screening. Staff was really nice, place filled up pretty quickly,  but parking wasnt an issue at all. Got there at 5 and place was hoppin when we left at 6:30. Most of what I love about the city, fun places to eat, with a happy crowd in a corner you dont normally find tourists at. Enjoy, we did
author: Peter I.

description:
Five full stars for being the new home of Tim, my favorite bartender.  
Five full stars for the Cannibal Sandwich (raw beef with onions on rye). 
Five full stars for the beignets.  
Five full stars for the perfectly spiced duck with noodles.  
Five full stars for well liquors that are found high on the shelf at many establishments.  
Five full stars for being well thought out without being overly conceptual.   

And, again, five big, big stars for being the place that brought my favorite bartender home.
author: L W.

description: This place has an old-world glam to it. Sort of like what you would expect the dining hall of a country club from the 1950s to look like. I love the vintage ceiling fans, and old fashioned cocktails, and porch that wraps around the place. Parking is easy, the comfort food is fantastic, and the service is great. I particularly like their meatloaf and steak. Also would recommend their rye cocktails and magnolia IPA.
author: Michelle T.

description:
My last relationship started in the Presidio so I am very familiar with the Lombard gate, much to the surprise of my friends, who know me as someone who never goes north of market EVER. But, it was my very classy friend's birthday, so off I went to this little corner of the city, which much like my life, has gone through quite a few changes in the past 4 years. For one, that person now hates me and for two, there was nothing to eat except moles in the Presidio the last time I hung out here (kidding. I would never eat moles! They are adorable! even I have my meat eating limits). 

Anyway, much like my friend and his lady, this place is not only attractive, well lit & classy, the cocktails are top notch and amazing. I have a very intense love of gin & their delightful "Original Aviator" cocktail does the juniper tree juice that I love so much lots of justice.  The food was pricey, but the kobe beef sloppy joe that we split was really good, especially with the french fries, which is my second love in life, after gin. Not gonna lie though, we still felt compelled to stop for some Indian food on the way home. But, you don't have to.

Anyway, I like this place. It's nice to know that the college students and stoners who live in the Presidio can have a place to come for a date without having to travel to the murky waters of Chestnut or Union Street.
author: Maria D.

description:
My husband and I go here all the time now: best cocktails ever, really great service, and the food has become SO good. It used to be okay, but now it rocks. We try to order something different every time, and now we're convinced that they've upped their game. 

One dish we go back to is the bavette steak - unbelievably good. We also went crazy the other week and ordered almost every dessert from the menu. (Even those were better than before.) Also, about six months ago I decided to let my waiters choose a wine for me, and now I'm never going back to picking my own. These people are seriously wise. 

The ambiance feels dressy, historic, a bit like a club, but the people who work here are so nice that you don't feel bad showing up in jeans and a t-shirt. The food is the same blend of comfort and ritz. If you don't try one of their cocktails, you're missing out. 

One gripe: I wish they would put in more plants or something, it gets a bit loud. Also: lovely views of the Presidio and plenty of parking.
author: zoe f.

description:
This is the place where my boyfriend, who is a very witty man, coined the term Haley's Waitress, 'cause, you know, you see your waitress every 76 years.  Strangely enough though, there always seems to be about 14 bus boys wandering around.  If only those bus boys could bring you things like, food, cocktails or your check.

It is a great little place to have a cocktail. It's pretty, the music is nice, and most importantly, the cocktails are creative and tasty.

Unfortunately, the same can not be said for the food.

The mac n cheese was amazing - and for $15 it should be.  But every other dish we have tried in our 3 or 4 visits have been rather... just... ok. 

We have found the best plan to be, arrive, order cocktails and one or two apps.  Then, the overly attentive busboys will continue to refill your bread and (foil wrapped, what the hell you be charging me $25-$30 per entree and giving me foil wrapped) butter, which absorbs the cocktails splendidly.  

Or at least that was the plan.  *hic* 

Boyfriend on the other hand says he will not bother to waste his eating energy on the two apps - even to get the 14 free bowls of bread.  Apparently he is fine with me being that drunk.

I mean friendly.
author: Cosmolicious L.

description:
At times, I can have a gay man's sense of pageantry.  When Mimi suggested a place for ladies' night, all I heard was "Social Club," and I was like, "let's get dressy, bitches!"  

The atmosphere definitely didn't disappoint.  An Art Deco diner with some modern fixtures set in the trees of the Presidio, you've got to love the little old school touches, like having your drinks handed to you on a silver tray.  I definitely didn't feel out of place in my ladies' night dress, but nor would I in my favorite pair of jeans.

Instant love: mac n cheese, Malbec by the glass or bottle, capirinhas, and beignets with chocolate pudding.  My flat iron steak was quite good, and I like that not only were they able to cook it black and blue, but the waitress didn't look at me like I had sprouted a second head when I asked if it could be prepared as such.  Prices weren't dirt cheap but they weren't nauseatingly expensive, either.  Service was unrushed, an absolute must for ladies' night.

Oh, and for the upcoming nightly specials, I would like to put my vote in now for a fried chicken plate.
author: Tanya N.

description: Great lil brunch spot tucked away in the Presidio with parking!  A good change up from your usual weekend ritual of breakfast in the Marina.  Nice bar with a small tv if you're looking to dine and watch some Sunday football.  Pretty good brunch selection- had the daily fritatta with greens and toast w homemade jam!  Beware- the Mimosa's can add to the tab $$$ quickly at $10 a pop!
author: Samantha A.

description:
This place has really gone downhill.  Yesterday was the second of two disappointing return visits.

On a return 6 months ago for dinner the food was bland, and not just like lacking salt, but bland.

Yesterday, three of us went for brunch.  The dining room has not even half full.  Waitress was dazed and confused.  The kitchen must have been on a break because it took 40 minutes from ordering to get our food.  I cook a lot of eggs at home and know it does not take anywhere near that long.  Unless they were chasing the hens through the wilds of the Presidio, which I highly doubt.  And then to top it off, it didn't arrive piping hot.

Not once did the waitress acknowledge to us that we were waiting an unusually long time, etc.  We even had to go to the bar to order our drinks because our waitress would never make eye contact with us.  The only concession made by the restaurant was to give us a free plate of toast - brought by the busboy, no less.
author: darla s.

description:
Holy!  Cow!  I had, perhaps, one of the most fun days of my life when I went to Presidio Social Club.  So okay, that might make me biased...but I don't think so...

Can I just say we had the BEST bartender.  Steven?  He shook our drinks with finesse and a little somethin' extra.  He taught us about some liquor we'd never heard of before.  Then after wards, sipping on marvelous drinks, we watched Breakfast at Tiffany's.  

Now, my company was 6 stars...but all in all I thought everything about Presidio Social Club was impressive...staff, food, drink, decor.  Absolutely the most fun afternoon I can recall.
author: Jess S.

description: After a run through the wind tunnel to Fort Pt last night, my date and I decided to go straight to the alcohol. We first stopped off at Liverpool Lil's..but nothing on the menu looked good to me. Since we were parked next to the Presidio Social Club, my friend suggested we go there. I hesitated a bit as I was dressed in my running cloths (yes..I am vain) but we went in anyway. To my surprise, we received a warm welcome by the handsome bartender. He brought us our drinks and a side of fries right away. I loved everything on the menu but we settled on a couple of seafood cocktails (scallop and tuna tar-tare), the chopped liver (which was more like pate) and the pulled pork with oysters. The food was rich and delicious--a wonderful reward for our jog. It's somewhat hidden location makes the place even more desirable for future visits.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Four stars for the drink alone (Moscow Mule).  The bartender was awesome, chatty in the best way, great in the server way, and incredibly knowledgeable in the curiosity way.  I have to say the atmosphere is right up my alley:  the the best blend of old and new.   Old pharmacy cabinets (I totally called it!) from the Letterman Hospital and the building itself, and great new design with the tables and art.   The food was solid, although I have to say a Kobe beef Sloppy Joe is really a food-snob dream as well as an overpriced fool's dream.  Otherwise I would say the food is solid three stars.  I had a special: lobster pot pie, and I wouldn't recommend it.  The flat iron steak looked great  and the Portuguese stew the same.

And not to forget:  I saw a San Francisco type star:  Walt Disney's daughter.  She is leading the construction of the Disney's Family Museum at the Presidio and I can't wait to see it.  The collection I suspect will be awesome.
author: Amanda B.

description:
It has now been irrefutably confirmed that cocktail heaven is adorned with languidly drooping giant potted palms and an exquisite, endless seeming Carrera marble bar. 

I'm convinced that a kind of magic is practiced by the alchemists who reside behind that bar. The drinks they conjure forth truly manage a kind of fleeting perfection... It's a good thing too, because tomorrow the hangover that sampling several invariably inspires will truly feel worth it, at least, mine did...


PS. Happy birthday dear P, happy birthday to you.
author: Stellah D.

description: Went here for lunch with Attitude Girl and Mamasan. Had the artichoke soup and the roast lamb sandwich from the special Easter menu. Both were really good. The pork belly side was ok - a bit bland and oily. Attitude Girl got the burger with bacon and onion. That was a decent burger. The Arnold Palmer was a bit light though...
author: Ace. K. M.

description: Used to love this place. It had good drinks, food & service in the past. & PARKING! 1st visit in awhile: drinks were smaller, "half" roasted chicken was dried-out (& not quite half), but the meatloaf, cheese toast & peas were good. I told our server about the chicken, but she did nothing.  We took the chicken home & doused it w/ bbq sauce to make it palatable. Wrote a letter to PSC & they sent an apology letter which sounded rather insincere and re-used.  We won't be back for a long time. There are other American comfort food restaurants nearby, like the Buckeye in Marin w/ bigger drinks and much better service and food.
author: Al W.

description: Been here a good amount of times (only because I had to) and will say that it's expensive and the food is just ok... There are many many better options on Union or Chestnut so just check out a new restaurant there.
author: Paul C.

description:
I give the Social Club four stars because it's fun and old-school, not because it's a top drawer foodie dig.  What I liked most about the place was the adventurous feeling of leaving the city by traveling a few blocks into the Presidio.  The atmosphere is a little more family-minded than other city spots and I expect that a good % of the patrons are down from Marin or Pac Heights so the crowd has more class than some other joints in the vicinity.  

The martinis were good, but not as dirty as I like them.  My steak was tasty, but not brilliant.  On the whole this is a good change of pace and would be an excellent spot to throw a private party.
author: John M.

description:
Given the uneven reviews here, I was not poised to love this place.  But wow.  Good stuff.

First sign of a good time: the cool space.   It has character.  History.  It was updated with class.  The bar setup kind of reminds me of an old-school pharmacy or apothecary or something (but with warm, flattering lighting) - I'm into the way they display their liquor bottles behind vintagey glass.  In fact, the whole place has that clean, airy, retro-modern feel that is very appealing.  I was strangely relaxed - as if I was far, far away from modern-day San Francisco.  Escapism.  I like.

The retro theme continued to the drink and food.  This includes portion sizes.   I mean, maybe I'm just used to monster martini glasses that could double as wash basins, but these were teeny-tiny - if I wasn't such a lady I'd have downed my sidecar in three sips.   Because it was smooth enough (and, on the lower note, light enough on the brandy) to do so.

Naturally the dainty drink sizes encourage multiple orders.  After ordering three (and I was hardly tipsy - hmmm) from the dapper white-coated bartender, we moved onto dinner.

Which was suitably throwback.  The small, plastic-laminated, California diner-esque menu offered such goodies as Kobe-style sloppy joes (which we ordered - delicious) and liver and onions (which we didn't).   The textbook-perfect escarole/endive salad with bacon and fried egg had me angry that we were sharing (internal monologue: "I want my own, I want my own, my own, my own").   Roast chicken with fries: solid.  Trout amandine with brown butter and sauteed spinach: even better.  

This is classic, simple, honest food done right.  I like that they serve proteins naked, so you can pick your side.  I like that the appropriately un-huge portion sizes make me feel not fat (well, except when it came to dessert: I really wanted the individual banana cream pie to be bigger, and did I really have to share the three baby chocolate cupcakes with the table? They should all be mine!).   I like that prices are un-high and the clientele low-key.  And I like the nice, efficient staff.   I like everything about this place.
author: Melissa B.

description:
This is a nice place; great atmosphere & location and plenty of parking. It definitely has the physical qualities to become a decent "social club." Despite my review of the dinner I had there I will go back, but probably only for lunch. 

I went here for dinner and was thoroughly dissapointed. Their "free" water is literally room temperature tap water, same water that comes out of my bathroom sink. No ice, no lemon...nothing. I had to have them take it back and pay $5 for a bottle of spring water. For the price you pay for the food, you would think they could comp the spring water. Another outrageous beverage charge is the $4 old-style bottled sodas. Damn they're tasty, but $4 for a 12 ounce soda is uncool. Make them 2-bucks max and I'll buy more than one. Better yet, give me soda with free refills from the fountain behind the bar. 

On to the food. The appetizers took forever to come and when they did were either way over seasoned or had no flavor at all. We had a tomato soup that was VERY good, actually it's the only food I had there that I can say this about. 

The entree's were small, overpriced, and generally not appetizing at all. The chicken had no flavor and the steak was not only cold, but almost a nuclear red color throughout. (I asked for medium-well). I couldn't finish it out fear of contracting some food-born illness. 

The food took so long that I had to skip dessert, assuming it would take another 20 minutes to come. 

Their bathroom was surprisingly dirty for such a small restaurant. Don't get me wrong, it's a nice bathroom with a super cool trough-style sink, but judging by the copious amounts of urine on the floor I could tell it hadn't been cleaned/mopped in a long time. The restaurant is too small & not busy enough to warrant lack of upkeep of the restrooms. But hopefully it was just that time. 

As you can tell I was definitely unimpressed, but I still have hope for this place. I'll stay away for dinner, but I will go back for lunch to try the Kobe Beef Sloppy Joe.
author: Justin B.

description: The food and drinks are good..although i was surprised the veggie soup was gray & totally overcooked!! But the passive aggressive server who shot me several dirty looks throughout our dinner really put a damper on my experience:( I was a server for years and have to say I've never been so upset by anyone waiting on me until Lindsey came along! So I decided to do something I've never done and give her a bad tip : / Soooo, of course as our group left she had the nerve to run out the door after us to ask for more tip money!  Everyone was stunned! It was historical in a way though...I mean this is who she was all night to our table..a totally bitch and for that I would never recommend the Presidio social club.
author: Mary N.

description:
For some reason I am truly drawn to the building and admire the simplicity of the place.  I love the Presidio National Park and truly admire the way that they are saving buildings and building a few new ones.  

The bar was fantastic.  The bartender made a perfect Side Car and the Mai Tai was amazing!  Crisp clean and perfectly proportioned.  

The meal was a solid a "good".  But the experience was "great". The two ladies that were with me LOVED their Alaskan Cod dish.  

I recommend the place and for sure will go back!
author: Ryan B.

description: Wow! Late seating, average food with expensive prices, terrible service except at tip time, and pig roast that tastes just like turkey.  Never again, too many good choices in San Fran to waste your $ on this place.
author: T B.

description:
I was a little apprenhensive when I first heard that this was among our choices for a group dinner on a Friday.  It looked like another overpriced semi-Marina establishment that is cashing in on a location and a gimmick.  Well, I was right, but the food was excellent, so I can forgive Presidio Social Club its sins.  (You do not have to say 50 Hail Marys as a penance.)

The restauarnt is tucked just west of the Lombard gate to the Presidio on the south side of the road.  The exterior looks more like a trailer park office than a restaurant.  I actually liked the look though because the building seems to preserve the character of the old army base.  (This is a good thing people.  San Francisco may be anti-war, but there is no need to trample on the history of the military and denigrate the men and women who have made tremendous sacrifices so that we can enjoy meals like the Presidio Social Club serves.)

The interior is not very plush or friendly, but I liked the 50's feel it had.  Our waiter was very friendly, accommodating, and patient considering we had about 10 people.  Kudos to him.  The drink menu is excellent, and our waiter checked on altering a drink for me, which I appreciated a great deal.  The drink list is long and chock full of bourbon, rye, and gin.  Very much in keeping with the 50's kitcsch of the restaurant.  

I started with the gruyere toast and tomato dipping sauce.  Totally overpriced at $8.50 because it was really grilled cheese and tomato soup.  Once again though, I was willing to overlook this because it was very tasty.    My girlfriend had the lentil soup.  She thought it was good.  I hate lentils, so I had a tiny taste which instantly brought back horrible childhood memories of being forced to eat lentils because, "they's good for you!!!"  We ordered two plates of mac and cheese for the table.  They remained true to the theme of the Social Club: overpriced but excellent.  I snuck a couple of extra forkfuls when people were not looking.  Next up was a spaghetti special.  Excellent.  Much better than the crap they serve at Delfina.  (This is part of my ongoing campaign against Delfina...a.k.a. the worst restaurant in San Francisco.)

Overall an excellent experience.  I did not see any couples there, and I don't think it is a good date restaurant.  It was a ton of fun with a large group.
author: Chris I.

description:
My friend has been raving about the Presidio Social Club saying it was his new favorite restaurant. I was a little hesitant because I have sort of a love-hate relationship with the Presidio, mainly because of sad experiences at the old Letterman Hospital, but that's another story.

The first thing I noticed is that the lighting is odd, dimly light with pseudo-old light bulbs. I like dim, but there was something weird about the color of the light. The hostess was great and seated us right away even though we were early for our reservations. 

Ordered drinks and hors d'ouvres, scallops and butternut-squash stuffed cannoli. Scallops were a little on the small side, but were good with nice presentation. The cannoli was fantastic.

My friends ordered the short rib bourguignonne and bouillabaisse. I got the kobe beef sloppy joe. All the food tasted and looked great. The sloppy joe meat was really tender and had great flavor, it came with skinny fries, which were OK.

For dessert, I got the apple cobbler. It was good, but the mouse that came with it was out of this world. When I put it in my mouth, it seemed to evaporate with a burst of sugary goodness, truly a weird, but delightful sensation.

The service here started off great, but it seemed like our waitress forgot about us towards  the end and we had to flag down the busboy or other waitresses to get more drinks and coffee.

The Presidio Social Club was overall very good and I would go back, it just didn't knock my socks off.
author: Jim K.

description: Always enjoy my visits here... best on a warm afternoon when you can sit on the patio.... everything is good. Love the Bloodies, Benedict, Taters, Soups, sammis. I wouldn't call it gourmet (which I'm not there for), but great for small or large groups. Just make a resi on busy nights and Sundays.
author: Adam X.

description:
Visited for the first time on a busy Saturday night. Arrived promptly  for our 8:15 reservation and was told by the hostess that our table was not ready. I asked when the table might be ready and she indicated, without any certainty, that it could be twenty minutes or more, seemingly annoyed by my question. No apology was offered. Not a good first impression.

Ordered a cocktail at the bar which was well made. We were finally seated around 8:40 in what had to have been the worst table in the place. We were surrounded by an aisle on each side that served as the only path of travel to tables behind us, so it was a constant stream of activity going by. Sometimes you get lucky with the table, sometimes not.

We started with a round of Caesar salads. Salads were fine, anchovies were excellent. For the entree my wife and I split a Painted Hills bone-in ribeye for 2.  Price was a reasonable $64 and included two side dishes. We ordered Broccoli DeCicco and fries. Broccoli was great, the fries were average. 

Oddly, the waiter brought out the cooked ribeye, unsliced, and showed it to us before it was cut. Not sure what the point of that was and we couldn't tell anything about the steak from a visual. Nonetheless, the steak was served a perfect medium rare and had very good flavor. Unfortunately the entire steak was over salted. My wife and I are salt fiends but this was over the top and really took away from the flavor. Someone obviously heavily salted the steak after slicing as every piece was salty.  We almost sent it back but were with another couple and did not want to disrupt the meal, and I felt bad about sending back a $64 steak. 

I did not sample dessert but heard from my dining companions it was good.

As for atmosphere, the place was packed and extremely loud. On this particular night, it was not really my scene. Seemed a mix of Southern Marin and Presidio/Pacific Heights, and was an older crowd.  

Our server was very good and friendly, and described the specials and other dishes well.

I hate to give a negative review on a place that may have had an off night but there were too many misses on this night.
author: Mike W.

description:
I came here last night was Liz S and I was quit pleased with PSC! The outside is just a plain barrack located right in the Presidio. You would never know you're in a restaurant. Once you walk in, you can feel the bustling vibe of the place. It has a very "old school" feel to the place, but yet very updated and clean.

I thought the menu offerings were quit limited and nothing was really catching my eye, so I decided to order two appetizers instead. The crab "cupcakes" sounded really unique, so I decided to order that and the cannibal sandwich. The crab cupcakes turned out to be just crab cakes presented in a paper cupcake holder. It wasn't has unique as I thought, but nevertheless it was delicious. I really enjoyed my cannibal sandwich. It was basically toasted "black" bread topped with a tasty spread and thin slices of steak tartare. It was really good! I was impressed with the portions because it really was satisfying. I would highly recommend this dish. Liz's slow roasted pork and oyster hash was wonderful. It was very juicy and tasty. The oyster hash had a really nice twist to it. 

For dessert, we shared the banana cream pie and brioche beignets. Both were divine!!! You know they were good when Liz and I both finished both desserts up and said (at the same time) "I love dessert!" The bcp was very light and yummy.. the crust was thin and flaky and the banana cream filling was smooth and I loved that it consisted of tiny chunks of banana. The beignets were like larger versions of donut holes. They were warm and soft and topped with sugar and cinnamon. The sweet syrup dipping sauce was really good too.

Overall, I would definitely recommend coming here for a casual dinner or with the family or parents!
author: Denise L.

description:
Luckily for us, this is the first negative restaurant review I've ever given.  We are SF residents who have been visiting Presidio Social Club since the night it opened.  We are neat, well-groomed, with normal appearances.
On a Sunday evening at 6:30 we walked in and were seated quickly, at a table for 2 in the first section, on the isle, across from the bar.  Not in the back, not by the window, nor in a corner.  Front and center in the room.  Empty tables all around us, so they were not crowded.  We prused the menu, discussed what we felt like, what we were going to drink, etc.  No one approaced us.  Wait staff and busboys milling all around.  The busboys kept looking at our table, as if to clear it, but no one offered water or assistence.  The hostess kept seating people, she could see we still were holding the menus.  A short, dark man who seemed to be a manager, was also wandering around, overseeing the tables; but he also ignored us.  The 
wait staff was attending to tables all around us, not rushed, just checking in with the diners.  No one ever spoke to us.  No offer of water, no 'I'll be right with you', no eye contact.  It was so not busy that the bar wasn't even full.  No one ever responded to our eye contact. We waited more than 15 minutes, then quietly walked out, even tho I was furious.
Obviously, we will never patronize this location again.  We had a lovely, QUIET, delicious dinner just a few blocks away, also a regular destination.  As locals, you can bet I'm going to spread the word to everyone I know to discourage them from dining here.
Restaurants rise and fall in the City.  No one can afford to be so self-assured to rest on his laurels.
author: Deco D.

description:
I'm sorry to give this place a low rating because I've really liked it in the past - good food, great atmosphere, friendly service - but after going there for an after-dinner drink last Sat night, I really have no choice.

We sat at the bar and sat and sat and sat.  Even though there were only five or six other people sitting at the bar, the bartender completely ignored us.  He was chatting away with people and when we finally got his attention, he seemed annoyed to have to come over and take our drink order.  He was cold and perfunctory and once he brought our drinks, he was gone again.  Totally gone.  

After waiting and waiting for him to come back so we could pay our check, we finally just started waving some cash in his direction in the hopes he'd get it.  He still didn't.  Another man - the manager perhaps? - came over, saw that we wanted to leave and then signaled to the bartender.  Again, he skulked over, didn't offer an apology or even any words, other than what we owed him.  His attitude left a worse taste in the mouth than the shitty port I drank.

I now call it, "The Presidio Anti-Social Club."
author: Suzanne L.

description: I always want to give this place a lot of stars. Really, I do. But every time I go there, it's just...meh... If it were a dive, I might have rated it better (because my experience overall would be more than meets the eye). But it's not. Ever. It's just that it has such a regal atmosphere with not so regal service or cuisine....I can't say I go there for any reason other than I know I can walk in and get a table/parking when I'm hungry...
author: Lucy C.

description: Love this place. It's not an everyday place. Expensive and classy food, but a more casual vibe. Never have had a bad meal or bad service here. Their desserts are off the hook.
author: Matt J.

description:
I wanted to wear linen.  My wife said she felt like she wanted to catch a train.  It had the feel of an expat enclave in Hong Kong.  The drink menu promised as much:  three or four different mules, a handful of manhattan variations, a pegu club.  

Unfortunatlely, the PSC is more style than substance.  The menu was limited.  We took a long time to order, but only because nothing looked all that great (a rarity for upscale SF restaurants, especially one so self-consciously groomed).  

The only decent dish was the starter, the fish plate of the day, which was a local albacore (though, it was pitched as barely cooked, and in fact it was in danger of being overcooked).  The mac and cheese had good crunchy bits on top -- that was a solid dish, too.

But, the fish and chips were too short on the fish and too long on the chips.  The butter lettuce salad was good, but not great.  And the seasonal veggies--blue lake green beans--seemed like they had been cooked since the day before.  If the food was fresh, the chef made sure to hide it. 

The only reason this place doesn't get one star is because of the great ambiance.  And the cocktails.  And the fact that it's just so damn easy to deal with--parking right outside the door.  A friend of a friend described it as an upscale Denny's, and that's basically right, if you're prepared to spend $50 per person for Denny's type food.

On the way out, we noticed that the PSC has a second room:  where as the main room is  gorgeous and sexy, the overflow room is lit with florescents, with no decor to speak of, where they seemed to stash the not so attractive folks.  How awful.  A seat there would make the PSC utterly without any redeeming qualities.
author: Ben A.

description:
I had a cocktail that was a mix of cognac, champagne and lemon as my first drink at the Presidio Social Club, and yes, it was just as gross as it sounds. Maybe my impression of this place was skewed -- along with my palate -- by that toxic, horrible mixture of alcohols that have no business occupying the same glass, or maybe I felt like one of those strange misplaced alcohols as I attempted to mingle in the yuppified crowd at this place.

There is only one vegetarian entree on the menu: a disgustingly bland and revoltingly expensive $15 macaroni and cheese. The side order of asparagus was blah, and the wine was straight up nasty. The saving grace of the meal was the dessert -- the lemon meringue pie was definitely edible. The dessert and appetizer sections of the menu were far more diverse (and appealing) than the entrees, and it was evident that people who know better go there only for side dishes, dessert and booze.

Maybe I am just jaded, but I found the atmosphere so contrived it made my skin crawl. I'm not exactly a Pottery Barn aficionado, but I can see how some people would find it charming. 

Bottom line: great place to please the Norman Rockwell-esque crowd, but leave the people with taste at home.
author: Emily D.

description:
I love the Presidio.  It is one of my favorite places in SF.  Presidio Social Club is a fun well-done restaurant with good service.  The atmosphere is perfect with old bentwood chairs, a vintage drum set in the entrance and a classic bar in the back.  The wait staff is friendly and honest.  I have been here many times and plan on returning.  The last time I went, I took two out of town guest and my roommate.  I had a reservation, but the table was running over.  No big deal, had one of their fabulous handmade drinks.  While waiting, the waitress brought us a complimentary appetizer.  Nice touch.   

The food is all delicious.  They have a small menu and done well.   I highly recommend coming here for brunch, lunch or dinner.
author: Megan M.

description:
Loved it.  Simply loved it.  

Ambiance= 5 stars. How can you beat the beautiful Presidio? And on top of it - they kept the fundamental building nostalgic with a few contemporary renovations. I love the look. The bar counter is great.

Food= 5 stars. I normally don't order chicken when I am out, but I decided to that night for some reason. It was absolutely outstanding. Had a choice of sides to go with it. Chose the mashed sweet peas. Unbelievable. So good. 

Drinks= 5 stars. You know why? Great margaritas for $5. Nuf said.

Service= 3. Now, this was strange. Sat at the bar counter. You'd think - can't go wrong here with service, right? Wrong. Our server/bartender was strange. He seemed too busy serving the drinks for the waiters for those at tables, and couldn't seem to handle that as well as wait on us at the bar right directly in front of him. Considering the length of the bar and how busy the restaurant is these days, they should have three bartenders behind that bar to properly serve everyone. I will be going back this week for a second try. Let's hope it was just an off night.
author: Anna S.

description:
I was in love even before walking into the restaurant.  

There's parking.  Parking.  Yes, parking.  And though I arrived in a taxi, having a place to take Mama that has parking is HUGE!

The space inside is very well utilized.  It is fairly long, but does not feel too big.  The dark booths and green plants add a certain coziness.  Whoever did the design on the inside did a great job.  

I started with the crab cupcakes.  I could have eaten twenty.  They melt in your mouth.  

The Dorade that I ordered as my main was way too fishy for my taste, so I actually sent it back and ordered the mac and cheese.  The mac was great.   Perfect crispy breadcrumb crust on top.

The wine list is super easy to manage.  Several GREAT bottles under $50.

The staff was also super friendly and helpful.

I can't wait to go back!
author: Amme P.

description:
