This is the first of my "Dinner before The Menace's Attic on KUSF" reviews, sure to be a regular thing.

The scene: Radio show at 9 pm on Friday night. Finished my workout at the J.C.C. and didn't feel like going home before the show.

The place: P.S.C. I had been there for post show drinks with two of my fellow rock and roll dads (their wives let them go, I was the single dad and my little girl was with mom as she always is on Friday nights.)

The location: The Bar for dinner. Same bartender from the last time. The food is as Larry David would say: "PRETTY  darn GOOD." I had the white fish (gosh I should have written this sooner though I want to say Escolar) on Mashed potatoes. 

Okay not the BEST food I've had in SFO. And I didn't have time for dessert.  I will go back for a longer dinner with friends to enjoy what is a really good looking place. 

I know, the Presidio is getting commercial. Have no fear, from what I can tell on my through it on a daily basis, there's lots of wilderness left. (This last paragraph had nothing to do with the restaurant review - and if Yelp had an editor, they probably would have cut it out!)
author: Dennis S.

description:
Brace yourselves, friends, this is not going to be short and sweet...

My boyfriend and I have decided to try all the restaurants in the Presidio because he lives, like, right there. So if the places are good, then it's super convenient and chill. As much as I love to be a diva, I much prefer a low-key, classy establishment to one with all the bells and whistles (and drama, attitude, etc).

With that said, I thought Presidio Social Club was a bit too high and mighty for its own good. My boyfriend made dinner reservations for 7, and we were seated in the main dining room. We wanted to order the buffalo burger  from the "secret menu" (Bunker Buster or something like that)... Well, apparently items from the secret menu can only be ordered in the dining room after 9pm or at the bar. This isn't exactly widely broadcast information. It also took about 10 minutes to get water and bread, and another 10 minutes to receive our cocktails. On a Thursday. Business wasn't exactly lining out the door. 

So we spoke to the manager and the hostess to see if the chef-owner would make an exception just this once since there was no one else sitting around us. 

NO.

So my guy and I are trying to have a sense of humor about this situation. When he made the res he specifically said he wanted to order this supposedly amazing buffalo burger, that was the whole point of coming here. And now he couldn't order it?

Hmm. How do we resolve this? 

We ordered some drinks and told the manager we would like to wait for an opening at the bar, and that we would eat there.

Done and done. Boyfriend ordered the buffalo burger (which I had a bite of, and yes, it was worth the hassle and drama, but next time, let's avoid the hassle and drama shall we?) and I ordered the Mac and Cheese which was also very good. 

The manager sent over comped desserts from the secret menu and the regular dessert menu (smores, chocolate cupcakes, and a coffee ice cream and mousse cake) and when the bill came we discovered the drinks were also comped.

So the Presidio Social Club handled their fuss and pomp with some class and dignity in the end, and my boyfriend and I may someday go back again. 

But we're in no rush.
author: Christy M.

description:
Maybe it's just me but I feel like I left the 2000s behind me the moment I stepped inside the restaurant and was instantly transported into the 1940s.  For a renovated Presidio building, it is plush and comfortable and cozy.  And being inside on a rainy night, enjoying evening cocktails just enhanced the romanticism of being here.

All that said, my friend and I couldn't help ourselves - we indulged from cocktails to dessert before we had to finally peel ourselves away. 

To start off, we went for cocktails...I had a French 75 - which was mixed well.  If you don't know what that is - a French 75 is brandy and champagne mixed with lemon juice - at least that's how they serve it here.  And from there we had the oxtail and biscuits, which is code for fall off the bone oxtail in a wine reduction sauce and served as sliders.  All that combined was a selling point for us.  For our entrees, the beef brisket was fairly good but not as good as the oxtail and biscuits.  Also, the mac and cheese was pretty good, but not being the big mac and cheese connoseur (I mean, some are), I thought it was all right.  

All was forgiven, however, and put right on track once we got to dessert.  Oh yeah, we were taking our time and enjoying dinner.  We had the cupcakes and smores.  Oh - and that's another thing - there is a deal if you get more than one dessert - there are desserts and then there is a siiide of dessert, get my drift?  For both, it's $10.  So, why get one when you can get 2?  We got the cupcakes and smores.  The cupcakes have a little crunch to them on top.  Then the smores are so soft, they almost smoosh down the second you pick them up - so be careful!

Entrees tend to run around $20 here, more or less.  For me, the biggest winners were the desserts, the appetizers, and the drinks (including the tawny port I had at the end) - in that order.  For each, they ran around the $10 area.  I'm willing to admit that maybe there are winning entrees, but for now, I'm happy enough with everything that came before and after. 

The service is also great.  I never felt like our waitress was inattentive at all, which seems to be a rarity these days.  She was always willing to give recommendations and was easily accessible.

Be aware that it is a little tricky to locate.  The restaurant resides close to the Lombard Gate, you would have to turn on the very next street inside the presidio.  Well worth the trip, though.  If you have out of towners looking for a little of that old San Francisco style, well here it is.  Can't go wrong here.  Expect to spend a little; though, I consider it a small drop in the bucket when they appear to be one of those places that pays tribute to the hey days of San Francisco with the verve and aplomb of taking you back there with them.
author: Lorraine D.

description: 6 of us went for lunch two Saturdays ago and all our dishes were just average in taste. Also,we had to return one of the cocktails which was done quite badly! The reason for the 2 stars instead of 1 is because the location is pretty -esp. that day with the sun streaming in through the wall to wall glass panes. A forgettable experience.
author: Renuka V.

description:
Great place to go for a lazy Saturday afternoon lunch.  The place wasn't too crowded, and we sat at the bar where the seats rotated to easily allow you to turn around and enjoy the views of the presidio.  Our bartender was great, and offered some excellent suggestions as far as menu choices.  Food was delish, very down home and decently priced (loved the oxtail sliders!).  Seemed like it could be a fun dinner spot too, and looked like they were able to easily accomodate big or small parties.
Two thumbs up, would for sure go back :)
author: Liz L.

description:
We were celebrating Greek Easter today (4/15).  My sib suggested the PSC.  I had never been.  We had a great time!  First, I have to say that driving in from Marin...it only took 20 minutes.  And there was parking!  These things become really important as you get older.  The building is vintage with ash beams.  I liked walking into the entrance and seeing the red 1930's drum kit with the restaurant's logo painted on the bass drum. The menus' look echos the 1930's style. Or maybe it's 1940's.  It's retro, but genuine retro.

My sister has a quirk about holidays in restaurants.  She brings decorations.  Always.  It could be cringe-inducing until you finally accept it.  So we had purple flowers and an easter basket, eggs, etc.  Then she pulled out some doilies.  Doilies.  I only mention this because our waiters got into the festive spirit.  One said "Oh look, doilies!".  That cracked me up.  Our service was attentive and relatively fast.

My brunch of two perfectly poached eggs atop a nice grilled slice of ham sitting on a half brioche and sprinkled with very fresh asparagus cuts was outstanding.  My sib loved her salad and my Godmother's hamburger looked good.  They didn't hesitate to substitute a side salad for french fries.

My godmother is 95 (god love her) and has everything together.  She was telling me in detail about the errors committed by Panda in yesterday's Giants game.  I mention my godmother because of the noise in the place.  It was not too bad.  We could talk.  There is a side room and the back patio if you want a quieter experience.

Note:  There is a handicap ramp but it is in the back of the restaurant.

There was a wide range of customers...older, younger, kids (a couple, that's about my limit) . This would be an excellent place for a small party or for entertaining out of town guests.

We all had a good time and I'm blown away at how easy it is to get to...just inside the Lombard Gate.
author: Jan C.

description:
Took my sister in law here last night.
Great food (had the steak) , amazing Manhattan (had 2).
Only complaint was it was chilly by the window (bring a sweater).
Will be added to my list of places to take visitors.
author: Liz B.

description:
we came here for brunch last sunday.  i wasn't sure what to expect as the reveiws are pretty mixed about this place.  the interior is so quaint....you feel like you're back in time to the 20s or 30s.  we had a table by the window, so looking out into the presidio you forget that you're in a city like san francisco and not out in some small town charm or something.

we ate:

-lobster roll:  it looked yummy and my bro said it was, but didn't share a bite

-fried egg sandwich:  YUM YUM YUM!  i wanted to order this, but seemed silly to have two orders when i knew the bf would share a bite or two of this devine sandwich.  

-burger:  flavorful and simple.  it doesn't come with lettuce, tomato, or onions or any of that garnish stuff.  just the burger and some cheese if you choose.  when it came out all lonely without the garnishes i was a bit hesitant, but then i took one bite and wow oh wow...the ozing, tender, juicy burger made me forget about the garnishes...

-traditional breakfast:  it looked yummy and the nephew says it was.  i got his biscuit and it was fluffy and tasty.

as if that wasn't enough food, we also had dessert:

-ice cream sandwich and benigets....YUM!

we had attentive and good service, so i would definitely recommend this place for brunch.
author: Mao K.

description:
I have never in years of fine dining sent back a dish, until the Presidio Social Club. The pork with hash was awful, let me repeat... awful. In addition, the service was terrible and the waiter explained how he would have to bring all of our food and appetizers at once because he was also working a large party and apparently could not balance his time even though he is a professional waiter. 

For all they hype this new restaurant has gotten, I was truly disappointed to say the least.
author: Alicia J.

description:
Presidio Social Club sucks! Our waiter was totally rude and ignored us for a while before coming over to ask if we wanted anything to drink.

We ordered the grilled cheese appetizer and I couldn't even taste the cheese. I ordered the kobe beef sloppy joe which was good but I like the original version from the packet better. My roomie ordered the pork - disgusting! It was cold and gross and she had to flag down a different waiter to send it back since our waiter never checked back with us after we received our food.

We got the banana cream pie and cookie plate for dessert. The pie was good, cookies were nothing special. 

The decor was kinda cool and I liked the campy/bunkerish vibe. All in all, I could have spent my money better elsewhere.
author: elissa w.

description: I had a pretty good lunch there! Roasted broccoli wasn't too greasy and the trout was the perfect size and well cooked. Not a mind-blowing experience, but a wonderful one nonetheless.
author: Joyce S.

description: Brunch was good - need to go back and try something else. Nice atmosphere and pretty location at The Presidio.
author: Peter S.

description: Threw my girlfriends 30th birthday party here. Im not sure this is really that kind of place but they really pulled it togther and did a really great job. Better mains would be required to get 5 stars but other than that i have only amazing things to say about these guys.
author: Ryan P.

description:
Disappointed with the service and food given that we had an early reservation for a gradulation celebration and a party of 12. First, the restaurant was nearly empty at 4:30pm on a Saturday and we were seated by the door. The hostess wouldn't budge when asked to be moved. Another disappointment was the service was slow and unattentive. We had to ask for water refills and my daughter's Shirley Temple was order at the beginning, but didn't arrive until well into the meal, after the appetizers. Also requested the dirty dozens and was told they they were not available. Bummer and the kids were so looking forward to them! Needless to say, it went going downhill thereafter.

I've dined at the restaurant many times before and this was definitely the worst.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Unlike the previous reviewer I would not say, "OMG, this place was absolutely [incredible]!"   The place is pretty damn good though.   I would just use different words to describe it.   

Newly built in an old Presidio barracks the Presidio Social club designers did an outstanding job of keeping the architectural integrity of the Presidio together with a hip eatery.   The long marble bar is impressive, as is the subdued furnishing in the dining room.   

They specialize in comfort food and for once a restaurant delivers on that elusive home cooked feeling.   The liver and onions are outstanding and they have a very affordable wine list to find just what you need to pair those tangy caramelized onions with.  

Desert is a little confusing.   They have "side deserts" and "main deserts."  The sides are meant to compliment the main.   I never really figured it out.    Instead I went with a plate of cookies and milk and regressed back to 3rd grade. 

The crowd is a little "old school" as pretty much everyone is over fifty.   Maybe it was because I was there on a week night, but it really made me feel young.  I even complained that the music was too loud just so I would fit in a little more.    

This place is definitely top of my list when I want a hit of cozy, artery clogging comfort food.
author: Jim Z.

description:
This restaurant probably best for out of town guests and the under forty crowd. Recently  heard about this restaurant and am always glad to find new interesting spots in or around the Presidio which I consider one of SF's gems. In it's favor: it's a great location, plenty of parking. spacious & pleasant with what looked like a nice outside deck. Where it fell short:. For about a half hour - well into the brunch seating- we were the only diners in the area. The food very good but a bit pricey compared to brunch items elsewhere,  skipped the flatbread  but hear it's really good) if you didn't want flatbread, the menu  selections were limited., our server was very friendly and attentive but he must have started that morning as he wasn't  familiar with basics and had to go ask  more than once.
Might  try it again at a different time of day and specifically request outside seating if not going in July or August!.
author: Anne C.

description:
Just for the record.  I had dinner at Presidio Social Club for the first time late summer, and I got to eat here again tonight.
Drink: Fantastic mai-tais at an awesome looking bar.
Food: Grilled gruyere toast with tomato dipping sauce.  Pork Chop.  Smashed peas.  Roasted brussel sprouts.  All excellent.  Order them if they are on the menu.
Dessert: Butterscotch pudding was phenomenal.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description:
Had brunch at the PSC today around 11:30. No wait, plenty of room and some outdoor options. The dining room is nice and open with a very sleek bar on one end of the room and a nice large window allowing a nice amount of light in on the other. The seating was also really comfortable for a nice dining environment. The design aesthetics remind me of something reminiscent of a Southern plantation. Colors and accents are very sharp and the wait staff is more or less dressing the part.

The menu is sort of limited, but most of the options are general crowd-pleasers. I had the standard breakfast and took a good looking sticky bun home. Everything was pretty great here, except the sloe gin fizz I tried left me a little sour. I don't know if the mix was over soured or it was just a poor order on my part, but I'm not sure i'm ordering another old fashioned cocktail here again and maybe that's a good thing.
author: Ed B.

description:
we came into presidio social club on a saturday afternoon.  the place was not crowded but the wait for the patio outside was a little bit.  there was a bleach or cleaning solution smell when we entered the restaurant.

our server seemed a tiny bit off or forgetful.  she almost forgot my drink and when we ordered another drink she forgot about it altogether.  i ordered the frittata of the day - cheese, spinach and cauliflower.  it was good but not piping hot. the bfs biscuits and gravy were only ok as well.  the biscuits were hard.
author: claudia y.

description:
Kobe Beef Sloppy Joe. 

My first thought was "If I have steak that tastes like butter, why on earth would I want to drench it in Manwhich". Much to my delight, this was wonderful. The beef was so tender, almost like high quality lengua that had been slow cooked and braised for hours...but since it was kobe beef, it also had that luscious melt in your mouth quality, but still held enough structural integrity to not be overpowered by the sauce. And unlike the Manwich in a can (by the way, I do love) the sauce was not too sweet or spicy, with slow cooked onions and tomatoes.

The mac and cheese was good, but not great. It was more like a mac and cheese casserole and I prefer the stove top creamy style. The mini cupcakes was the other huge hit. My main gripe with cupcakes is the abundance of frosting; sometimes it seems like one to one. These cupcakes were topped with little crumbly, chocolate crisps that tasted a lot like Cocoa Crisps. Rather than frosting, a small glass was filled with fresh whipped cream. 

The decor was absolutely cinematic. Bare bulbs hang from the ceiling, bathing the entire space in a warm ambient glow, but still retaining the upscale utilitarian aesthetic. Large windows, about a dozen ceiling fans and bartenders in white coats with red ties gives PSC the air of another time, another place...certainly not SF in 2007. I felt like I was in Vietnam, or some other output of american military imperialism during the 1940s. My friend thought she was in a southern antebellum country club.
author: Leslie Ann R.

description:
Ooh, I really liked this place.  The bartenders wear dandy little barkeep jackets and they smile!  I went with a friend who had baby in tow, and no one got angry that the baby was near the bar.  OK, maybe the baby had its own stool at the bar, and the baby was getting more head turns than me (damn baby), but they were still cool with it.  We went after a baby birthday party, and we were wearing clothing for the occasion..not my hottest look.  Nevertheless, we were treated wonderfully.  

They serve great cocktails in ice chilled glasses.  We liked the Pink Lemonade and the French 57.  My friend says that the French 57 is old school...it was the only drink served at her parents' wedding...classy!

And the food, well it was good and tasty.  Yes, it was pricey for the home cookin' fare, but my benefactor footed the bill, so I can't complain :)

P.S.  The one thing that needs a little help, the wheeled patron's access.  The restaurant is in an old building that does not have wheel chair access in the front.  You have to go around the back...where the smelly garbage is to find a ramp.  We only had a stroller to deal with, but I want to warn my wheelchair using friends!
author: Kara D.

description: First time there and it was a nice and comfortable lunch.  We enjoyed our brunch meals and clearly this is a cool place to eat.  We all tried different dishes including an arugula salad with chicken, killer eggs benedict and a Vietnamese vegetarian sandwich all which were good to great.  We shared a dessert called the carrot cake bread pudding with a tiny scope of orange ice cream and toffee sauce which was killer.  I suspect we will be back as the prices were fair and the quality good.  Nice outing and the server was friendly.
author: J K.

description:
Worst Food Worst Service Ever!

Let me start off by saying that I went here despite warnings from friends that what I'll be getting is overpriced cafeteria food.  I thought I'd give it a go anyway.  I ended up getting food poisoning from the roast chicken and stuffing entree - I'm talking vomitting and other projectile for the next 2 days.  When I called the manager when I finally had the strength to dial the phone, she was very hostile towards me and told me that she did not believe me and that no one else got sick so I must have gotten sick somewhere else.  There was no apology, no attempts at compassion, nothing.  Just a flat not-our-fault-buh-bye response.  

This place is nothing special.  Go spend your money somewhere else like Street, Park Chow, or any other place that has sanitary food handling and competent management.

I give this place another 6 months.  In this economy, they are kidding themselves if they think they'll survive with that kind of poor management.
author: Scooey O.

description: Pretty decent food. The dollar oysters special was a nice treat, and the roasted calamari was quite tasty.  I had the cod which was served over a celery root puree. It was quite tasty.  Overall the group I was with enjoyed the food.
author: Josh B.

description:
Everyone else has seem to cover it all- this place rocks!

My tip of the day: Off the menu items: 
-On Sunday they do a Pupus plater- nice simple sampling of a few items off the appetizer menu plus two Mai Tais ALL FOR $20!! Perfect for two people to start the night off right.  The Mai Tais taste like they are straight from Trader Vic's so be prepared to take it up a notch ;-)

-Bunker Buster Burger- Awesome buffalo  burger served with fries.  Best Buffalo burger I've had in SF ;-)

-Dirty Dozen- 12 tiny brioche beignets filled with delicious gooey chocolate!  Need I say more?

Enjoy!
author: Aaron F.

description:
Nobody puts Baby in the Corner.
Nobody.


The atmosphere of this place is great.  All that could improve it would be Patrick Swayze asking the diners to dirty dance with him.

The food however, leaves something to be desired.

Nothing stood out.  
Well, except for the fact that my bacon and egg salad (it had a fancier name than that, but that's basically what it was) was dressed with what tasted like pure bacon grease.  I didn't expect it to be light, but I also didn't expect to have to eat it before it congealed.

Oh, and my coarsely textured broccoli soup came without the described crouton.  I want my crouton dammit.

And the server took my wine while I still had a few splashes left in the glass.  I had been savoring it!  

Nobody comes between me and my wine.  
Nobody.
author: Meredith K.

description:
Somewhere between 3 and 4 stars. I'll give it four for now because it is new and they are still finding their way.

The location is nice. Cool to have a restaurant in the Presidio and easy to walk to from Marina and other nearby neighborhoods. 

The restaurant looks nice inside.  Large, but cozy space.  Long bar that looks like it would be nice to have a drink at.  Friendly wait staff.

We had shrimp cocktail, which they do differently than others.  The shrimp sits in a thin cocktail sauce and comes with oyster crackers.  Somewhere between standard shrimp cocktail and shrimp soup.  Not bad.

Their "house" salad is a chopped salad.  Basically lettuce, celery, and radishes, with pretty good dressing.  Could've used some more vegetables on the salad though.

Tasted the squash (vegetable of the day)--good.

The grilled cheese appetizer is as described below.  Basically grilled cheese dipped in tomato soup.  Which isn't necessarily a bad thing.

The desserts sounded good, as did the rest of the menu.  There aren't tons of options on the menu, but the options that are there look pretty good.
author: Brett J.

description:
I had the opportunity to dine here during my last trip to San Francisco and was very impressed with the service and the menu.

I ended up going with the Sloppy Joe and I wasn't disappointed. I also sampled the Meat Loaf and Mashed Potatoes from a friend plate - also fantastic.
author: Brian J.

description: Love PSC for brunch more than dinner.  I think it has gone downhill for dinner in the past couple years but it is a great place for brunch.  Love their cocktails, esp the French 75...mmm! Also, love the decor and relaxing ambiance of the place.  Another fantastic thing about PSC is there is parking!!! They get 3.5 stars in my book.
author: nicole s.

description:
My second time at PSC. I like the place, high end funky and typical of The Presidio in general. (I live in a former officer's quarters five minutes walk from PSC.) 

Great food: Broadway & Columbus (noodles with duck breast); Kobe Sloppy Joes; Chocolate Cupcakes; Chopped Liver; Almond Gateau (not on menu).

Good food: Fish dishes (salmon, swordfish); Crab cupcakes; roasted chicken.

No really bad food.

Really good wine list, generally positive and helpful and mostly prompt service. Learned tonight that they only serve "artisan sodas", which are expensive ($4 each) and not necessarily what you want in a soda. I intend to be a regular, either at the counter or communal table by myself or with friends on a res (Opentable).
author: Stewart A.

description:
It's in an old Presidio building that someone put Pottery Barn all over.  Had the baked fish (whole fish, two stars there), a glass of cremant, one cocktail.  For two it was about $100.   The menu features Kobe Beef sloppy joes -- that sums up the style of the place.

The peeps were mostly families and some Marina-style scenesters who are bored of Matrix Fillmore.  It was busy at 5:30 and the staff said it gets hugely busy later on with people clawing their Banana Republic asses up to the counter to get drinks.  The bartenders  wear ties and little white smocks that make you feel like you're in a Norman Rockwell fountain -- but with Kobe beef sloppy joes and P Barn decor.  I'm not sure it's worth the money  -- unless the Matrix is getting boring for you too.
author: ed y.

description:
The food was good.  The service was slow, I can't blame the only waitress on a Saturday afternoon though.  The ambiance is simple, nostalgic and fun.  I gotta go back to that amazing bar and just drink my lunch next time.

I had the Kobe beef sloppy joe.  I had to order a $17.00 sloppy joe just to see what it's all about.  It is about pure goodness.  My wife had some egg thing I can't comment on because I did not try it.  But, she liked it a lot.  I would go back.
author: Mark B.

description:
Fun location, consistently good food and service.

It's a notch above its neighbor Pres a Vi in food quality, ambiance, and service. We've eaten there 5 or so times, had an enjoyable meal each time,....from Suckling Pig to Kobe beef sloppy joes, really not that many "duds" on the menu and a warm feeling inside. Recommended for nights when you want a low stress meal.
author: Peter F.

description: Terrible restaurant; servers seemed bothered if you ask them so anything. Long wait for food & my seafood dish was cold. The table was dirty. There are so many great restaurants in San Francisco - would definitely avoid this one.
author: Lisa D.

description: For the service alone, I'm giving this place 5 stars. I just recently moved to the Presidio and like to stop by here on my way out for the night. They have some of the friendliest staff and the food/drinks are pretty good too. Definitely a spot to check out.
author: Amanda L.

description:
There's two reviews here:
1) As a bar for drinks - 5 stars.  Great cocktails, cool looking bar, nice way to catch up with someone
2) For brunch - 3 stars (hence the 4 star avg).  So, it's not that it's bad, it's just not blow your mind in a blow your mind food town.  It's less competitive than a number of breakfast places nearby, including Ella's on California.  I think I would put it below Curbside which is also great.
author: Raman R.

description:
Sitting at the bar of the Presidio Social Club having dinner last night, I felt like I was in the middle of Dirty Dancing and at any moment Johnny Castle was going to walk up and tell us that, "Nobody puts Baby in a corner!". Unfortunately, that didn't happen, but I loved every bit of this restaurant - beautiful cocktails, Gruyere Cheese Toasts with Tomato Soup, Brioche Beignets with a side of chocolate pudding (I had a dream about the beignets last night... I'm being totally serious). 

I'll definitely be back whenever I want feel like I'm in the Catskills circa 1962 and have some yummy cocktails made by cute bartenders in white dinner jackets.
author: Brandy H.

description:
Very nice location, building and staff. The food was average.

My companion had a nice fish dish, I order the fancy burger. The burger was very average. It came without Tomato so I asked for a slice of Tomato which came promptly, except that I had to wait 5 mins to ask for it as our server was nowhere to be seen (so burger went a bit cold).

We ordered a desert combo which was the usual ridiculously sweet small creme type thing.

Overall the service was reasonably good and the food arrived promptly (but they weren't busy).

Mains were about $18 for the fish and $13 for the Burger. The Wines are GOOD but EXPENSIVE. My Merlot was around $11 and a Cab was around $12 for a glass, but the pourings were very generous.

Desert was a special $10 for a combo (2 dishes).

Total bill came to $83 + tip. Expected much better food and a little bit better service for this. Location and building are very nice though.
author: N S.

description:
I give them 4 stars (breakfast/brunch) because:

- Great bloody marys (maries?)
- Best biscuits and gravy in town, hands down!
- Strong coffee
- Availability (never a wait)

The other dishes don't impress me that much (not bad, just not a homerun).
author: Philip I.

description: Great atmosphere and very mixed crowd, which I love!  The only reason this place didn't get 5 stars is the service. Our waiter was hard to find but they have other servers there buzzing around.  It can get a bit hectic during brunch time. I'm planning on checking their dinner service. The best thing on the menu is the bread pudding! It's amazing!! Carrot cake placed on top of a caramel pineapple sauce topped with orange ice-cream...who does that? Loved it!!!!
author: Diane N.

description: The Presidio Social club has a great setting, decently good food, nice servers  and fun drinks. It should be a point of destination, particularly if you live nearby. For the second time in five years, we were asked to vacate our table for another reservation after two hours. The place was not full, we had ordered two rounds of drinks, an expensive meal, dessert and coffee and were having a lovely time until our very nice waitress said she was sorry but they needed the table. It was rude and rather arrogant for a restaurant that is somewhat ordinary in a town full of fabulous restaurants. Do yourself a favor and resist the location and find a friendlier place to eat.
author: Susan L.

description:
Went to a private party at the Presidio Social Club for our friends 35th Bday party, and it was great. There is a room on the left when you walk in building that probably holds 30 people. Attached to that room is an outdoor deck that probably holds another 30. There was a bar set up and the the waitstaff was made sure that drinks were flowing for everybody ( I am sure they charged by the drink with a minimum). The apps were great although I have ordered the mini grilled cheese before and the portions are really small. Not bad when they are free at a party however. 


Really cool venue with a different vibe. The Presidio itself puts you in a great mood and the architecture of the restaurant gives the restaurant a unique feel.

Minus one star for the cocktail size when you order from the bar. Although the quality of the cocktails is solid, they serve them in glasses that look like the small OJ glasses that you get in some breakfast spots.
author: Honey N.

description:
Really cute place with beautiful flowers everywhere and a modern yet retro vibe (does that make any sense?).  I don't really ever go to the Presidio to eat so found it somewhat special to find this place out there.

I had a great Mojito and tossed salad for dinner tonight with my mom.

Service seemed solid. I'd like to come again.
author: Lauren S.

description:
Liked it! Love the theme, décor, and the whole approach of it. Where it started to fall down a bit was on the food and the drinks...oh wait, that's right: THAT'S THE IDEA OF A RESTAURANT. ;-)

Place looks great, menu looks simple but isn't. We had Shrimp Fritters as a starter (a bit on the spicy side, which I liked, but my wife did not) with a great tomatillo salsa. Also enjoyed their Butter Lettuce salad. The Smoked Oyster Chowder...eh. Not bad, but not all that. For main courses we had the Pork Chop (huge, flavorful), and the Trout (bland). Dessert was the chocolate cupcakes (yummy!).

Service was sporadic, but friendly. The drinks were a disappointment.  The place clearly is trying to evoke the "joints" of the 50's and 60's, so they offer all sorts of featured cocktails: Sidecar, Hoop-La, and a Cayenne-pepper topped Gimlet. Well, gotta tell you, I tried them all, and found them all to be about the same taste, and not all that strong. For a place that made such a "hoop-la" about the drinks, I definitely expected more.

Bottom line: fun place, good, if not great, food, fantastic ambience, and overall pretty good.
author: Joshua T.

description: We arrived mid-day on a Sunday.  Place was open, not too busy at all.  About 3 patrons at the bar, and a few tables occupied.  Patio was busy due to great weather.  We sat at the bar, and were told that they are only serving the bar menu at this time.  No problem we said... we were hungry and thirsty and not too fussed about a short menu.  Bartender asked what we would like to drink, I asked to see a menu.  Um... "a menu, yes, I am looking for one, just a moment..." and then continued to clean glass ware.  And then asked a passing server, do you have a menu, "no"... and kept walking.  another server "no" and kept walking.  a MANAGER, "no" and walked away.  So about 10 minutes after we sat down, there was our "menu"... she said the burger was "amazing"...  we ordered pretty simple.  A burger, medium, with a side of avocado.  A steak sandwich, with dijon on the side. She said fries are great, so no need to substitute with a salad.  We were pretty hungry, so about 5 minutes after ordering, we asked if we could order some olives to tie us over (they are on the menu)... "sure" and then another 15 minutes passed.  still no olives.  OLIVES.  put them in a bowl... how hard is it?  Olives finally came. 40 minutes after ordering.  The burger came well done. the "amazing" burger, overcooked.  No avocado.  The steak sandwich SMOTHERED with dijon.  "We're between service..." this was her excuse NO EXCUSES!  If you can't perform "mid" service, then close in between.  Avocado came after I requested it.  Could not be added to burger since it was not ripe.  Hard avocado, cold fries.  Completely NON-ATTENTIVE managers!!  They were aware that things had gone wrong, but did not engage with us.  Actually did not engage with another couple who had an awful experience... we got to overhear about theirs as we perused the menu.  There are so many choices in SF, why would we ever return to this place?  We just won't.  Staff didn't care about our experience... despite removing a few things from the bill.  We came to spend money.  We don't care about you removing things off the bill... we care about you having menus for patrons when they arrive, listening to what we order, preparing it the way we ask for it, and being empathetic and equally embarrassed for your kitchen when people have a shitty service experience from start to finish.  Shame on you Presidio Social Club.  Yes, that Manager at the front door... while you socialized with your hostesses, you should have acknowledged us on the way out.
author: Edgar A.

description:
This place serves an easygoing, slightly fancied-up diner type menu.  Surroundings reflect the style of food.  In so doing, they have nailed their target.  The food is tasty, as are the house-made cocktails.  Neither are particularly cheap.  Parking is reasonably easy.  Or take a cab and laugh when the driver gets confused.   Wine list is simple but effective.

Oh yeah, and for those people complaining about the prevalence of Marina-yuppie customers (which is true), please take a moment to realize where the place is located . . . right, now shut up.
author: Aaron F.

description: This is the perfect venue for having parents in from out of town. Delicious food, solid wine list, classic old time SF venue. And for girls who are perfectly content on a salad, the portion size, freshness of the veggies, and diversity of the menu was spot on. Just enough room for dessert!
author: Ashley T.

description:
This place decided to embrace everything about the Presidio and run with it.  From the building it is housed in to the menu, it maintains its charm and down-to-earth personality.

While the food ain't cheap, this is a perfect place to bring Mom and Dad to after hiking around the Presidio or sightseeing nearby.
author: Tim G.

description:
This place is okay. We came here on my birthday and we were a large party on a Friday night. Right there, you know you're gonna have some strikes against you. We had to do a prix fixe since we were larger than a party of eight. To her credit, the hostess, Ophelia, was amazing. We had to communicate back and forth a number of times to sort out menu issues, and she was always VERY nice and VERY friendly. I highly recommend dealing with her if you have a large party.

The place was packed and the ambience was terrific. I really, really liked the vibe. It was pretty effin' loud though. The bar was sexy, though poorly located. We got seated fairly quickly though.

Anyway, our appies (gruyere toast points) were solid and the salad was REALLY good. We each had our choice of entrees and I went with the flatiron steak. It was...okay. Not great though. We did have to wait a really long time between the salad and the main course though. I mean, a really long time. Our waiter was nice enough and managed to get all of our food out at once, but the people at the table next to us had major issues with him and with when their food was coming out. 

All in all, it was a good experience, but the price tag was $107 a pop. Granted, we might have gotten carried away with the wine, but it did seem to be a pretty brutal price tag for a meal that was just okay, not mind-blowing. Give them a few months to smooth out the rough spots and maybe don't go on a weekend.
author: kdub ..

description:
I am totally smitten by the decor and atmosphere of this place. They did a great job adding a modern twist to 1930's and 1940's decor. I also love how the dining room is very spacious. Unlike so many other restaurants in the city, you don't have to deal with stuffy air and deafening noises.

Most yelpers are right about the food though. It just falls flat. The appetizers started out pretty promising. We ordered the Ahi Poke and the PS Caesars salad. The poke was delicious and the Caesars Salad was super fresh and came in this very cute vintage rose plate.

The main dishes were very disappointing. The berkshire pork tasted like kalua pork. The rock cod had no flavor.

Fortunately, they've hired a really cute bartender so I spent the rest of my meal telling my husband how cute the bartender was :)

Still worth at least one visit though...
author: Denise H.

description: The  worst  service  ever!  After 45  minutes, I  had leave  before  my  food  arrived. Unreal!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
I didn't expect the Club to be so busy on a Wednesday night, but I guess that's a testament to its DELICIOUS food!  We devoured the mac n cheese, I licked clean my plate of ox tail stroganoff, and we inhaled our beignets (with a side of malted milk parfait).

One of my dining companions kept raving about the mashed potatoes and the other one enjoyed his fig-encrusted sardines (though he kept burping it up later and that was none too pleasant).

On the downside, we nearly got attacked by a pack of crazed raccoons in transit from the restaurant to our car!
author: Marcus C.

description:
I wanted this to be a good place to eat and enjoy

Sadly enough though - I have to say that the food was mediocre at best - the service really crummy - (Can I have a spoon with my soup please - PLEASE?!)

I'll go back for a cocktail  - maybe - but - ahem - sorry - not for the food or for the service.

(Can I have a knife now?)
author: Marc G.

description:
felt compelled to write how much i loved dining here last night. try it when you feel like having a conversation, being surrounded by greenery, getting taken care of by the most friendly servers, and enjoying a good meal with awesome drinks.

in the midst of finishing dinner and walking to the car, the lovely server ran out to the parking lot calling me. i had left my scarf and she was so sweet to return it back. 

no hangover today. so yes, drinks were awesome.
author: s d.

description:
Well, more of a 3.5 star....

Ambiance was off on Saturday night:  lights too bright, no music, and we were sat in the most uncomfortable small, wicker armchairs i've ever paid to sit in (aside from at the Orpheum and United Air).

Service was mediocre:  hostesses friendly, bar tender bored and detached (emotionally, not physically), and a waiter with no personality (nor any attempt to change out the chairs so two 6'4" guys could enjoy their Sat night out with their wives).

Food was fine:  nothing crazy but consistent americana-kind of food.  mac and cheese pretty good as was the grilled cheese with tomato soup.  Nice dessert menu with smaller "sides" as an option. I wish they had a better beer list (i.e. an IPA option).  Seafood special was quite good.
author: Greg A.

description:
I love this place! I guess I should say that I hate it though so the word doesn't get out too much!!

We went in late on a Sunday afternoon hoping to catch brunch. We missed brunch by 1/2 an hour but you can still eat at the bar with a modified bar menu, and relax. I love eating at the bar, it was perfect. The fish and chips and the tuna melt on rye were just what the hang over called for and the fries were perfect. I love that they have Allagash beer, even if it's in the bottle and not on tap, and the side car that my boyfriend got was also delicious. 

Another note - the service was great, so friendly and cool but not overly intrusive. 

Also - I love the decor of this place. Makes me feel like I am back in time at an officer's club, but it isn't stuffy, it is old fashiony and fresh at the same time. 

This is now one of our weekend spots and I can't wait to go back.
author: sarah k.

description:
This was my second time here for lunch and was looking forward to it after a very good first experience. My wife and I arrived shortly after opening and were the 3rd table to be seated. We were seated and received excellent service from the wait staff, prompt delivery of the drinks we ordered, description of items not listed on the menu, etc. An order of Poke and chips to start, an order of the soup and sandwich special, a chicken sandwich and side of french fries was our order.  The restaurant started to fill, but I would not guess it was more than 80% full at any given time. We started to see food brought to tables that were seated 5 minutes after we arrived. We finally got our Poke starter after 30 minutes, it was delicious and did not think that it would have taken that long, but figured that we were still OK for time. After several tables that were seated after us started to finish and leave our waitress came by and told us that our food would be right out. She disappeared for another 15 minutes and then came over to blame the slow kitchen on the large group that was there ahead of us. It did not seem to be effecting the 3 other tables who arrived ahead of us and were already served and exiting the restaurant. An hour after our order we finally received a cold side of fries with our lunch. The sandwich was well prepared, but nothing was going to salvage this lunch. We flagged down our waitress to ask for our check before finishing our lunch just to be out of the restaurant.

The sad thing is we had a really awful time there for lunch. The server probably forgot to enter our order and rather than taking the blame tried to pass it off on a large party. The 4-5 tables around us that got good service would probably post a glowing review of this restaurant and their lunch since they were able to be in an out in a reasonable amount of time, unfortunately I cannot provide a good review and the service received on this visit has turned me off to this as a lunch destination.
author: JP B.

description:
I wind up here fairly often, maybe more so becuse of the convenient parking, than the food.  Parking in the Marina is not always the easiest thing on the weekends. But the PSC, being inside the Presidio with its own parking lot, makes for an easy choice if avoiding parking hassles is an issue.

I like the atmosphere in the restaurant.  It has a great bar scene on Friday night.  The food is not terribly adventuresome, but well done.
author: Steve S.

description:
I actually really like this restaurant - and this is even after the two times I've been there being seated at least 45 minutes after my confirmed reservation.  With that said, the hostess takes notice of the fact that you've been waiting for awhile and rewards your patience with gruyere cheese toasts - which are DELISH!  I am a big fan of gruyere and anything melty - so much appreciated for not only the food but the thought.  The bar is fun to sit at though, we like to get there early to have a cocktail...it's fun to watch the classic bar in action...

While there we have tried:
Artichoke and Feta Dip (delish - but wasn't on the menu when we last went)
Chopped romaine salad (I LOVED it - so light and crunchy!  Mike thought it needed more seasoning but he's a chef so he's always saying that)
Fish and Chips (good!)
Flat iron steak (really liked it!)
Kobe burger (DELISH!)
Mac and Cheese (we wish we had ordered the larger size!)

Note:  All those were not consumed in ONE single outing. :)

Also recommend the PSC house white - it's not expensive and super easy to drink...almost too easy.

Also love the banana cream pie.....I still think about it to this day! :)
author: Jen L.

description:
I've gone to the PSC only once so far, and its location and decor alone earn it four stars. (The food is only worth three.) I love going to the Presidio because it offers a change of pace from the south part of the city and is so pretty and green. Also, I enjoy thinking about my visits from Sacramento as a kid, when it was still an operational military facility, when we got to stay on the base because my dad was in the Air Force.

So cool that the restaurant is in a former barracks. The interior is immaculate, but this cleanliness doesn't compromise its 1940s charm. Old movies are playing on a TV behind the bar, where bartenders wearing old-school white jackets and red ties are mixing up tasty cocktails. Big band and jazz are on the radio, which can be heard even in the bathroom. The color scheme is black, grey, red, and white, which may sound like it's drab, but it comes off as classy. Swank without being snooty.

The food...It's fine. Not bad. Not as great as the ambiance might promise. My chopped salad with green goddess dressing was pretty good, as was J.'s Caesar. Trout was so-so, the chicken a bit better, albeit super-juicy. My lemonade cocktail was good enough, also strong. The dessert list looked quite promising, and the small cup of chocolate pudding I ordered was actually quite yummy.

I say, come for the location and the setting, have a cocktail, and the food shouldn't be the most important factor.
author: Tara M.

description:
Another upscale comfort food restaurant in the city, but with a more interesting location than most.  They have a parking lot, but unfortunately, it was full so we parked outside the Presidio Gate (5 minute walk).

The drinks were good (I had the mojito, which was a tad on the tart side, but otherwise, tasty).  We started with the mac and cheese for the table, which was very good, and I ordered the soup of the day (lentil, bacon and chard, which was also very tasty).  Boyfriend ordered the gruyere toasts with tomato dipping sauce (basically, a fancy grilled cheese), which was just average.

For my main meal, I shared the braised pork with creamy cheese polenta and the flat iron steak with brussels sprouts (vegetable of the day) with a friend.  The pork was very good -- very moist and flavorful.  The polenta, however, was runny and not that tasty.  

The steak was probably about 3-4 oz (not a huge portion) and came with peppercorn butter on top.  I enjoyed the steak (although not out of this world).  Brussell sprouts were soft and very good.  

The service was good and the ambiance is also very nice -- lots of white, with a old-school feel but with modern touches.  They have dinners of the day -- the roast pork and prime rib dinners are something I'd like to try...
author: Mitzi C.

description:
Cool place with an old-time feel - paint-chipped walls and old signs with info about canons, gun powder and other war-time stuff...all of which is kinda' odd b/c it's not quite consistent with the hip crowd.  To the right of the entry is the main dining room and long bar.  To the left a much smaller, cozier room with a couple of tables for two, a couple of round tables for 10 and a rectangular table for 6.

Loved our waitress.  Really efficient, very sweet and knew the limited menu well so she was able to give recommendations of certain things over others.  We all thoroughly enjoyed the gruyere cheese toast w/ tomato dipping sauce kicked up w/ a bit of wasabe and the poke was fresh and tasty.  A bunch of folks at our table ordered the fish & chips which came w/ a huge mound of pomme frites, b/f ordered boneless short ribs subbed w/ mash potatoes and loved every bite, roast chicken looked and smelled scrumptious, special of the nite: halibut w/ a honkin' order of cooked spinach was a healthy choice but nothing special.  My fish stew was tasty enough but only came w/ one, count 'em, one, prawn.

now the fun part...dessert!  skip the parfait -- teeny tiny, loaded w/ whipped cream and way too sweet.  the banana cream "pie" is the bomb as are the beignets but i'm a sucker for fried dough.
author: Jeannie C.

description: Nice ambience, service was ok but our entree took way too long! Had to wait for about 30 - 45 mins for our food to be served. Ordered the roast chicken, tuna and the flat iron steak n frites. Food were pretty small portions but taste ok overall although the fries were very salty. Had the peach sorbet which was refreshing and sweet while the lemon meringue cake was not much to be raved about.
author: Clare H.

description:
The concept is great - the somehow Casablanca evoking space with its white jacketed bartenders behind the long stretch of bar, palm trees directing your glance to vaulted ceilings punctuated with fans, cold steel cabinets and warm wooden floors, and the multitudes of thick bare bulbed fixtures with naked filaments blazing, all works beautifully to form the unique convivial atmosphere - stark yet romantic in its nostalgic era way, it manages to blend industrial elements with classic ones to create a distinct old world charm.  I can't think of another place quite like it in San Francisco and it feels very natural in its Presidio setting.

As well thought out the concept is though, the menu seemed a bit scattershot.  Tuna poke and Kobe Beef Sloppy Joes felt a tad at odds with each other (and the idea of using marbled Kobe beef to be lost in a Sloppy Joe didn't seem right), as did the marriage of some ingredients like those in the cutely named 'Columbus and Broadway',  fatty chunks of duck on wide egg noodles bathed in a butter based orangey anisey flavored sauce, didn't entirely jive.  The Pork with Oyster Hash was more successful with simple clear and complimentary flavors. 

The portion size to price ratio was a bit off on a few things as well, perhaps something that is still being worked on.  Drinks were great, dessert was okay (the Beignets turned out to be donut sticks, good warm donuts, but honestly not Beignets).  

Before you go know that this space can get seriously loud. All of the hard surfaces do a great job of bouncing the raucous sounds around, thus making people talk even louder and the cycle goes on. It definitely adds to the 'social club' aspect, but I wouldn't mind it if they managed to  mellow the atmosphere a bit to allow for some sexy music to make it through the din.

Overall we enjoyed ourselves and we will be back; looking forward to the daily specials, word is the suckling pig will be worth pigging out on :)
author: GIR ..

description:
Five stars for ambiance,  minus two stars for the disinterested and kinda dickhead'y bartender. 

And watch out for that mai tai...I'm sure it's authentic and all but maaaan, it was rough going down.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
I went here last Sunday for brunch.  At around 11am, it was very busy but our party of 3 still only waited maybe 10 minutes for a table.  Our server was very nice, quick and attentive.  I had an excellent bloody mary (not too spicey but just the right bite) and the tuna melt.  The tuna salad was excellent although it came on a big plate of fries which while good, left me wanting some sort of healthy veggie.  

My other friends also tried the Oxtail hash and Biscuits and Gravy, and we all cleaned our plates.  The environment was a bit noisy with lots of little kids, but that doesn't bother me so much.  Overall good food, not too expensive, good service.
author: Amy W.

description:
I've been here twice. I really wanted to like this restaurant as it is one of the very few places that is walking distance from our house.

First time I went I really didn't like anything about it. OK, so I was 3 martinis into the night and maybe i wouldn't have liked anywhere but I had been really excited to check out the Social Club and it categorically disappointed. Slow service, mediocre food and a very unaccommodating waitress. We had 6 girls for dinner so OK there were a few special requests but it is not like we asked them to COOK the Cannibal sandwich or anything totally outrageous! I think we were there for almost two hours and we had exactly two rounds of drinks. Maybe she was cutting us off, I don't know

Second trip to the Social Club last night was equally as disappointing. The ambiance is cool. Its different. It "feels" like San Francisco. The food and service are just truly lacking, though. The menu tries to be imaginative and hip, but fails on all fronts. Kobe Sloppy Joes? Sounds good and comforting, right?  $20 Manwhich is the meal that shows up on your plate!

Maybe this is a good spot to stop in for a drink on your way to a restaurant with better food.
author: Megan L.

description: We hosted an informal gathering, wine and appetizers for 14 people on a Monday night and we couldn't have been happier with the service!  The cheese toasts (yummy grilled cheese with tomato soup for dunking) were a hit!  The atmosphere was a warm and inviting and our guests had a wonderful time.  Thanks for a wonderful evening!
author: Kristin W.

description:
Oh, sadness.  A place as cute and full of history as the Presidio Social club should at least get a three, right?  Well, before I tell you why I'm giving it low marks, let me at least be fair and tell you what I like:

- Better than average food.  I was really surprised, actually.  Good sandwich, and GREAT banana dessert!  I was actually blown away by the desert...

- quaint setting, very casual, very ww2 in terms of the feeling of history (there's even an old drum set as you walk in from back in the 40s)

- friendly service

... OK, now I have to tell you what kills it:

-  it's just too expensive for what you get.  I was shocked at the prices for a place that feels like a greasy-spoon diner with a little city charm.  I had a pork sandwich, and it was 20 bucks!  I dropped close to 100 bucks for dinner, drinks, dessert for two, and for that amount of dough, I could be at a 4 or 5-star restaurant downtown.  There's no excuse for the prices at this place, and honestly, deters me from going back....

- Okay, okay, but maybe one could just go for a drink with friends?  Sure, except for that fact that they had THE WORST house-made red wine I've had here in the city.  It was just dreadful.

I'm torn... I'd love to go back to give it a second chance, but as you can see, my first impression was pretty sad.  I live so close that I want it to be good, but it's just not worth it.
author: David C.

description:
We finally got around to eating at this place which is so close to home but we just never think of going into the Presidio for anything. We were very pleased with the whole experience.

- The menu is short and sweet and to the point. Yes, they have a "secret menu" but so what. The stuff on the real menu is real food in decent sized portions at a decent price for the quality and amount of food you get.

- Their "special" martini is awesome. We asked for it with 209 gin rather than their standard pour. It comes up with a lemon twist. Very nice! And one is plenty.

- The night we ate there (May 8th) the special appetizer was griddle cakes with Oregon shrimp and chive butter. Very good. Three cakes, nicely crispy on the outside and smooth and shrimp filled on the inside. My companion had the crispy fried oysters (6) and was very pleased with them.

- Since we were there on a Thursday, their daily special entree was a crispy pork shank. We were there at 6 p.m. and got the last two!! They only get 16 each Thursday and they sell out very quickly. They're done "confit style" which makes them meltingly tender inside with a nice crusty, crunchy skin. They were served with a delicious carrot risotto. As a word of caution, these babies are BIG so plan to take a good portion home.

- The wine list is, like the rest of the menu, short and sweet. A well chosen and well controlled selection. I was surprised to see an Austrian Grner Veltliner among the whites. This is our "house wine" when we're in Vienna and it's nice to see it making an appearance on American menus. We chose the Pinot Blanc which was drinkable but undistinguished.

- We skipped dessert, opting for coffee instead. I don't know who provides the coffee but it's very good.

- Our server was a bearded gentleman who provided very attentive service with good suggestions along the way. At no time did we feel rushed in any way. As a matter of fact, people came and left at other tables in the room while we sat there enjoying our meal.

- Check out their website before you go. The menu I saw on the website was the one I got at the restaurant so they must keep it up-to-date.

- A word on the ambience: There's the main dining room/bar area and a smaller side room. The side room is significantly quieter and less lively. If you enjoy conversation with your meal rather than shouting, ask for the side room. And make reservations! They do fill up and they seem to do a large group business.
author: H O.

description: Sunday night fish dinner, terrible Food Poisoning that night. Called the next day, left a message with hostess for the Manager about food poisoning.  Had to call back four (4) hours later since she had not returned my phone call .... at that point, she, the manager, spent the first part of the conversation telling me about her computer issues, then started blaming what I ate that day, or that food poisoning takes at least 24 hours to come on, then that no one else had called in and complained.  It took ages to get a simple I am sorry.  To boot, it was incredibly expensive.  DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS PLACE
author: Jeffrey R.

description:
Recently returned with a group of friends form work. While I still immensely enjoy the atmosphere, location and building... the food wasn't quite up to par. I had a venison chili which was the special for that Monday evening, which was good, not great. The standout was the gruyere cheese toasts, which come served with a little taza of tomato bisque. Timeless combination that never fails to please. The poke was tasty as well. 

The next day a few of my coworkers complained about the after-effects of the meal, and while I didn't feel sick by any means, my stomach the following day was a bit off. Nevertheless, I still consider the PSC a good go-to in the area and will return for the good cocktails and ambience.
author: Sam S.

description: Exceptional service.  They were able to accomodate a large group for one of my dear friends birthday and their service made the night a blast.  Have your next party here if you want an intimate space for a larger group. Fantastic service that always seems to be one step ahead of your needs.  Great food, great service and great drinks!
author: Matthew J.

description:
This is a tale of 2 reviews. Its a little late, due to the hangover which occurred, after I sobered up... which was after I ate at the Social Club. The idea of brunch on a Sunday morning after a Saturday night - well, its just ridiculous in every sense. 

So yes, I rocked up to the PSC still burning off the alcohol from the night before. I know this as I admitted things no adult ever should in the presence of their ever-knowing friends. 

Review 1
The food. We started off with the pancakes. To me, they were a little on the eggy side - something I have never noticed in a pancake before, so I guess they were really eggy. Still, a pancake is a pancake and so long as you have them fluffy and soaked in syrup, who really is going to complain? 

I followed up with the kobe beef sloppy joe. I am slowly working through the 'you won't have experienced America until you have tried this' list which includes the Philly Cheesesteak, baseball, Amerfican Football, eating at a diner (that doesn't mean you, Mel's Diner) and so on... For me, it was like a tube of tomato concentrate had been squeezed over some uber-fatty beef... let me put it this way, as a child, I would dissect a hamburger before I let it near my mouth so I could remove all traces of fat and gristle. So I didn't really enjoy it as much as I wanted to enjoy the idea of it. But on the plus side, it didn't make me nauseous, which is always a risk the morning after. 

Review 2
I don't touch Bloody Marys. Oh no. But, the main reason for visiting the PSC was on the recommendation of my fellow Yelper-in-training. The recomendation was for the Painkiller - a delicious creamy Harvey Wallbanger style cocktail made with OJ, coconut cream and vodka. Oh and a scraping of nutmeg. The nutmeg did make me feel a bit queasy, so I could have done without that. Asides from that, it was delicious all the way down. There are plans afoot to return to try all the other offerings that PSC has - asides from the Bloody Mary. Cold tomato soup with a stick of celery shoved in it really doesn't do it for me. 

The ambience of the place made us all feel like we were in some colonial estate during the 30's or something. The music was lounge, Frank Sinatra style, and the staff didn't intrude too much on us. Maybe because we were the loud lot in the corner who were interrupting the quiet chill of a Sunday morning. All in all, we had a lovely time at the PSC and will be back again, although next time with less expectations on the food side, but more on the drinking side!
author: Catriona C.

description:
Maybe PSC has improved in the last couple of months, but my food was actually inedible.  I sent it back, and I NEVER do that - I don't like to piss people off.  One plus - the bar is nice and the drinks aren't too expensive. 
Here's a breakdown:
Service - nonexistent
Atmosphere - quite nice 
Decor - retro and fun
Food - not good
author: Carrie R.

description:
This is one of those reviews where no matter what I write, I won't be able to fully describe how much I love this place. I've been 3 times in three weeks, and am headed back in tomorrow to round out the month. The only thing holding me back from going more is my wallet.

EVERY SINGLE BITE I've had has been delicious...from the Gruyere grilled cheese sticks with the tomato-soup dipping sauce, to the tuna poke that made me feel like I was in Maui with the flower on the plate, to the grilled trout that tasted like it leapt out of the stream and onto the grill, to the best roast chicken and mashed potatoes I've had in my life. (And I loooove roast chicken and order it everywhere).

The decor relaxes you as soon as you walk in...your whole body eases and you slide into that cool-by-association mode. And believe me, if I could ever be as cool as PSC, I'd be happy. White-jacketed bartenders (3 of em on a Sat night, which allowed one or two the opportunity to chat up the customers, which is MUCH appreciated). Dark wood and green inside, with lazy ceiling fans up above. 40s music that sounds like it's coming from a phonograph...I could move in.

Would give 6 if I could.
author: Annie B.

description:
I love the atmosphere here. Its a quaint place in the presidio.

The food is good, but not great. Im a sucker for oxtail stroganoff.
author: Alden H.

description:
Rustic and comfortable, yet more Marina than Mission, the bartenders are real bartenders, and they make fine drinks -- strong drinks, at that.

A great place for groups, the menu is simple, nothing over-the-top.  This place isn't pretentious, it merely delivers.

Big, solid shiny tabletops, a warm, lively atmosphere.  They know what they're doing, as there's a certain rigor in the air, like a well lubricated military march at a comfortable gait.
author: Abendigo R.

description: They cancel your reservation if you are more than 15 min late. We arrived 17 min after our 730 reservation and had to sit at the bar...fortunately it didn't matter much to us anyhow. It's old school feeling and they have an accompanying menu of old school faves.  I had the meatloaf with mashed potatoes. It was really tasty. My hubby had to pick the mac and cheese because there weren't any other vegetarian items on the menu. *he could have gotten fish, but that's not really veg*.  I tried a bite and it was tasty and cheesy. I'd probably come again, but I always seem to forget about this place until I drive by on my way through the Presidio.
author: Natalie S.

description: Had lunch with two friends yesterday, food and service were wonderful as usual. Just wanted to compliment the hostess, Katrina, for being so courteous and professional. Had reservations for 1:00 PM but with traffic, delays, I called to say I was running late. Katrina said that was not a problem, but mentioned the last seating is at 1:15. Finally arrived at 1:30. She took us to a lovely window seat, where another friend was waiting. Katrina was polite and never made mention of the fact we were over one half hour late. Not every restaurant would have a hostess that would be so gracious.Thanks, M
author: me m.

description:
Do you like soft low voltage lighting?
Do you like classical surroundings?
Do you like slow cooked meals with lots of flava?

This is your place my friend. It has snazz and class all rolled up into a 1940's vibe.

I recommend the ribs and steak tartar. Tables are spaced and large so you wont rub elbows...unless that is your desire? The bar is classic and well stocked with the good stuff. Stainless cabinets adorn the walls, saved from letterman, they now serve as keepers for the other medicinal liquids. The bar-keep was dressed as one would have back in 47', white coat, and red tie, serious and dedicated more like a chemist/soda man then a mixologist. But the drinks that are born are just as precise as the period they came from.

Glenn Miller was playing and the low hum of the soft bare sexy light bulbs kept in time. How I miss those days when women were ladies, and guys were gentlemen. So come in and step back in time, follow the Lombard road to the social club and bring your nostalgia and appetite.
author: Mark B.

description:
I went to PSC with a group of 8 people for my (horrors! -- 39th birthday)...

Drinks were good -- and I concur with GC D's posting that their cocktails are the BEST in the Presidio, but I might even say that their cocktails are the BEST cocktails in all decommissioned military bases that have are now manged by public-private partnerships!

Seriously, though... Appetizers were great -- Oxtail Sliders, Gruyere Grilled Cheese sandwiches with tomato fondue dip, Artichoke/Spinach/Feta dip, and Bay Shrimp fritters were all delicious.

The Frisee/Endive salad with croutons, bacon and a fried egg on top was well executed and was probably as good as any Frisee aux Lardons you could get in Paris.

Main Courses were a more spotty. I wish I had ordered the Sloppy Joe which was delicious... instead I had the Flat Iron Steak, served with the vegetable du jour, Blue Lake Green Beans with a Tomato Sauce --  First of all, a Flat Iron Steak should not be the only kind of steak on a menu -- it's the piece that you buy from the meat company in order to get them to also sell you the high-quality rib-eye or filet.  Then the veggies - tomato sauce was delicious, but the green beans could have used about two hours less cooking...

Dessert stood out... I had the excellent strawberry shortcake (with, thankfully just one candle, not 39). I tried bites of the tasty-but-misnamed Banana Cream Pie (more like a tart), the malted milk parfait (which was outstanding) and the brownie ice cream sunday (delicious!).

Then there's the service... A bit too slow and a bit too unattentive.

All-in-all, I'd go there again for appetizers and/or dessert, I'd have to be choosy with the main course and drinks.
author: Gary B.

description:
From the outside this place is not half as spectacular as from the inside. First of all it's got a very pretty interior. And then we came with a group of six without reservations for a Sunday brunch and they could help us right away. 
The sandwiches and burgers we had were very tasty and the portions were big. 
Service took a little while and since I'm such a sucker for prompt service, I give it only 5 stars.
author: Alexandra D.

description: Went here on a first date. Great atmosphere and friendly staff. We sat right next to a window overlooking the presidio. The view is just beautiful! The crab cake sliders appetizer was delicious- by far the best crab cakes I've ever had but it only came with three. I had the cod special for my entree, which was okay. Portions are definitely a little small for the price, but the view was worth it. Good wine selection.
author: Robin L.

description:
It's truly amazing when you can satisfy both your elderly grandparents' palate for plain, simple food AND the foodies in one meal.

Everything was delish. The star of the meal was the Frisee and Endive salad which was one of the best salads I have ever eaten. It had an absolutely savory bacon vinaigrette, pancetta, and was topped with an excellently fried egg- crispy whites and a deliciously runny yolk. I would come back to PSC for this salad alone. (I actually discovered an identical recipe in Alice Waters' new cookbook, and while excellent, my replication of dish didn't quite capture Presidio's mastery.)

For those with the plain palate, the menu echoes classic 1940s meals and includes chopped liver on rye (very tasty), liver and onions, and good ole mac n' cheese. Also yummy were gruyere cheese tarts (mini grilled cheese sandwiches) served with a little tomato soup. I ordered the Sloppy Joe as my main course, which was probably the only low point of the meal- not bad by any means, but not great. 

Overall a great meal, I will be back with family or fellow foodies. And did I mention there's parking?!
author: Allison S.

description:
We're fans. 2 pm on sunny Sunday afternoon. Just walked over from utter disappointment at Pres a Vi, so this can only get better, one hopes.

Alas, it's much better than better, even though we can only sit at the bar. Bartenders were super friendly, the sloppy joe and burger were tasty, beers are cold. 

Looking forward to trying them out for dinner.
author: Michael S.

description:
Don't bother....this place apparently losted its focus in being a smart, sharp comtemporary restaurant for the sophisticated SF dining crowd.
We were first presented with some beat-up tattered menus. The details of interior seem to rather well-worn and dark (during sunny day). The famous fried chicken appetizer was horrible...over-fried chicken over some re-heated chard. The salad and sandwich entrees were ok...but rather small in portion. The calves liver was half cooked and un-edible.
author: ArchTrk C.

description:
I just came back with a girlfriend for Sunday brunch.  This time we sat out on the patio with the pups (yes!  they are allowed).  It was a fine experience, but I wish they would expand their menu a bit... not a lot of choices, especially if you lean in the direction of lunch vs. breakfast when selecting brunch items.  I think my choices were: hamburger or a chopped romaine salad.  Luckily I am a big salad-head and the romaine salad worked for me, but it would have been nice to have a few more options to choose from.

I had a bloody mary that was pretty damn decent -- not the best I've had but hit the spot.  

I'm sure I'll come back especially after a walk along Chrissy Field with Lucy, but it's not something I'll be tremendously excited about.
author: Sheila D.

description: I used to live in the neighborhood and eat here all the time and loved it. I moved across town in June and found myself on that side of town last weekend so decided to get brunch for old times sake. We got the menu and immediately noticed a lot of our favorites missing. Apparently there is a new chef who thinks its okay to take all the seafood off the menu and replace it with bland salads. When the entree part of the menu is 80% salads - there is a problem! Give me some mussels, shrimp, clam chowder, crab pasta - not a little gem salad with nuts and apples and a vegetable sandwich BORING. The new chef stinks!!!
author: Kate M.

description:
Fun place... really feels like you're stepping back in time. 

The bar and drinks are the best part about this place. Food is a little pricey but good none the less. 

A great place to go for an after work drink and a few appetizers!
author: Elyse R.

description: I went here for my friend Pats birthday this last weekend and had a fab time! For one; we made a reservation for , like, 14, but, 14 did not show.  Some guests had work foisted upon them at the last moment, so they couldn't make an appearance.  It happens. The staff took this very well and didn't seem upset. When our fab waitress went around to collect orders, she actually leaned in, and took the time to hear what I said over the din. It definitely wasn't amateur hour for her. The food was fab; I had the traditional breakfast which is two eggs (any style) , bacon or sausage and hashbrowns. It was delish! I also had the ice cream sandwich for desert, which topped off a great meal. The drinks we had were all great! ( I had mai tais, others had bellinis, bloodys and mimosas). It is a little pricey, but, super fun, super good food. And the service was superb. I would gladly visit them again.
author: Jessica R.

description:
Went here when the fam was in town and it was a good spot for out of town guests who are paying for your dinner. Would come back and sit at the bar if I can back with a friend. Loved the 50s-60s vibe and decor. 

Nice bar menu, I think their bartender came over from the Hotel Majestic.. The Kobe sloppy joe was everything I wanted it to be. Also the brussel sprouts were amazing. 

Watch out though because according to Bill O-Reilly the Presidio is pretty dangerous at night ...
author: Katie M.

description:
I loved this place.  On a Wednesday night, we decided last minute to visit PSC with another couple.  We were pleasantly surprised to see the large parking lot.  When we walked in, I fell in love with the interior and mentioned to my husband that I hoped the food was good because I already wanted to come back.  We were ushered to a table immediately and greeted by a friendly waiter in a white coat.  

My husband had the potato leek soup and a kobe beef sloppy joe and loved both of them.  He mentioned that the beef was prepared differently than he expected (apparently he was expecting it to be shredded and it came out more like stew chunks), but he loved it all the same.

I had the entree special, which was shrimp with polenta and asparagus, and it was delicious and very filling.

For dessert, we had the made-to-order cupcakes.  My mouth waters at the memory!  Three perfect, warm little cupcakes with a side of some sort of vanilla cream... SO good!

In the end, we paid $73 plus tip for one soup, two entrees, two alcoholic beverages, and two desserts.
author: L Y.

description: Wonderful relaxed atmosphere.  Love the cheese toast with tomato dip, caesar salad, and braised pork.
author: Paul M.

description: We came back to this wonderful place for the second time in a week, because we loved the food, service, and ambiance so much... Traci DesJardins developed this restaurant, along with the Commissary, and Arguello's, all on the Presidio of San Francisco, all in historic buildings and all uniques gems (see separate reviews...) My wife and a neighbor and I were all looking for a good restaurant, after a day on Alcatraz... (see separate review...)  Because we'd recently been there, and loved the food and service, it was perfect for us; plus, we were able to call ahead for a reservation...  The food was fabulous...  They serve a Butter Lettuce salad, as well as a Kale salad that were both heavenly... Last time here, we had a 14 oz Pork Chop, that was divine, but it wasn't on the menu, so I went for the Meat Loaf and Macaroni and Cheese, my wife had the Dover Sole, and our neighbor had a beautiful steak...  Everything was super-delicious and, true to their word, the portions of their comfort food are quite generous... We all took "people bags" home, for lunch the next day...  We can't wait to take some of our other "foodie" neighbors to this wonderful place soon, as well as family members, from out of San Francisco...
author: CDR JAY C. O.

description:
