The mother-in-law was in town, so my wife and I figured this to be a good spot. We live in Bernal/Glen Park, so a trip to the Presidio is a nice agenda item for an out-of-towner. Also nice for us SF residents to get around to other neighborhoods and be reminded of how beautiful our city is! 

Very cool, unique space for a restaurant. The building was erected in 1903, and from the pictures we saw, it hasn't really changed. It was originally built as men's barracks and the history adds to the intrigue of the place. They did a good job preserving some of the standard issue/GI vibe too - the hanging lamps, dish cloths for napkins, stainless steel/glass medicine cabinet look behind the bar, etc.

We started with a Escarole and Frisee salad. Very tasty, nice thick chunks of bacon in the dressing, and the fried egg on top. Would get it again. Also an order of the Gruyere Cheese Toast. Nice concept, but too much bread, not enough cheese. Would pass on this one. 

For the main course, I had the Kobe Beef Sloppy Joe and was really pleased! There are big chunks of beef, seemingly slow-cooked as it was beyond tender. Reminded me of a slow-cooked pulled pork texture-just falling apart. The sauce was very tasty, a bit tangy, and for me, the perfect amount of flavor that added, but did not overpower, the beef (which would have been a shame.) The dish came with a generous portion of french fries (skinny pommes frittes style!) and a nice, vinegar-based slaw which suited me perfectly since I don't do mayonnaise. I'd get this again for sure.

Both my wife and mother-in-law had the Club Flat Iron Steak w/mashed potatoes. They ordered medium rare and it came as ordered. There was a tasty butter w/peppercorns melted on top .They both loved it -- I had a few bites and was very impressed as well. A nice solid dish for sure.

We ended up not doing dessert--too full--but the dessert options looked appealing.

For wine, we had a bottle of Havens Merlot Reserve '01. Was not familiar w/the winery, but it was a Napa/Carneros and worked well with the meal. Had some teeth, good tannins. Also, I don't recall the cost exactly, but I don't think it was more than $40 and when I looked this morning on Google, it was retailing around $36. 

Service was good. Attentive but not rushed and a super-nice guy.

I would definitely put this high on the agenda for dinner out when others come to visit (like my parents in July!) And I can definitely see coming here on occasion when us Bernal/Glen Park dwellers want a dose of the bridge, Palace of Fine Arts, Presdio, plus a great meal!
author: Carmine D.

description: I loved everything about our evening at PSC.  It is rare that you can go to a restaurant and LOVE every dish.  There were four of us and we shared everything.  From their delectable salads to fish to meatloaf to dessert, all our food was just simple and delicious.  While I did love every single thing, I do have to say, their Mac and Cheese probably the best ever!  I cannot wait to go back.
author: Eli B.

description:
love it!. The service was just a little slow towards the end waiting for dessert. Luckily I was in good company so it wasn't a tedious and boring wait. The atmosphere was also great.

The building is great inside, the tables layout is decent, you're far away enough to not hear everything your neighbors are talking about, but not too far where you feel so desolate. They have couches, a huge bar, and great view of the presidio. It does get very loud inside, but the waiters are courteous with that.

We waited a while for our dessert. Our server said they had burnt the first one, and comped our dessert, so can't complain there! We had a light dinner. Snackage really in comparison to what the menu is. Lobster bisque soup and Macaroni and cheese. Oh yeh. It was GREAT. Perfect lil dinner. We would have ate more, but we were eating and spending money all day already. I would definitely come here again. What I really appreciated was the servers were not annoying. Confident, not overbearing and professional.
author: jj c.

description:
Cocktails:
Pisco Punch --- Way too bitter.
French 75 --- Way too sour

Hors D'oeuvres:
Crab Cupcakes --- Decent, but meh. Tiny, 3pcs. 

Entrees:
Pork w/ Oyster Hash --- So bland, so pointless. Those were the only things on the plate, slices of tasteless pork, and the hash, which was a huge disappointment too. Why bother putting oysters in there if you're not going to let me taste them? The hash was a rice hash---the idea is fine, but if you want crisp, you're going to need glutinous rice. If you use long grain, you're just asking for a mouthful of gravel.

Flat Iron Steak --- Dear god, if you're going to offer steak make sure you know how to cook it. How hard is that? I ordered it medium rare and it came out rare. The waitress never bothered to check on us after the food arrived, so I didn't even have a chance to send it back. I was floored when I saw her stop to relight the candle at the table next to us, but not notice that the busboy had just taken away my plate, steak mostly intact. The horseradish spaetzle I had as a side continued the taste-free theme of the evening. Again, what had the potential to be great was crippled by their desire to be as inoffensive as possible. 

The clientele is a strictly Marina crowd, and I guess they are just pandering to their tastes. This also explains why it's so loud in there. Wait, drunk, sex-in-the-city wannabe's, loud? Like, no way!

I really wanted to like this place, but I left really wanting to punch somebody. I have no doubt this place is going to do just fine. I won't be back.

Update: I contacted the owners about my experience, and got a "well besides that Mrs. Lincoln, how did you like the play?"-style GFY. Classy!
author: Daniel K.

description:
I've lived in a lot of cities. And I suppose it's a function of my advanced age that I have come to love San Francisco more slowly than the other places I've lived. Which is funny, because it is by far the most beautiful of these.

Compared to Chicago, New York, Texas, and yes, L.A., San Francisco's special something -- that touchstone of authenticity that makes a place lovable -- was elusive. Until now. It's a restaurant called the Presidio Social Club. And I love it.

In a building that was originally an army barracks, the Presidio Social Club is in the heart of that lush geographic non sequitur set at the base of the Golden Gate Bridge. And unlike the rest of San Francisco, which works hard to make you feel like you're in a scene full of beat artists (apparently the era with which most locals identify), the Presidio in general, and the Social Club in particular, makes you feel like you're among the ghosts of the Greatest Generation. 

The interior is stark but warm, white with dark olive accents. The tables are made of rich dark wood; the bar is marble; and behind it, completely at home, are vintage medicine cabinets repurposed for holding liquor. From the ceiling hang bare incandescent filament bulbs and fans that are one part P-51 Mustang, one part Jane Russell.

You could be forgiven for seeing the ghost of Ike in this place. (Come to think of it, I think it's time Ike jackets came back into style). 

The food is fresh and creative, but 100% indigenous A-OK USA. My favorites are the gruyere cheese toast, the frisee and endive salad with bacon vinaigrette and fried egg, and the mac & cheese. The cocktails are noteworthy: the Mai Tais are the original 1940s Trader Vic' recipe -- "no umbrellas." Yum.

The Presidio Social Club is an emblem of a San Francisco I can relate to. Come to think of it, I think there's some Raymond Chandler I should be re-reading about now. And some Hitchcock pictures to see.

The Presidio Social Club: it's swell.
author: Christian R.

description:
Eh, it's ok. Not great, not bad. I'd go back without any fuss. 

The ambience is good, the old barracks, social clubby atmosphere and all. It would be so much better if there were a live band playing. The food is good and so so. They brought out bread, which was about 3 inches total for four people. I just stared at it for a second trying to figure out how it was supposed to be split. The bean and something soup was really good. So was the sloppy joe and a couple of the fish dishes. My mac and cheese was so so.
author: The Sock S.

description:
We had a wonderful Friday night here. What more can I say?

I highly recommend the roasted chicken and those cute little grilled gruyere cheese triangles. Wash those down with the house "pink lemonade" and you've got yourself a nice dinner.
author: April B.

description:
Do you ever marvel at how incredibly different the neighborhoods of this city can be?  I was doing that while dining at PSC last night. The whole place just reeked of my old, fat, white, republican, golf lovin uncle.  

The bf and I left our typical mish/castro surroundings to head over for dinner. I loved the idea of the restaurant- old, classic feel with traditional american dishes in a beautiful setting.  Walking in, I did like the ambiance.  Great, long bar and the whole place sort of feels like a summer home with the large patio and crackled painted walls.  

But 2 stars for the food and the guests (is it fair to knock a restaurant for the other diners there? i don't know, but the people at this place really detracted from my night)  The food made me forget we live in a city known for its culinary prowess.  We had the artichoke dip (that was good, hence the one star, the other one's for the ambiance), beet salad (nothing special), mac n cheese (even kraft does a better imitation of cheese-i had no idea it was possible to botch mac n cheese this badly, completely bland and flavorless), and the fish n chips (reportedly just ok)

I really wanted to like this place. It feels like a country club and fit the rare hot summer night we were having perfectly.  But then I remembered the types of people that frequent country clubs and the last time I ever ate a good meal at one, and why I ended up not liking this place too much started to make sense.
author: Laura H.

description:
Chocolate cup cakes and cinnamon have no business being together.

Good ambience but appetizers are too expensive.
author: Mei B.

description: The Presidio Social Club doesn't come to mind immediately when we're thinking about places to eat dinner. We've gone maybe three or four times. And before last night, the bell just didn't ring. Last night it did: meat loaf, excellent, 1/2 chicken, terrific, heirloom salad....among the best. The PSC has become a go to place for us.
author: Walter C.

description: Great atmosphere in the restaurant, especially on a beautiful early evening in June. The rib-eye steak for 2 was the best piece of meat I have had in a long time. Highly recommended.
author: Dexter M.

description: I am impressed by this place.  The food was great and it had an energetic buzz about it.  I love places with a little history and this is one of them.  I suggest making an afternoon of it and taking a walk or drive around the Presidio.  Well worth it!
author: Ashley F.

description:
I can say that i have been.  That is my big accomplishment.  Now, I had read the menu on line a while ago, and thought ok, foo foo comfort food, I am in.  
Went yesterday after a hike w. my mom and was hoping for gooey deliciousness etc.  wrong.  I thought the menu was very limited.  The chopped salad which was ok.  I was starving so i mowed it down, however just ok. My mom had the tuna melt which for sure was a better call. gooey and tasty.  I can get behind this. 
 The atmosphere is cool, yet freezing, make sure to bring a coat on a cold day.  I am guessing this spot is more welcoming on a cold winter night w/ a gentleman caller, yet not my first choice.  Put some more choices on the menu and I would be more inclined to return.
author: Nicole F.

description:
A solid three stars, which is better than three soiled stars.

Great location and ambiance, especially with the fog rolling in.  Our group of five scored a great, roomy table off the main dining room.

Our server was excellent, knowledgeable about the menu and attentive to our various needs.

It's the food, however, that knocks this experience down a couple of stars.  It was a bit uninspired and underwhelming.  We had been forewarned to stay away from the Kobe Sloppy Joe, so we did.  Our table shared a couple of rounds of the Gruyere Cheese Toasts with Fondue Tomato Dip.  This was probably the highlight of the meal, which says something.

The wife had the beef short rib and reports that it was actually a bit tough.  Coupled with a red wine sauce, potatoes and veggies, it looked like beef stew to me.

I opted for the Fish and Chips.  The fish was Atlantic cod.  The Anchor Steam batter saved this dish.  Then again, this struck me as pub grub.  I'm not sure how you do fish and chips upscale, but PSC certainly didn't do it.

The desserts were tasty enough and the bill for our party of five was fairly reasonable, all things considered. 

PSC is worth giving a try, but it's probably a one-and-done experience for us.
author: Daryl E.

description: We had our latest dinner club at the Presidio Social Club this past month and I knew it existed but wasn't sure where it was in the Presidio.  It's very close to the Cow Hollow/Marina area which I was surprised about because I had never seen it before.  The inside was nice and it was packed (and kinda hot actually).  The server was very good and the food was delicious.  We all had a different array of things but everyone was pleased.
author: Blake B.

description:
This place is great and a perfect restaurant to take out of town guests for a relaxed dinner in the City. The menu consists mostly of tweaked American homestyle dishes that are similar to Home on Market St. The gruyere cheese toasts with tomato soup was ridiculously good. I had the beef stroganoff with egg noodles which was a pretty hearty dish although lacking in flavor. Sampling other dishes, the fish and chips and sonoma roasted chicken were awesome. For dessert, skip out on the brownie sundae and head straight for the banana cream pie. Service was great. I also noticed on the menu that they have daily specials from Sunday - Thursday and Sunday just happens to be a roasted pig! See you next Sunday, ha.

If you don't hit a food comma after the meal, take Lincoln Blvd. all the way down to Fort Point for awesome views of the GG Bridge and the Bay.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description: I went here last Saturday night and this was my fourth time here.  I love this restaurant and the ambiance.  And I am a Gin fan and went to school with one of the bar tenders - try Tim Stookey's concoction...the '20th Century Cocktail'.  He also made a Slow Gin Fizz for my Mom for Mother's day brunch last year - and she loved it!  Thought she was back in the late 50's.  Oh and the Food - I had the Braised Lamb Shank - sublime.
author: L W.

description: Love the atmosphere. Love the service. But the food was blah for that price. If the would match the food to the atmosphere and service without making it any more expensive, this would be a hit.
author: KL H.

description:
I moved to the East Coast several years ago and on a recent trip back to San Francisco a friend took us to the Presidio Social Club. If you've ever been to an U.S. Military Officer's Club while overseas, this place will give you throwback memories of that club. The restaurant is located in old Officers Club of the Presidio. 

We started with an Gruyere cheese toast and an asparagus dip. For my main course I ordered the Anchor Steam battered Fish and Chips -- I couldn't leave San Francisco without another Anchor Steam. My W ordered the chicken but luckily my W's friend let us try her Beef Strogonoff, it had the largest chunks of beef ribs I have ever seen, the noodles were perfectly cooked, aldente. We ordered a small order of mac and cheese which owned up to its reputation. For dessert, the mini smores were perfectly prepared and reminded me of my camping trips in the Sierras. 

There's plenty of free parking in front which is uncommon for San Francisco. Across the street are the Lucas Films offices, a new San Francisco landmark. 

There is a large bar for dinning and a very long table if the bar gets full.
author: Martin O.

description:
Delightful place to dine in SF - how many places can you dine in SF without having a view of a street with cars parked on it?  Having the backdrop of the Presidio for dinner is a refreshing change.

The long restaurant is a former men's barracks, believe it or not.  With the sleek bar and comfortable banquettes, you'd have no idea.  

Friendly coat check and host greetings, outstanding, personable bartender made sure our drink needs were taken care of, and when our table wait turned out to be a bit longer than we thought, he helped us find a quick bite on the menu to tide us over.

The gruyere cheese toasts with tomato dip sounded like a really good idea as an ultimate comfort food, but failed to really deliver the comfort (or satisfy our cravings while we waited for that table).

Dinner service was friendly, and the server's wine and menu knowledge was commendable.  She wasn't as fun as our Brooklyn-born bartender, but it was a pleasant experience overall.  

The menu is limited in quantity of items, and I also found it a bit tough to find a common theme or thruline to it - it made ordering a little rough, but the server was helpful with suggestions, most of which were very good - especially the flatiron steak (WOW).  

The room is so beautiful and we had such a good experience.  I'll definitely go back someday soon.
author: Evan G.

description:
Skip dinner and get desserts.  
I had the gazpacho, which admittedly was really good, and the mac and cheese.  The mac and cheese was dry and not good.  
My friend and I got the combo dessert with the banana cream pie (like others have said not really pie but still really good) and the chocolate pudding.  The pudding was such a small serving, but it's really rich, so I couldn't have eaten any more.  The two together were really good, a little pudding on top of my bite of banana, yum!
Make sure you ask to get seated in the front section.  I made a reservation on opentable, and we were seated in the back side area with a bunch of older people and groups.  All the action was definitely in the other room.
author: Sarah M.

description: Nice place for business meeting and the name said it all. Great friendly service, easy parking space, clean, food and wine are wonderful and I love the great out door seating area.
author: Chris A.

description:
This is a brunch review:

This place is just like everyone else has said already. It feels like youre out in the country more so than in a city, etc, etc, etc. 
Anyway, the service was terrible. It took over 10 minutes to get drinks (not necessarily bar drinks). I was debaing between the tuna sandwich and the sloppy joe, but I figured the tuna would be a safer bet. It looked much better than it tasted, it came open faced with lots of tuna and cheese but for some reaosn just didnt taste as good as it looked. 
The actual restaurant is pretty nice and a good setting for brunch. I'd probably go back here even though it is overpriced but not for a while.
author: Jared M.

description:
Five stars for the ambiance.  I felt like I was in a little bubble of time from the 20s? 30s? 40s? There's definitely an old school, glam feel to the joint.

Zero for the desserts because that's all we had. 

Chocolate cupcakes baked to order. Eh. You get three cupcakes with crunchy chocolate bits on top and it's all covered with powdered sugar and a little cup of super rich vanilla cream to eat with the chocolate. It was a decent balance but not too creative and the cake...it felt like something was lacking. I just can't put my finger on it.

Banana cream pie. I suppose it's unfair to compare it to Tartine's banana cream tart. It doesn't even come close. The pastry shell was blah. The custard/cream was bleh. However, the bananas were nicely cut into little cubes and they weren't brown.
...........................................................................................................................
7 September 2007

I came back tonight for a dinner with some out of townies. *Major shout outs to Alex, Christina, and DJ!

I thought that they would enjoy the ambiance and I was curious about the dinner offerings. 

They LOVED the ambiance! I knew it! They thought that it was super romantic and felt special being there. Service was absolutely perfect. We had that waiter with the trendy D&G frames. 

The food was edible but not totally enjoyable. What did we order?

Steak and avocado tartar looked like it needed a little extra umph.

Soup du jour - cream of corn and bacon was really fiberous. I think that PSC creamed the whole husk of the corn into the soup. 

Red fish came with a really cute salsa with teeny tomatoes. 

Tuna poke had seaweed on it? I had never seen seaweed so wormy looking. But neat-o points for serving the poke with Hawaiian kettle chips. 

Fig and bleu cheese with balsamic vinaigrette. This was the first time that I ever had a green fig and it was really lovely. 

Ox tail stroganoff was kinda weird. I eat Chinese ox tail stew all the time. In fact, it's my most favorite clay pot. Who loves beef stew?! I do! But this one was weird because PSC didn't take the meat off the bone for you. For first timers, I would imagine it to be a little too much to see two hunks of tail on your plate. 

It's really difficult to be lady-like and dainty when you're gnawing meat off of a big bone. 

The brownie dessert was shared by all. We all thought that it was a teensy bit small. One $7 brownie was SMALLER than a 3rd generation iPod.  

Sheesh.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
First visit: Great martini. Amazing fried oysters - fresh, succulent, crispy, not greasy, *awesome* - I could have eaten a dozen. Brisket almost like a stew in a bowl with root vegetables and horseradish cream on top - also, wow. "Whole fish" special was sole, a mild, soft fish, so not super exciting, but nicely prepared. Overall, the food was _very_ good, and not overdone or fluffy in any way. I like the long low building, but it makes the flow of the room a little funny - there are folks sort of backed up or walking back and forth a lot. Great location too, nice change from the city streets, and parking is easy. 

That was 2+ months ago... On a second visit, the oysters were still great but quite amazing, the chopped salad had lots of super fresh, sweet/spicy seasonal radish - nice match with the avacado - and the B-for-bartender did it again with a very nice Negroni. Only black mark was a dish of "mashed peas with mint" that could have been spectacular, but instead tasted of the chicken broth used to blanch the peas, and not at all of mint. Nice spring peas are a treat, but they have to be treated with a delicate hand.
author: Bowen D.

description:
I really wanted to love this place, and as a disclaimer, you should know that my husband did love it.

It is in a truly great location in the Presidio with convenient parking and a relaxing feel even to the exterior environment.  Inside is warm, casual and inviting.  Sound levels are low, so you can actually have a conversation with your parents here.

Starting with the positive, the banana cream pie was delicious.   To start, we shared the chopped salad, which was fresh but very low on flavor, and the tuna poke.  The poke was ok, not inspired.

Hubby had the fish and chips, which were again good, but not inspired.  I had the venison chili.  This was the heaviest, most dense chili I have even had in my life.  I ate about 1/4 of it at the restaurant, then took it home and ate it for the next two days.  Don't get me wrong, it tasted good (not inspired).  But if you order this dish, either love it enough to make it your entre for three days or fast for a day and skip all appetizers.  This stuff is heavy going.

All in all, I can see us returning to PSC as the ambiance is so pleasant.  But my expectations on the food will be managaged, so to speak.
author: Valerie W.

description:
We visited the PSC on day 2 of being open. We found the wait staff to be very attentive plus the food was good. I had the butter lettuce salad and ribs. My BF had house salad and mac n' cheese. We were both satisfied with our meal & will be back soon.

When reading the posting from Phil H keep in mind that as of 12/29 the PSC has only been open 3 days! Im sure they will work out the kinks. Our meal went very smooth and was served fast & hot.

p.s try the beignetts (sp?) so yummy....
author: Sarah M.

description:
Great atmosphere, great food ...had the roasted chicken, mashed potatoes and the beets.  Fantastic. Great Gin and tonics too by the way...they serve them up where YOU pour the tonic...me likey!

The drinks seem very authentic...I think they are trying to keep the selection old fasioned.

I love the colors and design in the club..very comfortable!!   I think it may be my new spot!!!!
author: Piper C.

description:
We were forced to have an early table on Saturday night, but PSC made it a fun dining experience.   There is parking, suburbia style.  There is just some sort of immediate gratification for not being forced to walk for blocks in this winter's arctic temperatures.  

The place looks like what you would expect from a rejuvenated Presidio building, with ceiling fans and barracks style windows.  The colors are even slightly military.

The kobe sloppy joe was OK, but my dining companions really liked their  ahi tuna, roast chicken and ribs.  Our service was fantastic, as the barkeep automatically transferred our tab to our table and our server was very accurate and attentive.  

Based upon my experience and other reviews, they seem to be improving.  I will check them out again soon.
author: Matt T.

description:
Love the place..I think I've turned into a regular.  The bartenders are awesome...kinda cute too.  I love having dinner at the bar but you have to get there before 6:30 to find a space.  I highly highly suggest the side of PEAS...no body does it better I promise.  I've ordered a double because it's yummy.  And I know it sounds scary but I loved the cannibal sandwich too. 

Enjoy!
author: Lisa Kim J.

description:
Really nice place to meet friends for dinner,  I am sure we will be back. 

I had decided from the website that I was having the beignets and the mac n' cheese.

Our waiter had spent a year in New Orleans however and had never had the beignets here.  That should have told us something.  They are essentially donut fingers, definitely not beignets.  Tasty, but they are sugary donut sticks.

The mac' n cheese is decent, but I'm a snob and I have had and made better.  Violet Restaurant in LA posts the recipe for theirs on their website and it is amazing.  The butter lettuce salad with grapefruit was good, but improved by a little salt and pepper.  My husband devoured the tuna steak.

Nice decor, ate in a room off to the side which was fairly quiet for a Sat. night unlike the main dining room.  Loved the long marble bar and the '40s dinnerware.  Good atmosphere and decent food.
author: Amy C.

description:
Cute interior but service needs to be stepped up. If it weren't for an observant busboy, my dining companion and I may have starved - we were seated 20 minutes after our reservation and then ignored for another 15 after we were seated.

Starters of chopped liver (yes, I see the irony in this) and fried okra were good, the mains of chicken and pork were average, and the mini cupcakes for dessert were divine.

But for $105 for 2 including drinks and tip, I shouldn't have been so underwhelmed.
author: Priya S.

description:
Disclaimer.  I only had 3 desserts.  Didn't have dinner or drinks.  We originally came in to find out some info about having our rehersal dinner there and eat desserts.

Ratings:
Bar Service - 5 stars.  Super friendly guys and very helpful.

Dessert - 4 stars.  Rich and tastey.  Definitely helped having something to wash it down.

Atmosphere - 5 stars.  Cool, cozy and retro.

The Manager/Host lady - 0 stars.  We came in and said we just wanted dessert.  Then we said we also wanted to ask about having a rehersal dinner for about 30 people.  (Note: it was 10:30 pm on Friday night.  The restaurant was less than a third full.  And in the time we were there, no other people came in.)  The lady said with attitude "Have dessert and we can talk later, I have to man this" (referring to the front).  At the time we didn't realize it wasn't really that busy.  So we go to the bar and order our dessert, chill, chat and eat.  The lady walks by a few times, no word to us - not even a glance.  It's 11:00pm, still no sign of interest from the lady.  So we ask our bar server for some information.  He was helpful, as much as he could be.  So we pay and start to leave.

As we are leaving and passing the front, we see the lady "manning the front" by chating with a co-worker.  It appeared that she wasn't going to even acknowledge us as we left.  

My boyfriend says to her "we'll call you for information".  

He was expecting something similar to the following response:  "Sorry, I've been busy, but give me a call and I can help you."  

Her actual response..."OK".

I know it doesn't sound like a big deal, but it was the whole attitude.  I didn't expect fawning or gushing.  But some acknowledgement or at least a little common courtesy.  When we left I was so ticked I didn't even want to consider them for our rehersal dinner.  That's not the vibe I want the night before I take the plunge.
author: jen b.

description:
PSC is now doing brunch on Saturday and Sunday.  We got there at 10:15, right after they opened and there were only a couple of tables filled.  

The menu is somewhat limited (about 10 items), but everything else was up to their usual standards.  Prices ranged from $10-16 for entries, so it is really not much more than Park Chow or Ellas.

No crowds, no noise, for now anyway.
author: Alan B.

description:
OK,

Most of the food isn't amazing, but I must say that they do have their strengths.

Wednesday night Prime Rib is pretty amazing and one of the best in town.

I do love the bar, it's definitely not a scene, but great classic cocktails made with style. The menu is traditional American fare, Mac and cheese (decent), fish & chips, awesome smashed peas, and so forth. Try the desserts, they're fantastic, especially the beignets.

I don't know why I like as much as I do, but I've got to say it's a dependable staple for solid food and great cocktails and night of the week.
author: Lucky L.

description: Gruyere cheese toasts or Caesar salad Pan-Fried Rainbow Trout, Flat Iron Steak or Vegetable Frittata Dark Chocolate pudding with Creme Fraiche. Right?! Delicious! The service was wonderful, en-pointe and well executed. The atmosphere is glorious. Old historical building meets young not-too-hip restaurant and make for a beautiful setting. The long marble bar is elegant and their recent makeover in the "private room" made for a perfect intimate wedding lunch spot. They have an adjacent deck you can reserve too. If I'd had it my way, I'd have rented out the whole place. It was worth it!
author: Allison S.

description: Daiquiri. Crab cakes and eye rib steak. Perfect.
author: Georges L.

description: The food is average but its a great space.  I keep going back but it's only because of the ambiance.  Friendly staff, but the service is indifferent more often than not particularly at the bar even when the place isn't crowded.
author: Ed H.

description:
Really cool place that was packed on the 5th night of being in biz. The food was on the mediocre side but i will be back in the hopes that they work their kinks out.
We had the cheese toast which is a 5 star app..decadent but so damn good. The albacore tuna was overcooked and and flavorless. The chicken was decent but lacked meat. The choc cup cake dessert was awesome.
It would be great if they could turn the lights down in the bar area and create a real cozy atmosphere.
author: Not M.

description:
My friend and I agreed that this is a unique, cool mix of people which is refreshing from all the uber-trendy places that mostly fill the Marina.  It was nice feeling like you were out of the city just by walking a few hundred yards into the Presidio.  The old drum set was neat too, but I felt like we should have been listening to a real a big band.  

The food: We had a yummy cheese, prosciutto, watermelon and pistachios appetizer.  It was so good I pretty much blubbered about it to my husband.  And, of course, I had to order it: The Sloppy Joe.  DEEELICIOUS.  Added bonus? Visions of Adam Sandler's "Sloppy Joe, sloppy ,sloppy joe!" lunch lady routine!
author: Crystal K.

description:
Last time I tried to go to the Social Club was about a year ago, but we had so many people, we couldn't squeeze them in our reservation. We tried again this weekend, with a last minute Open Table find (love that). I think my favorite part of the evening was when the hostess raved about how hot my shoes are - actually the staff was quite friendly and greeted us seated us quickly. They also brought our cocktails from the bar over to the table and didn't require us to pay up front (how irritating is it when they don't  do that). So for service: I say 4+ points. 

I thought the cocktail selection was pretty good - I got a pink lemonade which was a bit strong, but yummy and Eric got a Manhattan with some Pastis which he enjoyed. Not so impressed on the wine selection. The wine we wanted they were out of and they didn't have a very compelling alternative at the same price point. 

As for the food: everyone enjoyed the sardines, but the fried okra was a bit of a let down - just tasted like fried dough. The mains were pretty good, but nothing really to write home about. Eric got the oxtail stroganoff, which he enjoyed (but wouldn't necessarily go out of his way to get it). I had to try the famed Sloppy Joe, which I enjoyed. It's much better than a sloppy joe - more of braised beef, which was good. The bread was sort of silly. 

I did enjoy the setting: a blast from the past. Would I go back again? Sure, but probably wouldn't go out of my way or get giddy about the prospects.
author: Julie L.

description:
Don't let my two stars fool you - the Presidio Social Club is not a terrible place to eat. The food is tasty and the service is friendly. Just know that you're paying for a hyped-up soda fountain. Expect $50 for two drinks, an appetizer, and mac & cheese.

I think it should be called Mel's Diner of the Presidio. Of course, then it wouldn't be as chic to go there, now would it?
author: Mike D.

description:
Overall a very pleasant experience.

I had the flat-iron steak, and it was excellent.  Cooked perfectly and the taters were danged good.  I heard pretty good things about the other meals.

As for atmosphere, it was rather quiet for such a  large, open space.  The wait staff was pleasant and courteous and the bartenders were excellent.

I will admit, the place is a bit pricey, and judging soley off the food I would say it is overpriced, but the atmosphere in general really made it worth it.

My only negative is the absence of a dress code.
author: Jim E.

description:
I'm confused by this place... the graphics and front porch aesthetic makes me think that the home-cooking style treats inside might be well priced and the whole place feel laid back.  That's not how it felt to me - pretty expensive, edgy tense vibe and really REALLY loud.

To be fair - we were a party of 10 on a Friday night for someone's birthday, which is kind of a good-dining no no.

When we arrived, the hostess greeted the birthday girl with the warmest of welcomes and invited all 10 of us to stand at the bar while waiting for our table.  The bar is a bit of an afterthought, and it wasn't too hot for us to be standing in the only path the servers had from kitchen to table, but there really was no where else to be.

We had to order a Prix Fixe since we were a big party.  I had the Gruyere Toasts (awesomey horsraddishey tomatoey), and the romaine salad (cruncy rockin good), and then the Club Flat Iron Steak Topped with Peppercorn Butter and Mushroom Sauce... which was pretty good for a skirt steak, but definitely not $25 good, I'd give it $14. The french fries served with it were TOO DIE FOR though.

A friend sitting next to me had the Trout.  It was really boring with very little flavor. I don't know how they came up with a $19 price tag for that dinky thing.

The Lemon Meringue Tart dessert was really really good. Perfect sweet-to-tart ratio.

The service was weird, our waiter seemed friendly enough at the beginning, but his personality died about 1/4 of the way through dinner. Our food came out with great timing and everything was the right temperature, but something was missing.

While we were there, I watched one person (another table) remind the server a couple times that she was sitting there with no food while everyone else at the table had theirs.  She ended up eating off other's plates and never got her salad or dinner.  

Seems like they have some big kinks to work out. If you're going to go, I recommend a week night, and maybe earlier rather than later.

We had a good time, but the $100 per person price tag didn't fit the experience we had.
author: cindy p.

description:
Decor of this place was very nice. Drinks were excellent, as was the service. The appetizers were tasty, but I found the entrees a bit on the overdone side. The slow-roasted pork was overcooked and my fish, while tasty, spent too much time in the oven. 

Overall I would definitely come back, but mostly for the drinks and the decor. Classy place, but they need to up their game if they're entrees are in the $20+ range.
author: DN P.

description:
The atmosphere in this place is really great. You feel like you're back in the 40's .... classy and fun at the same time. Every time I go in, I always feel like everyone there is in a really good mood. The bar is also a lot of fun to sit at if you're not feelin table seating. Now down to business.... 

The food is great. There's nothing particularly super unique or inventive about it, but it's quality. Definitely comfort food... but a big step up from fish and chips. It's also a really fun place to go for desert. It's kind of a two for one type of deal, so you get to sample a few treats, and it's really easy to share with a date or multiple people.  

The drinks here are a thing of art. If you've ever wondered if there were 20 different ways to make a Manhattan, let the bartenders here prove to you that yes.... there is! The cocktail menu is out of this world, and the bartenders really take their time to make the drinks just right.... with all the extras. 

Overall... good stuff. I always have  a good time here!
author: Kim B.

description:
I cannot wait to come back!  The menu takes interesting riffs off of traditional American coastal fare, such as seafood cocktail, Caeser salad, sloppy joe's and banana cream pie, all of which are as indulgent and satisfying as you'd expect.  

The decor, while not immedately stunning, is incredible in the small details and witty juxtapositions of materials and era, while still evoking a very patriotic USA circa 1949.

The service was actually quite good.  We changed our minds about one of the sides that we ordered, and they brought out the correct side like we wanted.

The other (early) diners were a strange mix of post-hippie retired types and techno-nerds, but, I suppose that is what you get when you dine at 5:30.

Dining in the Presidio is a very nice experience, and the Presidio Social Club really manages to enhance the experience.
author: Jim K.

description:
This place is so inviting to its guests. The setting, the people, the atmosphere all make for a fine dining experience. The food is decent but not over the top. 

Corn Chowder Soup = Heaven! Hot (in temperature) but light for the summer. Watermelon and Prociutto is fantastic as well.

Main course pork chop was the best dish of three I tried.
author: R K.

description:
I am not sure how I feel about this place.

I love the atmosphere, they did a great job recreating the feel of a 1940's officers club but still making it contemporary.

The food on the other hand was somewhat disappointing, it was not bad, but there was nothing special about it either.  

So I think the verdict is I will give it another try and see if I can find the right combination of cocktail cool and comfort kibble.
author: David R.

description:
I've been wanting to go here for awhile and we finally went.  I liked the layout and decor - it was a bit loud, but we did have a quiet table in the corner near the window so it blocked out a bit of the noise.  Not sure if my expectations were high because I left feeling a little disappointed.  Overall rating is more like 2 1/5 stars.

We were a bit early so we sat at the bar and were seated pretty soon thereafter.  The hostess came by with a tray to transfer our drinks to the table.  Our server seemed to be a bit green, but other servers in the area did also check in with us to make sure everything was ok.

We started with the beet salad and cheese bread.  The beet salad was ok, but a bit too much greens.  The cheese bread was tasty and the tomato sauce that came with it had a nice kick.  For our main courses, hubby had the kobe beef sloppy joe - nothing too impressive.  I had the braised short rib - didn't really have too much flavor so I had a lot left on my plate.

Luckily dessert was the saving grace.  I had the lemon meringue tart and a side of the smores.  The tart could do without the layer of raspberry gel on the plate.  I liked that the smores came with a shot of milk.  Hubby had the beignets and the pudding.  Both were ok.

Someone else had ordered coffee and it smelled so good I was looking forward to it all during dinner, but my cup tasted watered down.  That was disappointing.

We did have a nice bottle of wine with dinner and overall we had a nice evening out.  It was a bit on the spendier side so it's not likely that we'll return anytime soon when we're looking for comfort food.
author: Mabelle A.

description:
Last night was our first time to the PSC.  Been meaning to check it out for awhile, mostly because I love the name.  It just sounds like a cool joint.

And it was.  I think I could even get to a 4 star review with another visit or two.

Being a nice Jewish girl from NY, I was intrigued by chopped liver & rye toast appetizer, promised on the menu to be "NY Style".  Well, it wasn't really NY style, but it was rich and tasty and the gerkins served with it was a great touch.

For my entree, I went off the specials list and tried the seared albacore tuna.  The tuna itself was good, but the other elements on the plate were what really made the dish a success - finely diced up summer squash that had been marinated in vinaigrette, pureed fennel, and the sweetest tiny orange tomatoes I had ever had.  

So, the food was all good.  The service was only so-so, however, which is one of the reasons why I'm only going 3 stars here.  Our waiter seemed as if he was really trying hard to smile and be friendly.  It sort of seemed like he didn't really want to be there, or that we were bothering him or something.  He wasn't rude, but he seemed to only be going through the motions.  

Also, we were seated in the room off to the side, but it's the main room that has all of the cool atmosphere.  The bar area looked super cool, as did the rest of the main dining room.

Re-reading others' reviews, it appears that we also made a huge mistake by not having dessert.

So - more reasons to go back again!  I really do want to give this place 4 stars.  I think I can I think I can I think I can...
author: Bette K.

description:
We had brunch here a few weeks ago, and I could not believe how disgusting the food was!! The menu was so strange and limited, that it was like trying to order the less of the weird choices. Two of us ordered just plain old scrambled eggs and toast. No kidding here, both of the plates of scrambled eggs had burned pieced of eggs,not brown,but BLACK!. The toast was as white as a sheet, and cold. When we called the waitress over to tell her about the eggs, she looked at us blankly and finally asked us if we would like a replacement. I would never serve a human being those eggs,for that matter, I can't even see a dog eating them. 
I can't say enough, how weird the menu was. 
Don't go here for brunch, a restaurant that can't make even scrambled eggs is someplace to be avoided.

Weird decor also.
author: Elizabeth M.

description: OK food -- good service -- excellent classic bar.  Not nearly as stuffy a scene as I expected -- but the food wasn't as good as I expected either.  Limited menu with reasonable prices. I'd recommend going for brunch.
author: Jason C.

description: I've never written a review about the subpar experiences I've had here (2-3 star experience each time) but deciding to sell foie gras just to lure in people and press?  How about improving your service and food instead? There are many other ways to get people to like your restaurant.
author: Anjali J.

description: We had our wedding reception here in September. The Presidio Social Club team was a dream to work with. They created a menu perfectly tailored to our liking, including both alcoholic and nonalcoholic beverage pairings to go with the appetizers and each of the five courses. They also made three types of homemade ice cream sandwiches at our request. The service was impeccable and of course, the setting is beautiful. I could not have asked for more. I highly recommend holding a special event at this special place.
author: picky e.

description: My first review of this place wasn't great because I had to fight to get an overcharge of my credit card reimbursed.  But once I spoke with the manager, Elizabeth, I got my money back immediately.  It remains true that the service wasn't the best, but the food was great, so I'll give it another chance.
author: Elise M.

description:
Drinks:  The bar here is so cool that it makes you want to order a fancy drink. I had a Pisco Punch and my husband had their  Caiprihinia. Both cocktails were a little tart for our taste. All the more reason to move onto the lovely wine list.

Food:  The menu is mainly comfort food. Yum! Kobe beef sloppy joes, Mac and cheese, fish -n- chips, braised pork with polenta, baked feta cheese and artichoke dip (you get the idea). I ordered the filet of sole which was served whole. Luckily this nice woman sitting next to me had ordered the same thing and urged my waiter to filet and debone it for me tableside. Thank goodness she jumped in to advise me, otherwise I would have ended up with a mouth full of bones. After he finished the "fish surgery", we all tried my delicious dish. It was sublime. But the winner at our table was the sloppy joe. Wonderful texture and flavor. It was a hit!

Atmosphere: The vibe here is vintage Presidio. Beware that it can get pretty loud. Lots of hard surfaces for sound to bounce off. But the  lighting and setting make it feel really special and festive. No tablecloths, so it doesn't seem so fancy or serious.

Dessert:  We tried the banana cream pie, smores, chocolate malt parfait and the beignets. All were heavenly. We should have saved more room in our tummies. Aren't you glad that you read this? Eat half of your sloppy joe and take the rest home for later so you can save more room for dessert.

*One of the big pluses here is FREE PARKING!
author: melissa n.

description:
Brunch is relatively new here and is a great idea for people who love the city, its history and good food. The brunch cocktails are creative and classy and the food is also great for the culinary adventurous as well as traditional eaters. 

No need for reservations and fun to bike to on a Saturday afternoon.
author: Brandi S.

description:
Three of us ate dinner here Sunday night, January 30th.  We had excellent service, and the food was really good.  Not cheap, but very flavorful.  We were a little concerned about seating near a large party (because big parties can be LOUD), but our hostess assured us that our table was the best location available for view & noise, and she was right.  We had a team of four different wait staff who kept our drinks replenished and our bread basket full.  Our waiter was charming and accurate. 

The basic pear salad had a great flavor to it.  Our entree plates were licked clean, not a spec of food left.  I found the chocolate cupcakes for dessert only so-so (not really worth the made-to-order wait), but the other desserts we had were great.     

It was the perfect atmosphere to catch up with our out-of-town guest, and the staff really made it a great experience.  It might have helped that it was on a Sunday night.  The restaurant was about 1/2 empty, so not too busy.
author: Andrew S.

description:
[Note -- this review was intended to be posted last year but for some reason it didn't actually get posted at the time.  Hopefully things have improved]

We had a pretty mediocre experience at this overpriced diner last night.  The albacore tuna I ordered was a thick cut that looked unappetizing.  It was overcooked on the outside.  Preparing tuna is something of an art form -- when it is done right, it can taste almost like steak.  This didn't come close.  It was served on a bed of tasty sauteed vegetables but wasn't worth the $27 that was charged.  My wife enjoyed her overpriced chicken salad.  Neither entree struck us as well presented or particularly appetizing in appearance and both seemed disproportionally expensive. But what really ticked me off was that when I responded to the waitress's "Is everything okay question" by telling her about the tuna, her reaction was "I'm sorry to hear that" and went on as if it was business as usual.   No apology, not even an attempt to act like the customer's complaints mattered.  We won't be going back so soon.
author: Bob W.

description:
I know people who love this place.  I don't get it.
I've eaten there for lunch a few times, and it's ok, but it's WAY overpriced.  The only dish I really enjoyed was their roasted chicken.  It was really good, but it was $18 for lunch (not including a drink).
author: B C.

description: I really like this place. It's tucked in the Presidio and has relaxing old time feeling and not far away from my house I went for dinner and extremely impressed. I'd like to try brunch sometime as well. Tuesday nights apparently have half off glasses of wine and beer. I had a few of their specialty cocktails. A little pricey, but definitely worth it...I feel like I can always expect to have a good time
author: Jenny B.

description: Maybe we ordered poorly but this place left a lot to be desired. The restaurant is actually quite nice and comfortable. Our waiter was fine but a single smile would have been good. One of us (the happy one) got the kale salad with chicken and she said it was very good and the chicken was plentiful - lovely shredded white meat on top of a good sized pile of kale. Another got the roasted vegetable sandwich and he said it was okay but not worth the price. I got the chicken soup. Bad choice but it was a chilly day and I thought I'd be in for something special. Not so. The fresh cilantro and scallions on top were a nice touch and the carrots were cooked perfectly. The broth was moderately bland and the noodles tasted processed. I did expect fresh. The chicken was not abundant and was the dark meat. Generally okay but this included that piece on the get that is really dark red, some tendon and those gross bits with veins and fat. I'm not squeamish about those things because I cook whole birds and make soups but, really, as a lunch entree this was disappointing.
author: Dana T.

description: The two stars are given for the decor, coctails and setting. Experienced one of the worst lunches I've ever had in 10+ years in the City. If you look at my reviews you will see I usually only like to review good places, but this required a review. The food was just plain bad. The deviled eggs tasted like potato salad and the Gruyere cheese points were barely warmed grilled cheese - poor quality thin sliced gruyere melted on toast with nondescript tomato soup. The burger was awful - it was super salty and tasted more like a mystery meat quarter pounder with cheese than a gourmet offering. The meatloaf sandwich was the best thing we had, and that's because it was middling, and both sandwiches with gruyere came with the same thin sliced food service gruyere that was on the toast points. You know its bad when the server never even bothered to ask how was everything at any point; she simply asked if we needed anything else.
author: Joseph S.

description:
Three and a half actually.  Presidio Social Club is solid.  The location and atmosphere, I loved. There's always been something very nostalgic and "Pearl Harbor" about the Presidio for me and the restaurant captures that 40s-50s golden era nicely - lazily rotating ceiling fans, white walls, and all.  You expect to see Kate Beckinsdale all red-lipstick and curler-set hair, dressed in some great retro dress and heels walk in on the arm of some handsome serviceman at any moment and belly up to the bar for the delicious cocktails (pisco punch, mojito, pink lemonade...and the ridiculously good gin cocktail with cayenne pepper). 

The service was great - the hostess was pleasant, the floor manager was goofy, and the waitress had a good sense of humor, although maybe a little to opinionated about the menu.  Everything flowed nicely - bread, water, drinks, food...nice timing on all those fronts.  Two complaints: they were out of a LOT of stuff on the menu (including the cornmeal fried softshell crab special - bummer! -, the first wine we ordered, and the banana creme pie), which was a little frustrating, particularly in the case of the pie which we ordered and then were told ten minutes later that they were out of.  

As for the rest of the food...it was not incredible but it wasn't bad at all either.  The roasted chicken was okay - a tad dry and not very interesting, the kobe beef sloppy joe was the best dish at the table, and the soup of the day - a gigantic white bean and carrot soup in a bacon-parm base - was really excellent.  The salad with the fried egg was good but missing something (hello, fried oysters). Is any mac and cheese ever worth $15?  I didn't think so before we ordered this one, and I still don't.  The lemon tart was mediocre, but those baked-to-order chocolate cupcakes were a damn good end to a pretty good meal.

And the parking.  Bless the parking.
author: Tasha C.

description:
Walking into the Presidio Social Club has a nice feel, warm and welcoming with the vintage red drum set.  The hostess was pleasant and the dining room was interesting in a non-intimate way.

For a Sunday late afternoon it was filled with an eclectic group of people at tables eating and the long bar was nearly full.  I was actually surprised at the crowd.  We got a table quickly by the window  and I appreciated looking out at the old eucalyptus trees and, parking lot!

I wasn't very hungry and ordered a chopped salad and corn soup.  The soup was a WOW!  The flavor was really wonderful with fresh kernels of corn that had the right "pop" in a wonderful soup - not broth. It was so good I wanted another BUT saved my calories for dessert.

What a letdown the chopped salad was - it was literally chopped lettuce and a very innocuous. A limpid dressing that did not resemble the promised Green Goddess dressing didn't help.  It was saved from being uneaten as I asked for avocado to be added and the addition of salt and pepper made it edible.

I tasted my friend's trout and didn't think it was too fresh.  But, the fries were on the spot.

Bread pudding makes me salivate but their's didn't make me swoon.  It was okay but I like buttery rich pread pudding that has a wonderful
egg custard that puffs up the bread.  I think they forgot the promised sauce as well.

All in all I doubt if I'd go back.  It seemed pricey for what it was and the lack of a great chopped salad was a let down.

The staff people are really nice and friendly.  Maybe I'll go back for drinks AND the mac 'n cheese if they lower the price.
author: ELINOR H.

description:
Four and a half stars for food and ambiance, three for service - and because, in my book, service trumps the whole experience, I don't average. We had a 7:15 reservation and arrived on time to be told our table was just being cleared and would we like to wait at the bar? Why, yes, because I had read all the reviews about the fantastic bartender, and even though I don't know if it was in fact him, we were served manhattans by a charming young man. No sooner had we received our cocktail, than our hostess showed up with her silver tray to take us to our table by the window. The evening was off to a splendid start, indeed. 

Our waiter showed up just as I had positioned my napkin on my lap. To my horror, I observed that the retro tea towel had left lint on my black pants. (I thought restaurants thought that sort of thing through in this day and age.) I asked for a replacement and our waiter said, "I'll try to come up with something." I felt like I was the first person to bring the lint situation to his attention and I definitely got the impression I put him out. To tell you the truth, I was a little worried at what he might come up with, but he returned with a lovely white napkin. 

We had previewed the menu online and had an idea what we were hungry for. I ordered the poke and my date ordered the Cesar salad. The poke was fresh and tasty, but the chips were overly peppery. The salad was overdressed and not with what should be named Cesar.  Our wine order had been taken and delivered.

Upon finishing our first course our dishes were removed and our main course arrived, immediately. I would have liked to have taken a breath, but given the alternative of a long wait, I shouldn't complain. We had the liver and onions with a side of spinach, and the pork chop with peaches and a side of mashed peas and mint. I order liver and onions whenever it is on the menu and I wasn't disappointed. All in all, the entrees and sides were delicious. Our empty plates were cleared, but then we waited. And waited. My date said it was 30+ minutes. Our waiter was nowhere to be seen. Oh, actually, I did see him milling about the bar at one point. Eventually, he came by to offer us coffee and dessert. My date was pretty p.o.'d about the service at that point, but I went ahead and ordered the cupcakes I had read so much about. The cream with the cupcakes was to die for. 

We weren't in any hurry, and overall enjoyed the evening, but my date was all about the Michael Bauer review, and wasn't surprised by the less than stellar service. It dawned on me that maybe the negative reviews about service are a result of this one waiter. I would like to test the theory, and because I am the one who books the reservations when we eat out, we will go back to the Presidio Social Club. I will not wear black pants, though.
author: Donna C.

description:
The atmosphere and food at this Presidio fixture were both "yummy", but I have one complaint. I ordered a mojito, and they did not crush the mint before serving. For an establishment that is playing up the Buena Vista Social Club-like Cubano theme, sub-standard mojito-making technique is an oversight worth mentioning. 

Thanks for playing soothing jazz and being classy, though!
author: White-Gloved Rabbit I.

description: I love PSC: delicious food, fun vibe, decent prices, easy parking.  We usually go there before shows at the Palace of Fine Arts.  I've been there for dinner about a dozen times and for lunch once (they just started lunch service) and have never been disappointed.  They serve American comfort food like meatloaf and fried chicken made with top-quality ingredients.  I had the liver & onions, which were delicious, and my wife's pulled pork was great.  They have a nice list of wines by the glass and a full bar (usually crowded).  The back deck is a great place to eat or drink on sunny days.
author: Robert W.

description: SLOW SLOW SLOW - i took my boys and a couple of their friends for dinner.  Food was good, but the service was VERY slow.  Everything seemed to take way too long.  I even pre-ordered the cupcakes that are supposed to take an extra 10 mins.  Obviously they ignored that pre-order as it took 15+ to get desert.  Probably wont go here again.
author: woody m.

description: I have been a big fan of PSC for a while.  However, I am super disappointed.  They took one of my favorite dishes in the city off of the menu.  The Oxtail Biscuit sliders.
author: Markus S.

description: What on earth happened to this place? I have eaten here several times before and the food was fabulous. Went on 11/10/09 and everything was BAD. The waiter was an unresponsive, ill attentive SLUG and the food was completely dry and overcooked: trout, meat loat, BAD. Mojitos-- too tart. This place is now off my list. So sad.
author: Lynka A.

description: A beautiful day at the Presidio and an unexpected invitation to lunch at the Presidio Social Club began with understanding the parking meter gives out a receipt which you display on your car windshield. (no space numbers). We entered the crossover Malt Shop/Upscale restaurant bar to find no one manning the front. Shortly a young woman was able to seat the three of us. The waiter, a pleasant young man told us of the specials; an amazing butternut squash soup (he included the list of ingredients with flourish) I selected the 'Local Rock Cod sandwich with Gruyere cheese which comes with an arugula salad. I asked for it with no cheese. I received it with the cheese and back it went returning shortly as pieces of fish in a bare bun period. The rest of the fanfare was deleted. My first anticipatory bite yielded a flavorless sinew and hunk of fat as did subsequent bites. As I was not going to make more of a fuss I ate what was edible and left the rest (about 60 edible/40 not). Lemonade was good just the right tart to sweet and it tasted real or per the menu (Seasonal) as they have two variations on Lemonade (what would the other be?). The salad served on the same plate came with very little if any dressing so I asked for dressing and was given a tasty white vinaigrette under some other name.  The service was good the location open and cool with the view of the edge of the Presidio and some of the city streets through the trees. All in all I would not try the fish (read crab cakes review) and my take here is it is a hang out for the locals who work in the area and I would bet a Friday after work this place is probably jammed with drinkers who probably don't much care about the quality of food they are using to absorb the alcohol.
author: Michael M.

description:
What a disappointment! The food was very medicore and overpriced.  Maybe because it was the day after Thanksgiving and the staff was tired but, service was inattentive and the food down right lousy.

This was our third visit and last visit.  It just hasn't gotten any better.  Too bad, nice location and great potential.  The management needs to kick some ass in the kitchen.  The Chef should be embarrassed by the quality and presentation.  Come on people...you can do better!
author: Steve H.

description:
Four of us dined at PSC last night (TUESDAY) and it was wonderful!  A pleasant surprise. We loved the ambiance of the former Enlisted Men's Club, though brought San Francisco current.  Our waitress, Leslie, provided us with excellent service and she has a fabulous smile!  Our food, Lamb (2), Fish and Chips, and Halibut were delicious and served in a timely manner.  It was a bit noisy, as there was a party taking place with Mayor Newsom and I believe, Michael Bauer, THE food critic.  Still and all, it was a great experience, a nice surprise and I'm sure we'll be going there more often. 

Bon Appetit! :-)
author: Paula F.

description:
This place really feels like it has a sense of history.  Of course, this is all probably just an illusion on my part, however, I like the fact that it feels different from just about any other SF restaurant.

The bar is really cool although there isn't much room to hang out if you can't get a stool at the bar itself.  The restaurant feels pretty spacious (unlike most SF restaurants) and you can sit far enough away from other tables so you don't have shout to be heard.

The food is pretty decent, although some dishes are on the pricey side.  I always ask them to under cook the fish as I like it on the rare side and I'm not sure that is the default choice in the kitchen.  

BTW, this place really gets busy at the weekends, so you should book...
author: Stephen F.

description:
I went to PSC for the second time last night (first was to celebrate my brother's birthday a year or two ago, like it so much demanded we go there for MY birthday this year).  It's got a great ambiance and great food, and I appreciated how accommodating the staff was when I needed to change my reservation for our large group. Our waiter was attentive and helpful despite having two large tables in his section during  a busy night. 

Everyone at our table really enjoyed their meal- pork shoulder and prime rib were the biggest hits but everyone joined the clean plate club. And my god, the desserts. I am a dessert girl- but even my non-dessert friends inhaled these, they were so delicious.

I just had one complaint last night- I brought two bottles of wine with me, in part because I wanted to make a contribution to the cost of the meal (knowing that my fabulous friends and family wouldn't let me pay on my birthday) and because I really happened to enjoy these wines and had been saving them for a special occasion.  I also know restaurants really prefer that you purchase their alcohol because it's a good money-maker but that's why corkage fees exist, right? 

Well, I'm not sure if it was a manager or some other staff person who opened the first bottle of wine for us, but she tapped me on the shoulder and asked me to taste what I had brought as the cork had popped out and she thought it smelled like corked wine.  I appreciated her concern, but I tasted it and I thought it was fine, maybe not as great as it had been the day I bought it at (my favorite) winery but it suited my standards. My annoyance came when she kept insisting that the wine was bad- saying over and over again, loudly, that it didn't smell right - thank you, but we'll go ahead with this one (and the other I brought, which is also fine).  
What if that wine had been a gift from someone at the table? No need to make them feel embarrassed (or to make me feel embarrassed!) about the quality of their contribution.  
I got the impression she was irritated that I had not turned around and purchased a bottle from her. Charge me your corkage fee, but please don't make loud pronouncements about the wine I bring and choose to enjoy. 

Otherwise, great meal and great service.
author: Mary T.

description:
Best bloody mary.  
Great place to take out of town guests (great parking).
I thought the chilequiles were delicious...the frittata was okay. The egg sandwich rocked.
author: Cathryn L.

description: I take all of my boyfriends here! Men like their burgers. They have THE best hamburgers in town. Waiters are great and alsways friendly. I highly recommend.
author: Sandra Q.

description: food was tasty and local and healthy. had the pacific halibut. and squash/english pea soup very good.
author: Jeff G.

description: I love this charming spot for brunch or lunch in the Presidio. Easy parking & a great opportunity to go for a lovely walk in the Presidio after brunch
author: Johnna M.

description:
Really enjoyed our dinner at Presidio Social Club tonight. Good food--nothing fancy, but fresh ingredients and well prepared. Very attentive service and the atmosphere has a nice 1940s touch without being too over the top. My wife and I took my mom and grandmother to dinner there and it strikes me as a perfect place for parents and other out of town guests--good food, feels very San Francisco, and "hip" in an accessible sort of way. We liked it and I'm sure we'll be back.

UPDATE: Went back last night and have to update my review and take away a star. The food was good (the desserts were excellent) but the service was terrible. They forgot to bring our salads, skipping right to the entrees, it was impossible to get the staff's attention, and we were dying of thirst because we couldn't get our water re-filled. Still a nice atmposphere, but we left a little hungry and frustrated.
author: John K.

description:
Disclaimer: Ambience review only

Got sidetracked -- unsuccessfully -- by a lovely earlier in the evening on a recent Wed night while out with an out-of-town friend. Too late for dinner but decided to go to Presialub (does that even make sense to anyone?) for drinks to at least get an impression. 

He had seen a review in a (gulp!) airline magazine and was curious. What don't we do to be good hosts for our not-so-lucky non-SF-residing friends. 

40s ambience? I'd call it a combi 40s / colonial influences, especially the slow moving overhead fans. 
[Anyone else notice that in movies the fans always move slower the hotter the climate is supposed to be?] 

It was very quiet. The bartender was old-school friendly (that's a good thing). Eased us into the last call-alert. 

Cool mirrors behind the bar, especially the mounting system. The rest of the decor a little bland. Maybe my Bauhaus taste isn't compatible with the 40s.

I'd settle for "has some interesting touches"
author: Stefan S.

description:
I really like this place. Its tucked in the Presidio and has relaxing old time feel. They serve comfort food with a modern twist - fried chicken, meatloaf, etc. They also have a great bar that serves good variations of Manhattans and other drinks. 

This is a great spot for a relaxing dinner in a great location.
author: Richard C.

description: This place is an easy option, nice atmosphere, a social vibe and parking out front.  Good bar seating- comfortable, great drinks and good food.  The menu is oriented around comfort food and somewhat limited if not impossible if you are trying to eat a light or healthy meal.  That said, the burger is fabulous.
author: Sp J.

description: My wife works across the street at Lucas and we failed to make it here for years. What a mistake. An incredible space with retro decor that suits the style of the old military buildings in the Presidio. The menu puts a modern urban spin on a club menu from a different era. We started with avocado and steak tartare (very good). We also tried the lamb meatballs with grilled halloumi. This was exceptional...but isn't everything better with halloumi? I also had an old-school favorite of broiled trout with almonds that was perfectly done. There were a ton of menu items I wanted to try so we're definitely coming back soon. We've heard their cocktails are great too.
author: Bill R.

description: I went there for lunch today, first time I have been there.  I had the soup of the day (vegetable with fried garbanzos), gruyere cheese toast and shared a lemon meringue cake.  The soup was very salty, a shame as it otherwise had excellent flavor.  It favored cabbage and garlic, but then so do I.  I have an obsession with having my soup very hot and returned it to the kitchen when it came out warm.  Yes, I know many people like their soup cooler than I do.  The 4 points of gruyere toast were buttered and grilled with a thin slices of gruyere.  I would have like a little more grilling time for a crunchier toast, and a little less butter, as it overwhelmed the amount of gruyere used.  The tomato dip with it was a thick bisque, very good in this version of grilled cheese and tomato soup.  I would order it again.  My coffee was very strong- just as I like it.  My companion's ginger mint iced tea had a surprisingly delicate flavor approach.  Her burger was excellent, though tended more toward well done than medium well, so check exactly what their chef refers to as degree of doneness.  We both liked the lemon meringue cake very well, and had no trouble finishing it off.  We ended up having two waiters, one of whom was fairly good.  The other kept an excellent eye on us, and even remembered to refill my coffee (which I had delayed) at the end of the meal.
author: Phyllis H.

description:
Went with a large group from work for dinner the other night. I've gotta say, the front of the house was super accomodating as I had started w/ a res for 4 on OpenTable, then upped it to 6 and then had a couple more folks come on board last minute. 

Foodwise - I went for the the PLT salad and mac and cheese. Heirloom tomatoes were ok in the salad - it's getting late in the season. Mac and cheese w/ white cheddar was quite good -- good amount of bread crumb topping, not too creamy. I ate the other half for lunch the next day.  Dessert - we went for the brioche beignets. I didn't detect much of a brioche dough, but nevertheless, these doughnuts were light and not at all greasy.  Served with maple syrup for dipping (which I found odd, but whatever). They were damn tasty.

Service was good and the kitchen was well paced - no big gaps waiting for everyone to get their food. I'll probably go back to try the chicken pot pie special (Tuesday nights).
author: Michelle J.

description: 1920s swanky feel.  Lots of parking.  Good cocktails, but expensive.  Atmosphere is open and airy, but not noisy.  Food was good, not great.
author: Melissa A.

description: The food is usually fine though no foodie mecca, and the service can be a little forgetful, but there's just something so endearing and sweet about this place that keeps me coming back. Everyone is so friendly and the cocktail list is full of well-executed classics. It  can be packed at brunch so prepare for a wait if you didn't make a reservation (though sometimes you luck out).
author: Sara O.

description: The Presidio Social Club is within easy walking distance from our apartment and we've been here probably about 10x over the years. It's very reliable for solid American food in a fun environment. On our last visit, the service wasn't horrible but not fantastic either - our server seemed slightly annoyed that people were ordering multiple small plates and that we needed to ask about gluten free options. The food is good (the specials, in our experience, are often better) but not exceptional. The noise level is very high, especially if you're seated near the large bar area which, on our last visit, made it almost impossible to talk.
author: Maggie L.

description: Such a disappointment. I was really looking forward to checking this place out. I was excited by the fun retro Americana menu and thought that would be carried out in the restaurant decor and atmosphere as well. WRONG. The exterior building is cool, but the inside is drab and doesn't tie in with the theme. The wall paintings featured multicolored horses dancing together which seemed out of place and the service was sooo slow. The food was also mediocre (mac & cheese, fish & chips, flat iron steak & sloppy joe) and over priced for what it was. It's such a shame because I really wanted to like it.
author: Angela N.

description: I was so excited to go to the Presidio Social club with all of my friends. I had read the reviews and researched the restaurant for the best possible food. I ordered the Chopped Romaine Salad and Club Flat Iron Steak.  It was just all  right. For some reason I thought that this place was going to be really nice because it's in the Presidio. The decor was very plain with lots of plants. I'll check this place off my list and not go back
author: Michelle W.

description:
Tonight was opening night, and Roomie and I couldn't resist checking it out after catching a flick at the Presidio Theatre.  I felt like I had stepped back in time.  Which is strange, since it's very modern inside, but also very retro.  The way that works is interesting.  It's minimalist, and sleek, but with retro fixtures --- the fans, the wait staff's uniforms, the bar cabinets that are reclaimed from the old Letterman Army Medical Center just down the street, the end cut hardwood floors, the tea towels that act as napkins, and the wash basins in the bathroom that aren't quite sure if they're basins or urinals.  
The staff wavered between excited for opening night, to polite and attentive (almost to a fault) to completely distracted and aloof.  The food was. . . . . well.  The menu is very "down home" with nightly family style dinners to come (one main, two sides, a dessert, etc.).  They've got a few salads, some sandwiches/burgers, and then a standard steak/chop/chicken menu.  Plenty of apps and desserts, and a decent selection of cocktails and wines --- including the house "Presidio Social Club" red or white.  Roomie and I shared the Hawaiian poke which was combined with mango, onion, cucumber and ?seaweed?  It was served with yummy housemade potato chips, but to me, it just tasted of the sea.  I could've been swimming at Ocean Beach with my mouth open and had a similar taste sensation.  Good, bad, you decide.  We also had the Gruyere cheese toasts with tomato fondue dipping sauce.  Let's be real.  It's a grilled cheese sandwich cut into quarters, served with a ramekin of thick tomato soup.  I was ready for this to be awesome, but it was overwhelmed by the caraway seeds in the bread.  I don't like licorice.  Be it anise, fennel, or caraway, so this may be a personal thing, but I couldn't taste the gruyere at all.  
I LOVE the space --- there is a private room and soon to be outdoor patio, and the fact that it's an old community center, that used to be barracks, and all of the reclaimed materials they've used, means it's heaven to me and my 1940s fantasies, but the food definitely needs work.  
We'll be back once the ball gets rolling --- so far it's retro-cool, comfortable and quiet --- I hope it stays that way!!!  I bet it would be great for a buyout.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
casual yes, but with presidio style.

the service was warm and friendly like the ambiance.

the cocktails were delicious and i was glad that i was not driving since i sampled a few.  if i lived closer, i would be a regular at the bar.

i read up on what to order from yelpers so here is my take:

1. cheese toast with tomato dipping sauce - pls order this.  the surprising bits of horseradish really added a kick to this app.
2. the butter lettuce salad. simple but the dressing was just right.
3. the chicken was very good and the skin was so well seasoned.
4. the fried pork special - i subbed the polenta for risotto.  the risotto was eeeexcellent.  perfectly cooked and balanced the tasty pork.

for dessert: always leave room for dessert...
i highly recommend the beignets (doughnuts, folks)
the cookies were tiny bits of yummy-ness baked daily but GO for the doughnuts.

a miss? the lack of heating in the bathroom.  yeowsers! nothing like chilled buns on a cold san francisco night.

do call a cab at dessert because it takes 30 mins or...walk the dinner off to lombard. 

bon appetit!
author: Anh V.
