description: One of my favorites! Great views, great history, great food. The toasted cheese sandwich, yum! Old fashion diner type food with the upscale feel. Wonderful drinks. Sloe Gin Fizz!!!
author: S F.

description: I had received 3 referrals to this place for brunch(my favorite meal) and was looking forward to it. Upon entering, the hostess asked if we were staying, we said yes, she then walked away for a good long time. We finally grabbed her to get her our name that we thought might be required to hold a reservation. This started me off docking points before we even got started. As I looked around I noticed the wall paint was the PERFECT shade of grey, the light fixtures were fantastic, the Christmas decor lovely, overall interior/ambiance wonderful. Maybe it was just the hostess's first day. Then we sat at bar and got ignored. We finally got a drink order in and never heard from her again. We were optimistic enough to ask to move to a table in hopes of better service. We then sat down and had a friendly apologetic server, got drinks and were on our way. Had medium to good food and never saw our server again. Moral of the story is food decent, environment solid, service sucks and I mean on 3 accounts all around failed.
author: Tatum T.

description: Great ambiance, food and service.  While it's American fair and some comfort food, it is definitely California style as far as the freshness, spices and tastes.  Guyere toast and tomato soup is amazing and Tuna Tower tops the charts.  Tuesday's are half off wine and beer which is a huge plus if you are going to hang with a friend at the bar.  I think I've ordered one of everything from the menu and everything was delicious!
author: Dave L.

description:
Simple
That's about the only word I can think of, to describe my dining experience! I thought they did a nice job on the decor of the place. Service was fine. I guess they are going for a up-scale retro feel?
I liked the long bar and the community table and the menu was well, simple.
We started with the $8 cheese toast. Pretty much what you would expect. My friend had the $15 sloppy joe. Good fries,  but the meat was a bit too sweet. I had the $19 flat iron steak with whipped potatoes. It was a piece of fatty london broil and WHIPPED potatoes, period. 
Not saying it was bad, just very safe.
I have to say I was most disappointed in the cocktails. After looking at the reviews for this place, I was so in the mood for one of these great cocktails, everyone is talking about. What I got, was a tiny, tiny $8 martini. It was tart and I literally could have drank it in one sip! 
Crowd was a very interesting mix of people.
author: Lisa A.

description:
Not being a fan of Arnie's ban on foie i was drawn in by the bastille day special and  was not disappointed.  Great location, just being in the calm of the presidio starts the night right.  The old building and solid bar make for a great impression, no feeling of hey I have been here before because the place looks like everything else in "generica".  

I was incredibly impressed by the skill of the barmen, perfect manhattan - perfect and every other mixed drink ordered in our party was impressive.  Of course our entire party took part in the sliders and not one disappointing bite, i really enjoyed the extra sea salt on the top of the bun and the additional of the pinapple adding enough acidity to make the dish a wow!  

After moving to a table for dinner my party of 3 ordered the oysters so fresh i wasn't sure they were oysters rather than fresh sea made to look like oysters. We then shared rib steak prix fixe menu for 2 which was a great choice because we had to add the mac and cheese (umm cant stop thinking of you mac and cheese mmmmmm).  The butter lettuce salad we think had each leaf massaged by hand and seasoned perfectly, such a simple thing and such a fabulous flavor.   Our steak was cooked to perfection served with fries some of which had bathed in the luxurious demi glace at the bottom of the plate, this did in fact cause a tiny battle over  the best bits.  The foie torchon was served on the side, i would rather it was seared a bit but i am not complaining nor did i leave any on my plate.  After dinner we enjoyed a cup of coffee with our profiterloes and another battle ensued over the carmelized pistashios.

We went home 3 giddy, well fed newcomers already making plans to return for the whole roast pig Sunday's!!
author: Happy B.

description:
Don't believe the hype, I am completely unimpressed with this place. Sure it's clean and neat in that throwback to the olden days style, like I'm a young military guy out on a date with my best girl kind of way, but that will only get people in the door once. To keep them coming back for more you better have more to offer than slow moving ceiling fans old timey music and a soda shop bar. (No TV for catching the score of the Giants game either) 
We sat down and received our menu's then waited and waited to place a drink order. When the waiter finally came back he was there to take our dinner order, so we ordered drinks with our dinner and an appetizer mac & cheese. 
Strike 1
It took almost 20 minutes before the drinks arrived, mine was a white wine which was funny because I ordered gin. I decided that rather than risk waiting another 20 min I would just drink the wine.  
Strike 2
Another 20 minutes and our dinner arrives, but what happened to our Appetizer? We are told that our app has accidentally been given to another table and they would bring ours out right away... 15 min later!
Strike3
The Mac & Cheese is not amazing!!! it's OK but not even close to being worth $15, +2.50 to share. 
We complained to the management who didn't really care that we had a bad experience only if we liked the food. Yes the food was fine but I will never come back does that answer your question lady?
author: matt l.

description: We were seated quickly and the service was great. I loved the look of the place. We came for brunch but I don't think I would come back unless it was for dinner. I wasn't crazy about options on the menu. It probably wasn't my day. I got the mussels and frites, my sister got the huevos rancheros, and my mother got the chilaquiles with the pork belly. Mom's dish was by far the most interesting but only because her dish had pork surrounded by its own delightful fat.
author: Connie L.

description: We love this place. Great food and great atmosphere. We have an 18 month old and we always feel welcome here. We receive great service for brunch on Saturdays but can't say the same thing for Sundays. Both times we have gone on Sunday the waiters were horrible. Other than that don't have anything else to complain about. Over all a really great place!
author: Jessica R.

description:
A great little Friday night dinner with friends restaurant.

Location/Ambiance:
Perfect spot right in the Presidio easy to get to, plenty of parking. The ambiance is super cute with a vintage vibe. Has the upscale yet unstuffy feeling of a swanky little hidden away place. 

Service:
Our waiter was pleasant and offered suggestions that were actually helpful. Knew the menu well could actually chat with us about what was good. Checked on us often without being intrusive. 

Food:
Ohhh, it was great. Had the special of grilled sole atop of pesto white beans with a bit of greens. Was a large piece of sole and grilled just right. Light without leaving me hungry. My dinner dates had the kobe beef sloppy joe and the flat iron steak. I'm not a fan of sloppy joe but I would get this next time. Nice shredded beef but not too sweet with extra crunchy fries that I could eat pounds of. Flat iron was cooked to order and surprisingly the garlic brussel sprouts were a delight! I normally loathe them but they were just soft enough to melt in your mouth with the right amount of garlicky goodness. We all shared the apple cobbler. It was good but mediocre. Their drink menu is extensive and offered everything you can think of. If you're a fan of older drinks like negroni's and an old fashioned this is the place for you, they actually know how to make them without asking you for details. 

Value:
Good. Portion sizes are large and pricing reflects a nice evening dinner. Not an everyday place but certainly a monthly dinner spot. 

Return:
Most definetly. Its fun and a great place to take friends.
author: Jen T.

description: What a fabulous find thanks to yelp!  We took my father here for his 60th birthday dinner and it was perfect!  We had to wait an extra 15 minutes for our table but it was worth it because we were able to get some drinks at the bar and then watch our mom get sort of blasted (she doesn't normally drink).  Oh man that was great!  Our table was great, set off in the other room so we could actually talk.  My sister and I split the steak dish and ordered a side of mac.  Everything was perfect.  We tried our mom's pork chop and our dad's sloppy joe and tose dishes too were awesome!  When it came to dessert our waiter was awesome and informed us about a dessert that was not on the menu.  YUM!  All in all it was just such a nice dining experience.
author: Kirsten M.

description: I've always had a wonderful meal here.  Whether it is for business, just dessert, a snack with a friend, a group of troublemakers.  From the Fried Egg Frisee Salad, to the Liver on Crostini, Mac and Cheese, Pig on Sundays, Paired desserts: Beignets, Malt, Cookies, Cake, etc for $10.  I love this place.  Eating at the bar for a quick bite is also fun.
author: Diana L.

description: I came here for a guardsmen event, so I can't speak for the food, but it was definitely a poor choice of venue for the event.  It took us almost half an hour to get a drink at the very crowded bar.  Not because we had to wait in line, but because the bartenders were extremely slow, and there should have been at least two more of them on.  Once we got our drinks, there was nowhere to stand and we were shooed off the dining room floor forced to cram ourselves in a small standing room area.  At about this time a hostess came around telling everyone to leave cause they were above capacity and had people with dinner reservations that needed to come in.
author: Emily K.

description: Simply a perfect experience. I love the food - the menu possesses both creative and fun (Sloppy Joe, Mac and Cheese, a "Cookie Plate" for desert) and more traditional fare (the Flat Iron steak with Sauteed Spinach side). I've gone on dates, brought my parents and had nights out with friends as well - everyone has always loved the food (8 different people total) and had a wonderful time. Tough to give five stars when I don't consider PSC a "destination restaurant" but you'll remember every meal as well as every evening here.
author: Colin J.

description: OMG, this place was absolutely incedible!  My sis and I took our mom and dad here for dad's brithdays and man were they pumped!  The sis and I split the flat iron steak which included sauteed spinach.  My mom had a pork chop that was out of this world, and although I'm not a huge fan of sloppy joe's my dad's dish was delish!  Parking, for once, is actually easy as they have their own parking lot and their drinks are legit!  Tasty and strong.
author: Danielle V.

description: I have done dinner here and lunch.  Food is really good.  Lunch would be my preference because of the noise level.  Service is excellent.  Next visit will be the patio.  The squid salad was really good as was the crab louie sandwich.
author: nina l.

description:
Just came back from a nice light dinner at the PSC. Met a good friend there for dinner at 7:15; reservations were made this past Monday. 
The joint was kinda jumpin for a Wednesday night! I loved the retro feel to the place- the bar is very long, quite sleek as another reviewer put it. 
We had a lovely seat next to the window. My recommendation if you need wheelchair accessibility would be to call in advance, as our table was a bit snug in a corner section of the restaurant, to make sure you can get a comfortable seat. 
Food: we shared the Island Poke, Hot and Cold Crab Salad, Gruyere Toasts, and the seasonal vegetable dish (brussel sprouts and butternut squash sauteed in parsley sage butter, I believe). For dessert we shared the benigets and the cookie plate. It was all quite yummy, I have to say. I didn't order a main as they were pretty meat heavy and I wasn't in the mood. The sloppy joes looked yummy- if I were feeling more carnivorous I might have tried that. 
Our wait person was quite friendly, and our food came out timely, but it took awhile for us to get our check settled. 
I would like to go back to try brunch- we saw a sign near the front door advertising their new brunch service.
author: Jennifer C.

description: I liked this place.  Our waitress was adorable and the retro cocktails were quite good.  My meal of steak and sauteed spinach wasn't astounding but was good and my friends fish and chips were yummy.  The fish was crisp with tender fish and the fries were not the best ever but were crispy and well seasoned.  We both thought the tartar sauce was quite good, something you'd think would be standard but isn't.  The server uniforms are fun and I appreciate that they've preserved the feel of the building.
author: Kiki R.

description: We really enjoyed our early Saturday evening dinner at the Presidio Social Club. It's a throw back to another time and place. Having grown up two blocks away when the Presidio was still a working army base I found it particularly interesting to dine here. I also enjoy being in a true park setting in San Francisco. There aren't many places you can do that! The service was excellent and the food also hit the mark. We particularly enjoyed the butter lettuce salad with persimmon and Dijon champagne vinaigrette and the warm beignets with maple syrup for dessert.
author: Debra M.

description:
It was their 6th night having been open, and so far things seem to be running pretty smoothly.  The social club is pleasantly located right inside the Presidio, off the Lombard gate, across from the Lucas complex.  I got the feeling like I was on vacation in Tahoe, I guess perhaps the woodsy feel of the Presidio, the crispness of the night, and the retro ski lodge feel.
The have a cool counter bar set up with the tenders in white coats, pretty sharp looking.  
As far as our meal, it was pretty good.  The menu is fairly small, nice when you're indecisive.  Few salads, a soup, assorted apps.  Nice assortment of entrees, standard fish, pork, chicken or beef options.  They have a dish that my grandparents would dig, grilled chicken livers....I'm not so into, but that's just me.  Sloppy Joe sandwich too.  Pick a side with the entree, nice assortment there.  Looks like there's a daily special coming soon to the menu, but yet to be available on our visit.  
I enjoyed my food, shrimp cocktail, I got the veggie side and the gruyere toasts (fancy grilled cheese sandwich).
I hope this place gets booming, it has a good feel and friendly attentive service.
author: ERICA E.

description: Love the sleek, white bar. The decor overall is modern yet at the same time doesn't feel like 2008. This probably has a lot to do with the employees' dress code along with the old-school menu. Unfortunately, didn't have any time for food, but the drinks were good and the bar service was attentive and friendly...
author: Nicolas H.

description: nice place to stop on the way back in to town from the North Bay.  This place just has a good feel about it - it's open and airy, stylish but not over done, set in a very cool spot (Presidio).  Go at an off-time (like 4:30 PM), sit at the bar and have a bloody mary with the grilled trout and mashed potatoes while you chit-chat with the bartenders (in classic white & black suits with red ties).  Nice SF experience.
author: ashton c.

description: I've been here several times and it's always a solid choice. Food is always good and sometimes excellent, service is friendly, and the space is really cool. Living in Marin, it's a great spot for me to grab dinner on the way into the city for the night.
author: Jim T.

description: We went to this place twice for celebrations of wonderful things that have happened to us. We had gone for brunch and lunch and the alcohol and hamburgers and soup were above standard, as the way it should be.  I will definitely go again for the experience and try the dinner menu which looks delicious. Go and try for yourself and see!
author: N A.

description: The space reminds me of a cross between Balboa Cafe and Cliff House. Maybe it was an old army barracks? Not sure, but the Art Deco-like fans were cool, and the reclaimed wood table is OUTSTANDING. For bites there are crab cakes, oysters, and other San Francisco-style snacky things. Classic cocktails too, but I go for wine and champagne myself.
author: sarah s.

description: Awful.  Food was nothing spectacular and seriously overpriced.  We went on a Thursday night and it was not busy yet our service was horrible.  Our server, Robert, was terrible.  I wanted to like this place; was looking forward to it; have no problem for paying for a meal if it's worth it.  Steer clear of the pork---very fatty and flavorless.  It's a shame a place with such potential can't get the basics right (food and service).
author: Janet L.

description: Love Tim the bartender.  Love the cannibal sandwich.  Love the recycled decor from the bunker days.
author: Tracy A.

description: Went on a Saturday night - totally enjoyed it.  Food and service were great, and the vibe of the place is amazing. Can't remember the last time I was out in SF for dinner where there was such a great mix of a 'good looking' crowd and families together at the same place. Food is as advertised - new take on comfort dishes. Very easy to talk at the tables in the dining room as well - there was a lot of noise and activity but it did not preclude conversation.  Try the Mac and Cheese side dish. Now if they could just open up one of those porches for cigar smoking after dinner it would be perfect...
author: Arthur S.

description: I love the decor here. They did a great job keeping the integrity of the original space. The food is REALLY REALLY good! Their hanger steak and mini cupcakes are my favorite! The bartender Tim is really nice and is one of the best in the city!
author: jen v.

description:
We had a great time at the Presidio Social Club. We had reservations for an early dinner with a group of 8. We were greeted by a friendly hostess who was dressed in the 40's-50's style. We were seated right away in a room just of the main room and bar. This is a great place for groups as it can get a little loud. Really not a romantic destination.
There was piped in music from the 40's which with the decor really gave a good old fashioned feel. The food is home style cooking with little twists. They have Sloppy Joe's, Macaroni & Cheese, Steak, Fish and Salads.
I thought their appetizers were a little on the heavy side so you may want to split one. The Drinks - the  drinks were excellent and they make a lot of old time classics. Also when we ordered a drink that was not on the list (Jack Rose) they asked us how to make it and and found the ingredients and made a special one for us. As the night progressed the music become drowned out by laughter and talk from the bar room dinning room. You could tell everyone was having a great time. 
The restaurant is located just inside Lombard gate in the Presidio. 
great for groups especially good for families from little kids to grandparents. Also for young couples but you may want to eat at the bar.
author: Mark S.

description: 2nd time I've been there. I went on New year's eve when it first opened, it was okay.  Decided to try it again.  Had the chicken arugula salad.  Very minimal amount of chicken that was tiny strips of dark and light meat.  Very disappointing.
author: Monica D.

description: Best beignets ever. Malted parfait is so tasty.....loved the apps there.
author: Tami Y.

description: Took my parents here when they were visiting from the north coast.  Pretty standard menu, something for everyone and good too.  Parking availability is a plus!  esp for SF
author: Aimee J.

description:
I have been to PSC five times which is saying a lot since there are hundreds of restaurants in the city and its a personal goal of mine to try all of them.  However my last two experiences at PSC were HORRIBLE - both in terms of service (slow or non-existent) and food (mediocre at best).  So bad I felt compelled to add my two cents to Yelp...

Plus hopefully this will be a reminder for me NOT to go back to this restaurant!!!! 

Btw the two stars are for the ambiance (love the nostalgic feeling!) and location (I like having a reason to go to the Presidio, plus there's parking).
author: Valerie G.

description: Wonderful service.  Great ambience...a little on the loud side, but still very enjoyable.  The food is excellent, especially at its price point (you must try the Kobe Beef Sloppy Joe).  And we mustn't forget Tim Stookey, one of San Francisco's premier bartenders...Ask for a Southside cocktail. Bravo Ray, Shawn, and Bernd!
author: Donato C.

description: Went here last night with a friend. I think I found my new favorite local restuarant. The ambiance is great, and its a pretty large place. It was really busy for a Tuesday night but I felt it added to the charm. There is a great long bar which was full of people. I had a great glass of Pinor Noir from Carmel, which was nice.  We split the watermelon, goat cheese and procuitto appetizer, it was fantastic.  For dinner I had the roasted chicken and veggetables. It was good and light, however I kept eyeing my friends sloppy joe  which I obviously had a bite. The sloppy joe was by far the best thing. The beef was so tender and the fries were great. I will definently come here again!
author: Erin R.

description: I'm not even inspired to write a review on this restaurant. But I will just to say a few simple things: too expensive, food is not that great (especially for the price you pay), not many folks of color there which is always strange in this day in age in a city like SF. The chicken caught my eye, but I was disappointed. I ended up eating my boyfriends fries and taking 3/4 of my chicken to go. I hate wasting food even if it's subpar. I was excited to see banana cream pie on the  menu. I shared it with Deb. What happened to the cream? It was a pile of cubed bananas topped with whipped cream. Oh I get it...that is the cream. Yawn. It's not that it tasted bad, it just wasn't banana cream pie. It was banana cube pie. Our waitress was super. She was nice and attentive and never overbearing. Our bartender was also cool. Nice funny guy. Way to go you two. But, I won't be going back.
author: Judith S.

description:
I read a lot of the existing reviews on this place before going to dinner here so, I was prepared to not have the best experience.  I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised!!  There were multiple items on the menu I wanted to try and everything I did sample was GREAT!  I was there with a group of four people and three of the four of us ordered the same thing, which was the scallop special for the evening.  We also ordered a few appetizers to share, I think the Figs in a blanket were my favorite.  However, I think the best thing on the menu would have to be the beignets!!

The one down-side to our experience was that we were seated in the side room which, would be great for a large group or private party but, I think it would have been more fun to sit in the main dining room and experience the energy of the main restaurant.
author: bree s.

description: The atmosphere was really unique.   It didn't even feel like SF.  Our waitress was really attentive and friendly at the beginning of the meal, but she was no where to found for the second half.  I ordered the sloppy joe, substituted the spaetzle, and it came with cold slaw.  The meat on the sloppy joe was really fatty (I didn't finish it), the spaetzle was good, but overcooked, and the cold slaw was a little bland.  I loved the description of what I ordered, but it didn't really translate to the table.  I really hope they are just working out the kinks still and they pull it together soon.  I had the banana cream pie for desert, it was good, but a little light on the custard.  I would go back in a few months after they have a little more time to get used serving a full restaurant.
author: Juliana L.

description: I really like this place. Not sure if it is the location, the interior or just the whole experience. Maybe it's the fact that it isn't trying to be some fancy downtown expense account restaurant, it is just a fun place to go and have an old school meal. We started with the Gruyere cheese toasts with fondue tomato dip (a crowd pleaser). I moved on to the fish plate special, a very interesting Sardine Filet. Can't say I have ever had Sardines in a restaurant, but it was different (probably wouldn't get again, but I am glad I did). Dessert  was great as well. We had the chocolate cupcakes and the beignets, I would recommend both. Let's just say I will be going back and taking friends.
author: Raymond M.

description: Food was NOT good and it was overpriced. I had the lamb dish. Won't  be going back.
author: Konnie X.

description: A great place to grab a drink! The cocktails I've tried are: Gunpowder and the Original Aviation. Definitely get either of them! The bartender was also super nice. I was impressed with how friendly the hostess is. Also I died for the beignets! I've never had dinner here so I can't comment on the quality of the meals, but drinks and desserts are awesome possum in addition to the friendliness and helpful attitude of the waitstaff I've encountered on my two visits.
author: Beth H.

description: I have eaten here a least 10 times and always had a great, consistent experience. The atmosphere is both personable, comfortable but has some energy to it. The food, very comfort driven and always solidly very good. Extrmely satisfying... One of my favorties for out of town guests. Highly recommend their rotating daily specials and the 'sloppy joe'. Simply said, always a nice experience.
author: pamela h.

description:
as per my rules, only my fave spots apply. and after yet (another) stumbling experience out of the presidio social club, they rate high on my list of establishments that know how to make a real cocktail.

"why then" you might ask, "only four stars?"

reason is the prices. i can't get drunk and have a nibble for under 50 clams there. otherwise, five for certain.
author: Missy D.

description:
really, really disappointing.  high prices.  crap food.  +1 star for dessert.

the three of us were sat in the "party room" off to the left of the entrance in spite of having held a reservation for almost 2 months.  in hindsight, we really should have insisted on being sat in the restaurant.  my experience with side rooms is that the service is usually off.  no exception to the rule here.  service was initially fast to get orders and dishes on the table, and then, pretty non-existent.  the regular restaurant appeared to be pretty nice.  we wouldn't have known except  for our walks to the restrooms.

first surprise was that the online version of their menu bore little resemblance to the menus we were handed.  not a positive sign.

appetizers ordered: tuna poke, pear/lettuce salad, and bacon chowder.  my chowder was really odd: it was not much to look at (actually, it was awful to look... think of pre-disgested soup.)  taste was greasy.  the poke was average, but we couldn't be bothered to finish it.  the bread that came with the appetizers was a very dull, mass produced white loaf.  

entrees ordered:  pork chop, trout, and oxtail stroganoff.   my pork chop was the thinnest cut chop i've ever seen in a restaurant, and not at all tender.  it was covered in an applesauce/gravy that only distracted from the taste of the dish.  the spinach side was cold and under-cooked.  the trout was small, but well de-boned, and accompanied by a HUGE side of mashed potatoes (which weren't bad.)

i reserve additional scorn for the "stroganoff".  we had asked if the sauce incorporated a lot of sour cream and were told that it only had a little.  how about none!  the dish was served as a pile of massively over-cooked oxtail (the taste of which reminded me of the awful slow-cooked crock-pot stews we ate as children!) with another separate pile of absolutely plain stroganoff noodles.  no sauce.  maybe some butter was cooked in.  meat.  noodles.  no nice of a stroganoff to be seen.

the meal was not a complete disaster as the desserts were delightful: cookie plate, beignets, and chocolate muffins.  all three were very delicious.  and recommended.  in fact, we'd go back and just order coffee and desserts next time.
author: Geoffrey W.

description: Great atmosphere. Very comfortable. Solid menu, where you can't go wrong. Gunpowder cocktail is incredible.
author: Sean C.

description:
Friday night. We sashay through the front door and find ourselves in a hopping little scene. Fun, long bar inhabited by casual-dress Marina/Pac Hts types. Perhaps a little casual for a Friday night (I mistakenly donned requisite Canali black slacks, Bruno Magli loafers and cobalt blue DKNY dress shirt which would have put me in more comfortable surroundings at Maverick or Myth, but there it is.) We are escorted promptly to our table. No 'wait at the bar' nonsense, even with our 8pm reservation. Menus promptly arrive, echoing a bit of Buckeye Roadhouse meets Fog City Diner nostalgia. I like the short and to-the-point menus. Simple club-like items revised to modern palates.

Having heard raves about Tim the bartender and his attentive staff behind the granite topped bar, we order a caipirinha (for me), dirty martini (for her). Good solid drinks to be sure (nice hand-crushed fresh fruit mixer in my caipirinha, no Mrs. T nonsense) but felt a little shortchanged on the portion. Granted, perhaps I have gotten used to goblet sized martinis at other establishments that require a spotter to get it to the table without dousing someone with it, but these drinks were positively miniscule. Retro or note, please give me $8 worth of booze please. My caipirinha seemed to have arrived in a shot glass and the lady's martini in a glass so short and tapered I could have mistaken it for the contraption I put my contacts in at night. 
In any event, we order apps -- combo crab/shrimp cocktail for her, cannibal sandwich for me. The seafood was excellent -- very fresh. But, again, portion size was almost laughable. My cannibal sandwich (a Kobe beef tartare-esque preparation) suited me fine. Into the entree portion of the evening, some stumbles. First, the service. Very erratic. Our server seemed tentative throughout the evening -- unsure of how to describe dishes, and unable to make even basic recommendations. I mis-ordered. Having the Kobe beef app, I asked whether the Sloppy Joes would be repetitive; she said no. I ordered it. Poor choice. Sure the dish was fine as it went, but after the Kobe app why not the veal, or skirt steak, or special fish? Help me out here, please! My server offered me no guidance and I made a poor choice. My companion's veal was nicely seasoned, tender and unremarkable. She HATED my sloppy joes, so I tucked away in silent fuming.

Then dessert. We requested dessert menus...and waited...and waited...and, well you get the point. After 30 mins, I no longer wanted dessert. I wanted the manager and I wanted something comped off the bill for the fits-and-starts food delviery. No such luck. Instead, we got the bill, I ran the card and off we went.

In all, decent food and an unremarkable evening, but not worth our returning anytime soon. Service needs to work out its bugs, and the cost of the meal seemed high for what are essentially club-food dishes a la Balboa. We spent less at Oola and ate far better.
author: Jonathan T.

description: Upscale comfort food that was exactly what it set out to be.  Great cocktail (bitter, sweet and potent) was an awesome compliment to three great salads (butter lettuce, frisee and a fresh beat salad)  Roasted Chicken with a citrus balsamic sauce was tasty and kicked up with a slight bite.  The walk up to the restaurant was charming and I kept saying I felt like we were at a Savannah Shi-Shi place in the Presidio of San Francisco.  Great, attentive service and oddly enough, an empty restaurant by 10pm.  (sign of the times?)  A pleasant place that serves a great meal.  I'm guessing brunch must be way yummy here!
author: James P.

description: I made reservations 5 weeks in advance for brunch on Sunday, 12/18. The restaurant called on Saturday to confirm. On Sunday morning I discovered that they booked 2 large parties, one of which was planned for the outdoor patio. The guests refused to sit there and we were moved to the patio. It doesn't appear to be used very much, there are not the standard outdoor heaters, but a long tube that blows hot air. It was freezing outside and very uncomfortable, the staff positioned the huge tube to blow hot air on us, which was equally uncomfortable. I had to ask for complementary Mimosa's; they were not offered. The outdoor patio was bleak, while the indoor area is quite warm and nice. The food was ok. It certainly wasn't worth the 45 minute drive. My friends live close by and enjoy it, I don't know if they will return, but I won't. We should have left....
author: Ellen W.

description: The Presidio Social Club is a great spot for drinks, especially if you are in the neighborhood. However, the food is just so-so.
author: pablo e.

description: The brunch bartender is great. I learned all about Ramos Fizzs and Slow Gin Fizzs. Also, the patio in the back is sunny and secluded. Even if there isn't a waitress out there, you can order at the bar and they will bring you your food.
author: Rose K.

description:
Not So Good!
After reading many reviews, I got the impression people like the atmosphere, but the food, not so much! They are RIGHT. Cool spot, plenty of potential but even at this late date, in Dec. you can book a table any night of the week, you know why? Because it's NOT SO GOOD.First LONG wait for service, food, in betweens. But most of all, not worth the wait. Butter  lettuce salad was all lettuce with maybe one slice of an apple , diced, no flavor. Crab bisque, so bad, no crab or flavor.  Meatloaf, might have been good but it was served black, charcoal burnt, with RAW carrot grated on top, plopped on top of a pile of mashed potatoes. All this was unacceptable, but it was our office Christmas party and I didn't want to complain. It was BAD. Bignetts, get all the raves but they were just donuts, large and puffy, not even  a good dipping sauce. Fellow foodies, STAY AWAY until they wake up! too bad really,for such  a good location.
author: gwen g.

description: I've eaten dinner here twice at the bar and had great experiences. Maritini's made well. Friendly bar tenders. Good, American comfort food prepared with finess. Beff-buffalo burger delicious with perfectly fried fries. Beef stroganoff with mushrooms and noodles in light sauce that had delicious, subtle flavors. Many other interesting entres that are a take on old American classics, like chiken fried chicken. Can't comment on sit-down dining or brunch. But, for dinner at the bar it's great. And, there's ton's of parking.
author: Nick P.

description:
Nice dining room/bar and great location, but the food was blase.
The nectarine salad had hard and tasteless fruit, the macaroni and cheese was dull and the mashed potatoes were watery with no flavor.
After adding butter and black pepper the potatoes were still horrible.
The kitchen must have "whipped" the potatoes with electric beaters and did not add any milk or butter to assist this awful dish.
Go for cocktails at the bar and enjoy the ambience of the room.
author: Suzanne N.

description: Just for the cocktails - yummy classics, plus some with a twist.  Favorite was the one with some violent liquor (haha i meant vioLET, but that works too), so pretty and tasty.  Not the sick sweet kind.  Nice.  Great restaruant-izing of the barracks buildings - keeps the feel, but nice, clean, easygoing fresh air feel.  Maybe will try food sometime, but with the cocktails so good, why bother.
author: Today Y.

description: Love the space.  I want to come back for a sit-down meal.   Glad that Tim has a new home.
author: T-Bone L.

description: My disclaimer here is I've never had a full dinner here so I can't comment on the full menus... But I live near here so I can walk down and grab a drink.  I have to say the best feeling is hanging out on their patio, with one of their meticulously crafted cocktails and some awesome fries.  I've had some good sun soaking moments - just hanging out with the 50s/60s music bopping in the background.
author: Mark J.

description:
frisee and escarole salad...not bad.  entrees, sloppy joe and pork, nothing special.  average at best.  their appetizers are good.  the cheese toasts and oxtail and biscuits were good.  okay, but here's the catch...they have a "secret menu"....shhhhh, don't tell anyone....then you can be the "cool" one when you go out to dinner with your friends...a sure way to show your date that you are indeed worthy of getting a little nooky that night.  okay, here's the secret menu (make sure you order this precisely, and with a knowing wink and nod to your server):

the shitkicker: a kobe beef slider special (with seasoned fries)
the piggly wiggly cheezer: mac n' cheez with bacon bit (mmmmmm....)
the baaaak baaaak: southern style fried chicken with all the fixins
dingleberry deluxe: a fantastic seasonal fruit cobbler

so there you go....if you don't get some action after this date, then i really don't know what to say to you....
author: Miss P.

description: My Foodbeard and I came here for dinner on a Wednesday. We had made a reservation for 6:30pm and were seated promptly upon arrival. Foodbeard and I shared the lamb meatballs, which were quite tasty. I enjoyed my medium rare flat iron steak and mash, and Foodbeard thought his tender prime rib was tasty. I recommend skipping dessert. The banana cream pie was just okay according to Foodbeard, so I didn't even want to waste stomach space on trying some after his verdict. The waitress had me sold on the strawberry shortcake, but it ended up not being as parfait as I had hoped. The strawberries were too tart, the cake forgettable, and the accompanying shortbread cookies disappointingly underbaked.
author: Rose Q.

description: Excellent service.  Our table of four sat for over 3 hours without any pushing out the door like we deserved.  The food was also excellent --  interesting combinations, and fantastic, home style desserts.  Great view.  Easy parking.  Not too noisy.  Mixed crowd -- older/younger, casual/dressy, etc.
author: Sharon W.

description: Beef stew is insanely delicious. Hot tottie was ok. Servers were friendly and sharp. I don't love the decor and I think it's a little schizo in its menu but I really dug the stew. The whole pig is ok - a little dry and the cornbread is hard as a hockey puck!
author: Cindy F.

description: I finally got to try this.  Went for brunch Sunday and it's pleasant, our service was very good and friendly, and the solid enough food.  The scones were ok, not the best.  Served with apple butter. Probably would not get those again.  My husband had the biscuits with gravy and the gravy was delicious!  And I don't usually eat that dish.
author: R N.

description: The Presidio Social Club was my savior, great parking and wow, we could actually get seats at the bar and be fed.  The SF restaurant scene doesn't seem to be impacted by the recent downturn in the economy, on a Tuesday night between the hours of 8-9 PM , we encountered over an hour long wait at both  NOPA and Delfina, and then were turned away from La Terrasse...Thank you Social Club for letting us in and plying us with Sauv Blanc and Stella and sating us with tasty gruyere toasts and tomato sauce, and the beet and spinach salad. I would not get the Sloppy Joe again, too chunky for me... the pork chop though seemed popular.  I def think the apps here and drinks are the way to go!
author: Sarah B.

description: This place is really a 3.5 star, and has potential to be 4 star. SUPER cool setup, really great atmosphere. And the food was good. It was. Gruyere toasts with tomato dipping sauce - yum. Crab cupcakes - yum. Roast chicken - yum. Flank steak - yum. Banana cream pie - yum. They have Trumer Pils on draft, a total plus, and a fun cocktail list. Why not 4 stars then? I can't quite put my finger on it. We had a good time, but it's not a place you'd crave to go back to, food-wise. They just need a bit something more. That's not much help, right? I think when they settle in though I could become a regular. PLUS - they have parking! Check it out. I think you'll like it.
author: Sarah R.

description:
Went for brunch - it's not cheap, and it's not massive amounts of food. it is very good, though. Service was excellent. Choices are minimal, but you'll still find something you like in terms of both food and drink. Some specifics -
Tuna Melt - the tuna salad on the melt was very very tasty
Oxtail Hash - not what I expected. Lean meat with beets and a little bit of other stuff lightly tossed in. Not the big mess of food "hash" usually implies. Very classy and yummy.
Biscuits and Gravy - the gravy is orange. Orange. The biscuit was kind of hard, but in a good way. It wasn't what I expected, but I enjoyed it very much.
Absinthe Champagne drink - eeeew. no. If you LOVE absinthe on its own with no sugar, go for it, otherwise steer clear
Bloody Mary - yummy, not as spicy as I'm used to (good for me, but you might not like it that way)
Mimosa - plain but yummy. The sloe gin fizz looked excellent, and there was another gin drink with egg white foam that sounded amazing. Unfortunately, I can't drink gin. Boo.

I'll go back, but not expecting a big brunch.
author: Monika M.

description: Went on a Friday evening and were seated promptly, no waiting though the restaurant and bar were full.  The server had a little trouble remembering what was in some of the specials (whether a soup was vegetarian or not and what came with the special). No prices were mentioned for the specials, we had to ask.   I ordered the Brunelle cocktail, I love absinthe, but to pair it with overwhelmingly sour lemon juice which totally overpowered the liqueur?  What was I (and the bartender) thinking?  Blech.  The menu was not very vegetarian friendly. We started with the gruyere points (Pullman bread?), a small, dry, grilled cheese sandwich, cut into four triangles, served with an espresso cup of warm tomato soup for dipping.  It was better than the other appetizer: fried green tomatoes, slightly spicy batter, served with an olive relish and a dollop of ricotta? I thought they were nothing special (first time I'd had them, not sure if they were representative or not).  After a good 25 minute wait, we hungry when we received our entrees.  We ordered the trout on a bed of yellow and green beans. The trout was just shy of overcooked, beans were undercooked, not al dente and cut into tiny  1/2 inch pieces; the lemon half served with the entrée was broiled.  Also ordered the Akita salmon special on a bed of succotash ($27), which was good, but the thinner edge of the fillet was just overdone.  We ordered a bottle of Beaujolais which was presented and served correctly.  For afters, we had the chocolate cupcake and white peach sorbet with "blueberry" madeleines.   The server overheard us mention we were there celebrating one of our party's birthday; when the desserts arrived, there was a lit candle on the plate with her order (nice understated touch, no singing, thank goodness).  The cupcake (baked to order), arrived as three yummy mini-cupcakes, each with small crunchy chocolate bits baked on top and dusted with confectioners sugar, accompanied by a shot glass containing 1/3 chocolate pudding on the bottom, topped with 2/3 whipped crème.  Chocolate syrup to drizzle over the mini-cupcakes would have worked much better, the pudding didn't add to the dessert at all.  The white peach sorbet (served with blueberry madeleines) was full of peach flavor and made my mouth very happy, the madeleines did not.  Two came with the order, each the size of a quarter with one blueberry baked in the middle, the effect was superfluously meh.   The restaurant was very loud, when the tables were full, it was hard to hear our conversation; when tables turned nearby, we could hear much better.  The lighting could have been brought up a little brighter.  [No we are NOT senior citizens, not that there is anything wrong with that!] The server was very good and brought one member of our party another (comped) cocktail when it was accidently spilled shortly after we were seated. I know this place has its devotees, but I cannot count myself among them. Bottom-line, would I go back?  No.
author: Rosemary M.

description: Excellent atmosphere and beautiful space.  The whole place, from the physical environment to the service, screams friendly.  Hit it up for a birthday dinner, and your indecisiveness will be welcomes by the helpful staff.  The mahi mahi special wasn't anything to write about, and the fries rank way below absinthe, but the pork chop, man, that pork chop, seriously makes me hope my people will reconsider it's ban.  Milk with meat, fine - but the chop!
author: Lane K.

description: Its 1930ish plain army barracks exterior hides a modern beauty inside. An intriging menu and with very good service but the food (though good) couldn't push it to a 4th star. The bar area looks good for a casual drink and snack. Definitely a place to try.
author: Ed L.

description:
I don't quite get all the buzz that this place is getting (7X7 and San Francisco Focus).  Went there on a weekday night and just didn't find it that compelling:

Positives: 
Attractive, friendly staff, kept good track of the pace of our meal, made the service work, wine choices were good

Negatives:
Good staff service on the night we went couldn't compensate for mediocre food; salads were OK, but entrees, both the 'Greek" lamb and the oven roasted fish were off; the lamb lacked flavor (where was the rosemary, the spicing, the sumac?), the fish was floating in a sea of butter----and the bottom half was inedible because it was so oily.  The alcohol was good, but the prices seemed just silly for a place in the Presidio---and one more thing; it was loud; not as jet-plane-taking-off loud as Mamacita's in the Marina (that's LOUD), but too loud to talk easily even over a table----and sometimes you want to talk---maybe the back room would be quieter, but all the reflective wood and glass surfaces in the main dining room make it acoustical death...And the final tab for 2 with drinks and tip ran $120...
Probably won't go back...Unless it's just for drinks...
Too bad; was hoping for a winner.
author: Roger W.

description: This place was kinda weak! I loved the atmosphere but the food was just OK. For two adults and two kids it was a bit pricey and really bland. Might be a great place to meet friends for drinks before going somewhere else for dinner. Wait staff was really nice.
author: Jesse M.

description: Definitely stars for the motif. Very swank, and I appreciated our server's attentiveness.  That's what gives it the 4 stars over 3. Drinks were well made and to my liking, but I wouldn't call that the selling point. yummy noshies again, but maybe a bit too loud.  the menu is pretty SF standard upscale diner, but this is not a bistro and one should not set their expectation for that.
author: Dave S.

description: It's like stepping into a different era, and I usually dress for the occasion... You feel like any moment boys in navy white might come clamoring in. The menu: unique twists on classic items, and trendy drinks, like a sidecar, add to the experience. Be sure to save room for dessert--I love the strawberry "shortcake" made with fresh baked shortbread!
author: Angela G.

description: Went here for dinner. Great place and great food. A lot of snobby people btw.
author: Prescott T.

description: I was hoping for something special but was just met with a pretty standard meal.
author: Angela K.

description: We had heard good things about Presidio Social Club so I made reservations here for my boyfriend's birthday. We brought his parents who were in town visiting. Though we had 8 PM reservations we weren't seated until well after 9. The manager made up for this by first sending us an appetizer and then, when the wait dragged on even longer, he sent us a bottle of wine. We were impressed with how he handled things but still hungry and ready to sit down and eat. When we were finally seated at at our table, three of the 4 of us ordered the fish special. Our waiter went to go put the orders in then returned to  inform us there were only two pieces of fish left! When the food finally arrived it was good, not amazing. A number of birthdays were being celebrated at the tables around us - desserts with candles were bring brought out. Though I had called ahead to make sure they would send a dessert over for my boyfriend's birthday, I still got up from the table after dinner and mentioned it to the waiter. He followed me back to the table and awkwardly blurted out, " You know, I already have all that information, you don't have to tell me anything." I was so embarrassed that he said this in front of everyone. I wanted the dessert - which we planned to pay for- to be a surprise. Instead- the waiter left the table, returned with the bill and no dessert! My boyfriend was obviously aware at my failed attempt to get him a special dessert and felt bad about how the waiter handled it. Maybe like the fish they ran out of desserts or candles?? I don't plan on returning here anytime soon- it wasn't worth it. Long wait. Bad service.
author: K. S.

description: One of the toughest steaks I've had in the last couple of years...too bad because nice atmosphere and decent drinks.
author: Jon S.

description: Finally the Presidios walls are weakening and valuable land and space is being utilized! I dont want new devlopment, I just want current structures serving a purpose. The Presidio Social Club is what I am talking about, an old military barracks turned into a new and upcoming restaurant with good food. Go with the Flat Iron steak or anyone of their fish entrees and you will give yourself a reason to come back again. Their wine list is good and priced fair. The staff is still working out kinks and if I could recommend one thing to management it would be to get their glassware up to a standard 12 ounces. Working out kinks is all in the time, but good food is the foundation to any restaurant and The Presidio Social Club has got it!
author: Michael G.

description: I thought the food was soild and service was as expected. Nothing mind boggling but a unique atmosphere (old military barrack) and LOTS of parking. I enjoyed the Mac and Cheese and they had a half decent wine selection. What makes this place unique is the atmosphere, but better food can be had in the city for sure. Deffinitly worth visiting once.
author: Joseph C.

description:
So a great friend told me that this is a fun place and she is right.  We had a blast.  I'm still wondering what the sign on wall that says they used to fire from the windows means ... I need a history lesson (I'm not local) about who they were firing at?
When we arrived, there was no room at the bar.  We told the hostess that we had 2 friends joining us within an hour so we needed a table for 4 instead of our reservation for 2.   It took them a few minutes and they figured it out, which was great.
The wine list was nice and I had a decent Argentian Malbec.  I asked for some ice for the water and then decided on getting a chilled bottle of Pelligrino when they forgot.   It was hard to decide what to eat because most of the options were real comfort foods.  And who knew that the special on Sundays is a whole roasted suckling pig?
We were starving and ordered the Gruyere toast and tomato dipping sauce.  When I first looked at them, I couldn't believe that they charged so much for white bread and cheese.  But when I bit into it, it was yummy.
The chopped salad with crunchy vegetables looked good.  The waiter told us that there is blue cauliflower in the salad but when they brought it, there was nothing blue in it.  It was ok but had way too much dressing on it so I didn't finish my portion.
We took a break while we waited for our friends and they kept wanting to grab our menus and take things off our table.    We were asked by several different waiters if we were ready to order.
Luckily, our friends showed up.  Sheila and I shared the flat iron steak (before we knew about the beef recall today!) and it was ok.  The mushrooms on it were good but the steak had absolutely no flavor.  Very disappointing for the price.
I like the atmosphere but not sure that I will be craving the food any time soon.
author: Ayelet B.

description: I live the neighborhood, used to really like PSC but it's gone downhill over the past year. Clambake is a disaster and the crab sliders, which were great, are off the menu.  The bartenders are super slow and bad at customer service.
author: Michael M.

description: I had such a fun time here!  I took my parents here when they were visiting from Boston, and they enjoyed it too.  Our waitress was super-friendly and very helpful.  My dad is a little agressive and asks lots of questions, and she was able to answer all of them.  I was glad we were in the smaller, quieter room so we could chat, but if I wanted more action, it might be fun to be in the more lively main room.  The food is great, the prices are reasonable, and it's always fun to be in the Presidio (and a nice change from Chestnut or Union Street).
author: Spice O.

description: I went to dinner here with my parents and boyfriend.  The food was okay, not great.  I had the flat steak with spinach and wasn't terribly impressed.  They did have a nice wine selection and the dessert that I had was good.  I went here a few days later with a girlfriend for a cocktail and had a nice time at the bar.  The bar tender was friendly and attentive, he even gave us some sort of tequila shot concoction.
author: Elizabeth D.

description: I was expecting so much more.  6 of us at the table 4 of us had the "rib eye for two".  They looked great but when cut up it was chewy, I had a very high stack of fat I had to cut away, and the salt level was over the top.  It came with "5" pieces of zucchini and yellow squash.  5 pieces.....the yellow were little flowerettes the size of my thumbnail and the zucchini was the size of my pinky.  Mashed potatoes, well, an OK amount but no flavor what so ever.  Disappointing.
author: Mark A.

description:
$18 fish and chips.  $17 sloppy joe.  but fries were MONEY.  shoestring butaytas.  can't beat the atmosphere (did someone say "gatsbyesque"?- barf).

service got progressively suckier as the crowd increased.

HOWEVER, 2 desserts for $10.  Banana Cream pie, s'mores and beignets . . .are you kidding me? Delicious again Peter.
author: Jon K.

description: So, don't take my review too seriously as I only have been once and it was when the place had just opened.  The service was very amateur and food was average.  I love the bar though and it is in a great location.  I tried to eat there again with a group of friends but the wait was too long and we ended up going to Pres a Vi and sat at the chef's table without having to wait (see that review).  Anyways, I'll give this place another try since it has been around for a while now and I'll keep my fingers crossed that it is better next time.
author: Carolyn D.

description:
2nd time there was Saturday night with my parents. We had secured a 8p reservation through opentable a couple weeks prior...I took them b/c I wanted to share a completely different SF atmosphere with them, a unique menu and get out of the normal touristy places. The energy was great, loud, electric and Fun! 

The biggest problem was i felt RUSHED the whole time. They removed plates when we were still eating! My fish stew was only 3/4 finished and we were still eating and the server took the plate! my father still had wine is his glass, looked away for a sec and they removed the glass of Malbec!!
WE were still eating the banana cream pie, had a few bites left and the server attempted to take the plate!! It was not until I said, "hey hey! put that back!" that he did set it back down. WOW, rude and completely unprofessional! Our waiter needs sering/customer service training 101 as does the rest of their staff! This was sooo disappointing and has really left a bad taste in my mouth.

again, love the atmosphere but I am paying for the service and food, so C'MON! Get your act together! I was embarrassed!
author: Claude S.

description: The atmosphere was really cool and it was great for a party of six.  Service was excellent, food was just  OK.  I had the Kobe sloppy joe and my wife had the mac n cheese.   Sloppy Joe was mostly bread and not a lot of meat and the Mac was kind of bland.  Dessert was the best part.   Our group shared the entire menu and we weren't disappointed.  Overall a cool location inside and out.  Parking was not a problem.  If you have out of town guests I'd recommend this spot .
author: Mark F.

description: We were not impressed. Mojito tasted good. Smashed peas look like it came from a baby jar but it is tasty. My halibut & spinach dish was dry and overall on the bland side. I heard the steak wasn't good. For the price we're paying, I wouldn't recommend coming here for dinner. The bake to order cupcakes is good but overall portions are too small for the price we're paying. The liver and onion is their signature dish and the liver was tough to eat. Beignet was soft but not enough powder sugar. Atmosphere and service was ok.
author: Yenly M.

description: This used to be a great place; but it has deteriorated a lot in the past year.  They took our orders quickly; but then we sat for an hour.  The butter lettuce salad was a few leaves with a very light dressing.  Braised beef short ribs were terrible quality, skimpy and mostly gristle.  My son's steak and frites was a tiny piece of average sirloin and a plate piled high with lukewarm fries.  My wife's sand dabs were mushy and tasteless.  The bill was $220 for four of us.  None of us would go back.  This was a Saturday night on Memorial Day Weekend, so it's not as if this was an off time.
author: David S.

description:
Obnoxious service!

We'd been a few times and the service was always pretty mediocre but on our last visit a waiter at the nearby table kept deliberately hitting the chairs of my 70 year old parents. The tables were all a little tight and their chairs weren't pulled up to their bellies and I guess he was just pissed that he didn't have room to maneuver his generously wide girth. 

The food was always sort of fun, albeit expensive, but that will be our last visit.
author: bubbles t.

description: I took my mom here for Thanksgiving dinner. They served a traditional Thanksgiving turkey dinner and it was perfect. Spacious, great service and excellent food. It was my first time there, but I'll be back.
author: Matthew M.

description:
We have been going here since it opened and, frankly, and have noticed on our last two visits that it is going downhill.  On the positive side, they have introduced some new items including a pork chop that is very good.  But the negatives outweight the positive:

Their signature dishes like the mac and cheese and mint peas just aren't as good anymore (the mint peas now taste simply like peas -- we barely touched them -- we mentioned to our server and simply got a shrug of her shoulders).  

They seem to have raised a lot of prices.

Finally, and most importantly, the service has gone downhill.  The hostesses are still great and friendly, but the waitstaff is incredibly rude -- it's like they don't want to be there.  We noticed this with our server on each of our last two visits.  

Times are tough and people are clammering for restaurant jobs.  My advice to PSC is upgrade your staff and find some people that want to work there and want to treat your patrons well.  Until you do, there are way too many good restaurants in town for us to come back.
author: Doug T.

description:
The Presidio is not a usual haunt for me - but this is a great reason to go there. Oh there are others too - but this is a good joint.
I miss the Green Goddess Salad. I hope they read this and by some miracle bring it back to the menu. Maybe it is seasonal. I will ask on my next visit.
Oxtail Stroganoff - so delicious. Like a wonderful flavorful stroganoff that my granny who was a great cook made. The meat is so tender and the egg noodles are - um yum yum.
I've also had the Sonoma Range Chicken - another home run. Juicy, and seasoned so nicely. A friend of my swears by their Liver and Onions. Don't ask. It's not my thing. 
For dessert - the banana cream pie. So scrumptious. The lemon meringue tart and the chocolate cupcakes are also very nice. The brioche beignets are in my near future - I will let you know.
Cocktails here - theirs is a very specific menu. Look at it closely. Several times friends of mine have not enjoyed what they ordered - but only because they did not read the description close enough. This is old school cocktails. They make a fantastic Old Fashioned - and I'm a sucker for any place that makes a really good one.
Thumbs up for Presidio Social Club - the are consistently a great place to eat.
Now can someone tell me why every time I sit at the bar I don't exactly get the most friendly vibe??? If they could nail that -I would be here 3 times a week. Maybe someone a little bit.......charismatic behind the bar? I don't want to get ugly - cause I do love this place. Just a suggestion -
author: Tom R.

description: Great Atomosphere. Totally like being back in the 40's. Like i was ever there to begin with. We sat at the bar and had a couple of cocktails. I highly recomend the 4th degree. Tasted wonderful with the Absinthe. The Poke appetizer wasn't what i expected but was really good. Brian the bartender was really nice and knew his drinks. Ya a little pricey but not an every day pub. Will go back for sure.
author: Dave B.

description: I took my family here and it was perfect for the old folks.  I liked the atmosphere and the service.  The food here was ok.  I had the braised beef shortrib and it was terrible.  It was just a square chunk of meat. blehh!   I did like the atichoke dip appitizer.  The wine list is really small.  They do have a nice long bar.  The desserts are really good.  Try the cupcakes and the smoores.  The Mac and cheese and the sloppy joe are good but not great.  I have yet to be impressed by this restaurant.
author: Pete L.

description:
Eating dinner at the bar is a pleasure at PSC.  Bartenders are friendly and knowledgeable, and the food is quite good!
Had brunch for the first time this weekend, and I was pleasantly surprised.  Excellent bloody mary.  Delicious, slightly more adventurous food (i.e. no eggs benedict).  I will be back.
author: Lauren J.

description: Great place that my partner found on opentable.com.   It was a great place that I never knew existed in the presidio.  This was originally the Old Officer's Club so it has cool decor...simple and elegant in it's own way.  I love the menu!!!!! Be ready to be in a food coma when you leave. Oh ya make reservations!!!
author: Jay S.

description: Gorgeous classy bar with great cocktails, and obviously in a fantastic location.  The food is a bit of a letdown in comparison to the atmosphere, and overpriced for what it is.  You should come here once for the experience.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Best Sloppy Joe ever.

I dined at Presidio Social Club twice last month and had 2 vastly different experiences. Both times we were with parties of 6+.

The first time was a Friday night with some out of town guests. Great food and ambiance - service was extremely responsive and professional.  

Second visit was new years eve (so I'm cutting them some slack) and we were seated in the "side room" - which left much to  be desired. Though conversation was easier (not as much ambient noise) - the decor/service was sub-par. Our server appeared to be distracted - though she only had about 3 tables the entire time we were there. If you're making reservations for first-timers, make sure that your table is in the main dining area.

A huge plus: Parking is plentiful. And if you don't mind walking about 10 blocks, the Marina bar/pub neighborhood is about a 15 min. walk away - we left our car in the Presidio - and avoided the hassle of searching for a spot in the Marina.
author: Laura L.

description:
Had drinks across the street at Pres a Vi, then dinner here.  Very different scene - more low-key and casual.  Can't get service at the bar - we waited for 20 minutes.  They need to hire more than 2 bartenders.
Dinner service was good.  I had the steak which was very tasty.
Madeline Albright was there on the same night.  A very mixed crowd of old and young.
author: E H.

description: Beautiful space, slow and indifferent service, flat food, impossible to get a drink.  Wish I could say that I would go back because it is truly a beautiful place to relax but everything was OFF.  Hopefully they are still working out the new restaurant jitters.
author: Lulu L.

description: I loved my cocktail and enjoyed the decor.  The food was pretty good (avoid the chopped salad) and I really liked the grilled cheese and tuna tartare thing with mango.  Entrees were not as good as the appetizers, but I knew that going in and ordered accordingly.  My companion had the veal and it was tasty.  The noise level was excruciating; I still have some residual hearing loss.  Overall, it was a good time in a fun location.  I loved that they included a postcard with the bill.  Souvenirs are always a plus.
author: Eleanor E.

description: Really great. It has a cool laid back vibe. The sloppy Joe is the absolute best I've ever had...& I don't like Sloppy Joes.
author: Kelly M.

description:
absolutely fantastic... they really got all the details right here. the decor is gorgeous and unusual. they obviously used the building and the surrounding of the presidio to inform their design decisions and the whole space comes together in an understated and elegant way. i felt like i was in a 1940's movie set in pearl harbor or something along those lines.

the food was also excellent. i don't really understand the reviews that have stated otherwise... either they caught the cooks on an off night or they have a skewed sense of what really nice cuisine should be. we started with two cocktails that were top-notch (freshly squeezed juices, good proportions, beautiful glassware) and we shared the tuna poke. it was simple and very fresh with clean flavors of cucumber and mango to compliment the fish, but then had these super spicy homemade potato chips as a counterpoint. really nice with our drinks.

next we had the bacon and egg salad (a very traditional french salad) that was made perfectly. you won't have better in a great restaurant in paris. it's pretty straight forward... frisee lettuce w/ lardons (small chunks of crispy bacon), croutons, vinaigrette and topped with either a fried or poached egg. the dressing on this was nice and tangy and stood up to the bacon and egg yolk - yum! it was not greasy like someone else said... i think they were confused by the texture of the egg yolk on the lettuce which is how this salad always is.

bf had the whole fish - dorade- with delicious herb butter and perfect thin, crispy, french fries... like as good as mcdonald's fries. (and just admit it... even if you don't eat there for any other reason, no one makes fries like mcd's!). i had cod served over corn and clam chowder w/ a side of spinach. my fish was also really good. so good that i saved 1/2 for lunch today, but then my bf left the to-go bag in the car last night and now i'm pretty annoyed i didn't just eat it all then.

dessert was as good as the rest. the cup cakes were really good - and i didn't think they were going to be, especially because they don't have frosting, just whipped cream on the side. but damn those things went down easy! and the meyer lemon tart was sublime.

it was definitely the nicest meal i've had out in the city in a long time.
author: eva g.

description:
Been there twice, it's expensive but the liver is excellent. unfortunately it comes with fries!! and poorly done onions. Also the cheese plate is an utter rip-off - $12.50 for a pathetic little plate with stale crackers. we asked for fresh crackers, they gave us more stale ones, we complained and they looked at me as though I had two heads!

I won't be back.

Also the wine is exorbitant!
author: norman w.

description:
Fun little "scene" but there are so many better options for the money.  The menu is very basic and the food is executed well, but not great.  I had the steak and it was fine but not memorable.  I like choices when I go out to eat, so when the menu has so few - none of them particularly unique - it's a little disappointing.

It's one of those places that specializes in "comfort food" - like Mac 'n Cheese and Sloppy Joes - but at prices that aren't very comforting ($15 for Mac 'n Cheese?!)  So if you have any inclination/ability to cook yourself, this is probably not the place you want to go to eat out.

On the plus side - nice setting and super-easy parking inside the Presidio.
author: Nate B.

description: Love the 40s motif, but what made it sink in was the absinthe cocktails!  Tangy and so full of flavor, like no other cocktail.  The crispy peppered trout was perfect and came with a generous portion of thin, deep green asparagus.  Halibut was a touch dry but yummily flavored.  The miniature homemade chocolate cupcakes were still warm, and tasty, like they just came out of the Easy-Bake Oven.  They should have left off the crunchy sugar topping though - the cakes were too small to handle that kind of distraction.  They came with a scrumptuous shot of white mousse.   Friendly and professional service - everyone acted like they owned the place - I love that kind of accountability and enthusiasm.
author: Laura C.

description: I came here for Sunday brunch.  I started off with the guyere cheese toast and the beignets.  The guyere cheese toast was pretty much a $7 grilled cheese sandwich accompanied with a small expresso cup of tomato soup for dipping.  The soup made the sandwich.  The beignets were also really good.  Probs one of the best I've eaten.  I eat a lot.  For my entree I had the chilaquilles cuz it said it was from the mission district and everyone else in the club was eating them.  Its basically soggy tortilla chips with queso.  Except these chilaquilles were super sour.  The person that made these had a heavy hand on the vinegar.  It was crazy.  They make good scambled eggs and hash browns.  I wanted the burger but it was $16!  It wasn't even kobe.  Pass.  Some other fatty had the braised oxtail hash.  It looked good on the menu but it didn't look appetizing due to the addition of beats.  I thought the oxtail was still wagging its tail.  Poor ox.  This place is pretty good but pretty expensive.  Just order the beignats and $7 cheese toast.   Those two itemss plus tip and tax will set you back $20.  Have fun fatties.
author: Fatty A.

description: Love this place.  Very charming, old Officers club.  Fish and Chips are always my fav!  I haven't been disappointed by anything on the menu.  I think it is a great place for kids.  My littles ones 2 & 4 love the tomato soup with mini grilled cheese for dipping.  The mini desserts are D-Lish!  Take a close look at the liquor cabinets/shelves...they are from the old Presidio hospital!
author: S R.

description: So reservations mean absolutely nothing here. 45 minutes late and they continue to tell us people have reservations before us. No acknowledgment that they're running behind either, just walks by no eye contact, no update. Saving grace are the bartenders who are super nice. Hostess, another story.
author: Tammy C.

description:
Mentioned, but not lauded,  by a highly regarded critic, what could I do, what with accidents all over the place blocking my way home but to stop in and see for myself?

Charming venue, reminded me of my time in military barracks, but in a good way.  Mixed crowd, young, old, but all well-to-do because it ain't cheap.  Friendly, competent staff, a little overworked but up to it.

Great drinks, a little slow in coming, but I had seated myself at the communal table, wide enough that I didn't have to talk to other diners, but intimate enough that I could without yelling.

Gryeuere toasties with a thick tomato soup to dip them in.  If they had no calories I would have eaten two or three loaves worth. Could have been my main course.

'Columbus and Broadway' for the main course.  Sweet, rich duck chunks served over thick, delicious noodles.

Why, if it hadn't been seasoned with more cilantro than is grown in Napa valley all over it, in it, under it and marinated in the broth, I might actually have enjoyed it.

Should have had parmesan cheese, not cilantro, not so much cilantro, not any fucking cilantro.

Would have received five stars otherwise.

Check it out.  Ask them to go light on the cilantro.  Or not at all.
author: Tony F.

description: I had been looking forward to trying this place for quite sometime, however I was disappointed.  Ambiance was above average, but the food was just about average as was that service.  Day-boat scallops I recommend as well as the spinach.  Overall, its really a glorified, overpriced diner.  Not a terrible place by an means.  OK, I'll give it  2 1/2 stars.  Might be a cool place to get a drink and go over to pres a vi for dinner.
author: scott g.

description: Very very enjoyable.  Tasty martinis.  Nice wine selection. Friendly people.  Good food. Beautiful location.  Everybody had a good time, even when the lights went out and we had to eat by candlelight.  Not their fault and nobody seemed to care.
author: Kanani P.

description: The Presidio Social club has a nice ambiance for a large dinning hall.   I like the bar atmosphere for a happy hour after work despite the cold energy of the old military building.  Somehow they've softened it up just enough.  The food here was phenomenal, especially the banana dessert.  The house wine was awful, and the prices were way too high for what it was that we had for dinner that Sunday night.   I'd rather go to Liverpool Lil's if I want to have a nice meal/cocktail with the over 65 crowd.
author: Meg C.

description:
I was excited for their new brunch service, but have to say that I just don't think they were ready this weekend.  Service was excruciatingly slow.  We had to ask two separate people if they could take our order, but both said no and that they would let our server know.  20 minutes later.... we were finally greeted.  The food and drinks were slow as well so I'd say that they just need more serving staff and kitchen staff.  I can forgive slow service if it is at least friendly and personable, but alas, it was not. 

Hash and eggs were good, but a little bland.  Couldn't detect any horseradish, and some of the beets were crunchy and undercooked while others were really soft.  Biscuits and gravy have an awesome spicy gravy which was a little too spicy for one of us, but the rest of us were quite happy with it.  Great selection on the fruit bowl:  mango, figs, peaches, strawberries, blueberries, bananas, & cantaloupe.  

Value is average to perhaps a bit overpriced for what you get.  The bloody mary was average, nothing special, I'd probably recommend trying another of their brunch concoctions instead.  I'd give them some time to work out the kinks before returning (ie, like how we were given more drink menus than food menus, and how stifling hot it was inside).
author: Haxter G.

description: i didn't know what to expect. i thought it was gonna be all old people dining here, but that wasn't the case. they have a really big bar.  this place is very spacious and the food and service is great. the tuna tartar is okie, the beef tartar is delicious and so is there mac and cheese. we had sloppy joes, which was very flavorful and tender. the fish and chips were good too. i would def come back here!
author: Karen H.

description: Great location in the presidio within walking distance of the office, pleasant decorum, unfortunately limited and not very enticing menu. Still I went for a simple burger and had actually a great experience with the best burger bread ever allowing me to eat without making the usual mess. Service was under average and prices over average overall making it just an average experience.
author: Cedrick C.

description: Wow, 1 star for the owner of the restaurant telling me "i don't want your service".  I'm getting married in the Presidio and wanted to have our guests dine there for brunch the morning after.  I won't go into details about the outrageous private room charge but will go into detail about how the OWNER of the restaurant told me flat out, 'frankly we don't want your business because we only have 2 guys sweatin it out in the back'.   Not only will I never go there for dinner or happy hour again...but the word will be spread about how inhospitable they are and that our dollars are better spent elsewhere.
author: Marina A.

description: Being a true San Francisco native I have spent many weekends enjoying great food in all the wonderful restaurants this city has to offer. My family has a long history with the Presidio and so when my parents told me to meet them there for Sunday breakfast I thought sure why not. Let me set the scene for you. Beautiful San Francisco Sunday morning, sun shining, nice soft breeze, you couldn't ask for a better day. So I go meet my parents at the PSC and we sit outside on their rear deck area underneath an umbrella (After all I'm delicate I don't want to burn) :) The waitress comes right out and offers me a drink so I have a nice refreshing mimosa and a slice of their oh so delicious cheese toast. Its like a grown up grilled cheese with a luscious little cup of tomato bisque. If that wasn't enough their breakfast was out of this world. Now I'm not sitting here saying its some fabulous french cuisine..Thats not what this place is about. Its about soul quenching, heart warming, home-style goodies that make you feel like you're eating at a friends house. The service here is nothing less then amazing. The crowd is mixed which is refreshing. At any given day (or night) there you'll see families with Lil ones playing with etch a sketches (which by the way they keep on hand) and young couples sitting at the bar enjoying one of their amazing drinks. (I recommend the French 75)! I've eaten breakfast and dinner here and I'm proud to call this place a true San Francisco Gem. Come check it out!!!
author: Jessica L.

description:
The Presidio Social Club is a new addition to the restaurant/bar scene in San Francisco. There are many things it has to work out before I can call this place a wonderful addition.
