First the pluses: The location and the room are really nice. They have taken an old army barrack on the old Presidio base and turned it into a great dining area. Some of the food is very well done. The appetizers, soups, salads and sides were wonderful; the desserts were even better. Items to recommend are, gruyere cheese toasts, the soups, whipped potatoes, chocolate pudding and the banana cream pie. 

Now the minuses: The main course items left a lot to be desired. Our table had three items and not one was a total winner. The Grilled Calf's Liver was not tender and the seasonings used were all wrong, The Kobe beef rib sloppy Joe was way too sweet for a meat dish.  The "Broadway and Columbus" is a clever concept: Chinatown Peking duck over North Beach noodles. The duck was very good but the noodles were drowning in a buttery "soup". The wait staff, while well meaning, is very inexperienced.  

These things in a new restaurant must be corrected or, within eighteen months, we probably will see a new restaurant in this wonderful space. For now, I would say go for the small plates and desserts and skip the main courses. 

My hope is that The Presidio Social Club will make the necessary changes and be a successful restaurant on the SF dining scene.
author: Michael R.

description: I WOULD EAT HERE EVERYDAY IF I COULD!  Simple yet perfect!  Get the salad with the egg and bacon and you just might have an orgasm in your seat!  LOVE THIS PLACE!  I have been here at least a dozen times.
author: Jason P.

description: The big draw when they first opened was the $5 margaritas - which they no longer have.  Well, they have the margaritas but now they're $9.  You could get better margaritas elsewhere.  Food is alright but not a large selection.  Bar is not really made for socializing, it's too close to the dining area so unless you're right up against the bar you always feel like you're in the way of the wait staff although it's not a cramp place by any means.
author: Deb S.

description:
My party made a reservation for New Years Eve on October 31st.  We were told that there was no special fixed price planned and that we would be able to order off the normal menu.  We made our reservation for 8PM, which we thought would give us plenty of time to eat and still meet up with other friends for a NYE celebration. 

Our party organizer called on several occasions during late November and early December to increase our reservation size, first from 6 to 8 and then from 8 to 10 and confirm we would still be able to order from the standard menu.  On both occasions, no mention was made of a fixed price menu.  

Fast forward to Dec 29th, the party organizer gets a call from PSC to confirm our reservation for 10 people at 8:45PM for a 5 course fixed price dinner at $120 a head with no wine included.   Two days before NYE and we are informed for the first time that our reservation has been moved 45 minutes later and a extremely pricey $120 a head five course dinner has been instituted.  None of use were looking for a large 5 course meal on NYE, that was one of the reasons we went with PSC because we could order off the menu.  Plus, when did PSC start thinking they could charge Gary Danko prices?

As you can imagine, both these changes would have caused us to miss our larger NYE celebration beginning at 11:30 so we cancelled.  I was really sad and upset that my dinner plans for NYE had to be cancelled two days before NYE.   I called PSC to let them know about my disappointment and sadness, and to let them know that I think that their communication to potential patrons needs to improve.   The manager, Shawn, I spoke with took my call as an opportunity to be defensive and blame everyone except herself and the restaurant for this debacle.  So much for the customer is always right...   In fact, Shawn referred to my party organizer as rude, curt and abrasive and informed me it was her fault that we had to cancel dinner because she didn't get the three messages she left her.   These message were actually never received by the organizer.  

Needless to say, I consider the practice of the PSC and the manager Shawn to be out of line and completely unprofessional.  As a result, I will never recommend this restaurant to anyone ever again.   It's a shame too because the few times I've eaten at the PSC the food was actually pretty good.
author: Stephen D.

description: Cool place.  I love the building and the way it feels old.  The drinks are great and not too much $$.  You'll want to sit in the room to the left, as you walk in.  The main dining area is very loud and the bar spills into the tables.  The food is good 3 stars and the drinks are 4 stars, so it's more like a 3.5 star place.  you should check it out, but don't expect an intimate experience.
author: Andy J.

description: We have had dinner at the Presidio Social Club several times and always liked it. Last week I called from Santa Rosa to make reservations for 6 people on Friday at 6:00pm. I was told that 5:30pm was all they had until 9:00pm, and that we would all have to be there before we could be seated, also we could only have the table until 8:00pm. We did take the 5:30 reservation, and 8:00pm was time enough for us to have a good dinner, but during the evening we noticed quite a few empty tables.  Would someone please tell me if other SF restaurants  have the same rules. I have never had any restaurant say that we could only have the table for a certain amount of time, then we would have to leave. Is this a SF thing or is this just the Presidio Club????????
author: Darla B.

description:
Don't you dare skip the cocktails.  One of the best Manhattans I've ever had the pleasure of sipping.  The space feels like something out of Casablanca which made being perched at the bar alone waiting for my dinner companions while sipping a delicious cocktail all that more classy.

Both times the service has been spot on - very helpful and knowledgable.  The timing is just right.  The menu seems a little limited but well rounded.  Everything I've tried has been great and very reasonably priced.

Very enjoyable!  I'll be back many times.
author: Kimberly B.

description: a trumped up mel's diner. i think that sums it up. a bit too loud, bright  and bustling for my liking.
author: Angela N.

description: I've been to lunch here twice now with a large party and we will not be going again.  The atmosphere is nice but the food is overpriced, odd, and the portions are very small.  The menu on-line is not the same as what you get in the restaurant, they select a few from each section so the choices are very limited.  Our server couldn't stop talking about how he only got 1 hour of sleep and it definitely showed when he messed up two salads, forgetting the chicken and to put the dressing on the side.  He also forgot our orders of grilled cheese toasts -- the item we were all looking forward to the most (they are very delicious). In the end we canceled the salads & cheese toast orders because it was taking way too long.  The fish and chips are minuscule -- for $13 the two small pieces of fried fish and twelve french fries (not kidding) are not worth it...  It did not make a dent in my boyfriend's large appetite.  We were up to give this place a second chance, since two people in the party live near by, but not a third!  Don't go here hungry.  It was also disappointing they did not have the outdoor patio open since it was a beautiful day.
author: Olivia M.

description: Cool plantation space and really great cocktails. I like the americana menu and the server was hot!
author: thad b.

description: Went and tried this place out on Saturday night and was very pleased. I had the New York steak which was cooked Really well!  Their was a bit of home made kimchee with the sauces that was tasty. The strawberry shortcake was delecious too. The service was fine and there was a lot of smiling faces.  I will recommend to my friends.
author: Thomas F.

description: If I were rating the desserts, this place would get a solid 4 stars for serving up first-rate comfort food yummies. My husband and I went with his parents tonight and, overall, I have to say-- we loved it.  The ambiance was bright and lively, and the menu had something for everyone.  Not as much for vegetarians (I always think, what would my vegetarian Santa Cruz friends eat here?).  But the fresh seasonal veggies and the smashed peas w/mint were both pleasant to the palate.  I shared the Sloppy Joe with my husband which was pretty good... the appetizers (we got the oxtail sliders and the cheese toasts) were more memorable.  After reading prior YELP reviews, I was dismayed that they no longer served fried oysters and that the chocolate cupcakes were taken off the dessert menu.  Bummer.  But the beignets and s'mores left us fat 'n happy, so I won't complain!  Check this place out... it's well worth a visit.
author: Vickie N.

description: had the fried chicken last night - was very disappointed. Clearly the chicken has been fried some time ago and was merely sitting under heat lamps until served. Very rubbery and overly salty. No where near the quality of Farmer Brown or even Townhall for that matter. The side smashed potatoes were okay.....they could have been served warmer. The brioche beignets were the hit of the evening while the choc. cupcakes weren't bad either. Wine selection is limited, but sitting at the bar was sort of fun....overall 3 stars
author: Anon Y.

description: I returned to have dinner here with a friend after having cocktails after work with friends last week. As every one is saying the decor is charming. Kudos to the designer. Leather banquettes, rustic tables, I don't know what kind of lighting this is. To describe it as bare hanging bulbs sounds bad, but it is not, its warm and lends to the atmosphere. Dishtowel napkins, long marble bar. It was raining and looking inside from outside was warm and busy and cozy. It felt like WW2 British occupied tropics, Colombo perhaps? The bathroom decor I thought suited the place, the sinks were interesting stainless steel trough like, but for a military building appropriate.  I started with the chopped salad with cucumbers and radishes and green goddess dressing. It was nice and crisp and cold and very lightly dressed. I have had many versions of this dressing. This was light and seemed like a mix of ranch and blue cheese and thankfully did not have green food coloring in it. (someone try the wagon wheel in L.A.) My dear friend Erin had the endive salad with egg on top sunny side up. She enjoyed it, I did not taste it being too involved in my own dish. Erin and I shared the beet side dish which was perfect. Red and gold beets, goat cheese, walnuts, very good and lightly dressed. I had the pork chop with spinach. The chop was salty but cooked well with mango chutney chunks on top. I will forgive the salt this time. Erin ordered the Chicken with mashed potatoes. The chicken was a large portion and very well herbed and juicy. The potatoes were perfect, creamy, not too seasoned. For desertI had tangerine sorbet and Erin had the cheesecake. We both had the 10 year tawny port. If anyone knows me or Erin, this in one of out most favorite treat's in the world. My sorbet was divine and a perfect palate cleanser. I was so pleased to discover fresh tangerine sections under the sorbet. Without skin. (such a perfect touch) I tasted more than one bite of the cheesecake which was extremely light and fluffy and delicious. The host was very nice and checked on us and made sure our wine was attended to. Our waited was good, he didn't offer an opinion of the menu and said he didn't eat pork, but he served well. We left happy satiated and will return. I would like to try  ore when the menu expands. We were there before the room filled up, I can see that once this happens the service might suffer.
author: Amanda L.

description: I tend to be too generous with stars and was wavering between three and four, so this time I am rounding down.  That said, I had a very nice dinner at the Presidio Social Club last night.  The building and decor are great and despite some loud acoustics, it is very well designed.  I really liked that they have a common table and was almost disappointed when we didn't sit there.  Service was friendly, although it was clear that our waiter was not very experienced or comfortable in his role.  But, he worked hard, was polite, and did a pretty good job.  We learned after the meal that the place has only been open six weeks, so given that I think that they are doing a great job and are working out the kinks.  Food was actually great.  We had their special seared scallops, which were good although portion size was small and there was a bit of grit in them, and the flatiron steak, which was great.  Possibly a bit pricey at $19, but I wasn't complaining.  The entree comes with a side and one suggestion for improvement would be to allow the mac&cheese or a green salad as a side (fries, mashed potatoes, etc. are the only options now).  For dessert we had banana creme pie and a Meyer lemon tart, both of which were very tasty.  Nice atmosphere, good food, improving service, and prices still reasonable although pushing pricey.  All told, I probably prefer Pres a Vi, but I think there is room for two good restaurants in the Presidio.
author: Brad K.

description:
Last night a friend and I went to this lovely new eatery in the Presideo. It's neighbor, Pres a Vi has a different scene entirely. PSC's decor was minimal, not to say that it was empty. High ceilings, white walls, comfortable. The service was very friendly. Our serve was very sweet
and enthusiastic that it was our first time eating at PSC. The menu looked diner-like, but was not anything like Mel's. We ordered a few small plates. Crab cupcakes, spinach cream soup, sardines,
Hawaiian style poke, and a butter lettuce salad. I must say it was a very nice meal. The chips for the tuna poke were homemade, and I loved the black wakame seaweed that was mixed in with mangoes. The soup was just right for a cold night. The crab cupcakes were just right, two bites and delicious. Desserts! My friend ordered the cookie plate. We didn't expect much being in the food industry and all, but we gave it a try. Yummie! The macaroons were crispy on the outside and moist and chewy on the instead. The Ginger snap was
a rolled cookie- impressive, the caramel with sweet and buttery, the chocolate cookie was moist and a nice ending to our meal. I ordered the brioch beignets . I am a total sucker for anything with the word beignets on them- savory or sweet Sarah's gotta have it when she's out.  I was pleasantly surprised. Eclair shaped donuts that were delicately placed on a cloth napkin without a speck of oil on it. Dusted genetly with baker's sugar (something less course than granulated). There was a little ramekin next to these delicious morsels of yummieness. Syrup! We got to dip the beignets in sweet comforting syrup! What a hit! I ate three!! My friend had one. We stayed after our dessert plates were taken away and the staff did not mind that we stayed it chat for at least another 30 minutes. PSC has a SF feel, very comfortable, a hidden spot in the Presidio that I will be going back to soon.

P.S. There's PARKING! Big plus in the city.
author: Lisa J.

description: I've been here a few times.  I went for the first time after they had been open a couple of weeks and the service sucked.  Very slow waiter, even though it appeared that he only had a few tables.  I would see him standing against the wall looking over his notes and talking to himself.  We ordered a couple glasses of wine that never came.  So the manager came by and comped the wine.  That was nice.  I did love my food though.  I had an asparagus salad to start, steak, and beignets for dessert.  Boyfriend had the gruyere cheese toasts w/ tomato fondue, kobe beef sloppy joes, and banana pie.  Yes, we were hungry.  On another visit, it seemed like some kinks were worked out.  Service was much better.  But this time around, I tried the noodles with duck.  That didn't really impress me.  Lots of noodles with a few pieces of duck.  I'm hosting a bridal shower here in a couple weeks, so we'll see how that goes!
author: Chibi Q.

description: after my most recent visit to PSC, i am increasing my review to 5 STARS!!  i just really loved my experience - everything was great.  this is a very good place to take parents - mine loved it.  i tried 2 of the specials - the melon/prosciutto salad, and the tuna.  both were fantastic.  i also finally tried the beignets... oh my!  PSC is definitely high on the list of my favorites!
author: Carolyn B.

description: i'd like to give it a 2.5 actually......the food was pretty good...average....although the thing that annoyed me was their portion sizes are inconsistent from table to table.  the table next to us got 4 "crab cupcakes" (which were actually just mini crabcakes in paper cupcake holders)...and we only got three.  plus, someone else's soup came in a bigger bowl than mine...i know im being butthurt, but i got a little shafted.  everything was pretty tasty...nothing stood out too much.
author: Genevieve M.

description:
b/w 3.5 - 4 stars. 

Food was good, service was friendly but can be improved. 
Nice decor, easy parking, a bit on the pricey side. 

So when we first got our menus, my friend saw the cupcakes on the dessert menu and knew she wanted to order that. Cupcakes take 10 minutes or so to bake, so she mentioned to our waiter at the beginning of dinner. He noted that but forgot when dessert time came around. That's cool, didn't really expect him to remember but would have been happy if he did. So as we were finishing up our entrees, we reminded him...He noted it, but then forgot. Then brought us the dessert menus, which we immediately reminded him that we wanted cupcakes...he noted it, but then seemed to forget or was confused - again. When he came back to take our dessert orders, we again ordered the cupcakes for the 4th time! Finally, it came but we did have to wait the 8-10 mins...so much for ordering in advance. Seemed to have enough service staff but didn't see our waiter come by that often. 
I had a pricey sloppy joe but it was very tasty. I enjoyed my dinner there and glad we tried it out but not a place I see myself going to very often, maybe once a year max if at all. It was fun checking it out though!
author: Mellie D.

description: I went to this place very early on with very big group of female friends (table for 13) and we had a great time.  Even in the early opening days the service was really good and the drinks fab. We just repeated and I found it just as good and the ambience has actually improved by bigger crowds and sort of well-loved-local-place feel it now has.  The post-industrial look of the place would make you think it was loud and cold but the acoustics were really good. Oh yea, and the food. All I have to say is Kobe beef sloppy joe.  Everyone who reviews the place says it and yes, it is that good - if you like that sort of thing, of course. But what is not to like about delicious messy amazing meat and sauce sammy?  The other more more traditional options are really good too. Highly reccommended for big group dining, or a date night.  Nice ambiance and free parking.  I think it is more bang for the buck than Pres A Vi across the street (although I like that place too but for very different reasons).
author: Kirsten M.

description: I keep waiting for this restaurant to be out of business.  Horrible horrible horrible.  I had a very unpleasant experience with a female manager.   "Social" club?  Says who!
author: Chay P.

description: Great location. Good drinks. Ok menu.  Gets crowded and easy to be left standing up with your cocktail after a long day -- they need to add more bar area seating -- there is room off to the side, just no chairs...
author: F. V.

description: So I have now been to PSC twice, the first time back in January and just recently at the end of April.  The space is great, not hard to find (as long as you enter through the Lombard gate, I've lived in SF for almost 5 years and have gotten turned around in the Presidio more times than I care to admit to), parking (yay!), upscale diner ambience.  Beautiful marble bar (FYI, in case anyone was wondering, those metal cabinets behind the bar were reclaimed when the Letterman Hospital was demolished).  In January they hadn't been open for very long and the service reflected that.  Gruyere cheese points with tomato fondue, trout with almond butter, flat iron steak - these were all good but I save really freakin' good for the cocktails and the chocolate cupcakes - oh my goodness, the chocolate cupcakes!  Do not be fooled by the crab "cupcake" appetizer (call them what they are people - Superball sized rounds of crab!).  That's no cupcake size!  The service was slightly better this time.  I know they're famous for the mac & cheese which my dining companion had on the most recent trip - I failed to see what the hoo ha was about.  I could make better and I'd be happy to throw down if anyone wanted to challenge me.   A personal nit - the hostess who seated us.  Honey, your breasts are quite lovely and I honestly couldn't tell if they were implants or your new pushup bra but they do not add to my dining pleasure.  Seriously the girls were OUT there - it was distracting and it kind of felt forced and not at all sexy.  I realize the appeal of the hot hostess but there's a line and those boobs crossed it.
author: Nicole B.

description: my neighbor next to me says this place is "a bunch of yachters and families". this may be true, and our waitress just informed us that she thinks big brother is after her, so we are going to leave now.
author: David F.

description: Good, casual ambience and great drinks. Consistently good comfort food. The artichoke and feta dip is incredible! But a tad overpriced.
author: Lemon S.

description: very good, hearty, meat and potatoes kind of food.  He had steak and I had liver and onions.  Yummy yum yum!  The interior reminds me of the restaurant in the main house of one of those north eastern social camps.  Think Dirty Dancin a la Presidio Heights  LOL  Service was spot on
author: Stephen P.

description: Although, I have eaten here on several dinner occasions, I am going to comment on my breakfast here. With the exception of my friends and I, the restaurant was basically deserted. The only other party there was an out of town crew, that turned out to be the guests from hell. Granted the waitress did accidentally spill Mimosas on on of the guests. It appeared to have not only RUINED her hair, outfit, Prada bag, and day, but also destroyed her father-in-law's birthday breakfast. It was quite the scene. The poor waitress was mortified and ran away crying. The breakfast was good. I had, the omelette that they were serving. Decently cooked, good sides (honestly, I can't remember what the sides were.) My friend got the bourbon french toast, excellent and bigger than her head. The menu per se was limited (kind of a bummer,) and it seemed like it is not a well-known breakfast destination. Kudos to the staff who had to deal with the unhappy, ridiculously demanding guests. The environment is great. Wonderful decor (old school) and also great staff, positive and welcoming. I think if you combine breakfast with a walk on Chrissy Field later it can be quite a dreamy Saturday morning.
author: Virginia A.

description:
This place gets 2 stars only because its easy to get to and the parking is simple.  So if that is important to you then go.  If you want good food at decent prices dont waste your time.

The food is WAY WAY WAY over priced and very boring.  On top of that the staff was very unaccomodating to our needs.  Specifically the person I was with asked for a simple substitution of a vegatable that came with the dish they wanted.  They didnt like the vegatable that it was served with and wanted another one of the vegatables that they offered on the menu to replace the one they didnt like.  The vegetable they asked for was LESS expensive than the one that the dish came with so the restaurant could not even say that the substitution changed the price of the dish.  The waitress told us the Chef would not do that and if they didnt want the vegatable they would be happy to serve the dish to them without a vegetable.   Talk about horrible customer service.  Are you kidding?  I do give the waitress credit as she told us not to order the dish that way and recommended another dish.  She was apologetic and we understood it was not her fault and the Chef was the one to blame.

The food itself was average at best.  This was the second time I have been there and it was equally as average and overpriced the last time.  Not much has changed in a year or so.  Because of the parking situation and the nice retro feel the place has its not a bad place to meet friends for a get together so long as the company is more important to you than the food.  

The bottom line on this place is that there are so many other options in this city where there is better food, better service and at much more reasonable prices.
author: Jeff S.

description:
such a charming and quaint find right inside the lombard gate at the presidio!  it's like stepping into a time machine and flashing back to the 50s, you can just feel the history and memories captured in this old army barracks, and yet there are modern touches throughout to (pleasantly) remind you of the present day.  the menu is similar - a throwback to homey, comfort food faves, but with updated twists here and there to keep everything fresh and interesting.  LOVE the modern take on the grilled cheese and tomato soup (i'm such a sucker for buttery wonderbread sandwiches with gooey kraft sliced cheese and campbell's mmm mmm good soup, and these are such an UPGRADE).  the butter lettuce salad was perfectly dressed w/ a champagne dijon vinaigrette, and the sweet-tart nectarines added just the perfect contrasting bit of freshness.  i debated between the flat iorn steak w/ french fries and the broiled trout w/ almond butter and spinach, and opted for the "healthier" fish choice - little did i know that it would be so rich w/ butter, both the trout and the spinach!  but it was oh so tasty - i love fish that is simply prepared, and the spinach was to die for - i don't know that their secret is, but they managed to make simple sauteed spinach taste as rich as creamed spinach w/o the cream!  (and i'm not a big creamed spinach fan...)

dinner ended on a perfect sweet but not food coma inducing note - a tart lemon pound cake w/ fresh strawberries.  

minus 1 star for the slow service - we had a large group seated at 8:00 and we waited quite a while before a server even came by to the table to take our drink orders...then serve our drinks...then take our food orders...things picked up a bit after the appetizers and as other diners finished up.

pluses: 
-the soft lighting - so flattering for everyone!
-nearby parking lots (although they do get crowded, as people have found out how wonderful the psc is!)
author: Jen P.

description: The faux forties decor and soundtrack try too hard to distract from a menu that leans too heavily on overly salted and cloying American comfort food.  It's the kiddie menu writ large.  Makes me nostalgic for The Nut Tree.
author: gail t.

description: Last night was our third visit to PSC.  We had the same issue with slow service at the bar.  Indeed, they need two more bartenders when it's busy.  Further, we had out-of-town guests who laughed at the smallish-size of the cocktails.
author: Rick R.

description: Very Gatsby inspired!   The palm trees and ceiling fans definitely add to the vibe.  Along with the long marble bar that always has attractive ladies and gents sipping wine.  My girlfriends and I went here for a birthday dinner and had the best time!  Food great, service fun and fast and ambiance excellent. I was very happy with my steak, smashed peas with mint and the cupcakes. Enjoy!
author: S M.

description: I have tried the PSC 3 times several months apart.  Despite my claim I wouldn't be back, I was talked into it 2 more times.  3 different sized groups of friends with different degrees of food/wine expertise. 3 different servers and numerous different entrees. 3 different nights of the week. Every visit has been equally disappointing. I posted a negative review about going for the "pig roast" back in January. The service has varied from downright bad to indifferent; from being ignored after we ordered to trying for 30 minutes to get the check and then pay.  The entrees are moderately interesting but not particularly well-executed, not for the price. The sides are often more interesting/flavorful. 3 strikes, PSC, and I'm afraid you're out....
author: Scott K.

description: Firstly, 5 BIG stars for having parking.  That's a plus in the City.   The hostess was gracious and courteous.  Good start for the evening.  Loved the bar.  It was nostalgic for some odd reason...or maybe it was the lighting that made me feel nostalgic?  Our server Jess was actually the highlight of the evening.  She was "sensational" from the beginning to the end.  Bar drinks - *****, Appetizers - pigs in the blanket gets ** because the figs were a little green and tasteless, but the Tuna Poke gets **********!  The homemade potato chips that accompanied the poke had a bite and crunch that was the epitome of gourmet snack food!  It was so yum that I took the chance of asking Jess for the recipe and voilà... she hands over a computer printout of the recipe.  Now that is s-e-r-v-i-c-e.  Frisée & Endive Salad - ***** (& that's how wonderful Jess is.  She took the initiative to split the salad and had a fried egg on each of our servings. Six stars for Jess on this move, Main entrée - ***** my short ribs were really tender and tasty to the last bite and finally... Dessert - by this time we were stuffed, but Jess talked us into the baker's dozen of mini beignets filled with chocolate that oozed when bitten into.  Must be the PSC's secret weapon 'cuz it's not on the menu.  Need I say anymore? :)   Charming evening with a good setting for having conversations during dinner.  Oh, one more thing...on my way out, my eyeballs just about popped out of their sockets when I saw a patron eating the Thursday special "Crispy Pork Shank".  It was hugemongous and looked like it could feed a family of six.  So, if you're ready to pig out... knock yourself out.
author: Lizzie L.

description: i love being greeted by a red vintage drum set. the greyere cheese toasts are the best appi on the menu. i also appreciated their wine list; we got a nice bottle of malbec for only $28 bucks! cute 'baked to order' cupcakes were warm, tasty and cozy; like the restaurant itself!
author: Kelly B.

description: I had a wonderful time here. The bartender was really impressive - a true artist. I was there the 2nd weekend it had been open on a Friday night in early January with some friends and the food was wonderful ... the atmosphere was friendly. I even got to meet a movie director who is an idol of mine - who was waiting for his table at the bar.
author: David M.

description: Neat atmosphere.  Huge plus for easy parking.  Food-so so and a bit too $.
author: W S.

description: I love the cocktails here!  The menu has some unique items, and all-in-all is really good food.
author: Christopher L.

description: Solid traditional American food.  Nothing spectacular, but it has a good feel, the service is decent, and the food is satisfying.  Great choice for a late night diner or snack.
author: Alex S.

description: I've been to this restaurant several times and have always enjoyed it. Good food, nice atmosphere, easy parking and nice staff. I wanted to review it, however, because almost exactly one year ago I took a bunch of clients there while they were in town for a conference. On very short notice they fit in our group of 16 persons, and we had a great meal. I recently met a bunch of these folks again at the same convention this year. They were all from different cities and I thought it was so cool that on three separate occasions a member of the original dining party told me (unsolicited) they had LOVED the Presidio Social Club and wanted to go back. I just thought that was awesome that they would all remember the place and want to return.
author: Dave B.

description: I agree with Phil , whoever he is. It started out great and then just fizzled. Appetizer never appeared, Sloppy Joe which was really flimsy sounded great but it lacked volume and flavored heavily of green bell peppers. Mashed potatoes were yummy.The server, Caroline, was very attentive and did her best to see that we were o.k. with at that point, the hectic atmosphere. She genuinly was interested in our opinion and did we let it fly! We were told we would be compt dessert but after we ordered we got the wrong one. No need to belabor the issue, I was with a great friend and we just ran with it. When the check came, we were compt  the sloppy joe but not the dessert.We gave Caroline a good tip.The place has too many people standing around doing nothing. It is a great and convenient spot.Be warned...when we went,(6.30) there were alot of kids there.I will go back but this place needs to find it's center and it's crowd.
author: Taylor W.

description: Loved this place.  The staff was great.  The drinks fab  & the deserts are out of this world.  The location is wonderful.  We were there early so no problem parking.  IAs a San Francisco native t's so nice to see great dining in the Presidio.
author: Kathy R.

description: I've driven by this place lots of times, and it always looks like everyone in there is having fun.  We finally tried it last night, and I will definitely go back.  I had told them (via Opentable) that it was our wedding anniversary, and every staff person greeted us with "happy anniversary."  They gave us a 4-top by the window, and comped our desserts.  The atmosphere is really nice -- old fashioned by stylistic, casual and cozy.  The food was also really good, especially the smashed peas with mint butter.  All in all, a great experience.
author: Trish T.

description: Horrible service and mediocre food. While the atmosphere, cocktails and appetizers are great, this place has never been known for top notch service. However, my family was in town, so I wanted to give it another shot. We were seated 15 minutes late. The manager was kind enough to comp us some appetizers for the inconvenience, yet our waitress didn't show for another 10 minutes (I had to ask for her), nor were we served water or bread initially. The seared tuna was almost inedible, fries were cold, special (roasted pig) was dried out. Our waitress never came around during our meal to ask how we were or if we needed anything else. I finally asked a runner to track her down for some coffee, and that was the best part. My father was served stone cold, bitter coffee with skim milk instead of cream. What kind of operation is this? When I complained to the manager, she was apologetic, yet disappeared for another 10 minutes. I went again to track her down and she said they were making more coffee -- uh, moot point. She didn't seem to have much management experience, as was evidenced when they CHARGED us for the bad coffee! At this point, our waitress remained in the back, instead of coming out to address the issue and/or apologize. Worst dining experience in SF by far, and I've lived here more than 10 years.
author: kelly m.

description: the food tasted good going down, but coming up ... awful. i had the nectarine salad and cioppino from presidio social club, and i got food poisoning. (another woman in my party suffered the same fate. food poisoning strikes again.) beware or be facing your porcelain.
author: Elizabeth D.

description: i had heard good things...and on the face of it, there's a lot going for this place. but it definitely didn't deliver. it also reminded me...again...how much good service adds to an enjoyable night out...or in this case, takes away from it. nice environment, but the food was average. the waiter was weak from the start, and literally couldn't think of a vegetarian option on the menu...so he offered to bring me some of the sides. mashed potatoes f or dinner...impressive. at that point, neither he nor i realized mac'n'cheese was on the menu. in the end, he asked the chef to make a pasta dish, which was good. thankfully, we had a good busboy who remembered we were eating there. plenty of other places in the city worthy of $100+ for a dinner for two.
author: John D.

description: I'd love to go back here, but I can't.  I am deathly afraid that the manager lady is going to beat me up.  I guess the moral of the story is to not try to go here with a group.  Someone else reviewed earlier and described an attempt to have a New Year's Eve party here ... but they saved themselves and cancelled before NYE after lots of rules were imposed.  We showed up to our group event ... forced to be there at 6 on a Saturday ... some showed up late ... a few did not show up at all, and we were charged full price for 4 non existent people.  The same type of blaming of our organizer by the Manager Lady, it was all our fault, etc etc -- same as those NYE folks occurred.  So...if we have to pay $200 extra, can we take the food they would have eaten home?  NO.  This is unfortunate ... you know that 10 people who just ate here (and paid an extra $100 or so on mac and cheese?! and tons on drinks and other extras) will probably never come back and would never recommend this place to anybody else?  I'M FINE WITH THAT.  Yikes ... as I walked away, she called out "AND THANKS FOR SHOWING UP ON TIME."  Wow.  We probably left around 9, and the place was not packed at all.  Maybe we were not the best guests, but there was probably 500 different ways this could have been handled so that there were no lingering hard feelings.  I feel like I did something horrendous, but all I did was eat a real simple dinner for which I gave them a ton of money.  Maybe you will have a better experience.  Just show up on time, dammit.
author: Cole P.
